headline: Would not recommend
pros: Good lunch options on site
cons:
Job descriptions are not accurate.
This company do not care about their customers.
you are asked to rush people off the phone.
you are not allowed to take the time to correctly deal with each customer and due to this many staff will make mistakes on customer profiles (which you will then have to deal with) making everything much harder.
They do not complete anything in a timely manner .
managers literally sit around on Instagram and do not know how to do the role they are managing and therefore are completely unable to help you with any questions or queries.
High turn over with staff due to the way staff are treated.
Staff are offered a chance to advance in their roles but will have to wait 3-4 months to be able to move onto their next opportunity due to lack of staff.

headline: A truly international environment
pros:
- If you join Barclays, chances are that you will be working with people from at least two different countries, sometimes even different time zones. Great opportunity to learn and hone your English skills (it's a must-have anyways)
- Great variety of financial and IT-related skills to pick up on the fly, depending on the team you joined
- You will gain insight to one of the biggest investment banks in the world, a brand recognized in the UK and US mostly
- Good salary, and other benefits, sick days, vacation (in Europe at least).
- HR (and generally everyone, with some exceptions) is helpful if you need assistance
- most people, including managers, are nice to work with, especially within IT
- varies by the team and month, but generally speaking, IT jobs can be pretty relaxed, Barclays has quality pressure on you, not time pressure. (quality over quantity)
- as an IB, the company is performing well, their quarterly results are public, and you can expect this to be long-term employment. It's not unusual to see people working there for 3+ years. There are regular promotion evaluations, although it's difficult to get promoted, it does happen if you perform well above the expected
cons:
- with big multinational company comes big multinational issues, policies, mandatory training (potentially) completely unrelated to your job, slow and painful procedures (just to ensure everything is fine, so it has some quality assurance benefits, I know)
- things can feel slow the further you are from trading floors

headline: Worst appraisals
pros: They Have let us work from home so far but they are desparate to change that.
cons:
1. Everything is too slow. Like every decision is taken post an approval from on shore.
2. They call it that they treat all fairly but how come some people get cab and some people not ( non hiring zones). There should be non hiring zones but not no transport zones as all employee cannot afford to live in hiring zone with the package they provide. Least you could do is to provide cab.
3. Manager decides who gets o/s rating and not the person numbers.
4. They can make you work for two process at times when your process work load is little less.
5. Colleague engagement are always attended by same people ( not in calling process ). Calling people are continuously on calls no colleague engagement for them.
6. Here 'your view' surveys are filled by TSS taking remote control ( how come that is my view ). They always have surveys like either you agree or disagree but no feedback of free will writing.
7. Not even single penny being paid for wfh expenses and on podcast they say they'll ensure salaries in line with that ( got appraisal at strong rating which I don't call being appraised ).
8. They never retain people. A lot of people have left who wanted to work still with company but poor salary appraisal strategy. They are ok in hiring new ones. 
9. Only your first year appraisal will be good after that don't expect any good news whether bank profit soars high or not. They only retain people in UK and USA but not in India.
10. When you work here then forget to celebrate any festivals. Don't expect any extra payout or less work also. Last diwali they did not give anything (No respect for employee festivals). But if there is any festivals in UK then we will be working as a back up for them (not fair practice).

* If you are outspoken, get prepared to be fired at the first redundancy plan. The processes are dedicated to make it "transparent"
* Difficult to move roles when you start getting poor performances (not always deserved). Make sure you befriend your manager (I couldn't)
* Diversity is a word, not a reality at the top management. Only 5 black MDs out of 130/150 in total

headline: Generally Positive
pros:
- Dynamic working
- Inclusive workplace
- Most people are nice and good natured
- Decent number of opportunities of being able to move around
cons:
- Inclusivity and dynamics is variable with each team.
- Strong concentration of remuneration in the front office, separate and smaller compensation pots for supporting functions.
- You are contractually banned from discussing remuneration with your peers, which means there is likely to be discrimination and inequality.
- Generally focussed on the client facing employees in terms of bonus, benefits and perks.
- Three tiered rating system of what and how heavily impacts bonuses, with very little uniformity (that is you need to suck up to the boss a lot) and from my experience management don't give you warning of required development points.
- Concept of 9-5 isn't present anymore, including the non-front office areas of the bank, which doesn't align to fair remuneration.
- Though there are internal opportunities there is no training provided to support this

headline: Salaries inconsistent
pros: Good benefits, good pension scheme. Nice offices.
cons:
Salary: different people, same grade, same team are all on different salaries. Salaries are different for the same role. Had numerous conversations with HR about the gender pay gap and got no where. HR don’t allow salary negotiation for promotions. My salary was lower than the persons I took over, and is lower than the person who is now doing my role. Both are men, 

Slow: to get anything done is painful, lots of hoops to jump through. But this is the be expected as bank and legacy. 

Management: l had numerous managers during my time at the bank, most managers were awful: didn’t care about development, didn’t prioritise work, played politics, couldn’t get hold of them ect. 

Politics:  little collaboration. dog eat dog environment 

Pressure: the amount of pressure put on you to deliver is sickening. 

Overall: it’s not a *bad* place to work. Slowness is to be expected and bad managers are everywhere.  but salary inconsistencies, the pressure and the politics is a reflection of the banks culture. Leaving was the best decision I’ve made.

headline: Great to work for.

headline: Overall a Good company to Work
pros:
Overall a very good company to work and grow, and with a great Brand name. 
Barclays has invested heavily in creating a great workplace at the Pune location.
The higher management, especially the UK counterparts are very open and supportive.
cons:
I felt the HR system/team is not strong. I did not see a great annual review system. They have only 3 ratings, and If you are given the lowest rating by your line manager, there is no way you can question it or raise concerns. Even if concerns are raised, there is no one to review them further. Even if you don't accept the ratings, the system will just auto approve and move forward.

They did not even conduct an exit interview to understand why the employee wants to exit the company. Not sure if they have any exit interviews.

They need to have more structured team management and line manager assignment. In a few teams have observed, just because a person is in the team for a little longer time than others, they make him a line manager with just 2 or 3 colleagues under him, even though the line manager and other 2 colleagues are doing the exact same work. 
Just creating more roles that tend to add or bring very little or NO value to the team as a whole. This also creates too much dependency on the line manager who may tend to misuse their power.

Bonus is not a reflection of the PD rating. Someone met get A rating and get £1,000 bonus as BA4 (analyst) Whilst someone can get B rating and get £5,000

Permanent staff are cheated with the facade of PD consistency checks

Hardly room for career progression

headline: Middle management are terrible - if you are from a BAME background, beware
pros: Not much to be honest - some of the people
cons:
If you are from a BAME, especially Black background, beware.
They pretend to care, but really don't.
Too many Black staff have been mistreated and end up leaving, then management 'wonder why'. They know exactly why.

Some Directors are trying to 'have it all' in life, and in turn put unnecessary pressure on their staff, then try and penalise them.
Competitive, non-team players are promoted and rewarded.

If you are lucky, you might get a nice manager - but a lot of the managers are inexperienced as managers and just focused on outputs and results, to the detriment of team morale.

headline: Avoid at all costs
pros: The only Pro was my manager but it was extremely lucky to get a good manager.
cons:
- 	As a call center job you expect to encounter customers that will be abusive to you but in this role you are abused on a daily basis by customers, brokers and solicitors.The amount of verbal and mental abuse that is received on the job is disgusting both from your customers and lack of support from the company. Throughout the peak of Covid 19 the company made lots of changes which meant that it was harder for the customers in our department to get the support they needed, this lead to high amounts of abuse, racism and threats at time (one customer even joked about a doing a bomb threat if we did not give them what they needed) Barclays refused to send out letters to the brokers and solicitors to state that they have a zero tolerance policy on this behavior as it would "have to go through to many channels". One specific broker has been reported numerous times by different colleagues for sexist, racist and abusive behavior and Barclays apologized for their staff's behavior and did not bother to even listen to the calls that were provided to the team.
- 	The sickness process/line was changed at least 6 times in the last year meaning that if you were ill (even due to covid) the procedures were unclear and it was difficult to know who to contact. Due to the way the department was ran and the abuse we received at one point up to 40% of the department was on sick at the same time. 
- 	 One team is a new path that Barclays is implementing so that the departments all work together more efficiently and merging numerous departments into one. The formation of this has been an utter shambles and information that the staff needed to know about their hours, pay, how the role would work. The only details that were provided was how it benefited Barclays. Staff were also rushed through training and did not receive the full support that was needed. There was a marginal pay rise for some staff members earning below a set amount (those already above this did not get any pay rise for doing two departments work) there was no backdated pay for the staff that had been doing the extra work for months. 
- 	The department held a trip down to York in the middle of one of the lock-downs, which lead to numerous team members catching and spreading Covid. This was whistle blown by a colleague in the department. 
- 	The former CEO sent out regular emails that seemed to be bragging about his trips around the world paid for by Barclays, this was at a time where we were told that "one team was implemented to prevent redundancies"
- 	With the changes to Covid 19 regulations staff were required to start returning to the office, staff were not briefed correctly. We were told we would be given 6 weeks notice in writing (letter) before we would be expected to return. No letters were ever sent and a vague email was sent instead and we were never updated about the changes. 
- 	In the department I worked in, we were closed on bank holidays and the holidays were automatically entered onto the system and removed from our allowance, with the changes and mergers that took place due to "One team" upper management decided to change this process and did not notify the staff. This has led to people now owing holidays and having reduced holidays for 2022. 
- 	Through my time at Barclays they worked with the mindset of if it ain't broke, break it. Feedback was consistently given by staff, customers and brokers about the systems and Barclays refused to update these. Instead any systems that worked smoothly (not many) they changed them completely and provided no training to staff on how to use these. System issues were consistent.
- 	In relation to systems in my role we were not provided access to the systems that our customers and brokers used, instead we were given outdated and vague screenshots that were extremely unhelpful. This led to regular difficult conversations with customers and brokers on how to use the system. This was raised numerous times and Barclays' response was "we did have a few dummy accounts that you used to be able to use but they are now locked", no effort was ever made to provide additional training or access to these systems. 
- 	 Staff members would regularly breach processes that were set by Barclays, which lead to abusive calls when you would not breach the process. Whenever feedback was provided to team leaders to investigate this would just fall on deaf ears and the same staff members would consistently get away with breaking the process.

Majority of the above has taken place throughout the last year and the way staff are treated is becoming worse by the day. There is a high turnover for staff and you are just a number. There are many more examples I can provide but the list would be endless.
If you are considering applying for Barclays my advice would be don't, avoid this company at all costs.

headline: Do NOT work at Barclays
pros: The good thing about Barclays everything is remote so you get to work from the comfort of your home. I love working remotely because it gives me the flexibility to travel and do day to day activities. Working in the call center can be interesting at times it just depends on the day.
cons: I work at the Wilmington location and it is VERY DISORGANIZED! From Day 1, I was given the incorrect equipment and training was terrible because we were given outdated information during training plus new policies were being inforced everyday which made the job even harder. I'm overworked and underpaid Barclays pay is very low for the amount of work we have to do. I'm basically working multiple roles with my customer service position in the Care department. Barclays is desperate for employees so that's why there constantly hiring I regret working for this company because its truly been a nightmare. Management is rude and trash. Very clueless individuals who don't know anything about the job. I swear I would NEVER recommend anybody working at Barclays because they don't care about their employees.

headline: It Doesn't Feel Great Working for Barclays Now
pros: Generous Sick Pay and Good Employee Support Especially during the Covid period
cons: Things are changing so fast and some of our benefits are getting eroded. New contracts are not particularly employee centric. They want you to work on Bank Holiday on Normal Pay. This is not valuing employee time pr sacrifice they have to make especially just a day after Christmas

headline: In the middle of woods
pros: none Pros slow increase of salaries
cons: In the middle of woods

headline: Losing sheen and a sinking ship (US region)
pros: Good pay, good benefits and good diversity inclusion programs. Can be a great place only if you fall into the right team and manager. You will get rewarded for good work in the global recognition tool. Internal job opportunities/transfers are a plus and can help career growth for lucky folks.
cons:
1. The US arm of this bank is gradually losing sheen and is no longer an important decision making unit as it used to be until few years ago. With most decision management happening in the UK and most execution out of India, the US region hardly has any say. You can see reduced employee strength in the US and most folks in whippany are entry level or mid experience ones.

2. The bank is now controlled by bunch of bureaucrats sitting in the UK who have no idea in what direction to head. All good folks have almost left and the ones left behind are there to stay forever and hence not the best of the lot. Decision making is random and poorly channelized. There is lack of seriousness in execution in certain areas.

3. People can make huge blunders and yet get away easily in the name of senior management and experience. If the guy at the top says 2+2 equals 5 then entire hierarchy has to stick to 5 regardless of what the correct approach is. This whole culture of covering each other and allowing blunders to slip through will ruin the bank in the long run.

4.  Immigration arm of the company is totally misleading. If you are an international candidate then you better be prepared for a horrible H1B/GC experience path. Total disregard for international employees who need sponsorship.

headline: Good career pathway to start
pros:
Good career pathway to start underwriting whereby you are introduced to many referrals codes on applications that you work through and inside sla.

Expand financial acumen in relation to ising different credit agencies, affordability and fraud tools used to make a decision on customer application which can be enjoyable.

Good career pathway to start and the move into different types of underwriting such as mortgage, commercial etc.

Barclays has a decent discounts and offers especially with medical, life and dentist insurance/ subscriptions.
cons:
Typical same cliques and office politics where being promoted is about who you know and not what you know. If you are good friends with the management then it's very easy to climb up the ranks.

Unsociable hours which can consist of working any hours from 8am to 10pm. Work rota would consist of working g weekends, Bank Holidays, Easter etc. Affects social life and other commitments.

Salary is below average and the different shift patterns on a weekly basis makes it even more undesirable.

headline: No growth, politics, Favouritism, dummy seniors

Very unethical culture.

headline: Good company
pros:
As a fresher, a good place where you slowly get use to the corporate world. The managers are good and maintain a healthy relationship with their team members. 
Though you get to learn and grow, any project you work for more than a year can become monotonous, thus, you may switch internally.
Company was quite support during Covid and also delivered IT equipments to our home.
cons:
The incentives and year end bonus are not at all attractive. Basic 5-6% yearly increase and even on a promotion, the increment is not too good. 
The company is a safe place to work - won't get fired easily!

headline: Terrible Graduate Experience
pros: Good Salary, Not too demanding work
cons: The graduate scheme in Glasgow feels rushed and undercooked. Being asked to list your skills, experiences and what you want to do feels like a waste of time when the team assignments feel random. The managers don't feel trained to handle graduates either. I didn't come from a CS background and I feel even more alienated than the other graduates due to being expected to keep up with the rest. Covid may have exacerbated these problems but when I actively bring up my issues to HR to see nothing being done I just feel invisible.

headline: Need Better Benefits and Treatment For New Joiners
pros: Good work for carrier growth and good projects
cons:
So after a New Joiner joins this company these are the cons:
1. NO work from home allowance for new joiners considering the new variant has come from south africa 
2. Atleast we have to pay 6000 from our CTC for the insurance of our parents and spouse since "Here NO FREE INSURANCE FOR PARENTS " (So lets assume u got a 30 percent hike here so you get 6000 less from the monthly salary along with taxes if you apply for parental and spouse insurance).

3.After joining "NO NEW BOTTLE,T-SHIRT ,HAND BOOK ,PEN  FOR NEW JOINERS" and ONLY laptop,laptop charger and bag will be provided
4.No Diwali Box gift
5.Miserable virtual Induction program for new joiners
6.No salary for first month if you join after the first 4 days of the month

headline: The worst company in the world, bully and offensive culture
pros: Don't want to mention this.
cons:
If you work at this company, you may face following problem if you are unfortunately work with an insane supervisor.
1. Supervisor extremely rude and he not willing to support colleague.
2. Refuse to answer any question. If you ask, will shout at you.
3. He will shout at you with unreasonable reason or with no reason during a one-on-one call or no other colleague near by and pretend take care of you when there are colleague surround .
4. Give you wrong instruction or don't give you sufficient information intentionally and said you are wrong. 
5. Find any opportunity to mentally abuse you and verbally offense you.
6. You will not be treated as a team member and put unreasonable expectation to you.

Bully & offensive culture.
Never met an insane supervisor like this.

headline: Could do so much better
pros: Since working at barclays I have met some of the most lovely people ever. Management are supportive and you do feel like you are part of a family.
cons:
The constant targets and the goal post is constantly moving by people that have no clue what we deal with in branches. Upper management seem to only care about profits. When the machines in the branches don't work, and customers have travelled for miles to get to us because every other branch has closed. The last thing they want is us trying to sell them contents insurance. 

There are so many things wrong with barclays and although I enjoyed parts of working there I'm so happy I don't bank there, the competition are doing it simpler and better.

headline: Don’t do it if you care for your mental health
pros: Pension and after working 3 years you can have up to 6 months off
cons:
Even though they won’t say it, they are data and sales driven. You’re expected to deliver calls of 6 hours or more a day. Even going to the bathroom has to be justified. Management are more focused on calling than well-being. 
If you’re off sick you are asked if you can still call from home. 
You are penalised if you don’t otherwise. 
No career progression. Only 1 person in my work place had a promotion in the last 3 years. They don’t want to even support progression. 
Hardly any diversity in the management or higher up

headline: Beware!!
pros: No respect, No learning, No motivation, No work culture, Poor compensation. Absolutely no good reason to work here. Just the Brand name which is just for namesake now. No pros.
cons: I’ve never experienced the kind of culture where supervisors shout and disrespect you because they have the power and you won’t be able to do a thing because there’s no way. You’ll know what unfairness means in this company. I’ve seen the ugliest side of corporate here. Thanks to Barclays for giving me such unforgettable experiences.

headline: Frustrating
pros: The benefits are very good, especially the health insurance and 401k match. Pay is fair.
cons: Computer systems are outdated and very slow. They claim to be customer centered but care more about handle time than doing the right thing for the customer. They emphasize diversity & inclusion but only if you fall in their preferred categories. There is definite favoritism depending on the team you're on. Communication is extremely slow, especially with HR.

headline: Antiquated processes and systems
pros: Working hours and now the opportunity to do hybrid hours.
cons: The servicing model for Corporate clients is way behind retail and wealth. For example, a mobile banking app is currently being developed which only has the function of being used for identification, whereas retail bank have had an app which allows both transactional service and product application for years. There is huge resistance to change. There is virtually no career path unless somebody leaves, and the department has isolated itself from other areas of the bank.

headline: Not a good time
pros:
Work from home
Great Benefits
Supportive Management
cons:
The pay is really not worth the amount of emotional stress you have to endure. You are essentially the callers financial advisor, therapist or punching bag. They also constantly pitch upward mobility into management, but there are not enough available positions.

They keep track of every minute of your down time (bathroom breaks, lunch, clock in and out). You are quite literally chained to your desk because your bonus relies on the amount of time worked and taking calls. 

You are expected to get to the point where you are taking ~ 100 calls a day. Really an insane experience to work there during the pandemic.

headline: One of the worst jobs I’ve ever done it made me hate life so much!
pros: I think the only pro of working for Barclays is the people and the brand recognition. I’d say about 70% of the people are amazing helpful and outstanding however is the rotten 30% that ruins the whole experience
cons:
Typical Barclays politics
Continuously changing the goalpost
Criminally underpaid for the level of work you do
One of the worst IT systems I have ever worked with
Senior leadership is absolutely toxic and does not deserve the ranks nor the reputation
Numerous empty promises that I never for field
Pay was messed up multiple times with zero accountability or was really rectified

headline: They preach but don't follow
pros:
Good name on the CV
Good pay and benefits
cons:
If you don't suck up to management they don't give you space to progress.

If you express your concerns are not taken seriously
Cover up of sexual harassment and promotion of the harasser

They talk a lot about well being and taking care of their employees but in practice they don't care at all.

Was working in a big branch and learning to be an operation banker, when the operation banker that was supporting and coaching me was moved.

After few months I was moved as well, I was treated like a parcel. 
No one took the time to ask me how it would have impacted my life moving to another branch and they did not ask me if I was happy about it. One month before they just told me, from that date you will be in that branch. Zero conversation. 

Moving to a much smaller branch I was stuck on a till for the whole time, all my previous learning was wasted and my career progression was stopped without any care. I started having as well physical issues which took me to have multiple sick days not being able to move my wrists and shoulders from the pain. I told them was the same movement over and over on the till was the one causing the issue because before I never had problems. They did not care and kept me on the same position, talking about wellbeing but not practicing at all.

I resigned for the first job I found and since it was one month's notice during that time they started sending me around covering other branches, even 1h travel, it was a nightmare, I had to take sick days for the stress they put me through. 

I don't recommend it at all, there are better companies to work for, where they really care about you as a person.

headline: BBFA
pros: None. No pros at all.
cons:
Poor pay. Bad hours. Zero support. 

Job role was wildly different to the job advert. Barclays said it "wasn't a call centre job" and "outbound calls will be at a minimum". "No scripts!".

The first 5 months were all outbound calls. It very much is a call centre. You absolutely have to use a script.

We were promised monitors and keyboards for working from home. 7 months later and we are still waiting for them.

Constant oversight. Can't even go to the toilet without someone ringing you to find out where you are.

The team leaders have as much experience in the role as you do (none). The procedure guide is 4-5 years out of date, and cannot be used anymore. You couldn't practice on the systems at all. So the first time you ever set any plan will be live with a customer. 

You're only allowed to put a customer on hold for 2 minutes, but it can take 15 minutes for you to get a team leaders attention.

They operate like a dodgy call centre out the back of a business park. It beggars belief how a multi-billion pound business can be this poorly organised.

At least 65% of the staff that joined when I did have left within 6 months. Barclays answer is to hammer the employees that remain even harder. I started in a team of 15 that is now just 6 people remaining.

headline: Not the place if you want to progress as a junior colleague
pros:
- Great colleagues
- Substantial early career development available (College and university courses)
- Nice work environment (for a bank)
- Direct management that actually care
- Easily a lifetime role if you get in at the right paygrade
cons:
- Less and less 'professional' training as the years go on, simply on the job training for you role.
- Non-existent promotion scheme. You either rise if you take someone else's job who has left, leave or work your way up in a political manner. Heard directly from upper management that pay rises are not an option and not part of the strategy. If you're not happy with what you make then leave
- Bell curve based PD/bonus system. Although management tell employees and the union this isn't the case, it very much is.
- Upper management only care about the numbers, not the people, nor the work. If doing the job the right way takes too long to satisfy the stats then 'botch it in'
- Severely short staffed and huge workload
- Very political and cliquey in some areas (especially management)

headline: My experience after 1 internship and 1 year from the graduate scheme
pros:
-good pay
-variety of positions
-high chances to roll over onto a normal position after the scheme
-low entry requirements
-great as a stepping stone into the industry
cons:
-huge variation between available positions (some are great, some are terrible) and there is a chance that you will not be allocated to your submitted role (I know of one scenario where a manager submitted a false role description to get more applications)
-HR tends to be very hard to get a hold of and is not flexible in their approach to role allocation
-bonuses and raises are uniformly mandated by HR (everyone got a tiny bonus and no raise, regardless of their performance)
-the corporate nature of the company can be overbearing and reduces your QOL in many small ways to the point of frustration

headline: Stressful role
pros: Good benefits & great pension
cons:
You will work a lot of unpaid overtime and the salary is not great either. 
Mortgage advisors work a lot harder/ longer hours that other staff of the same salary grade. 
Management keep adding tasks without taking into account reports of stress. 
High targets that are hard to achieve and if you do achieve them, there is no real reward, but if you don’t achieve them you’ll be put on a plan. 
Very hard to progress as mortgage skills are not transferable in the business. 
Low moral across the whole team.

headline: Very bureaucratic organization with legacy technologies
pros:
- good salary and benefits
- for someone: possibility to work from home
cons:
- extremely bureaucratic organization, it's really hard to work as a developer - no admin rights on your laptop; you always have to request million additional AD groups / permissions / software to work
- bad IT support. If you have some issue with VS or your laptop it can take days to get some response from some outsourced guy from support (you don't have admin permissions, remember? So you cannot fix it by yourself)
- at least in Prague there is no enough place to work together with your team - terrible openspace environment (they call it "dynamic working") . No walls - you have to listen all 20-40 people sitting close to you. Very noisy and always someone walking around all the time. You don't have your own desk and you have only one curved display (you cannot choose peripheral). If you want to meet with all your team members, you need to ask another team not to come to work that day, so you have some places to seat and work - in the company there are 2 people for one desk. Barclays even has a mobile app where you need to book your work place one day before
- projects and solutions in most cases are legacy and splitted between several countries, mostly India and sometimes USA/GB

Too much hierarchy.  If you are a developer (especially male), want to work, and want your work to be recognized then don't join this company.  You will kill your technical skills and the recognition, appraisal, and promotion is reserved for females.  Its new form of racisms on the name of gender diversity.  Either join this company as fresher or as VP/Director

headline: Lack of Growth Opportunities and severe lack of diversity
pros: Company is good for a starting point in banking career as well as good range of employee benefits. There is a good chance to work with other departments but only for odd queries and subject to approval from your manager.
cons:
The role is good; however after 9 months there is no further progression from the training provided. As this was a call centre role, micromanagement is a severe issue, where managers are not trained in the role but focus on soft skills and not the technical issues against regulation. 

Also, there are several cases of discrimination for development of those in the in certain ethnic groups; where inappropriate questions are asked by managers and only the medical room can be provided for prayer grudgingly by management. Staff retention is a major issue as a result even for hard workers; and insufficient support for those with mental health.

Overall a poor experience, and salary under average compared to competitors in Glasgow/Edinburgh

headline: Barclays
pros: Great staff benefits and offices. The people make Barclays and there are so many interesting and talented people. Unfortunately a lot are not recognised and don’t manage to reach their potential.

headline: Good but also very bad
pros: If you can work at Barclays you can work anywhere, the saying goes, and its true. On a positive side the training is first class, and depending which division you work in you should get a very broad range of experience. The bank is very focused on charitable work (see cons too). There is a very clear career progression until you get to a more senior level.
cons: Toxic working environment. The companies public vision of diversity and inclusion isn't what you experience in the workplace. Senior management in the majority do not follow the (very well written) culture code at all, and there is a fear culture such that much goes unreported, and what does get reported is investigated thoroughly but seldom found against the leader in question. Expect to be spoken to like garbage one day, and like you are best friends the next. Fire drills are daily (hourly!) and that's where a lot of the poor behaviors come from. The amazing focus on charity hides a large number of people using the time to avoid work. Very few senior leaders are female, they also try to hit the numbers by focusing on promoting females for that purpose rather than through worth/skill/experience. That said, you can work in a different division at the bank and have a polar opposite view to these, and that's also why it's toxic - you can have horrendous managers or really good ones, its the luck of the draw where you work, if those leaders move, and whatever fire drill is happening that day. Once you get to a more senior level (VP) the career path stops and its dead mans shoes for the promotion.

cons: Same repetitive work over and over again, people are reluctant for change and technology stack is very much behind than the rest of industry.

headline: Good initially but soon hit a glass ceiling...
pros:
- Decent enough basic wage
- flexible with annual leave
- established and recognised name
- flexible working / work from home
cons:
- strict credit policies and a severe lack of discretion meaning we can't support 99% of our customers
 - feeling like a cog in a poorly oiled machine. Poor systems, over-complicated processes, pointless meetings. 
- monotonous working practices (mainly through covid)
- lack of development opportunities to learn new skills, study new courses.
- poor internal recruitment - too many hoops to jump through
- low bonuses, poor pay rises, no commission 
- lack of culture
- hasty decisions on big changes by management without colleague consultation. On smaller changes, they like to ask to seem like its a consultation i.e. uniforms. Larger changes like a complete change in business model, is implemented without.

headline: Has looked after employees during Covid-19
pros: Has looked after employees during Covid-19, suspending redundancies and giving employees time off to look after their kids during school closures.
cons: Still has a hierarchical culture in some areas and a lack of diversity at senior roles. Slow to role our new technology but is making progress.

headline: Treasury Operations

cons: The hours were not the best. Some nights i ended second 8/9pm, but thank God i was WFH

headline: Disorganised
pros: It was nice to work on digital, and teaching customers how to be safe online.
cons: Completely disorganised branch, which was the managers’ fault, all giving different instructions which led to angry and upset customers who would take it out on essential bankers like myself.

headline: Great Staff led by Poor management
pros: Was a great fun environment to work with an amazing office. The team where great. Good support from the team and being able to bounce off each other.
cons:
The management was rude, aggressive, pushy and had their favourites i.e if you went drinking with them and you go to have a smoke outside then you are very much liked and respected. This lead to discrimination toward hard working individuals who were neglected and had little or no support. Management had their heads in the clouds thinking that you can achieve ridiculously high targets, without fail, well they where correct 'if you missell' you can hit any target.
I'm not going to name drop but the Barclays Wealth International Mortgage team was the worst to work for due to the poor management.
Long working hours just to hit targets which included never leaving work on time and working on weekends. this meant no work / family life balance.

headline: Tech analyst concierge
pros: Very nice team flexible and good working ours the values and culture of the organisation are amazing
cons: Not enough progression opportunities due to covid unfortunately. It will great to have more progression opportunities but I am glad that the company provided us with full pay and we did not lost our jobs in this difficult times

headline: Exit process of Barclays make sure Employee should not come back or recommend it to anyone
pros:
Company has world class level campus. It provides Laptops to all employees, makes WFH experience very easy. 
Term life insurance is best in class, 5*CTC
work life balance is good, but it depends entirely on project and manager.
cons:
No value of empoyee once he leaves company, in my experience they have not collected company laptop even after 30 days of my LWD. seems they do not care about Laptop, Its company data and most important former employee. 
Teams has lot of politics if you are close to your Sr manager then its a good org and may give you lot of opportunities. diff to work with old ppl from team and Manager always has bias for them. overall my experience is not so good when i was in company and after I left as well.

headline: Stable workplace with ample opportunities
pros:
- employee centric organisation
- strong policies (expected of an organisation of this scale)
- strong desire to be the leading digital bank in the marketplace will give you ample opportunities to be involved in challenging projects
- enough tools available in the bank to help you learn and grow
- flexible working
- good rewards and recognition culture (but like anywhere else can be perception led)
cons:
- being 350 years old, bureaucracy is engrained in the banks way of working
- the security standards in the bank are way toopp ancient and restrictive, and can prove to be frustrating if you are trying to deliver something innovative
- a very traditional method of investing in the professional growth of employees, just exploring new tools but no thought process
- subpar compensation as compared to market
- no support for WFH during pandemic except for a monitor, chair and a keyboard / mouse. Expects the employees to fund their own WFH.

headline: Don't Join Barclays if you have VISA dependencies
pros: Good salary but work stress is much more.
cons:
Greencard sponsorship is a nightmare here at Barclays. They will torture you mentally for years before they start the actual process. Even you are eligible according to policy, they don't start until it is last minute or an emergency. Many people who left to INDIA due to this process.
Do not trust the HR words. They always lie.
HR team is invisible and any process takes months.

headline: An okay job
pros:
- Benefits package is good - discounts for shopping etc., benefit pack can be customised according to preferences
- A decent first job or good while you study - will show you what hard work is and will make you resilient
- Nice colleagues, 2-3 months initial training
cons:
- Overwhelming workload
- Long shifts - 9/10/12hr. shifts which is not communicated on the interview
- Lack of support from team leaders - they promise they'd be available for support and then tell you to use support groups on Skype
- Asking questions and making sure you're providing correct information to customers isn't stimulated - on the contrary, team leaders tell you off if you ask too many questions.
- Stressful job - dealing with pissed off customers over the phone for 9-12 hours straight

headline: Amazing Company to work with
pros:
One of the best companies I have seen, who provides such a good care to their employees, specially during COVID situation. They provide a flexible environment to work and support their employees in best possible ways. Some of the benefits that an employee get in Barclays are:
* Good Increment while joining the company (Don't forget to negotiate well)
* Flexible working environment
* Very good perks - free transportation; free tea, coffee and soups
* Annual Bonus (not included in your CTC)
* Encouragement for internal job movement. IJP policy is very good.
* Decent Annual Appraisal 
* No. of leaves are very good and there are many more.

During Covid, Barclays has extended enormous facilities to the employees, such as:
* Advance Salaries (which needs to be paid back in 6 months)
* Increment in the medical policies
* Additional Cash reimbursement for Covid treatment
*Free WFH kits that includes Ergonomics Chair, Monitor, Keyboard, Mouse, etc.
* Transportation for Covid treatment and Oxygen Supply
* A dedicated toll free for all Covid related queries, and many more.
cons: The only Con I found is that Barclays does not cover the Parents in the medical policies they enroll the employees. You have to pay the premium separately for your parents under VPA.

headline: B-
pros:
- Great Benefits
- Good pay
cons:
General lack of coherent processes and operational backbone. Team managers are often lacking in knowledge of navigating the landscape.

The company is made out of random number of teams each of whom attempts to leverage each and every bit of power they are in the possession of.

The IT is built around forbidding as much as possible without providing any carrots.

Office politics is there and it appears to be more rampant in geographically distributed teams.

Promotions appear to be done at random with no prior knowledge of subject teams.

headline: Deck chairs on the Titanic
pros: With work at home, you get the benefit of not having to drive to work. I like working with my dog.
cons: Upper management has NO concern/care for lower level employees. They say they care about the customer, but they don't. Micro managed, almost to the second. Don't talk too long or too short, don't go into after call, don't go over your break by a minute, all things to get you on a report. Company has gone from almost 500 people, to just over 100. It won't be there too much longer.

headline: Train your managers
pros: Good employee benefits at Barclays.
cons:
Hr is a joke and aids in anxiety. They are not there to help you they are there for the bank and solely the bank.

Your complaints about bullying culture in Barclays is ignored.

They in fact encourage bullying because once you report a manager for bullying and unfair treatment, they make you tell this manager and this manager then moves you to another branch. 
The issue does not get dealt. Managers who have had grievances against them by an entire branch are just moved around to terrorise another branch. It is really horrible. 

There are a few gems in there from colleagues but barclays management is awful! 

Favouritism and Bully culture.

Speak up and they get rid of you. Passed around London as if you were the problem. 

I left in the end because i was getting bullied for trying to be save in covid19. Forced to come to work to do telephony when you can do this at home?
Telling you its just what it is however on BarclaysNow it says work from home if need be. 
What they preach is not what is done. Especially in the branches. Head office do not know what goes on in their branches. Clearly.

headline: False sense of care for employee wellbeing
pros: Good PTO for US standards
cons:
- Overly matrixed org design- slow on decisions, competing priorities from the top create unmanageable workload. Org design at lower team levels feel arbitrary. One team I was on was filled with directors and BA4s but few VP/AVP leading to too much strategy and not enough delivery. Current team filled with VPs who overlap and need more processors.

- Very limited growth & advancement opportunities in the US - the firm recently underwent a seismic org redesign, resulting in scores of Directors and above being laid off with the same jobs relocated to the UK. Very unlikely to be promoted beyond VP in the US

- In the US in order to receive recognition, increase remit/responsibility, you have to sacrifice worklife balance - aka meetings on UK hours before work and work all day. Better than the past, but still little timezone respect. Have to choose between a 5 AM meeting (advancing career by gaining exposure, knowledge, getting the information to just do your job) and wellbeing.

- Pay is subpar for the industry in NYC. Losing talent in the US to other firms who will pay normal salary and promote. 

- Pre COVID comments but still valid- no budget for anything. Systems only replaced when the third party is about to decommission support (= fire drill). Holiday party (pre-cv) no budget in NYC- could afford a drink a person (not all even got one) and a couple apps. Seems like they had a lot of fun in the UK though.

- 'Committed' to reducing gender pay gap, but not very transparent. Would like to to see honest reports by business area/function/location. My male peer on my team, performing a similar job function (but who I sit above in the team/management hierarchy and who has not been at the firm as long as me) makes $50,000 more in base pay. 

- Sense of care for wellbeing is well intentioned and widely broadcasted, however, it feels like a farce. Managers seldom adjust themselves as to embody the desired behaviors and effect change. 

(1) multiple initiatives/townhalls from senior leadership about taking work breaks -> manager works 10-12 hours a day and is emailing/skyping/texting before/after working hours 
(2) multiple initiatives/townhalls from senior leadership to reduce meetings > no meetings dropped from calendars.

headline: Middle management sucks
pros:
Overall your bosses don't know much, but think they do. So if you know few things and are ready to follow the slow mammoth then you will make steady progress - but definitely a slow one.
Also, by face its a pretty flat organization.
cons:
Avoid if you're having good capabilities because you'd be surrounded by mediocres.
And it is a rule of thumb in corporate: if you're too good you create problems (yes, overall productivity goes down, really).
Consider this as a red herring.

headline: The role itself had potential , too bad management only listen to their superiors
pros: A fair bit of variety to the role, unless management put you on the same task again and again.
cons:
Management claiming to listen to employees and encouraging suggestions but never even trying to apply them. It was all just lip service.
Similarly, they claim to support employees to achieve their best performance but would often take people off tasks they're performing very well in, putting them on tasks they're not very good at, and then give them a bad performance review which would prevent them from even moving to a different department.

headline: Review
pros:
Compliance Dept has a great culture - caring employer. 

Even pre-pandemic generally supportive with WFH, flexible working. 

Collaborative culture generally. Generally good at promoting women and ethnic minorities up to VP / D level.

Some crunch periods have longer hours, but generally a really good work life balance. 

Good sense of integrity and doing the right thing - generally lives the values it espouses.
cons:
Systems and IT generally fragmented, difficult to get set-up with the systems you need - once something works you never want to move off it onto another platform because the experience is so painful.

Only promotes into vacant roles as they come up - very limited scope for in role promotions.

Collaborative culture is great, but decision making can be slow, a lot of careful stakeholder engagement and sign-offs in implementing changes.

headline: Marketing Manager role review
pros:
- There were some nice people
- Nice office space with communal areas
cons:
There are so many. As a top level review this is one of the worst places I have worked at - which actually really badly affected my mental health.

My manager who was male was awful - definitely played favorites, made a lot of back handed comments and because he had been there for years nothing was ever done about it (despite other people also complaining about him).

There is such a lack of gender diversity within senior members of staff and because it is such an old company, there is no room for progression as those who stay the longest tend to move up when someone leaves . Some of the managers there (including my own) have clearly had no people training and just been promoted to managing positions due to their length of time at the company.

Being that it is financially regulated, there is so much red tape which makes getting anything done/ signed off really hard.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend. It's very political and even flexible working is not encouraged.

headline: Draconian micro monitoring if you are on the phones
pros: Overall I would say it’s a good company but your job satisfaction and enjoyment and stress levels are highly dependant on who your manager and ops leads are. Luckily most of my managers have been quite hands off with a laissez fair approach.
cons: As a telephony based role where you answer customer calls, it can get quite intense especially in terms of monitoring performance - you use have to use a software to measure all aspects of your work day including breaks and lunch and that is counted down to the second. If you go even 1 second over your lunch that is flagged up all the way to senior management. Luckily most of my managers did not enforce this but I found this very draconian

headline: I would rather have no money doing something that I love than ever work here again.
pros: Theres a strong feeling of solidarity with other team members because of the mutual understanding of how soul draining the work is. The canteen in 1CP is nice.
cons: They expect you to work 25 hours a day to get the job done. They wont increase salaries but also wont hire new staff to lessen the work load. Everyone takes their job too seriously and being around stressed people all the time makes for an extremely stressful, anxiety ridden working environment. When we were in the office people didn't want to take their full lunch hour for fear of looking like they were "slacking" and now that everyone is working from home, people don't want to leave their desks for too long for the same reason. There is a feeling of working towards a ticking time bomb at all times because of the ridiculously tight deadlines and lack of people to share the workload.

headline: It's a Shrinking Pie, No Matter How You Slice It
pros: Large budget for access to whatever subscriptions or data you need. Convenient midtown location, famous brand.
cons: Sell-side research is a dying business, having been segregated by regulators from the trading sections of banks a number of years back. Consequently they produce a massive reports that don't make money for anyone and aren't widely read. Basically you're just doing outsourced maintenance work (updating data etc) for clients. Top people in the department seeking to preserve their overpaid positions, and definitely not looking to bring up their own young competition.

headline: Working at Barclays Investment bank
pros:
Generally nice people and good culture. 
Strong desire to become a top five investment bank.
Strong equity product.
cons:
They are ten years behind the leaders (MS, GS) in things like tech, vision, and so on.
The IB remains very silo'd so it is difficult to create projects/businesses that work across asset class.
The culture is changing: It used to be very collegiate in the equity business. But with four changes in management in seven years, the folks now running it hark back to the old days i-banking where secrecy and everything is on a "need to know" basis. Equity is now run more like a fiefdom that where the views of those lower on the totem pole are disregarded.

 It has been 4 weeks and i have not received any communication from HR. I have no idea when will i receive my salary, about leaves, benefits..etc..

headline: Good company
pros: Very good employee benefits which would otherwise cost you many thousands of pounds a year.
cons: Very few people you’d look at and think damn they work so hard are so smart deserve to be here. It’s a large corporate so you’ll have a lot of ppl staying out of convenience and through their own laziness or incompetence prevent others from excelling at theirs. To progress you need to make a lot of noise about nothing, just boast about stuff that you’ve done no matter how small and insignificant it is. Chances are nobody really cares nor understands what you’re rambling on about anyway so they’ll all think it’s awesome as long as you make it sound awesome. Also depends on the part of the bank that you work in - there’s definitely a different culture in Investment, Corporate, Business Bank. Opportunities for career progress aren’t the same throughout the company, with some departments it’s easier than others. It really depends on how much noise you make and who you know. Rarely matters how you perform.

headline: Great to work for, as long as you are ok with a bit of bureaucracy
pros:
Work-life balance is encouraged 
Strong culture and leadership 
Long term strength in the market and business output over the medium to long term looks good.
cons:
Everything takes 3x longer than it should due to bureaucratic processes. 
Seem to think introducing another layer of senior management will improve things-it doesn't
The IT process makes you want to scream, 5x tickets for every problem and a request system that would have been clunky in 1995.

headline: Don't expect to use your skills & experience, nor make any decisions
pros: High Profile name for your CV, reasonable pay, nice office

Decision making is only for the C-suite, not the minion. Spend half your week in meetings, but you must have prepared and shared what they're still calling "papers" in advance of every meeting. (Says it all). An energy suck. Don't go there.

headline: One of the worst nightmares came true
pros: Except for the pay, everything is really bad.

Don't address any real issues and incase you escalate anything it is taken in bad light and then the manager and team head give you a tough time. After having worked for so many organisations, Barclays GMM has been the worst experience so far and I will not recommend anyone to join the Macro team especially.

headline: Terrible
pros: Some good people to work with as with any job. Made some great friends and the work was interesting at first.
cons: A LOT of people I would never want to see ever again. Environment is exactly like secondary school, very childish. And the childish behaviour and favouritism from all managers is encouraged by senior Management. Lack of any support and total disregard for any constructive feedback given. No opportunities for progression even though this was stated during interview. Maximum one promotion opportunity per year in a department of 150 meant that people with the right friends would always be considered over the employees who did more work. It is a classic office environment in that way.

headline: Mediocrity rules
pros: Very supportive culture when there is a problem. A lot of focus on mental health. The location (Canary Wharf) and building were great pre-COVID. Flexibility to work from home if needed
cons: Mind blowing bureaucracy. Committees after committees after committees to tick boxes and say if something is red amber or green instead of actually fixing problems. Really poor senior management (some are real bullies). No interest for proper employee development. Keep talking about diversity and inclusion and yet they promote very few women. When promoting they don’t look for real quality of work but about how much BS the person can say. People who have done well and have stayed for many years are those interested to work within the lines of bureaucracy and do the minimum necessary. Anyone who wants to bring innovation and change is doomed to crash against a brick wall

headline: I'm moving on
pros: Colleagues, pay, benefits , clean modern office and practicing social distancing in office or working from home
cons: Repetitiveness off the role, calls micromanaged and scrutinised. Expected to answer next call within seconds, no time to do additional tasks. Shifts are all over, no set shifts and you can be doing any range off shift between 7am and 8pm, and if your phone calls at 7.59 your expected to take call past end off your shift and get toil, which you can never take back as it is far too busy. In the middle off a pandemic it is also difficult to be dealing with irate customers, or people in difficult circumstances which can affect your own well being. Not for sensitive people.

headline: average

headline: The benfits are good but the UK rules the roost
pros: The flexibility can be great depending on your manager. The company contradicts itself a lot on what they're okay with in terms of "dynamic working" but generally the work/life balance isn't terrible. Compensations is nice and pretty generous. The office setting is pretty laid back, casual attire is permitted which is nice.
cons: The company broke off into several smaller entities a few years back. This has created a company dynamic that is 100% dictated by the UK (Barclays is a foreign bank technically). So now everyone answers to the UK overlords. This would be all good an fine if they weren't constantly trying to fit a square peg into a round hole. UK rules and structures just don't fit into an American run entity. This isn't a place where you'll come in and love your job. But it might be a place where the benefits are enough to tolerate the mess.

headline: Front Office Stress for Back Office Status
pros: Scale of the company allows you to see how Barclays impacts the community.
cons:
Continual massaging of the figures without investigating the root causes of the anomalies. 
Unequal distribution of budget and status. The Cost Management team did not have a Christmas Party one year whilst Business Managers where always travelling to India etc. 
Coldest company I have worked for. Off shore support are treated as drones. My managers in Radbroke had no interest in my welfare or development. In 2 years, there was no budget to travel up to Cheshire. The first time I met my manager's boss, face to face was when he came down to London to start the redundancy consultation. This was after my manager (who I never met) sent me a cryptic email to be in the office that day. It was disappointing as my manager (despite over 20 years experience at Barclays) ever spoke to me immediately after or during my 3 month notice period. This indicated a lack of courage or compassion.

headline: Existing Employees 's Politics Will Ruin the Culture
pros:
Free Transportation
Gera Commerce zone new Campus Facilities 
Nothing Else

Products on Old Technology .
Old Managers (AVP/VPs ) who are there from last 5-10 YRS don't want new joiners to settle as they are insecure and create same environment within team as they are not sound technically.
Politics at team level , Boot lickers will get hike and promotion as is in hands in manger whom to give hike and promotion.
Get reviews in which department you will join before joining the company .
Less number of ratings so it is must to give last rating to some people within team.
Give 1 star to senior management as glassdoor not allow 0 star.
New joiners starts searching elsewhere as soon they find the actual work culture of the team .

pros: Good place to learn and grow

headline: Great work/life balance but lots of politics and limited resources
pros:
- Barclays offer exceptional work/life balance via the "Dynamic working" scheme, which was well established before 2020 & Covid-19. You are able to adjust your working hours or/and work from home, as long as you manage to manage your workload. Just great service.
- Barclays is a huge organization with millions of customers. Any project that you are involved might result in millions of additional revenue or reduced costs, which is always nice both for personal satisfaction but also to include in your CV.
- Barclays supports heavily volunteering. There is a pound-for-pound match for any donations made by employees to most global non-profit organizations and initiatives and you are able to participate in Barclays' Lifeskills program, which is a great program with mane opportunities to get involved in volunteering around your area.
- The benefits package is quite generous. The pension scheme must be one of the best in the UK market, private healthcare, annual bonus, buying stocks at preferential rates, income protection, etc.
- Redundancy rounds. Barclays during the past couple years was under an enormous restructuring. So lots of people was offered to leave the bank and get significant redundancy packages. If you want to change a job anyway, then this might be a nice way to get a great bonus on your way out.
cons:
- Lots of politics
- Lots of scrutiny, bureaucracy (I guess like everywhere in financial services)
- Limited resources - You will never be able to hire the number of people that you need. It is very rare to have them pay for any professional certification/training. When I joined in the first 2 weeks I didn't have a laptop, and then they gave me an old/used one from someone who left! It wasn't even cleaned properly and it was disgusting. I finally got a new laptop after 12 months!
- As mentioned it's a great company to work and has great benefits. So you will meet many people who are working in Barclays for more than 10-15 years (and some even stay for their whole career!). This means that eventually, you might have a manager who joined Barclays right after school and managed to get promoted after so many years. Hence, you should expect that you might have to work along people who are not the brightest or/and have limited skills when compared with other companies at that level.
- Redundancy rounds. I mentioned earlier this as a pro. But it's a con as well, especially for people who were close to retiring and it's almost impossible for them to find another job at an advanced age. Also, quite tricky to become redundant during a pandemic (COVID-19).

headline: Poor leadership, political, inefficient and relatively a toxic culture
pros:
Remuneration is high, but not always fairly applied - reflects lack the of control and transparency in Reward.
Some great people - but many unable to be successful because of the toxic leadership in HR - and other parts of the business.
Flexible working is encouraged.
Supportive of inclusion and diversity in principle.
Some ineffective leaders in the function have been removed - hopefully will change for the better.
Some great business leaders in pockets of the wider Bank.
cons:
Political and hierarchical.
Too many people with no clear accountability - work is duplicated - too many senior people in HR creating inefficient working practices.
Some particularly poor leaders in HR - ‘fire drill’ culture and lack of strategic, future-focused approach and often covering own backs.
Successful people manage upwards well, but in reality, treat their teams poorly.
Lack of openness and transparency to colleagues - performance is not effectively managed, difficult conversations are avoided.

headline: Do not even think to join the Finance Department
pros: If you read the story below you will not be surprised I do not have anything positive to report
cons:
The worst professional experience in my life!!! A toxic environment and a CFO not capable of holding his word. Disrespectful and unethical behavior.  After eight interviews I decided to join Barclaycard to lead a team of four finance analysts. This is what I was promised and what I agreed to. 
The first day I joined and without any previous notice I was informed that my role changed and I had to co-lead the team with a colleague that was already in the team in the same role the last 15 years. It was the first time in my life I heard the term "Dual-leadership". 
When I asked why this change happened and what was the plan moving forward, I got from the CFO a high level response that growth opportunities might exist in the future. 
On top, the colleague who was officially the leader of the team, was refusing to handover to me any element of the work, downplaying me constantly by taking advantage of his powerful position in the organization and pushing me to the limits. 
After two months I decided to quit. I paid a huge personal and professional cost to join them because I simply believed that they would have offered me the role we agreed to. However, the CFO was not capable of holding on his word. An unbelievable behavior. Of course, I did not even hear an apology from him for the inconvenience his decision caused to me.

There’s a lot of opportunity to move into other roles but progression/promotions are very competitive and the application process is time consuming

VP's and directors behave like school bullies
You will be treated like a slave even small roadside firms have better values and cultures towards there employees.

headline: Great Exposure to Inter-Workings of An Investment Bank but Monotonous Work
pros:
- Great exposure to senior leadership as part of the graduate program and enjoyed the ability to rotate through different groups within Compliance
- Room for growth and a defined promotional ladder
- Competitive compensation package for the years of work experience required for the role and generous vacation allowance (4 weeks PTO, not including federal holidays, sick leave, or personal days)
- Generally kind and supportive colleagues
cons:
- The work is very monotonous -- it takes a couple of months to get the hang of what is required for your role but after that the work very rarely changes
- A fair amount of turnover and cuts in the department take a toll on morale and this decline in morale is not appropriately addressed
-Not enough focus on relevant trainings to improve the technical skills of workers -- creating workshops for learning technical languages to automate some of the more monotonous tasks could be vital to enhancing the department
-Compliance department has more mid-career professionals than young professionals , which results in a bit of complacency in terms of really enhancing the department and being forward-thinking

headline: Overall, it wasn't bad. If you're someone who has the capacity for a position like this, you will succeed.
pros: You have a set schedule, you are going to get 40hrs/week. They also would offer a ton of overtime. Managers were nice, would want you to succeed and give you the tools to increase your productivity. The nice thing is that there was no upselling to customers, just helping them with whatever they needed regarding their account(s). Paid training too.
cons: They refused to work with me to create a work schedule that worked around my school schedule which is why I left. Also, a lot of contradiction when it came to values of the company they wanted us to portray and goals they wanted us to achieve. One day it was "provide the best service..." and the next day it was "hurry up and get them off the phone."

headline: Not a Technology Company
pros:
1. Good work life balance.
2. Good Bonus but not at all comparable to other banks like JPMC and GS. Compensation is also good as compared to other companies in Pune.
3. Good Office.
4. Pluralsight account is given free .
cons:
1. Has already become a service based company by culture and benefits.
2. They have started using a metrics named blue Optima. I have never heard of more illogical assessment of developer productivity. Now people have started pushing crap on BitBucket just to improve their score.
3. Many of the leads (Atleast with whom I worked) aren't technically sound. I had an incident one AVP came asking when does string out of bound exception comes.
4. Almost 0 technical growth. If you want to laze around and want to work more on process than tech then it's a right organisation. (Not good for developers).
5. Hiring process is not at all good. Inside company one can see so many bad hires. 
6. Too much politics and too less interaction of higher management with devs.(Culture is suffocating).

headline: No growth in Singapore

headline: Full of sexism, homophobia, racism...
pros:
Nothing. Literally nothing.
Everyone hates the place but somehow they choose to stay because of the salary being a pitiful 1k higher than other similar local jobs.
cons:
Being sexually harassed and having it swept under the rug is definitely a con here! Unless you enjoy having your experience invalidated, driven to suicidal thoughts, and expected to hop back into the office!

An absolute shambles. Management are likely trained to veil the fact that they don't care about you or your situation, and want you to work like battery chickens.  But hey free dominos eh! 

Nepotism is rife here. It's really who you know and how much you suck up.

If you love homophobia, then this is the place for you too! Ignore the fancy IDAHOBIT days, a lot of people working here hate equality and make it verbally obvious. Also hearing racist and ableist remarks was an almost daily occurance.

Honestly just don't even bother.

headline: Treat you like meat and backstab
pros: looks good on your CV
cons:
- A backstabbing culture where most are attempting to constantly one-up each other to get a promotion, very dog eat dog culture
- Put on a front of wanting to help the customer but actually, all they care about is how many loans & insurances they can sell
- Management is more worried about covering their own backs than helping you with your job
- Messed me around with my contract leaving me constantly on probation and "under review" for almost a year as they needed to review their local employee numbers
- Always felt like you were being watched and scrutinised

I could go on... if you are looking to work in a local branch on the front line and have any kind of dignity, avoid

headline: Mentally and Physically Exhausting
pros:
Free one time food in Noida location.
Free Transport 
Rest I'm yet to discover
cons:
Certain AVP's have no idea of handling a team.  They just try to finish the task without getting into details of how much effort it will take, they just want to shine in front of their director/VP.  So this make the life of his subordinates living hell. So much work pressure, daily on the receiving end of yelling. Certain days I feels like if I'm really good at anything or not.

People are not good or bad, but they are not experienced enough to handle the situation. So try to train them well before loading them with so much work load so that they take out their fear of disappointing their seniors on their teams.
All power lies with AVP+ level. Don't think that HR is of any help. 

If you have any concerns then talk to your manager or his manager but No HR.  So I'm just absorbing all their negative energy currently in hope of a better team in my next project.

headline: No empathy
pros: Colleagues are nice but that's about it
cons:
I started working for barclays in 2012, in 2013 i broke my wrist and at the time was a temp so couldn't afford to be off work. I asked to reduce my hours but that was not an option, i was forced to work with a broken wrist (right wrist) and i am right handed which has caused me long term damage. 
In 2018 my father died, i was currently on a contract with another department and because my father died and i couldn't give me 100% i was let go from the contract, i was told the day before my fathers funeral.

headline: Good Employer
pros:
I have worked in their IT department for over 20 years. 
Generally a very flexible enjoyable place to work. 
The culture is professional without being oppressive. People/Managers are understanding and reasonable. (Of course you get the odd one!)
Working environment is good, with good pay and share scheme etc.
cons:
I have very little bad to say about Barclays. 
I believe that colleagues are very reasonable and friendly/helpful. 
However, I also understand that senior managers/directors realm there is a culture of politics, empire building and shenanigans! This is ultimately destructive to Barclays. Culture stems from the top and it is up to those on the board to stamp this out and set a more positive culture for the benefit of customers, staff and shareholders.

headline: Bad Pay; Lack of Growth;
pros: not bad for 1st year out of college; good vision benefits
cons:
I started off in the internship program. That itself is mayhem, with the process designed for interns to just schmooze as many people as they can without really learning too much in the process (albeit its a 10 week program so only so much you can learn about trading). I ended up accepting the offer to join full time and it has been an overall average experience. The analyst to AVP program underpays you considerably. So kudos to those that take the offer and leave within 1 yr to get a higher salary elsewhere (where it is really possibly in trading). Overall the bank has no regard for juniors, which is why there is so much turnover. You will not find many from the internship program at Barclays, but they do stay in trading, which shows the bank is unable to retain talent. There is no feedback process for your boss. They have the ability to say whatever they want, without you contesting it. The main reason why I left is because I felt significantly undervalued. I was doing work and making the kind of money my AVP wasn't and he was paid double what I was. Thats just not the right way to treat people, especially a woman trader. So I would say this bank does not particularly support women in trading. I would say this to those interested: join, use the bank for as much as it can give you (1 yr pay), and leverage to do something better. DO NOT stick around. It is not worth it. I had several MDs of different desks that supported me and my work, but were unable to help me get the pay I deserved. So mentorship can only go so far when your immediate director is unfavorable. 

Also I worked 12+ hour work days all the time; it went completely unnoticed despite my book absolutely killing it. 

Below was my comp. Evidently it is SIGNIFICANTLY below market rate. 
1st yr: 85k/yr base with 15k sign on bonus; 10k stub bonus
2nd yr: 90k base with 50k bonus
3rd yr: 95K base with 70k-100K bonus
4th yr: 125k base with 90-120K bonus

headline: One of the worst experiences of my life.
pros:
Parking was available.
There was a pension scheme.
cons:
I was based in Coventry Westwood business park personal risk. This was my first job after leaving University.
It was just a really horrible place to work. I think you would call it a culture of 'passive aggressive' bullying now.
Memories of this was an office whereby nobody spoke to anyone. Silence was the norm for the whole day.
My job was to in effect understudy a contractor with the intention of taking over her job! She who didn't want to lose her job. This put me in a very awkward position.
She reported to the head of the department that I couldn't  do my job with my inevitable dismissal due to incompetence. It took me a while to get my confidence and career back on track. I don't think I will ever truly recover from it.

headline: Overly complex organisation
pros: Good amount of flexibility and autonomy. Most colleagues are friendly and easy to work with. Pay and benefits good overall.
cons:
Organisation is horrendously complex. Very hard to get things done. In recent years has become even more centralised following a big re-organisation. The effort to centralise 'centres of excellence' has unfortunately made it really difficult to deliver change as orchestration across business and tech areas is really difficult. Each area is only focussed on their goals. Not enough focus on shared objectives and truly serving the customer, not just shareholders. 
Additionally there is a bit of a glass ceiling when you get to VP level. Not many senior roles available at Director or MD level. Lot of shifting of deck chairs at those levels and now focus is on promoting women (noble intent but not great message to hear if you are a man with ambitions). 
There is also a lot of theatre and showcasing of achievements that are just not value adding. The internal PR is more important than actual delivery and customer value, driven mainly by senior leaders competing with each other and creating a façade.

headline: Need to change the outlook
pros: The salary and benefits attached to it are good
