Legacy IT infrastructure .
No Learning curve or career benefits .
Any lateral hire cannot stick to the culture for more than 6months. If they are sticking it is just because of personal commitment.
Attrition of lateral hires is high
No work life balance. 
No human emotions. People going through personal exigency are treated in a inhuman way. 
Even the state of mind during such exigencies are considered as lack of performance
Ideas or innovation are not welcomed unless it is given by senior management
Inhouse projects to create products without minimum understanding .

headline: Toxic culture
pros: The cards business continues to grow. Base compensation is fair compared to the market.
cons: The culture within cards & payments is very toxic. The CIO reports into the COO, which means Technology is run like Ops. Senior management seems to think technology people  are exchangeable like people in  a call center. The focus is on people being in the office from 9-5, instead of looking at true outcomes. No flexibility for remote work. Although the cards business is doing well and growing, bonuses are down year after year after year. New management In Cards & Payments is looking for opportunities to move positions to India.

headline: No improvement
pros:
Pays over average, no benefits bullshitting.
Safe position.
Great flexibility if you have family: flexible hours, occasional home office possibility, option for part time.
Diversity in every sense.
cons:
As for feedback and improvement ideas: full force against such from management. First nobody wants to improve things. Then, if somebody wants so, nobody listens. Then if somebody listens, nothing happens. What finally may happen is that they tell you to shut up and work; unless there is scandal. When scandal comes, managers start to push responsibility downwards. 
Technology: there are new technologies but since nobody has the view on those, they work worse than old ones.
Bureaucracy: impossible to achieve any goal in the time frame it would make sense. Not complaining about 3 days instead of 2... but more than a year instead of less than a month?!
Internal tooling unusable.
Talent retention: it's considered something that HR must solve alone, quickly and possibly without expense. What we get is an insult from employee perspective.
Environment: the office is _dirty._

headline: Great employer but very insecure employment these days
pros: Great pay and rewards - pension the best for new starters in the industry probably.  Staff have just had big pay rises as the bank moves away from incentives, and the focus on staff wellbeing is great.  People are passionate about giving their best for customers, and this is at all levels of the bank, and everyone lives and breathes the values from top to bottom.  So many talented staff, and so many nice people.  I miss Barclays a lot.
cons: If you don't work in a big town or city centre branch or one of the key sites in the UK, then your job is probably going to disappear. The bank is spending a fortune on laying off experienced staff in sites that are no longer considered key - such as Cardiff, Coventry, Leeds - and replacing them with colleagues who have no experience in Glasgow, Manchester, Northampton.  It is costing Barclays a fortune, it is losing many of its best staff and key expertise, and it is against the interests of customers and shareholders alike.  Someone senior needs to call this out for the madness that it is - that's what most staff think

headline: Some Good's Some Ok's. Read review and make your own judgement
pros:
Good flexibility for WFH
Good social environment and team feeling in many projects
Flexibility to IJP to different businesses if you've worked for more than a year in one area
Digital teams/Ventures Team and business is the place to be as lot of investment is done to insource and grow business.
cons:
More project management as old school managers don't believe in Agile Ways of working.
VP culture/ army style hierarchy in some teams who don't mingle if you don't hold the same level or acceptance.
Culture of Bank for location strategy, permanent staff vs contractors changes every one to two years with change in management perception or the management itself
Bonuses are peanuts or just ok as HR adopted a new strategy with ratings as follows
> Needs Improvement
> Strong
> Exceptional

Earlier there was something like Very Strong in it. This new criterion makes it difficult to haggle as everyone can't say they are Exceptional. So you end up losing your bonus.
London has become non strategic for many businesses so if they are hiring for a position think as you maybe asked to move to Radbroke or Glasgow or other areas where they are opening 3000 seater own office spaces.

headline: A place for mediocrity
pros:
- Good work/life balance
- Supportive of activities outside of work (I was able to complete a graduate program while working full time)
- Generally nice people
cons:
- A lot of the smart, “go-getter” types of people have left; somehow the place is now full of people who are around to just collect a paycheck
- Lack of strategic direction, constant turnover of leadership and each new leader comes up with a strategy that is radically different from the previous one and basically teams have to abandon previous projects because there is a new pet technology to convert to; projects are constantly being decommissioned or converted to the new tech stack but never fully completed before a new leader comes along
- No opportunities for growth 
- Zero investment for training

headline: Could do better

cons: Always short staffed, never get out on time, you always get one or two lazy ones that don’t pull their weight. There’s always one staff that’s been there for donkeys years that can’t accept change or change or procedure. Dont work in a branch that opens on Saturdays as you end up working more Saturdays then you should as it’s always short staffed. There’s no work life balance, expected to come to work between 8.15am then leave on a good day 5.30pm.

headline: Not paid enough for the role.
pros: Good training provided at the start for two weeks. The environment can be great if the right management is placed.
cons: The company and promotional opportunities is not as progressive as they put it. There are jobs going but they only hire people they have in mind so you’re literally just applying to get rejected. Had a big management change in April 2019 and since then it’s gone downhill. Employees are not treated fairly and over worked. The staffing is a joke and they don’t have enough staff to cope with the pressures. The job itself is not the paying enough compare to the work employees do and promotion is just promised just so the employee remain in job and carry on working.

headline: Buyer beware
pros:
NYC office location 
Cafeteria 
Base Compensation
cons: It’s a highly dysfunctional organization. Functional leadership is muddled and the US operation is shown little respect from HQ in London. The excuse is that it’s a highly matrixed organization but the reality is that it is incredibly inefficient and political even over the smallest things. Also know that few resources are being invested in NYC and NYC jobs are moving to  Whippany, NJ. Basic things like  paying vendors on time doesn’t get done and support for  key IT systems doesn’t get attention. Getting the most basic things done is extremely difficult and external (experienced) input likely will be ignored and certainly is not enabled. And nobody seems to care.

headline: Bad working environment
pros:
* Good perks
* Some very smart people to work with
cons:
* Not up to date with tech. Even though there are talks to upgrade things this is just talk. Nothing ever comes out of it. My skills are actually worse since i joined
* Ambitious projects which will never work out because of the lack of tech. All they will ever become is a slide in a presentation somewhere. No niche solution will be used in production or anything.
* Abusive managers. I cannot stress this one enough. It depends on the team but in every team i have been there was always one manager who thought abuse, yelling and belittling his subordinates was a good idea
* Constant reorgs and hiring freezes. In the time i have been there there were 2 reorgs and a constant hiring freeze.
* Massive attrition which also means that given the hiring freeze the people staying have to do everything. People leaving constantly doesn't raise any HR flags. No one cares if a team of 20 suddenly becomes a team of 8. It is BAU.
* Below market salary
* A lot of people who have been there for more than a decade and cannot understand that things have to change at some point. Banking is still viewed as a job for life for some generations and that leaves no space for younger people
* Promotion is hard. If you dare to question anything you go directly in a blacklist. You just have to nod and smile constantly for about 10 years if you want to get promoted. Young people with great end of year reviews do not manage to get anywhere most of the time and they end up leaving. 
* You get sucked in a world of bureaucracy which i can only describe as kafkaesque. While I understand this is a massive organisation and certain things have to be regulated this is on a whole new different level. I have worked in big organisations before but they were lightyears more efficient than Barclays

cons:

headline: Forced to lie
pros: Very few I am afraid to say.
cons: Every day I have to lie to customers and justify management decisions which are not only immoral but probably illegal. I have seen customers with their lives destroyed by the bank's actions and have been asked to lie to them, withhold information they are legally entitled too, all in the knowledge that if they take a complaint to the ombudsman they will side with the bank. This job has put me off banks for life. We are literally killing people with our actions.

headline: Mind numbing work in a poorly led environment
pros: Barclays still offers a fantastic work/life balance and this is probably the only advantage of a bank that once had numerous positive attributes that have sadly gone.  Aware that it needs to tick the relevant social boxes, the bank has promoted female promotion and diversity (LGBT) across the bank - you will certainly get preference above other candidates.
cons: The business systems go back as far as the 1970s and some of the processes are still manual so you might spend a lot of time performing mundane tasks that should be automated.  In the past, the work was very exciting when the bank was innovating and pushing its technology capabilities but now the lack of skilled technologists, who were made redundant or have simply left due to the boring work, have left a large intelligence gap that simply means that most projects or programmes fail or lack sufficient funding.  I have been at the bank for a number of years and it used to be an exciting and challenging place to work.  It is now mundane, boring and mind numbing.  Corporate systems, such as personal laptops and the software upon them, are so brittle that if the laptop doesn't fail the software will.

headline: Overall a good company just not the department I was in
pros: I loved the job, the customers were so interesting to talk to and hear about their lives and professions. Most customers were high earners so a lot of them worked in very specific niche areas of their professions and it was interesting to hear about their specialities. Before working in my last department I had always praise Barclays as an employer, their benefits package is second to none and the wages are really good.
cons: I was in a department called premier direct when I left, I originally started that department as a team leader, when I was interviewed for the job, my understanding of the job role was that I would have a portfolio of high value clients and that my team would manage the clients due to the size of the portfolio, I couldn’t have been more wrong! When I began they put me in new to bank training even though I had been a part of Barclays for 5 years already, it had been a while since my last management position and some management training would have been a lot more beneficial. They also gave me a team that they had taken on as a risk due to the majority of them coming into work from long term unemployment and as such a lot of them were difficult to manage! The job role they were doing was not any kind of relationship building or management. They were on an outbound dialler making sales calls, all the calls were loaded into the dialler based on prompts about lending, mortgages and sometimes savings (although the focused heavily on lending mainly). The people I was managing had no idea what they were targeted against Yet I was expected to put action plans in place when they didn’t get things like mortgages or loans within a 2 week period. In the end I had to take time off and decided this wasn’t the job for me. When I returned I was made a direct premier relationship manager where i would contact the customers to build relationships myself, while this was using the same outbound dialler there was more of a relationship building style to it and not just completely sales. However, on returning I was clear my card was marked and I wasn’t wanted there, I would imagine it was due to having knowledge of the underhand techniques and sales they were driving when as a bank Barclays do not set targets for sales. I soon found myself going through a disciplinary process and when speaking to other people within the department and the union the “offence” I had committed should have been dealt with by no more than a file note. Soon after this was resolved I found myself to be the main suspect of another investigation for a laptop which was stolen 12 months earlier from my car, at the time this was reported to the police and they had seen the damage done to my car from the break in. I was told it was someone within the department who had contacted their special investigations team to raise this with them requesting it was looked into. This I also believe to have been done maliciously and in an attempt to make me feel like i was no longer welcome there, I’ve since decided to leave Barclays as they made it difficult for me to move to another business area.

headline: Love working for Barclays in Whippany, NJ
pros:
I’ve been with the firm about six months. Barclays in Whippany had a great culture that many companies strive for, but is hard to truly create. Leaders are humble. Employees work hard, but that is a lot of emphasis on work life balance. I’ve never been at a company that is so supportive of employees engaging in employee-driven events and community service. Most teams, at least at this site, have flexible work schedules. Benefits are great, a clinic, backup daycare and awesome gym onsite. This is a solid company for veterans with a long history of supporting them globally. 

The reason I think the cultural tone is so strong is because the senior leaders I have met are humble and accessible.
cons: It’s a big company and sometimes because of that and because it is not HQ’d in the US, it can take a lot of time and effort to move change. That said, people are supportive in working to find a way. Overall, I am thrilled with my experience. The onboarding process could be improved to make getting initial accessed easier and faster but I felt supported and was always able to find someone to help me when needed.

- Whippany location is trying to be sold as a “high tech” location. When in reality it is a remote location, where your career becomes stagnant and essentially as an employee you’re forgotten. 
- Morale is at an all time low and it’s challenging to come to work 
- Resignation will continue to occur

headline: Personal Assistant
pros: Barclays’ esteemed reputation and the role initially attracted me. I was blown away by the stunning Whippany NJ campus: fresh air walking paths, weekly vendor sales, barber/manicurist/masseuse, on-your-honor convenience store, hot and cold brew coffee bar, arcade game room, pool and ping-pong tables and an employee cafe down the hill replete with healthful food choices including an Argentinian grill. I’m awed by just how much effort the management has expended in making this such a delightful workplace.  That the Barclays’ values mirror my own makes this company a keeper. Management hires you to tell them how things should be done, not vice versa. So refreshing. You get a lot of flexibility with work-at-home arrangements. There’s two-way trust here. Bring your strong sense of integrity, desire for excellence, as well as communication, teamwork, negotiation, and collaboration skills. You’ll need them to navigate the behemoth company and get things done. You’ll meet lots of great people, and make some good friends. Barclays likes to help people rise, to get us to the best place for us all. That includes not just customers and clients, but employees as well. I love working in a professional atmosphere, with brilliant minds. I’m really glad I accepted the offer.
cons: If you’re not familiar with navigating a large company,  you’ll need to start smiling and reach out to your colleagues to get things done.  Not so bad, because of the rewards in friendship that it brings.

headline: Absolutely rubbish department do not work on the Northampton site
pros: There were no pros when working for Barclays Partner Finance.  The values are not followed by people.  Lots of mobile phone use on the floor, team leaders know that mobile phones are used but not action taken.  Very noisy department, saw for 6 months one person swearing and being loud. But because he was the team leaders pet no one said nothing.
cons: if your face don't fit dont work there. When I first started there I thought it would be a neutral culture but it isnt. If you go to the pub and your name is john your cool.  I saw a alot of  people get spoken to like dirt. In the BPF department there were alot of cliques and alot of chavs. I saw a guy get racially abused on a number of occasions.  Diversity in the Northampton site is a word only. Team leaders are a clique. If you want to be in a clique then go to Barclays Northampton, also you are going to have to share your personal social media accounts to be in a clique.  The management are two faced and very rude. Directors have sexual relations with female staff members even when they are married.  It is like a equivalent of a  pedophile ring. They then talk about Honesty, Stewardship, and integrity on a regular basis.  I also saw a guy ask another worker for a fight. That guy was a team leader. There is always talk of diversity but it is just a word. Picture all the fat and insecure people at school, they are the type of people that work in Barlcays Partner Finance. Also HR takes the side of managers over staff. Their employment policy is not in line with the ACAS code of conduct. Unite the union sides with the Bank.  My advice dont talk to anyone there unless you can trust them.  The directors at this site are equally rude. They are paid £60000 a year but they dont know anything about underwriting.  There is rule for the directors and one for the workers.  Most of the team leaders in the Northampton  Site  are Far Right Sympathizers, they think England should be white and only white.  If your from a multicultural background and stand your ground they dont like it.

headline: Pathetic
pros: They pay you well but there is a cost to it.
cons: It’s not a office . It is a school with a lot of rules and restrictions. If you are in a calling process, you will be treated like robots expecting you to take back to back calls for 9 hours. They don’t even have simple facilities like mute . They are not at all performance oriented . They just care about their policies like not eating at desk. They claim to provide meals but your break timings might not align with their cafeteria timings and you are expected to work on empty stomach. Performance is not a parameter here for growth . You need to offer everything to your boss to get promotions (if you know what I mean). The managers will treat you like kids thinking that you don’t understand anything. Management keeps changing within months. I worked for 8 months and my manager was changed twice . They keep on moving managers from one process to another wasting money on their trainings . All the decisions made by Barclays are unreasonable . Pathetic place to work .

headline: Fun while it lasted
pros: Learned alot of the ongoings and processes involved with credit cards, had potential to move to new departments early on. Management was great and you were punished harshly for mistakes,  but rather corrected and educated.
cons: The cons come from the silence of corporate.  They promote this idea of togetherness and hippy garbage but remain silent to it's own people when  times seem troubled. A hiring freeze for over a year with no ability to relocate to another position,  being told we are not closing and then watching, without warning, 5 or so managers get walked out. I know its business and these thing happen. But do not lie and stay silent to your people.  Allow us the time needed to start preparing  for the future if in fact the location is to close.

headline: Mindbending bureaucracy caused by million levels of middle mgmt
pros:
Reasonable pay although bonus is distributed amongst mgmt.
Good people to work with.
Reasonable work life balance. 
On managers discretion some teams have flexible working.
cons:
Apart from breathing every thing else requires you to fill forms on umpteen request systems for which you have to then send multiple manual chasers to multiple approvers. Utterly chaotic atmosphere in the tech/dev area. Devs are basically treated like low skilled manual labour with minimal rights, while non-technical incompetent but very political middle management takes all the rewards. 
Everyone receives hundreds of completely irrelevant pointless emails every day.  Some times entire days are spent on phone calls trying to explain technical stuff to non technical mgmt who still dont get it. I have actually seen people with tens of thousands of unread emails in their inboxes. 
The Core values(RISES) only apply to low level technical staff. Mgmt is beyond it. 
In normal companies the process that takes 30 minutes can some times take 30 days to do in barclays. Other times people just give up. 
Technical staff have to do mandatory irrelevant trainings every quarter because mgmt cant be arsed to filter the trainings. 
list goes on .... if you are a competent developer do yourself a favour and stay away.

headline: Too Much Change
pros: Barclays has some really great people that come to work and give it their all and want to do good job.  The company is generally supportive of flexible work arrangements and a lot of emphasis is placed on giving back to the community.  Internal mobility is encouraged and people do move internally fairly easily.
cons: The organization is very convoluted and very often there is a lack of clear ownership and accountability which make decision making difficult.  Advancement to the Director and Managing Director levels is very subjective and based on who you know and who likes you rather than accomplishments.  Internal systems are antiquated and need upgrading.  Finally, depending on what area of the bank you join eventually your team may be transferred to Whippany, NJ.

headline: Most unprofessional firm I have ever worked at
pros: Free cab transport service, Free 1 time food, Infrastructure is good, Work life balance is above average.
cons:
Not sure where to start. Almost everything about this company is bad.

1. Very unprofessional - Most of the employees and therefore the culture are unprofessional. They hire just anyone and everyone. Hiring of relatives is common.
2. The current senior leadership (Indian) are average joe (without good background) and therefore the culture has worsened a lot.
3. Favoritism and partiality is very visible. You need to have much more than good work ethics to move up the ladder.
4. In the name of diversity and women-power, many undeserving and incapable women employees have been elevated to senior position.

It is no surprise that good senior leaders have already left (and are leaving) this company.

headline: If only top management listened
pros: Great company benefits, share save plan and private pension.
cons: Stepping up on the career ladder is not so easy; you have to constantly prove yourself. I just wish the leadership team at the very top involved themselves more with the front line team , listened to what really works and doesn't work when it comes to new customer products; how team members feel when changes are made that directly impact them...... there is still is huge gap between the top and the bottom line.

headline: Poor culture / bullying from managment

cons:
Managment cause stress and presure , bully their staff . 
Managment not interested in getting colleagues engaged . Too much presure and targets in a role that is supposed to be autonomous and provide risk protection to the bank . Errors made because the culture is all numbers . No interest in staff well being , or happiness .

headline: Worst management I’ve ever worked for
pros: The company itself offers a lot of perks, discounts at certain places, good pension scheme, good sick pay/mat leave etc. They also do a lot of events for diversity and inclusion, theres opportunities for you to get involved in a lot of different networks. The actual people that do the work are great, a lot of nice and talented people there.
cons:
The management don’t care at all about their employees, as long as the work gets done. All they do is talk about 360 feedback, yet when presented with feedback themselves, they are only willing to take on positive feedback rather than constructive as well. I even had an exit interview with a director where I gave mix of feedback, and as soon as I mentioned the management he didn’t want to hear it, it’s a disgrace. They don’t care about people and they’re obsessed with control, they literally prevent their team members from making internal job moves as well, like go and speak to the hiring managers to ensure they don’t give people in their team the job. They make fun of the people in their teams, laughing at them and bullying people. One of the managers was even clearly sleeping with the head of department. 

I personally was heavily involved in one of the networks that got a lot of shoutouts from senior management, and as soon as those shoutouts started happening, my manager was trying to push me to not be a part of the network, because she literally didn’t want me to be getting recognised.

There was one guy from another department who did a secondment in our area, had to re-interview at the end of his secondment and found out he didn’t get the job by logging into the HR portal, his manager who he’d been working with for a YEAR didn’t even have the courtesy to take him aside and let him know.

The managers conveniently find BS excuses to mark people down or put people on action plans right before the half year and end of year reviews. It doesn’t matter at all what you write in your own review as it’s completely based on whether or not they like you.

headline: Great business & Culture, with some challenges.
pros:
Barclays are a really amazing company to work for, without any doubt.  
For a start - the benefits are fantastic.  You get a generous benefits allowance and can tailor your package to what you want, everything from life, illness and accident insurance to gym membership and bike to work.  
The culture is very relaxed, almost too relaxed at times.  Barclays are normally the last bank to get to an offer when they're in competition against the other banks, and this needs to be remedied.   However, this relaxed culture means I've never been micromanaged.  You're left to do a job, and as long as you're delivering, you'll be left alone and can work as you wish.
The opportunities are there, for sure.  I went from Cashier to VP in 8 years, but you do find the competition intense the higher you get.
cons:
As mentioned above, the floors of head office are filled with exceptional people, and competition for senior roles is intense.  This, however, is what you need to expect, and is universal across the industry.
Having said this however, promotions, in my experience, are very much about the face that fits, and you do find some very unexceptional people moved very quickly up the chain.  The biggest flaw that Barclays have is their interview process for promotions.  The process ONLY takes into account your performance on a rigid, scripted 45 minute competency interview, and not your prior performance in role.  This hasn't been the case at other banks I've worked at, where the highest performers tend to get promoted.  At Barclays, it's all about how good your (often made-up on the spot) examples to these questions are, and it's terrible.

headline: Soul destroying
pros: The majority of staff are lovely to work with and make the place almost bearable.
cons:
Pretty much everything. 
-don’t get paid for starting early and staying late 
-targets targets targets 
-constant pressure about selling products and loans to customers
-told your rubbish on a daily basis 
-training is a shambles first ever appointment in my moment banker role got told I’d be fine doing it myself and was never observed until 7 months into the role and even then it wasn’t even my manager
-no support then threatened with being put on a plan
-1-1 monthly meetings with manager supposed to be about what you want to talk about but it’s your manager telling you what to write and telling you to put unrealistic figures in.
Now this is just a review of one branch and Hopefully not all all branches are like this. But I wasn’t going to stick around and find out.

headline: Mixed bag really
pros: I was treated really well when I started and got the appropriate training from some really supportive people. I found the benefits package to be really good too, especially the private healthcare.
cons: I know this differs across different branches, however I find that the management in my branch is very self centred, I find it very difficult to approach them about things. There is a very toxic atmosphere in the workplace, you can be moved branch very quickly with minimal notice so everyone is treading on eggshells. They have a strong emphasis on development and career progression, however when I have tried to express my willingness to move on, I am met with false promises of help and nobody really seems to care. I used to really enjoy the job but now I find it incredibly boring and generally not enjoyable.

headline: Your job satisfaction will depend on your team
pros: Great benefits (typical of a corporate) - like healthcare, insurance, etc. Great name on CV. A lot of programmes and events to support employees. Although depends on whether you'll actually have the time to take advantage of them.
cons: Legacy systems slow down your efficiency quite a bit, typical corporate bureaucracy, need to be seen and heard to get promotions (so if you're quiet/introvert, prepare to stay in the same position for a very long time regardless of how hard you work). A lot of job openings but most are only advertised to meet the policy - the suitable person would've already been identified/decided on - mostly someone the hiring manager already knows. This is a public secret and widely accepted by most. Not saying it doesn't happen in other companies, but just because it happens elsewhere doesn't make it okay.

post-it note meetings (where meeting updates are physical post-it note style kanban boards)
Agile - in IT. Even Agile themselves has said IT shouldn't be in use with IT, but we're being forced to use it. It doesnt work. 
Really old tech (some servers are still running 2k3)
Too much red tape

headline: Average, Stubnorn and unprofessional on a lot of occasions: Developer review
pros:
Not too much work pressure if you have the right skills

Getting leaves is easier compared to other companies.

Flexible times are allowed if you have a real reason to be late or to leave early.
cons:
Initial Judgement based on reviews by people who might not even know technology

Not that much work. So if you do your work and don't get vocal about what you have done its equivalent to not doing any work.

Visibility is over valued.

Some colleagues don't follow RISES.. If you don't give respect you are not going to get it.  People feel entitled because they have spent more time in the company.

People who have been with organization for long enough assume seniority in aggressive ways and that can seem very unprofessional at times.

Even the people with expertise in a skill are ignored in discussions relates to that skill just because they are new joiners.

More importance given in discussions to people who are more experienced in organozation  even though they are making the same point as their new joinee colleagues..
In fact at times people copy someones view in front of them and state them as their own... That's what happens when visibility brownie points are linked to bonuses.

Pathetic on boarding.

headline: Great place to work

headline: Great place to work, flexible, internal mobility
pros:
-Open door policy in most departments, senior management is very accessible
-Employees are encouraged to seek internal mobility opportunities for new roles and growth 
-Great learning & development
-Many resources for career development 
-Flexible/remote working (though may be dependent on your manager’s preference)
-Great benefits & salaries (if coming from external) are competitive
cons:
-Technology investment does not seem to be a priority - it is siloed and not consistent across departments
-Company can be very bureaucratic and hierarchical 
-When moving internally or getting promoted salary changes are not competitive 
-Regular structural changes make it difficult to understand the company objectives
-People impact of changes is not given the appropriate amount of consideration and effort
-Best practices are siloed - no central repository for information exchange

headline: Poor policies and work environment for working mothers - Pune EON
pros: Company policies for work life balance but managers take it away
cons:
1. Very rude managers in Pune EON office.
2. Lack respect and understanding for working mothers. Not sure why they hire diversity candidates.
3. Company policies support work life balance but managers dont allow.
4. There are no HR policies or network to check if women are treated well.
5. Directors are famous for being womanisers
6. In start of year managers start mentioning you will get worst rating, way before mid year, leave about end of year. Leaves employee totally demotivated and looking out in start of year itself.
7. Make you work on technology thats not your skillset and expect you to work 12 hours a day.
Overall very stressful environment - why did I join?

headline: PPI Claims Handler
pros: The canteen food was quite good
cons: Treated with very little respect as a new starter coming through the in house Barclays Recruitment Agency. Understandable strict financial background check and the threat that at any time in the first 12 weeks of work you may be removed from the office floor by building security and made to leave without being told the reason and no means of rectifying it. Also the job description and training give people a sense that their opinions are valued to handle the case in line with the training when in reality the guidelines were changing on a daily basis making for a feeling of instability within the role.

headline: Not what they promised
pros: They have great health benefits.
cons: They try to pretend that they aren't a call center in the interview, and that there is no pressure. Until you get out of training and onto the floor. Within one day we were pressured to take calls and manage them perfectly. They promised easy bonuses in the interview, and you find out that the only way to achieve them is by working crazy hours. Management all seemed to have attitudes, but I'm guessing that is because their bonuses depend on how well you do.

headline: Great benefits for employees with families
pros: Flexible working patterns, well constructed benefits package (pension plan, discount, cycle to work scheme, car allowance, training etc)
cons: When I used to work there I sometimes did not like that re-structures happened really often, leaving staff feeling a little insecure. The hours were also very long. However,  I now look back to my days in Barclaycard as some of the best in my career. I learnt lots and I loved the flexible working patterns. In general, employees are also very empowered. Great for females and members of minority groups.

headline: Barclaycard Northampton

Long term staff underpaid versus new colleagues joining the company. Experience and loyalty not always rewarded.

If you get a call from the company, expect things to take months to conclude. No exit interviews, very little support from HR for the business. Very little stability in HR. Technology is very legacy but is improving. Overall good company to work for except the really inefficient and almost non-existent HR function.

headline: VIP culture, no one cares if an employee is overutilized
pros:
1. Big MNC

cons:
1. Earlier it was BTCI, now it is Barclays global service centre. Only name is changed but everything else remains same
2. Managers enjoy without doing any technical work
3. There is full VIP culture and no open door policy. So if you are joining here please keep in mind do not talk to your AVP's VP's directly about your problems. 
4. No one bothers if a resource is utilized for more than 100%. There is no proper work distribution. 
5. Since manager here are only doing unnecessary things hence they are not involved in any technical tasks. They cannot help you technically

headline: Spring Intern
pros:
As a student who aims for constant learning, development and new challenging opportunities I thought the Barclays Spring Week Insight was a perfect opportunity to kick start my career since an early stage of university. The process of applying was very straightforward, I really enjoyed the process as it involved a video-interview, in my opinion this recruitment tool is way more effective and personal than a cover letter, as an example. 
Once the Spring Week started, I felt motivated and involved from the first minute and I quickly engaged with the other interns and employees of the firm. I woke up every day looking forward to arriving to the office. I couldn’t’ t wait to get exposure to the Spring Weeks learning and development, providing me with a honest insight into the industry, which for me was vital as it made me know how it really is to work in the financial services industry. Before the Insight Week myself and other interns did not know if we wanted to pursue a career in this industry, however, now I am very sure I want to, and if it wasn’ t for this experience I would still have major doubts about my career and future plans, now I have a clear image of my future role and how I will create a positive impact on the financial services sector.
The supportive environment makes justice to Barclays identity. The help I received from my team created an exceptional working environment that allowed me to feel comfortable sharing my ideas and being myself. Their hospitality and the way in which they value the talent of new generations were both motivating and unique. 
What I really appreciated about Spring Week was how from the first day, interns tried their best to talk to each other aiming to create and develop positive relationships which would not only help them throughout the Spring Week insight but also in life in general, as a point of contact for our future careers but also as friendships. I saw a positive competitiveness, something which is much needed in most organizations as it leads to maximum effort and development of its members but also, it leads to people pushing each other up and collaborating towards the goal achievement of everyone.
During this week, the learning curve was steep, this learning was not only about Barclays and its culture but it led to a deep contact with its functions and its employees by also learning about Barclays clients and how to deal with them. I am very grateful for the vast amount of knowledge I have learnt which will help me in my life and future career 
This experience was unique and life changing. It has improved my life, it has developed my desire to become great, but most importantly it has given me the confidence I know I need to achieve my dreams.
cons: From my short experience with the bank I can not find significant disadvantages. However, there may be disadvantages depending on employee preferences. It is obvious that hours are long and projects are extent. Banking is an industry which requires sacrifice and consistency.  Also, in most cases you will be reporting to senior management, some people dislike this as they would like to be their own boss.

headline: Honest review from long serving staff
pros:
Worked with some great people. Really had some fantastic managers who have been considerate towards my needs as a worker, and tried to be considerate to my career.

Good bonus scheme (quarterly)

Senior managers are easily accessible

Good working hours
cons:
No real opportunities for progression. There is a culture of favoritism. If you do not make the correct connections, you cannot expect to progress into senior roles regardless of experience or talent.

Poor opportunities for development

Some (not all) managers who act in a threatening or professionally inappropriate way towards the staff.

Internal communication is bad.

Pay is arguably unjust and too low. You can have 2 people on the same salary, one of which is performing in a much more difficult role, while the other is taking on less taxing work.

headline: Investment Banking Associate
pros: Relatively colleagial culture for investment banking, though some groups better than others.
cons:
Compensation is well behind peers, and employees are nicked and dimed wherever possible, for example:

The firm defines your “salary” at a figure well below your annual fixed compensation so that the firm can pay your retirement and health benefits off a lower number. The firm is the only bank on the street that doesn’t make annual salary bumps effective January 1st, instead waiting until late March, meaning you lose a meaningful catchup bonus (~5-10k) every year. The firm requires you buy your own laptop and does not reimburse you for very normal expenses like holiday parties, recruiting lunches and dinners.

Barclays is also the only firm on the street that fires a meaningful portion of its staff right before bonuses every year, which is really an awful thing. I saw many colleagues, including fathers and mothers, completely shocked and devastated as they were escorted out of the building with half the comp they had been expecting to live on.

headline: BI Compliance is not good
pros: Good name to have on CV. Across the group, Barclays is making a huge effort in promoting women and diversity, which is really positive. Mobility is easy after you’ve been there a year.
cons: A flexible/dynamic working environment is encouraged across the group, however for Barclays International Compliance it is non-existent without extenuating circumstances - there’s a very “old guard” approach and long hours are expected just because that’s how investment banks have always been. There is a huge staff turnover currently due to a very poor atmosphere in the department, the problems are deep rooted. The politics is prolific.

headline: Dying bank

This is independent of how much money you make the bank, or what the reason is. This is a casualty of Barclays giving up on being a major investment bank, and shutting down major parts of the business.

HR was generally untrustworthy.

headline: Hamster Wheel
pros: Let me say this before I start...THIS IS A CALL CENTER. Like all call centers in the world. The pros are the benefits with this job. The benefits are a 401k, sick time, vacation, 2 call out days (just random call out days). They come in handy because...
cons: If you are on the unlucky end of working in the Relationship Manager position. Try as hard as you can to be promoted before they keep you in that position. Managers have a HIGH turn over rate like everyone else. Your manager can just NOT be your manager one day. Next would be the volume of calls. Very high volume call center. Credit card questions are easy to answer once you get the hang of it. But the volume burns you out really fast. A lot of the coworkers I have started with quit because of stress. Relationship Managers take ALL calls and everyday it seemed as if we had to learn a new module on taking MORE calls for the other departments in Barclays. As an entry level Relationship Manager you are taking Fraud, Dispute, and Credit when there is a department for each! But they start counting your transfer rate. So before you know it...you are a fraud, dispute, credit, escalations Manager but only at entry level taking 200 calls a day(and the number is an ACTUAL value). The mass of people that are hired get practically thrown on the floor and a large wave of mistakes happen. ALSO and most importantly, TENURE does not matter here. If you really want a career with Barclays you have to start making friends in different departments. The longer you stay at Barclays at an Entry Level the bigger the risk to be fired. There is absolutely No job security.

headline: Human Resources BP
pros: HR fundraising events, challenging work environment and culture of socializing outside of work
cons:
HR leadership team favors those from UK. Culture is very political and cut throat.  There are numerous change imitatives but very little progress in making systems work. All interesting projects and client groups are assigned to UK HR. There’s also a clear “in vs out” group in most teams. If you don’t mingle with the right people or form friendships, you hurt your career here regardless of how good an employee you are. 

Engagement scores for HR are the lowest compared to any other group 

Attrition for HR  in the NY office is very high. Leadership is also not stable so directions, goal and mission is never understood.

headline: Big Job - Little Salary
pros: The only good thing about working at this place was where it was located.
cons:
They make you work more than you get paid for. Senior management are on a power trip and I have never seen any company with such a bad salary bracket in every field.

I want to start off by saying, if you are going to apply for a job at Barclays then take my advice save yourself from working for a company who will pay you peanuts but expect you to work harder than the senior managers. 
Not only is Barclays really bad for giving you salary that is lower than ever other financial services out there, Resource Solutions are the worst for making it look as if its a good salary and they are doing you a favor. The staff at resource solutions will not even try to negotiate a better salary for you. Everybody within this organisation only thinks about themselves. I was working for Barclays for a short while but i noticed a lot, by talking to many of the staff within my department and other departments and nobody had anything positive to say about their job. I also witnessed senior managers prioritizing their friends and family to get jobs before other better qualified staff. 
Micromanagement is also very common, but it ok for managers to do what they want but when it comes to you they treat you like a child. 
Also, if you are Asian or from any other ethnic background, the interview process will be even harder for you than others, so your chances of getting a job here are even more slim.

headline: The whole place is a huge chaotic mess
pros:
Good hours,
Quarterly incentives,
Flexibility in terms of part time/full time and changing your hours or shifts.
cons:
- The pay is really terrible considering what you are expected to do in your role on a day to day basis.
- There is a constant shortage of staff in ALL the branches in the area I work in which means we are constantly struggling to manage work loads and customers which makes all of us much more stressed and unhappy than we need to be. Despite this, they refuse to hire more staff even though people are constantly leaving due to the highly stressful environment. The staffing crisis is huge at barclays right now.
- Management is BAD, they have 0 support to their staff during the day, they have 0 idea of what goes on in the branch on a day to day basis. All they care about are sales and numbers and performance but do absolutely nothing to motivate their staff  or identify problems with the working environment.
- Career advancement and progression is almost impossible. They are so desperate for staff that they will not let you move on from your role because they don't want to replace you and hire staff. Again they just care about numbers and do not care at all about your individual development and what you can offer to the company.

headline: Frustrating
pros: Known brand, access to training within Barclays, lots of data, encourage your development (e.g. paid study leaves, supporting qualification financially), nice office in London
cons:
You are limited in almost everything: terribly designed policies, overly protective (blocked access to data or useful functions e.g. in SAS), slow computers (20 mins to boot), old square monitors, cost cuttings on vital things (e.g. there is a hiring freeze so they can hit budget targets even tough your team really need extra people, not updating 10+ years old system as it can cost £100k), you need to count pennies you spent (e.g. don't buy open return tickets because it is expensive, sometimes pay for your work-related travel), outdated technologies (make you waste hours during your week).

In certain groups, you often end up working with less than smart colleagues and see quite questionable practices. Also, low expectation on work quality, poor decision making based on gut-feelings and within 5 minutes. Slow promotions.

headline: Good to have on your CV. Read the other reviews and make up your own mind...
pros:
- Great if you love close contact with customers. Most of them will be sincerely grateful when they perceive that you care about them and are trying to help them make the best choices. That is very fulfilling. 

- Decent company benefits and bonus. Nice quarterly and annual ones.

- Good chance to build a career within the company: if the company and job is for you, possibilities of growing are endless. There are plenty of roles, especially in the corporate field.
cons:
- The Moment Banker role is advertised as a purely customer service job but has a strong sales element to it. You will be told that what matters is giving the customer the opportunity and let them then make their own informed choice... but if they don't end up taking  the product you will then be pressured by the management because you done enough of this or that. You will essentially be measured according to hinted-at targets that you officially don't have and that you are not allowed to call by that name. There is no fixed number, but it will always be "more".
Officially the world "sales" is anathema and cannot be mentioned, either with customers or with higher-ups in the business,  but it will be constantly utilized in internal meetings, giving rise to a recurrent cognitive dissonance. 

- The branches I worked in were highly disorganized and there was a certain culture of leniency going on. People just didn't turn up, or they overslept and turned up late, or behaved in a very lazy, unprofessional and juvenile manner and were allowed to just get away with it. The worst they'd get is a slap on their wrist. 
On the other hand, hard-working people with strong values were constantly being monitored and picked up for the slightest inaccuracy. 

-Terrible IT infrastructure. Computers and systems very sluggish and constantly crashing. Sections are full of bugs that stay there for months and months. Designs are very much nonsensical and not user-friendly.

-Senior management severely lacking in many compartments. Colleagues who really cared about helping customers make the best choice were being pressured into leaving the job, colleagues with personal issues (sometimes as serious as mental health) were told to just "man up", openly threatened to be managed out of the job or bullied in staff meetings.... and this coming from a company that prides itself in values such as inclusiveness etc. etc.

Overall, something like 10 out of 16/17 members of staff were leaving or actively looking to leave the job/branch.

headline: Barclays
pros: The company is very big and offers a lot of opportunities for internal mobility. This gives you the ability to develop your knowledge across products and geographies. The company encourages dynamic working.
cons: Very slow to react to technology advancements, new data and new work tools. It is also changing almost constantly the org structure and the operating model. There are often decisions made in silos without thinking about the impact on other areas.

headline: Slow learning, political
pros: Salary is good, bonus comes on time if going is good.
cons: I was working in Barclaycard. Its a political setting - UK bosses favor people in the UK. Vendors can become your boss even though you are an employee - especially if the vendor is from UK. Things move very slowly - learning opportunities are less. You need to know how to talk polished english and talk big but deliver nothing. Because Barclays UK employees want to avoid work - if you are doer kind of person and deliver work they feel threatened about their job. If you are a doer kind of person this place is not for you. If you are meticulously delivering value, your boss will pretend not to understand it and will underestimate you, but yes he will speak sweetly with you as if he is on your side and understands everything.  Appraisal is flawed - if a UK vendor complains against you, despite your justifications it wont be considered just because you are India and he is UK.  Boss doesnt have visibility of your work and neither wants to try for getting visibility because he is lazy - so surprise alternative !!! -> you have to to beg your colleagues to give feedback, even if you know they lack any knowledge about your work, so its not smart appraisal and quite random. Then any negative comment is picked up from their feedback and focus is only on negatives and not on any positive. They will also put you in ImprovementNeeded as you are not aligned to them politically. Most of the time of afternoons is spent in meetings.  In Barclaycard, projects are planned to be delivered within 6 months these needlessly go on and on, there is a lot of needless polished english exchange in them - then big meetings are arranged to say with polished english taglines apologizing that this project is delayed by another 3 years. After 3 years also you deliver projects only partially - just think what will you tell in your next prospective employer about what you did in Barclays in all these 3-4 years!! Meanwhile frauds get committed continuously at higher levels, and those who are innocently working at India offshore have to waste time going through hours and hours of Barclays values trainings - while the top level goes scotfree and continue to commit frauds.

Work is given but seats are not, on asking your manager tells you to manage somehow share desk with peers. I feel most of the good reviews are fake. Your manager simply walks on to your desk and starts shouting out of no reason.  You would hardly hear anyone speak in English mostly hindi or regiional language if you are in mahrashtra even in meetings. It is just  a high paying TCS job. You are forced to come on weekends even without work just to impress senior management.

headline: “Cover-ups,  bullying,  harassment,  managers are threatening if you challenge them”
pros: Good if you just need a job to make ends meet
cons:
- we offered mortgages to costumers however our pay is so low in retail banking that we cannot get one ourselves.   Shameful. 

- managers take offence if you ask them to help out in banking hall even though their job description clearly states they need to actively pitch in. They turn up just for tick in box for ten minutes a day in certain flagship branches in west London.   In fact they bark back saying “you should work smarter so you don’t need extra help”

- I complained about a member of staff who verbally and physically abused me-and when I went to manager to complain- the managers answer was “oh no please.  Not today.  We have the hot shot directors coming down today...... we can’t afford any issues today”

- a lot of managers are power hungry and can and will pull up staff for not smiling in morning meetings.   It’s insane.   Iv seen someone get ticked off for not looking interested because she wasn’t smiling for no reason in morning group meeting.   The managers feel they can pick on people for sake of it 

- it can be very demoralising and depressing working in an environment where manager have petty mentality.   For example being barked at by counter manager for doing something she does and her pals at work.  But if someone they don’t like do it- they will shout at you and when you complain to branch managers........ they brush it under carpet and tell you to grow up and not take offence. 

HOW CAN ANYBODY BE EXPECTED TO WORK IN A PLACE WHERE YOUR TOLD OFF FOR TAKING OFFENCE WHEN THINGS ARE THROWN AT YOU AND YOU FEEL VICTIMISED.  

Awful demoralising culture.   

Iv seen managers watching someone laugh, then managers will say “have you not got any work to do?”

There’s a culture of not wanting people to be happy.  They want everyone as miserable as they are themselves.  


Iv seen managers sit in banking hall and gossip with their mothers who pop in during their shopping trip.   Iv seen manager play with her kid in banking hall (which managers mother brings in during shopping trip) whilst the bank is full of customers - 

But god forbid that anyone of the cashiers laugh or talk amongst one another in banking hall......   they get a ticking off by manager for not being professional.  

Hypocrisy.   
That’s why I left and I’m now working as a manager in another financial institute and I’m more happy and more healthy emotionally.

headline: Currently lacking strategic direction
pros:
A steady employer with some very loyal staff
Lots of good sound knowledge of banking around the business. Geographically well placed branches and currently a good breadth of head office locations to pull in that good balance of staff.
cons: It’s been a stable employer of mine for some time and I always believed that if you cut me I’d bleed blue. However the last few years have seen more work with less people with less direction coming from above. It’s in danger of pushing its loyal staff to the edge and a bank needs people with a good understanding of the industry and customer needs. balanced and mixed in with innovation. Needs to be brave and advertise what it is - a Bank! We need to show customers we have strong propositions, a good and trusted branch network that is not obsessed with digitising to the point it’s frightening the less digitally savvy customers away. Let’s serve the customers and be a go to bank....

headline: Barclays Mortgages
pros: Flexi time available within limits.
cons:
- A culture of putting costs above everything else, including customers. 
- Ancient systems that badly need dragging into the 21st century, unfortunately because this will cost money it's unlikely to happen. Consequently; people who have been working in the business for years have unique knowledge of these systems. Once they eventually leave there is no one else who has the relevant knowledge; leaving mission critical processes in the lurch.
- Upper middle management and senior management unwilling to listen to feedback and warnings of the above. They feel like this is only a stepping stone onto bigger and brighter things, so they don't want to get too invested before yet another director takes over. 
- Some managers have set up their own little fiefdoms and will do everything within their power to keep it that way. 
- Everything is in a silo and not much in the way of cross overs between different teams.

headline: Mixed bag
pros: Many of the people from the Lehman-era are still here and are amazing to work with. Midtown NYC location.
cons: Some of the OG dinosaurs from Barclays need to be let go. Work/life balance is non-existent — it’s showcased but rarely ever carried out as it is manager dependent. Lots of red tape and no clear cut path to promotion. Lays offs every few months or near-sourcing to the middle of NJ.

headline: Real Life at Barclays - I Quit
pros:
1) Good health care benefits 
2) Looks good on your resume
3) Gym and Clinic in the building
4) Good technology 
5) Very demanding and competitive but you will learn a lot. Stressful; however, it builds create tolerance for stressful and challenging environment.
cons:
- Favoritism is king also a lot of harassment 
- Depending on the department crap salary (mediocre bonus)
- Women make significantly less than men.  I know this from years at Barclays and speaking to colleagues)
- Very long hours. 
- Power struggles within senior management 
- No room for mistakes. 
- Extremely hard to get promoted 
- Little to no support for internal moves
- Your social media will be checked (this is common sense)
- Horrible HR. Do not ever make the mistake of thinking anything you say is confidential

headline: Have some self respect and don't bother.
pros: Some good, hard working, decent people but they'll never get anywhere in the business as they are too busy working instead of brown nosing.
cons: Expect to be spoken to like a small child and backstabbed by power tripping management. Not one of them in that office has the slightest clue what they are doing nor the relevant experience or qualifications, all talk and no walk. Managers forgot where they came from, which most of the time was fresh out of school and into a minimum wage job for the next 10 years. Everything is rushed and ALWAYS goes wrong and needs fixing. Managers seem to have a very high opinion of themselves which is funny really 'cos you're more likely to get promoted by sexual favours than actually working.  Computer systems are a disgrace. No on site computing specialist. Air conditioning broken for years, no clean air, roasting hot or freezing cold. People really do not matter there. Have a good idea? Keep it to yourself 'cos if the managers see you as a threat to their chance of promotion they will screw you over in a flash, which includes stealing your ideas and/or manipulating your yearly review. If you don't like it you will 'easily' be replaced. Intelligent, good workers are left to rot when people are getting promoted through butt kissing and bribery and who can make the boss laugh the most. The salary is dire and years behind other retail banks. Sexist in relation to all promotion of females while the males get ignored. Utterly disgusting treatment of staff, particularly those with disabilities and/or health problems.  Childish culture, much like school, in the remedial class. Management couldn't give a toss about your work/life balance. The 'Barclays Values' are promoted but the exact opposite is actually what occurs! Undisciplined and disorganized staff and processes. Worst place I have ever worked and I've been around a bit!

headline: After 2.5 years with the company I’ve learnt a lot but have also seen a decline in the way employees are treated.
pros:
You will learn a lot in a very short space of time, with intelligent and helpful colleagues as well as a lot of challenges hitting the industry. 

Flexible working is also strongly sponsored, however in many ways this has become forced as a cost cutting exercise, at which point I question whether it is truly being done for the benefit of the employee.
cons:
Despite a “pro internal mobility” culture, there has been a hiring freeze for 50% of my 2.5 years here which limits career progression. There have also been significant cuts to former staff perks, e.g.
- employees required to work dynamically 2 days a week
- little/no budget for staff socialisation (self funded Christmas party)

The organisation is also incredibly bureaucratic, with many of the processes being followed not following appropriate lean/agile methodologies.

headline: Good depending on team
pros:
- Good salary, specially if you do overtime.
- Good work environment (depending on the team).
- It is easy to outperform peers if you put in the work. Many people are smart and good professionals but lack the motivation to put in the effort.

I was happy in my time in Barclays, moved on to role elsewhere.
cons:
- No training
- Some IT service operation teams are a joke (Unix, AD, Windows Server specially). Others such as SQL and Networks are pretty good.
- Some managers do quite a bit of micro managing attempting to climb the corporate ladder on your back. It is very obvious. 
- CEO lacks focus, has taken decisions which proved to be wrong, specially with regards to non-core disinvestment.

headline: Not a bad company to work for if you can navigate its complexity

cons:
-Recruitment process took 4 months

Salaries and bonus are not good and below the job market (if you compare to other big names or other Barclays subsidiaries) ; even corporate titles are not in line with experience or responsibilities. Everything is done to give the bank a good image locally but atmosphere at work is below average for employees and no employment security. No particular advantages to work in a bank (no bank accounts, bad loan conditions, allocations, ....). A lot of actual employees would consider another opportunity in a competitor.

headline: ZERO BONUS AND HIKE
pros: free membership of pluralsight .
cons:
I have been working in API Team since last few months now n overall for 3years. 
1) we are forced to come on weekends and on top of that we are not given any compensation.
2) NO HIKE AND BONUS this financial year, not just me but many of my colleagues.
4) Boot licking and politics is encouraged.
5) MD walks in and bashes us all in very unprofessional and rude manner as if we are dogs.
6) The requirement list changes every other day and you keep refactoring and updating your code. Too much chaos and mismanagement.
7) No Onsite at all! 
8) Salary structure is such that you get nothing but peanuts at the end of financial year.
Before you join, ask which team they are hiring you for. BarclayCard is pathetic. Not sure about others.

headline: Government job (in a bad way)
pros:
Policies are quite good. 
Cultural activities and values are given respect.
Great for open minded people who believe in equal opportunity.
You are encouraged to grow but only on paper.
cons:
I was hired as a developer but I'm doing development work for only about 5% of my time. Rest is all taked up by management and bureaucracy.
This feels like a government job. 1 day's work takes 1 month here. I mean 1 month to fix a bad sql query!!
There is no knowledge transfer at all, so if you are unfamiliar with their business logic and kind of systems they use then you are left on your own. You have to fight and beg for little information.
Secondly there is no clear HR policies and helpline. I'm here for more than 8 months yet to meet any hr personnel (haven't even met my recruiter, only phone), somethings can't be dealt with via a online form. No proper way to submit tax claims or get more information about policies.
Everything is slow. 
They use outdated technologies. But are trying to improve though.
There are no onsite opportunities.
I wont recommend to anyone who is hungry to work and learn new things. Also their code quality is not up to snuff so wont recommend it to a fresher as they will learn bad practices.

headline: Depressing
pros: I actually can't think of anything that good.
cons: Stressful job, management are stressed, the world is expected from everyone but the real basics are not provided. Many humiliating experiences in branch where either a process or a service is screwed up because of half-assed technology or stupid out-of-date postal or fax system or just completely broken new software. IT problems don't get fixed in this company any more, they just sit there forever hoping they might become more of a priority at some date in the future. Nobody above cares about you in this job, thank god for the other poor humans who work with me. I'd have had a breakdown if it wasn't for them.

headline: Bureaucratic, Political, Distracted Organization. No focus on sustainable revenues
pros: After the Libor scandal, at least there was a realization that poor talent with dubious ethical standards had been long tolerated and at times promoted. Great place to hang on with a stable paycheck if you can show you are performing 'citizenship' activities, irrespective of your actual contribution at work.
cons: Post-LIBOR promotion of values was a good PR campaign branding exercise but not much has changed. In fact, the bank has veered off to a misguided path where real innovation is stifled under several layers of bureaucratic red tape. Really talented employees are made to fill out paper work with the implicit understanding that the more paper work they fill out, the better they are likely to be compensated. Meanwhile, management has severely dented technological capability and innovation by under-investing and reducing headcount in any function or department remotely linked to technology.

1. Promised Green Card when joining the firm. After getting in, was told to wait until end of first year. At the end of first year, was told the policy changed need to wait until end of second year. At the end of second year, was told that because our department was moved from front desk to risk, need to wait until end of third year. What???
2. After resignation, repayment was asked without HR looking thru the whole case. Once complained, was forwarded to three different department/people none of whom ever look thru the whole case.
3. Incapable manager had to hire a pushy bossy project manager who has little respect for knowledge and effort. Asked in front of everyone if you still want a job.

headline: I guess we're still bulge bracket
pros: I actually do like what I do and like the people that I work with for the most part.  I think that the investment bank is generally decent at getting people exposure and experience, and giving people rotations, etc. It's obviously different team to team, but they do give people a chance to grow, step up, and advance their careers.
cons:
The direction of the company and lack of coordination among various levels of management / silos look like a chicken running around with its head cut off. 

The leadership in the investment bank has great ambitious, but then when it comes to actually implementing those ambitious, the bank completely hamstrings itself because IB management isn't actually coordinated between products, sectors, etc., or between IBD and markets, or between the IB management and Risk, or the Investment Bank and Wealth or Group, etc. 

The IT situation also feels pretty grim, but you hear everyone complain about. 

There seems to also be a trend of "upward delegation" with some levels of management passing the buck upwards when they don't want to make a decision or a call.

headline: Forward thinking friendly organisations.
pros: Great pension. Forwarding thinking and really does invest in the future. Everyone is very friendly including senior staff who are very approachable.
cons: Bonus payments are not good. There is a lot of red fake internally and the non-client floor facilities are not great. Trying to sort out I.T. Issues is difficult as is anything HR related.

headline: Take, take, take
pros: Unique opportunities. If you are lucky enough to get a manager who trusts you you can get own with and really own your work allowing you to punch well above your weight. However that is dependent on the manager as opposed to the culture of the organisation.
cons: Institutionalised directors have a tendency to favour promoting those that have been there the longest rather than those who can do the job well. Pay is atrocious, yet they will juice you for everything you have - expect to do the work of someone who is at least the level above you but don’t expect the benefits that come with it. Some have been known to gaslight career progression. Very open display of favouritism. Directors will not reach out to you to welcome you or talk to you.  Changes in the way they review staff means you will almost never have the chance to hit the top rung, even if you are perceived as one of the strongest members of the team. Great set of values - on paper alone.

headline: Excellent management who really cares about your well-being as an employee.
pros: There is no micro-managing in the investment banking world which allows for a stress free environment. We have schedules of course, but we all put in our time and get the job done to the best of our ability so there are no small issues involving time management.
cons: It is very difficult to advance unless a member of senior management decides to step down. We have 2 managers and the rest are analysts and the only time employees advance is if they leave the department or seek other employment opportunities.

headline: Excellent management who really cares about your well-being as an employee.

headline: Resourcing Business Partner
pros: Barclays is a company that is focused on keeping up with the evolving world - that pace is really fast, so with this comes lots of change, it's interesting, diverse, and it's challenging.  There's always a project you can get involve with, so great to broaden your skill set and experience.  Internal mobility is very successful.
cons: It's a very big company and the pace of change is not for everyone.  It can be stressful so you need to take accountability on where you are at with that and ask for help when you need it.  Not all managers are good at helping there staff through this.  You need to voice and self promote (not necessarily a con but something to be aware of.  It's a big company so experience varies greatly based on the team your in.

headline: If you are early in your career, go somewhere else if possible
pros: Great work and life balance because there is not much work, reason see below.
cons:
Barclays has a culture that doesn't  care about personal growth and employee happiness.  The entire management is plagued with such culture.  The upper management cares about themselves than anything else. Fun fact,  in one of the townhalls CEO came to stage and talked how recent Barclays stock plummet made him lost millions of dollars and vowed to bring the stock back to where it should be. 99.9% of people down there didn't give a **** because they have zero ownership about Barclays.

The end result is the bottom level  of the company structure is filled with incompetent people content with pay and work (or not work for the matter of fact). Everything moves at glacier pace with layers of bureaucracy. 

If you are in early of your career, regardless of your job (trader, IBD, developer, operations), and you want to learn and achieve something, Barclays is not the place for you.

headline: Dead-end Job. Thank God I'm out!
pros: Great interview process where Barclays spend a lot of money wining and dining prospective applicants during their assessment centres. Once you've joined Barclays, there are many quality events and socials and decent orientation/ training. Good pay compared with competitors for graduate/ entry level roles. Great Canary Wharf headquarters.
cons: Not very bright people/ colleagues, with many from polytechnic (or similar standard) universities. Very hierarchical management where creativity is stifled. And finally the role was an absolute dead-end job. Don't get into Operations (or Technology or any Back office role for that matter), as you do a lot of menial tasks for average pay with no future career prospects (other than to continue working Back Office).

headline: Barclays India- Officially soon to become "ServCo" a service company like TechM & Infy:Don't plan to join, save yourself
pros:
1. Employee friendly policies (few for now and which are soon going to be changed )
2. Infrastructure
cons:
A. Location & traffic
B. Biased higher management
C. Agile has been implemented as a joke
D. Bunch of jokers who take most of the high level decisions
E. Lay offs  - not a secured job
F. Policies which soon going to be implemented as "ServCo" organization -
1. Strictly formals
2. Strictly 9 hrs flash in flash outs
3. Reduced number of leaves and holidays
