headline: Amazing company with great potential for a great career!
pros:
- Great team.
- Great opportunities for personal and career development.
- Varied day to day working. Many different areas in which you are trained on.
- Really great fast paced environment.
- Great benefits as a full time member of staff which make the staff feel valued such as performance related bonus.
- Really enjoyable place to work once you are trained, as there is a lot of knowledge to learn and job fulfilment. 
- A great job for someone who really enjoys making a difference.
- Some of the more senior staff are really supportive.
- Great company ethics concerning female empowerment and morals. A really supportive company for women who want to further their career goals. 
- Great culture day to day with management support if a customer is particularly difficult which is a great aspect of management.
cons:
- Often lots of customer pressure based on you if you are in the banking hall as you are often the first point of call.
- Left feeling overwhelmed and untrained at the beginning of the job - training should be longer and more in-depth. The online training does not prepare you for the job as much as it should and there should be longer practical training to enable best customer service.
- As a temp, there were no benefits including no sick pay or holiday pay.
- Management often place lots of pressure on the front of house staff off the back of MPS customer service calls. We are often told conflicting ideas to approach customer service i.e. We must man Zone A (meet&greet zone) then told after customers say we aren't helping enough to not man Zone A. Told to encourage customers to use Assisted Service Counters, but often getting feedback that as customer service providers we are too pushy/intrusive. The zonal system does not work and needs to be reworked by people who have actually been party to the first line of defence within customer service as they have the best idea of day to day service and know how there banking hall works best.
- MPS system for customer feedback is poor as the questions are open ended and long which results in discrepancies between MPS calls due to differential customer opinion on good customer service. Essential bankers often facing the brunt of this and not getting their good work recognised.
- Management are not pro-active enough and do not show banking hall presence - often showing a begrudging attitude to being asked to cover the banking hall-  therefore it is often condescending to staff to be told how to improve their service as management do not know the day to day running of the banking hall and thus can not devise plans. 
- All staff should be trained on all aspects of the business before progressing as often it leaves the banking hall short as people can not cover the counter and therefore leaves people alone in the banking hall - which is not only dangerous in case of emergency but also reflects poorly on customer service.
- Some staff are on old contracts which is unfair to other members of staff. Staff often got to leave early or not work saturdays because of their old contract - this should be updated to ensure there are enough staff provisions for the whole day - not only part of the day as it forces pressure on the staff who complete the whole day. 
- Management encourage competition between staff which creates an uneasy atmosphere. Praise is often not given on merit - as managers often have their favourites (which is not unique to barclays but should nevertheless be worked upon to ensure all staff feel satisfaction within their job.) Cohesiveness of the team would also improve alongside a healthier working environment if this was fixed and looked at.
- Technology at Barclays is among the best within the banking sector, however often it fails which is not only embarrassing but also reflects poorly on customer service. Barclays should enable all technology is piloted and works well before rolling it out in to all their branches. For example the Kiosk and its software& privacy must be looked at and improved upon to improve customer service. Counter software should be updated and easier to use. iPad's should be able to action prompts and the software should be improved to ensure it doesn't time out constantly which results in poor customer service as often staff take customers out of the counter queue to help them but due to technological error have to place the customer back in to the queue.
-Marketing also needs to be improved upon. Often posters are released with poor wording regarding branch closure or hour reduction which results in unhappy customers. Again, essential bankers face the brunt of this. Marketing should ask essential bankers their opinions or create a poll in some instances - or even take someone on who has had front line experience because the company would benefit from correct wording and knowledge of someone who has dealt with customers on a day to day business.

headline: Retail team
pros: Great benefits package, shares, pension etc
cons:
Bullying in the workplace by senior. Extremely low moral between staff members who are made to feel inadequate and don’t know which branch they will be working at from one day to the next. Staff never given positive feedback (take a look at the personal development reviews). Bad management with no people skills. Nasty comments made about members of team in front of other sections of workforce. Passive aggressive tactics displayed by branch manager. 
Can not get holidays during school time unless booked at 9am 18 months prior to time off and even then you probably wouldn’t get it agreed. 
High level of staff turnover due to lack of moral and lack of positive management strategies. Very sad state of affairs. People afraid of reprocussions if they want to raise issues.

headline: Finance  - ok place to work but very top heavy and serious lack of progression
pros:
CV
good place to work temporarily to understand what you don't want and how a large organization works despite having robust reporting.
A lot of learning opportunities however the politics are a hinderance with a very strong blame culture.
Pay reasonably good however being squeezed for new recruits due to stagnant external market.
cons:
High attrition in finance roles with Head Office driving a lot of the chaos due to a lack of understanding of the business issues. 
Finance is very top heavy (MDs/ Directors) and now you have highly competent AVPs and VPs leaving out of frustration as the senior managers hold on to their roles in desperation. 
Lack of progression due to a number of average talented people who have been at the bank for a while blocking the way.
Anyone who has been there more than 3/4 years seems to miss the good old days and more of a hinderance to progress as it will mean more work for them.
HR is very switched off.. and do not help or provide any guidance.
Culture and Values are non existant as the CEO's own integrity has been questioned re:whistle blowing.
Bonuses are used to align total comp and not performance.

Please note this is only the case in a couple departments, many departments i know of have none of these issues.

headline: Career Graveyard
pros:
I’ve been working at the Barclays Investment Bank for 8 years now. There’s been a lot of changes over these years but these have only been gradual. As Barclays continues in its slow death-spiral into irrelevance it’s becoming harder to justify working here.

Work Life Balance - you can "work from home" most days of the week because the Bank is saving money on office space. Sure, you can be sucked into working 18 hours a day but you'll quickly realise this is pointless (more on that below) and end up doing the 9 to 5 like a normal person. You’ll probably have to work a weekend every month though (no overtime paid).

People – the ones that are left are clever, talented and, above all, human (if a little bitter) and have a wealth of experience that you can learn from. Because most of the employees have given up there is an atmosphere of capitulation that makes for a day full of acerbic jokes and swearing.
cons:
Career Progression – there are no promotions by design. The HR rules mean that you can’t be promoted in the same role. You have to move department to get a higher grade. The side-effect of this is, of course, that there is no incentive to do well in your current role. And as you’re not learning anything new you end up just doing the minimum and do the 9 to 5. You can only become more specialised sitting in your current role and therefore even less employable by another department.

Office – because of the cost-saving you don’t get your own desk so your first hour every day is spent trying to get the desktop and monitors to work. You’re packed in there like angry chickens. That’s fine if you like close body contact but bad news if you’ve got a noisy or smelly neighbour. 

IT Infrastructure - this is decades behind the real world and programmers spend most of their time trying to keep creaking servers running. You’re not going to be working on any new technologies for sure. As teams have been fired their systems have stopped working. Sometimes this can be a good thing – there is no database for tracking holidays so it’s a free-for-all. On the other hand, you’re going to have to pay for getting company emails and conference calls outside of the office.

Management and Culture –the current atmosphere of anarchy is amusing but doesn’t help the less aggressive employee. The only attempt at fostering a company culture is the occasional “newsletter” from the senior management. It’s filled with fake good news so, yeah, thanks for that but I can read the press about the latest fine we’ve been slapped with because of some board members’ behaviour. It’s so anodyne that both the person sending it and the person reading it thinks the other is an idiot. I realise that managers are restricted in what they can do (there are no promotions allowed, after all) but the failure to engage with their employees is either cowardice or contempt.

headline: Too much work place politics
pros: Its really hard to find one, My only Pro is its a job.
cons:
You are under paid and over worked.
Your expected to get to work Half an hour to an hour before you start getting paid, to which you can not claim over time then you are expected to not request over time for the first 20 mins after your hours. Try to discise selling with 'Helping Customers'. You are repeatedly told we are a business and expected to have a percentage of helping customers each day/week/month. You are expected to be self sufficient with reduced staff and more work. When mamagement makes an error or has a go they can say they are tired. When you are an EB and you do the same and you are informed your behaviours arent inline with thwur standards. You will be told progression is often and fair, not true.

headline: Delay Process in Full and Final and Experience Letter
pros: Good Salary, bonus is not part of salary.
cons:
Very bad HR team. My last day of working with Barclays was 2nd August 2017. Today its 25th Sep 2017, even after 53th days I have not received my Full and final and experience letter. I have dropped several mails to HR team, I had at-least 10 calls in these 53 days but what I got is just a promise that after 1/2 weeks we will do settlement.

I don't understand why Barclays is not able to provide experience letter even after 53 days.

headline: Don't do it. You have been warned. No Excuse. Better to work at Target or Pizza Hut. Run away as fast as you can.
pros: Nice people. People tried to do their best.
cons: It is what it is.. The repetition of the scripts will drive you insane.   You want to help the customer, but you can't unless they say the magic words.  The Customers will treat you like a pinata. I had one customer call and curse at me because we sent him an email that his payment was under the minimum amount.  Think about that...he took the time and effort out of his day to call and curse at a stranger because a computer generated email was sent to him so he wouldn't be charged a late fee.  Some Managers were just lazy and unhelpful. Saying "look in the P&Ps" is not helpful and makes you look like a joke.  Not just at Barclaycard, but Call Centers in general... you will be treated like child.  You will be fired if you have to many sick days, late to work, Dr. appointments, etc.  (Occurrences).

headline: Investment Bank: Big Review
pros:
I wrote a review just over 2 years ago and I'm still here at Barclays Investment bank – on the whole it's a good place to work. Unfortunately due to lack of career opportunities I feel it's time to leave but decided to write this review so others can learn from my experience over the past 3 years working at Barclays.

First of all, it's a big bank. A lot of your experience will be determined by those around you rather than the company as a whole. Also, the banking group led by CEO Jes Staley is actually made up of smaller parts – as of 2017 it’s essentially two major legs:

Barclays UK
-	The retail bank (typical high street stuff), 
-	Barclaycard (UK only)
-	UK wealth business (rich clients)
-	Corporate banking (small and medium firm finance)

Barclays International
-	Corporate banking (large global firm financing)
-	Investment bank (trading global markets)
-	Barclaycard (outside UK)

These two legs (designed to ring-fence risky stuff away from conventional banking) are both supported by a service company, Barclays Services Limited. The service company is where all the non-revenue generating parts such as IT and other operational back office teams are (they share the same resources); this company supports both the UK and International legs. Each bullet point is a separate company so it’s a very big group. Barclays predominantly focuses on the UK and US markets, clients and firms. Someone working in the retail bank will experience a totally different career to those in the investment bank -there are pros and cons for each of them.
--------------------------------------------------------------

I work in the investment bank middle office (supporting front office – sales and traders).

Jes Staley, CEO. He knows what he is doing, comes across as humble and has sensible plans. Jes makes sure his ‘generals’ carry out what needs to be done, especially around restructuring Barclays for the future (thankfully a lot of big changes are now done). Totally agree with Jes about the need to have a diverse set of people to work with (i.e. no old boy clubs) and the need to have better technology; he understands the bank today is actually a tech firm and IT is not a cost center – it is the bank. Also emphasizes that Barclays has a role to play in society and the greedy self serving banker has to be stopped (not too sure how this works with him taking such a large salary though…)

The brand. It looks good on your CV.

Learn on the job. You don’t need to be up to your eye balls in fancy qualifications to do most of the jobs. Studying finance helps but honestly, it’s not something that everyone needs as the roles across the teams are so varied you have to just have a good attitude and work hard to get it. Like I said – most a just well paid grunts with easily transferable skills to other offices in any industry.

Diversity. People don’t care about your background, ethnicity or anything like that – it’s what you bring to the table and your ability to do your job. We have people fresh from school, 18 years old on apprenticeships and those that have PhD maths doing some very clever stuff.

Work Hours. The culture of “lunch is for wimps” is long gone and working hours are pretty good. No one frowns at you for going to lunch or leaving on time, although most stay beyond their contracted hours to finish the job. A big cultural shift from the days before the 2008 crash. Also everyone is being encouraged to work from home occasionally as this saves desk space (in turn saving the bank money from building costs, etc)

The People. On the whole they are a nice bunch of people to work with. They are always busy but are approachable; I can’t recall anyone saying “avoid so and so because you’ll get shouted at”. Everyone is down to earth and very hard working (except a few management types). Some people here are very smart with PhDs and other big qualifications – don’t worry though as not every role needs a rocket scientist.

Work Environment. It’s quite good to be fair – you get multiple monitors, virtual desktops, access to a lot of software. Some of the systems are old but they are looking to update them over time (will take years). Realistically it’s doing alright though – haven’t quite got to everyone using touch screens but it’s not ancient (Win 7 or Win 10). Nice open plan office area, canteen, meeting rooms, etc but certainly not like Google (unfortunately).
cons:
Okay, so now you know the scale of the firm it’s become apparent that it is very hard to climb the corporate ladder. Each company such as the investment bank has its own large hierarchy with thousands of people working for it; due to the numbers involved it is often the case of not what you do but rather who you know which will allow you to progress. You can get someone incredibly talented at analyst level (bottom rank) but will never get chance to move up and really shine due to the odds against them – this means that good people leave as they aren’t progressing as quickly as could have been or they get bored and want new work. Based on what I’ve seen people usually leave the firm after 2-3 years (sometimes just after 1 year) at lower levels as it dawns on them that you are playing a numbers game. 

Politics. Okay, I’ve yet to work for any company where people don’t play politics; it’s a fact of life. Unfortunately I feel that those that have made it to pretty good positions (VP, Director level) are reluctant to do good job and end up falling into the politics game. I hear very senior people saying “work together as one company” but in reality in each team managers are playing politics and looking after their own interests. No one from very high up ever visits the ‘ground troops’ and so they are out of touch of what it’s like back on the floor (I assume they are always in important meetings being told everything is fine).

Pay and bonuses. I said this a few years ago and it’s still the same – unless you are one of the lucky few forget about being handed a cheque with a long number on it. Those days are well and truly over. Sure, some lucky senior people will get a big reward but most of us are just well paid grunts. Speaking of which the pay is good (not amazing), however when you work it out per hour it’s honestly not above and beyond any other place. My contract states my working hours are 9-5. Every day I work 08:30 – 17:30, which is alright (it used to be a lot worse 3 years ago!). I don’t get rewarded for all those extra hours though so it makes my bonus almost insulting each year. Every year people go into “the room” expecting to be told you’ve just got a big fat pay check and every year you get told “here is your 2% pay rise and £1,000 bonus”. Grateful for it but believe the media hype of millionaire lifestyles.

Annual reviews. Seriously – there isn’t any point if I’m honest. There isn’t a structured career path for most to take. It’s like most jobs – take your seat, work hard based on your role, think outside the box by making stuff better and learn some things along the way. There isn’t anything I’m aware of where they have a structured career path, despite HR making out there is such a thing. My manager is woeful at best; it’s like taking career advice from a fast food manager with politics thrown into the mix.

Leadership. Same as everywhere else I’ve been. Lots of managers but not natural leaders. A lot of managers are not real leaders, despite what they view themselves as; happy to delegate and be the chief getting paid the most but somehow avoid listening to concerns, helping nurture talent, provide knowledge to those below, working with other teams. Usually a case of “I’m in charge do what I say” rather than “I have something to teach”.

Pigeon Holed. People feel like they are stuck in certain roles and are not given the chance to move. For example those in middle office have a huge barrier to those working in front office. A complete “us and them” attitude – both don’t know what is really involved by either side. The front office see everyone else as a cost and waste of time; the middle office see sales and trading as people making constant mistakes and not appreciating what we do for them (nothing would go through unless other teams are there supporting the money makers).

You made it! Now you can read about that dreaded one star rating that makes you question if the whole company is rotten to the core (it’s not; it’s down to who you end up working with, promise). :)

pros: The Good ~ Barclayacard US has solid benefits. Work life balance is good but that depends on who you work for.  Nobody is being treated the same.  See concerns about HR.
cons:
The Bad ~  The Barclaycard US IT department is being forced into the Global Support model.  The Global model has more holes then a screen door.   Conform to Global standards and embrace the suck!  How does and IT organization ever progress when the foundational Leadership Team changes almost monthly?  Answer it doesn't.  Be prepared to change direction more then a Uber Driver if you work in IT.  

The Ugly~ Lots to list here but will stick to the main pain points.  If you identify as a Transgender you have a free pass to sit at your desk and do nothing all day,  play video games, watch TV, you will never get fired.  This might be a pro to some but it's a major distractor and demotivator  to those who come to work to work.  

There are almost to the point of suffocation a zillion different culture and diversity events.   Be prepared to shake your head at how this organization focuses so much time and energy on this while critical functions are neglected.   Be prepared to feel left completely out if you a white middle class American.   Speaking of which I actually heard a management level person say we don't want grumpy old white people here.  What a disgrace!   Why didn't I report this to HR?

The local Wilmington HR team is worthless!!!! Again worthless!  They protect people who don't do their jobs and scold line managers who are trying to weed out the paycheck stealers.  Follow the guidelines they say?  Since when is sleeping, watching sporting events at ones desk acceptable behavior during work.  Are you effn kidding me?  

The local HR team does their best work across the street at the local watering hole.  Absolutely the worst HR / Recruting teams I have ever felt with.

headline: Good place for college grads and to stay invested for 5 years
pros:
1. Good working environment
2. Less work pressure, hence employees can complete additional studies
3.  Lot of flexibility for women employees
4. Learning opportunities depends on team and regional stakeholders
5. Good place for seasoned  employees wherein they can have good work life balance
6. Good brand to start with for college grads
cons:
1. Would not recommend prospective employees to stay beyond 5 years (at max).
2. Less scope for learning as things move very slow (compare it with any Indian PSU).
3. Quality of work done out of Mumbai location is not at par with other IB's such as MS, CS & DB.
4. Pay is sub par to the extent that even Nomura pays better than Barclays.
5. Nepotism is visibly present. IITians are praised and taken care like god.

headline: Very hard to progress your career
pros:
- If you get the right manager who's trustworthy then you can learn and develop a lot.

- People are generally friendly and most know what they are taking about in terms of their expertise.
cons:
- People management skills of managers vary a lot. I've been very lucky to have had a great manager, but than due to a restructure was my worse experience in my whole career, and you have to look out for some manager's favoritism to the point whereby it's detrimental to your own career.

- Paid little vs. other banks and even other sectors, but constantly told by HR salaries benchmark well. So often feel underpaid and not recognised.

- Extremely hard to progress and develop. Experience and eagerness doesn't mean much, it's more on if you walk the walk and talk the talk.

- Like most huge corporations, be careful who you trust. And document everything to back yourself up.

headline: Vice President at Barclays London
pros: Good work/life balance with working form home and dynamic hours actively encouraged. Staff are nice people and respectful to each other. The push to ingrain the 5 values has had a positive impact.
cons: Below average pay for industry with the lack of financial success used as the justification, whether or not it had anything to do with you. The IT systems are poor following a prolonged period of under investment, although this is gradually improving. There is a suffocating level of bureaucracy, with whole cottage industries producing little of value for the firm except headcount problems. Senior management are often out of their depth and excessively deferential to regulators. Whilst staff may be individually pleasant there is frequent avoidance of responsibility, 'not my problem' is a phrase you will hear day in day out.

headline: No good quality work after joining, and being harassed after leaving employment
pros: Did not see many positives out here.
cons: I was recruited as an Assistant Vice President in Barclays shared services in Mumbai. The jobs given to me after joining were not in line with those outlined during interviews and were not at all relevant to my profile. After many conversations with management, I finally resigned . My notice period was 3 months. However, I had asked for an early relieving of 1 month after resignation date. My manager agreed to reduce notice period by 1 month only and HR issued a letter to me that my contractual end date and last working day would be 2 months after my resignation date.  since I did not have much responsibilities at work, I approached the MD for early reliving. He agreed to cut my notice period to 1 month after resignation date. In accordance with this, HR issued another letter to me stating my last day of working and last day of employment both to be 1 month after resignation date. I served till this date, completed all exit formalities and left. Now, HR has sent me FNF in which they are asking me to pay 2 months notice pay , have withheld my final salary and not giving releiving letter after repeated reminders.. this is how I'm being harassed further even after leaving the employment . Looks like Barclays can only boast abt it's values but not live upto it..

headline: Community Banking
pros: Good benefit package comprising pension scheme, private medical insurance, annual and quarterly bonuses. Great experience on your CV,  recognised brand. Good mobility options, very flexible with working hours for students and parents.
cons: Salary below average for entry-level positions, retail branches constantly understaffed, high personnel turnover.

headline: VP
pros: Job Security, brand name - long standing institution. Good clients
cons: Poor quality of leadership/management.  No consistent business strategy - managers/leaders cannot clearly articulate the business vision or strategy.  Lack of accountability from senior management - they do not clearly communicate how they've delivered or failed against their objectives.  Extremely political culture - you will do well if you become your manager's favourite in terms of bonus & performance.  Values are stated but not practised or adhered to - managers at all levels especially at MD levels fail to be a role model.  It appears MD's and D's aren't  held accountable by senior management to deliver on their objectives - deadlines and timlines are constantly pushed out - there is minor consequence if you don't deliver on time. Lower grade employees aren't always respected by senior management.  There is a real issue at line manager levels across the organisation. Culture promotes mediocracy.

headline: Still enjoying my time here
pros:
People are great and genuinely want to be different. I've found excellent support in my career (I've had 2 promotions in 4 years), and enjoy the work and projects.

The building in Northampton has just finished internal renovations, and has cool break out areas and lots of colaborative space. 

The pay and perks are good, too.
cons: The men's changing rooms are pretty dire. There's far too many people than space allows. It's all well and good promoting cycle to work / lunch runs etc., but improve the facilities. Also lack of gym!

headline: Overall a fantastic employer!
pros: People are extremely friendly and supportive. Lots of encouragement to progress and flexible working is brilliant; showing that they're an employer intune with the demands of a professional in the 21st century. I'm genuinely really enjoying my time with them and see many opportunities ahead for progression within my current department and elsewhere. They also do a very good job of enforcing their values, which deserves credit!
cons: Hours can be long and work demanding, but that's the nature of the beast with reference to my particular role and is not company specific. Communication of change could be better, but to be honest, in light of the sheer scale of the organisation, I appreciate the complexities involved in this and believe that management do try their best. Demand planning for workload could be improved in some departments as people are frequently overstretched; but I've every belief that efforts are made to reduce the stress.

headline: Its ok but not great
pros: Well my hours are ok, the job is easy enough. Thats it.
cons: Angry rude customers, lots of gossiping and two faced behaviour, passive aggressive colleagues e.g eye rolling insults masked as jokes. Job is boring. The higher up staff just bark at the colleages and assume things not letting them stick up for themselves. Just assuming they are doing wrong. Literally i hear people gossiping  everyday and then being nice to those people. Its a very  fake environment. I don't feel part of the team. I've heard higher up staff say some awful things about other staff members and then be super friendly and jokey with them the next day.

headline: gender gap
pros:
Great NY headquarters location.
Internal transfer are possible.
cons:
The risk management of the firm has shifted and is now set up in a very conflictual mode where members of the risk organization are encouraged to be aggressive and to use tough language towards their counterparts. Whether that comes from top managers is unclear but it appears to be related to the addition of personal in managing roles with prior-experiences from other banks. There is a clear gap between the official company  culture and the day to day working environment that does not promote collaboration.

Being a woman inside Barclays in NY is very difficult. My new manager explained to me on his first day that I would certainly have kids soon and that in anticipation I should adjust my schedule. Most of the new hires are men and were engaged with less experience at a higher pay rate and with a higher ranking. I first thought I was misinterpreting events but my opinion in a masculine-only environment started to be frequently overlooked. I even reached out to receive some mentoring from successful women in the firm but that did not help. Some of them aknowledged that they were not really happy with their responsabilities and pay. I also learned that other women had experienced similar situations.  The situation was much different in the UK where the salary gap between me and my male colleagues appeared much less asymmetrical and my opinions were equally valued.
   
I also experienced akward situations related to diversity for instance a colleague and I were singled out as assets not for our contribution but for our ethnicity. While several other awkward situations occurred I think this may be an isolated problem specific to our department. It raises the question of the oversight from HR and/or top management on yet another theme that impacts the working environment.

headline: Enjoyed my 10 years but wouldn't go back.
pros: The people are Barclays biggest asset, they really care for the customers and their colleagues.  The sales culture of old has been replaced by a real customer service culture.  Long term share plans are very good and employee benefits with the exception of base salary for front line roles are top notch.
cons: Low pay and miserly incentives for front line staff.  Too much micromanaging of staff.  Hardly any opportunities to progress within the branch network unless you want to become a salesperson.  Staffing levels in branches are too low.

Different shift patterns every other week.

headline: You can work here
pros: Good company to work for
cons: Frequent management changes makes it difficult for you to prove your performance at year end.

headline: Variety, personal dev & work-life balance
pros:
I appreciate this isn't possible for every employee in every team at Barclays but I'm fortunate to benefit from Barclays' dynamic working and flexibility. Having that little bit of flex on when I start and finish each day makes me feel less pressured and I'm able to achieve a healthy work-life balance. And actually, I pretty much stick to the same start and finish time each day but just knowing I can flex this makes me really happy to work here. I could hit the wall one afternoon so it makes sense to leave a bit early whereas other days I'm on a roll so don't think anything of staying late; it all evens out over the month. Or I could decide I want to hit a gym class or go for a run; having the opportunity to fit that into my day helps with balancing demands of work and personal and maintaining wellbeing. I've also been able to compress my fortnight into nine days meaning I have a day off every two weeks which I often use for personal development or to progress other areas of my life. 
Also, I'm able to spend some of my time at work on my personal development. whilst some employers could see this as unproductive, my manager understands how personal development ultimately benefits the team, department and company.
Variety is also important to me. I've moved around roles and several sites, exposing me to a lot of colleagues and opportunities.
Barclays' focus on citizenship is a key part of our agenda and it means I've been able to get involved with some really amazing opportunities. This is something my friends are always a bit envious of when they hear what I've been up to!
I've had ups and downs here but from day one I've known how fortunate I am to work for this company so I've stuck at it and been loyal.
cons:
Whilst there is a lot of talk about dynamic working/flexibility etc. I get the impression my area is leading the way on this so I'm probably in a fortunate position to benefit from this. some areas are still micro-managed in comparison to what I have. 
Recruitment process can be a bit clunky.

headline: Stressful occasionally, but a good job for helping people; and those genuinely interested in customer service.
pros: Good career progression available. You are able to work your way up quite quickly if you adapt yourself and remain focused.
cons: Lack of effective communication at times between branches. No set in stone training regime for new colleagues. Mostly have to learn on the job.

headline: Work experience in Barclays Northampton
pros: Working there was great. Just that the salary is low as compared to other banks. People usually use it to gain work experience. It's a lovely building and lovely members of staff. The canteen in Northampton is good too. I enjoyed most of it hence I stayed even though the salary was low.
cons: You do not get promoted. You have to apply for higher positions. I left because the person filling up a vacancy is usually known before role is advertised in the Intranet. I am black and there are not many senior positions filled by blacks.

headline: Good while it lasted
pros: Relatively high salaries, bonuses and decent benefits, in terms of travel (mostly business over 4 hours), health insurance, maternity/paternity leave, pension. Compared to another European investment bank I worked at, there was a surprisingly flat management structure
cons: From 2012-2016, the company had too many management changes, which also led to drastic changes in the company's strategy, especially in Asian IBD and global markets/equities. While the benefits were quite good, the flipside was the company lost focused on costs. Quite amazing that employees were still flying business class, staying at top notch hotels with relatively decent bonuses, right before business divisions were closed down.

headline: AVP (Sr. Software Engineer)
pros:
- Benefits: 5 weeks leave, meal vouchers (fully paid), up to 60 days of sick leave (fully paid), private polyclinic with better-than-average waiting times for appointments, on-site stretching exercises 2x/week, Czech & English language classes
- Office location: near subway station with a good choice of lunch venues
- Office facilities: foosballs, table tennis, bean bags, free beverages, decently sized kitchens 
- Decent salaries, but not above market as before - attrition would be less otherwise
- Friendly and knowledgeable colleagues (in general), not a toxic environment (at least locally)
- Relaxed dress code for a bank - smart casual
- Paid overtime and on calls (or time off in-lieu)
- Work/life balance is generally very good but depends on team/project. Usually not a problem to work from home or leave for an hour or so if you must be somewhere (e.g. home parcel delivery, visit authorities/bank/dentist) - with some notice ahead of time (common sense, not 5 days in advance or the minute you already leave)
- A lot depends on the project/team: codebase, clients (understanding or very demanding/picky), team leads in other locations, etc. Could be a relatively smooth ride with little stress except a few days a year during major releases OR could be hell with constant stress, late nights due to messy systems and management who chronically overcommit and underdeliver.
cons:
- Processes and bureaucracy - e.g. it takes several weeks to become productive - have a working PC with access rights and software. And this is just one example
- Interaction with other teams (e.g. DBA, IT support, app servers support, other dev teams) - often need to send several chaser emails, otherwise you get ignored. This got progressively worse with time, but you might get lucky and get more responsive people.
- Quarterly mandatory trainings that are 90% irrelevant to IT people, are a waste of everyone's time and are mostly there so that the firm would fulfill the terms of yet another plea agreement with DOJ (or whoever it settled with this time).
- No budget for any real training opportunities - technical or business, besides the basics, but you can get Pluralsight subscription, which is better than nothing.
- Outsourced support to India and Mexico with staff of dubious quality (technical and/or language) and high turnover. Many support people don't know the systems and often don't want to learn. As a result developers on level 2 duty get swamped with issues that should be dealt with by level 1 people. This eats into your deliverables for the sprint.
- Change management - God forbid you must coordinate/deploy changes into production or UAT (yes, testing) environments regularly - the effort to document and push it through could easily exceed the actual change you did many times over. Only to do it 2 more times because team 3 out of 5 didn't approve your change in the system in time because you didn't chase them enough. If you are pure developer and only push code to version control then you're fine and spared of this.
- Tooling - collaboration tools are a mess, ancient IRC-like clone for chat, disparate (and often broken) systems for online meetings and videocalls. 
- Feeling like working in silos, little visibility of other teams and your own contribution, but this is supposedly getting better
- Limited career progression once you reach AVP - it is a "catch all" position where you can find people with anywhere between 3 and 13 years relevant experience.
- No budget for business travel or technical conferences. You can work with teammates daily for years without ever meeting them in person.
- Unless you're promoted, you get about inflation level pay rise for very good performance, otherwise below that, if any.
- Bonuses vary, but rarely exceed one monthly salary, often below that, if any, also they're paid in April for the previous year so they keep you on the hook longer should you decide to abandon ship

headline: Work hard and move around
pros:
At AD/ AVP grade there is a great opportunity to move around all of the areas of the Bank.
Work hard and network well and you will have a lot of opportunities available to you.
"The Bank" is very social, a good work hard play hard culture, but don't expect this from backoffice teams dotted around the country outside of London.
1CP is a great office, if you can, base yourself there. It's much more involved. 
The bank is well structured and well led. 
From my experiences management really stand up for their team and take care of their own. If you work hard and do well they will help to open doors for you.
cons:
Being based outside of 1CP can sometimes hinder your ability to progress.
I don't think the Bank pay that well compared to other company's in financial services. 
Don't believe the media hype, the bonuses are not as big as you think they are.
The Bank is highly regulated, there is red tape and slow progression of change, but it's for the right reason. 
Work life balance varies around the group. Some areas encourage you to go the gym for 2 hours in the day and then discourage you from leaving before 7pm. Whereas in other areas WFH is a regular occurance and managers will leave 5pm on the dot. 
Sadly, I was sexual harassed during my time. I don't think this represents the Bank (but more the individual) and the Bank handled my case well and the process was very clear. But I don't think he received an adequate level of punishment.

headline: Good... if your face fits.
pros: Being a large organisation means there was a lot of scope to move within the business and get involved in different projects. Getting 1.5 hours of breaks during the working day is unheard of amongst most companies now, while the facilities were exceptional. The cycle scheme also helped me to afford my first bike.
cons:
The management bias was unbelievable in my department. The employees felt very much divided into two categories - those that fit, and those that did not. 

Being in the latter group meant that I was passed over for promotion against a less-qualified and less-experienced colleague, and that I was amongst a sizeable group of staff denied any bonus for completely arbitrary reasons. It was this last point that drove me to leave as it became clear that the personal development scheme and reaching improvement targets meant nothing in the face of a pre-determined outcome.

headline: Decent place to work .
pros:
Good work-llife balance. 
Better pay as compared to service companies.
Flexible timings. No need to strictly clock 9 hours as in service companies.
Stable and continuous work unlike service companies where you don't know where your next project is going to come from or who will be your next client. Single client who is Barclays.
Encouragement for extra activities such as Community initiatives in addition to work.
Posh facilities such as Breakout area, TVs for watching matches and news even while working (!) and Workspaces.
There will be many vendors like Cognizant, Infosys. So we get a good vendor management experience.
Tech-savvy Bank, so we get work on the latest technologies and methodologies. 
Encouragement for celebrating Fun events.
cons:
Less job stability as compared to service companies, but redundancy happens only at high levels such as director and above.
Single Client , so exposure could be less.
Limited onsite opportunities.

headline: "Great place to work"
pros:
The company really encourages team work, collaboration. It invites new ideas and wants you to challenge the status quo. You are encouraged to innovate and follow your ideas through.
The Founding leaders continue to grow and foster the company culture, by staying close to all levels, company events, and philanthropic initiatives .

headline: Average
pros: Flexible working, Benefits package is generous, Pay is above average for IT employees compared to other industries, Internal Opportunities and growth path.
cons:
No bonus commitment for IT employees, infact not transparent at all. No bonus despite bank profit tripling compared to last year.
Not many employee recreation events, infact none at all to be counted as proper events.
Terrible IT systems, very old and outdated.

headline: Incredibly political and hierarchical environment
pros:
I worked in the Head Office in Canary Wharf
Good name
Large organisation meaning if you're fortunate enough you can scour for and find fresh internal opportunities
Lots going on -different networks and communities
cons:
Values and morals not embedded - it really is dog eat dog. It's not clear what the organisation stands for 
No leaders, lots of managers - very hard to find sponsors/support
Poor progression - you can easily stay at the same level and pay grade for years and years and I met many who time and time again were denied promotions and pay rises despite being excellent
Multiple layers of management doing the same or very similar things -very hierarchical
Lack of meritocracy - it's not clear what promotion criteria is
Very traditional - poor evidence of racial and gender diversity in top leadership positions

headline: Good company, good career prospects
pros: If you're a hard worker and you're proactive, Barclays will help you progress in your career. There are plenty of opportunities for growth.
cons: It takes a lot of stakeholders to get a  simple sign-off, which can become frustrating. There are also several processes that delay getting things done.

headline: Stepping stone
pros: Reimbursed cabs, private cars; free meals; salary + bonus
cons: Hours; everyone was miserable; encourages culture of "drones"; After redesigning outdated systems/mechanisms that are used to provide support to my entire team with huge time saving enhancements as well as learning how to be a better analyst with regard to products/industries/financial valuation methodologies outside my direct scope, I was told that was a waste of time and just to focus on my little niche. Company is very outdated and old school with lots of hazing techniques embedded in the various groups. All the investment banks probably have this to some degree, but at least the others know how to pay employees and keep them from going to hedge funds / private equity.

headline: Treasury
pros: Reasonable work life balance-no expectation of weekends or evening work. Plenty of VP/D's who do very little if thats what you want.
cons:
I have never worked anywhere where so many Powerpoint slides can result in so few actual decisions.

Systems are unfit for purpose. Obsession with top down planning and 'messaging' to senior management. Focus on 'getting stuff done' so the right message can be given to snr mgmt, with little regard to 'getting it right'.

Prevailing blame culture means middle management spend more time avoiding responsibility than actually adding value.

Bizarre role based promotion process effectively block progression until your boss leaves, and leads to large numbers of AVP's applying internally for VP roles they have no qualifications for

headline: Toxic Organisation.
pros:
1. There bonus is not included in the CTC like in other companies, so u actually get more than what your salary is.
2. They like meetings and talking a lot, it will suit you if you are not a coder but an aunty of kitty parties.
3. You get free tea and coffee of machine. That's it.
4. You get one laptop for entire team for support, which is too slow and annoying and you keep figuring out how to connect VPN.
cons:
1. Incompetent colleagues.
2. No good manager to look forward to.
3. They talk in the air most of the time, zero in implemention.
4. For interesting thing they say, we are a bank we are not a software company.
5. The non technical scrum masters which they have in every team, keep a record whether you come on time or not, whether you updated the task you did yesterday.
6. very slow, old and cheap Windows desktops.
7. Heads at pune india has a cheap mentality of cost cutting. They cut costs to an extent when it does not even sound professional anymore.
8. Basically once you go there, you are destroyed caus you cannot take your laptops and you can't install even a single software on their desktops.
9. For even the smallest of things, you need to raise a request.
10. Office culture is very bad, you can sit and code quietly for straight 10mins, everything is too open.
11. Growth is very slow.

This is an organisation for girls or incompetent guys who like talking a lot, and who like discussing random things and in whom even the left 10% of actual coder has died.

I would pay you salary till you don't find a decent job, but pls don't join this.

headline: On the rise again

cons: Somewhat still hierarchical and management is heavy in the U.K. The retail and corporate bank drive the culture from the U.K. While the investment bank remains in the shadows sometimes coming out to bask in a scathing scandal of its risks.

headline: Great place to begin career

cons: Biggest downside with all banking firms is the hours and constant need to be plugged in 24 hrs a day. Also very high associated stress constantly

headline: Excellent Employer, Wonderful opportunities and all colleagues support you in whatever you're pursuing.

cons: Most of the times you end up finishing much later than what you're contracted for which is kind of annoying.

headline: Very Good

headline: Good Company to work with

cons: Sometimes I badly felt the work life balance. This was because of small team size and at the same time you need to support 24/7 globally.

headline: A Real Headscratcher
pros: Good work life balance, especially compared to the other investment banks on the Street. MDs will leave around 5PM-6PM and there isn't an expectation for face time.
cons: Major HR and talent retention issues. Every week, an announcement about a top-level resigning is sent out. Whenever there's an issue, management's solution to fire someone at the top and hire a new and shiny band-aid with a large paycheck to solve said issue. However, what you have in the end is a loss of infrastructure knowledge. There are so many new people that no one knows how any of the legacy systems work, why they were installed, and they keep trying to re-invent the wheel. Company spends a lot of time and money hiring new people and expensive consultants, who at the end of the day are unfamiliar with why the problem exists. Barclays is still stuck in the old days of banking and they have not realized the value of technological innovation or cheap analyst labor. It's a very small company, but people are very unproductive and morale is very, very low. No one is committed to the company or takes pride in the company brand (at least in NY). It's hard to convince someone to stay when all other US banks on the street have better culture and better compensation.

headline: Great people and benefits

interesting projects

bureaucratic as the organization grew larger

Benefits were ok, but had a decent paid leaves, right form when you join them.
cons: I was here for around a year so didn't see much, only thing bad was we had to work on remote VDI machines, never liked them.

headline: Great flexibility, above average work-life Balance
pros:
- Great opportunity to contribute across functions.
- One can take on additional responsibilities beyond his current role. 
- Internal job moves a big positive. Chances of growth immense provided you can network well.
- Above average work-life balance, wfh is a big boon for some.
cons:
- Slightly unstructured - specifically the HR processes including hiring.
- Old Timers who are at VP level don't want to move anywhere. Their attitude towards firm and work is not something to be positive about.
- Slightly averse to risks. Lot of money waster by the bank because of such attitude at the senior level.
- Not for techies, this is the place for people who can make projects deliver, vendors do the low level work.
- Growth for few can be a problem. Not a very dynamic work environment.

headline: Find an alternate if you are young and bright
pros:
1. Work culture : Most of the people in the firm are nice and friendly. They will help you if needed.
2.  Work/life balance: Its a great place if you have a growing family or have lot of commitments outside work. Although, you will be busy most of the time, the work wont kill you and should have enough time for personal life
cons:
1. SHrinking industry: Finance and Barclays overall are shrinking and its not a good place to be if you have just started your career.
2. It's probably still a good place for investment bankers but not so much for technology graduates.  Top IT candidates usually find another job in a year.
3. No career opportunities since the senior guys wont leave and no new opportunities to grow.

headline: Awful, bullying, poor coms, incompetent leaders, dead wood
pros:
Great pay!

If you are a professional and you would like to work in a place with other like-minded professionals to progress your career do not work here.
cons:
Being led my dear old ladies that have been there years that are just interested in the 50k bonus they will be awarded if they employ the right contractors to do the work for them. 

"Leadership team", subtext for privately run cartel ensuring objectives are met to meet bonus requirements.

Institutional bulling from leadership teams by dictation, they don't really care how the work is completed just whether it is going to be on time for them.

Two of the "leadership team" were having an affair and kept leaving work early together for a quick sh%g - both married with children.

The company seems to be obsessed with ramming LGBT values down your throat but then openly bully individuals on there personal appearance - "if the face doesn't fit"

headline: Horrible Communication, Hard to escalate issues
pros: Casual workplace environment. Good pay, benefits, and opportunity for incentive pay.
cons: I have never worked for a company with worse communication. Trying to escalate genuine and systemic issues is like bashing your head against a wall. There are rarely meaningful answers or progress. I have personally tried to escalate several system and policy issues for over a year with no success. One is normally told that their question is a "know issue" that will be reviewed later. This does not just apply to small issues, but large overreaching ones that effect the efficiency and integrity of the company.

headline: Analyst

The location is handy as it is near multiple forms of transport - train or bus. General attitude of people working there is great and positive working environment.
cons: There is the odd feeling of secrecy from senior management and not always transparent with what is going on in the future. There have been occasions where the company promotes and is proud of being a flexible employer however when it comes to crunch time, they appear somewhat rigid.

headline: Trying hard to change things
pros:
Have worked for 10yrs+ in different roles and teams.
Benefits - Health, vacation, etc, all above average.
People - sharp minds in many roles. International & multicultural.
Progression - were brilliant at it 10yrs ago, then struck some rough patches, but getting back to a good place now with focus on retention and internal mobility.
Desire to change - ExCo understood the need to restructure to ensure relevance, have made bold moves, staff generally very supportive and optimistic.
cons: Experience really depends on which function you're in - "management discretion" can be great, but also not as great if your boss is not progressive. Pay attention to your interviewers - if they are consistently projecting a genuinely positive culture, your team is probably a good place. But if not, beware.

headline: Barclays glory days long gone
pros:
Prestige company.
Great salary package.
Latest technology available. 
Challenging work. Opportunities to achieve something.
cons:
Culture of fear. Continual restructuring created much insecurity.
Authoritarian rule. Any kind of dissent or criticism will result in dismissal.
Flat org structure. No chance of promotion.
Management are faceless. It allows them to run the business without any compassion for staff. 
Not a place to work if you want a relaxed, fun environment.

headline: Employee friendly but lot of red tape

cons: Bureaucratic, hierarchical, Poor IT infrastructure

1. good location
2. well known company
cons:
1. bad structure
2. not a good learning environment for new grad

headline: HR Coordinator

headline: AVP

headline: Very good

cons: None since it is focused on employee welfare and adhering to values.

headline: Lovely place to work but has morale issues
pros:
Great benefits package
Flexible working
Big brand
Stringent training plans
Mobility is great should you want to uproot, very straightforward
Looks good on resume
cons:
Progression is down to politics, it's not what you know, it's who you know
Branches are regularly understaffed
Staff are bound to make mistakes due to the stress of regularly dealing with an understaffed branch
Morale cannot remain high as main cause of customer dissatisfaction will always be staff attitude but the branches need to be under closer inspection to identify key issues
Staying back until late hours daily due to lack of staff available to close the branch

headline: Barclays Shared Services Noida India Management Lacks Transparency, Ethics and Fairness
pros: Easy to get in to the company (BSS Noida India) as their interview process is sub-standard
cons: Management plays all kinds of dirty games. People in management position are biased, lack knowledge, display lack of maturity. IJP process is rarely an honest, open process. Poorly run leadership at Barclays Shared Services Noida India

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Great experience, value driven organisation and really care about its customers. They invest a lot of time in recruitment so good hardworking peers. Great work-life balance and flexi-hours. Very innovative and creative organisation with a lot of focus on community development.
cons: Bureaucracy and political. Job promotions rely a lot on who your manager is and who you know, rather than how capable you are.

headline: good compnay
pros: good team environment, good management team
cons: salary is not very competitive and reward is not very good

headline: B4
pros: Being Europe centric, people do not have to stretch much and do not have to work on weekends
cons: Unstable leadership. Senior leaders do not have focus, everybody just try to put the tick the check boxes

headline: Great Company with lots of support
pros: Great pay and benefits. Culture is pretty good but is adjusting as senior management is always changing.
cons: Always competing against the best banks and hours can be grueling. As the bank is trying to find its US presence, you sometimes wonder if their goals are obtainable.

headline: Okay
pros: Work hours were reasonable, pay good.
cons: Superficial culture with little focus on longevity.

headline: Barclay's AVP
pros: Good perk and job satisfaction, also good learning
cons: No onside position, mostly work with vendor partner

headline: Barclays is always changing
pros: fantastic set of people possibly the best brains in market sit here with all possibilities and opportunities.
cons: ever changing environment will keep you busy wondering whats happening all the time. Change is the other name of the place so be prepared for that.

headline: Bittersweet
pros:
Good opportunities to move into other business areas
Strong share benefits 
Good work life balance
cons:
Silly retail politics
Lack of employee respect
Sales focused role, without defined targets

headline: Not exceptional in any way
pros: It is a big brand and has all the trappings of an organisation with large resources. The work conditions, benefits and job content meet the minimum standard of any large bank.
cons: There is absolutely nothing to distinguish the organisation from other organisations. Their policies are never path breaking. In fact, they lag the market in several of these. The organisation is largely impersonal and people come and go without anyone noticing.

headline: Not exceptional in any way
pros: It is a big brand and has all the trappings of an organisation with large resources. The work conditions, benefits and job content meet the minimum standard of any large bank.
cons: There is absolutely nothing to distinguish the organisation from other organisations. Their policies are never path breaking. In fact, they lag the market in several of these. The organisation is largely impersonal and people come and go without anyone noticing.

headline: Great Place to work

headline: Good Internship india
pros: good pay, benefits and work life balance

pros: The pay was OK, we got 1 free piece of fruit a week, the cafeteria wasn't extortionate, nobody seemed to really care whether you turned up or not.
cons: Very limited advice or opportunity for career development, rude unhelpful management, immature office environment, rampant sexism in the office (I am a male, so it was not directed towards me)

cons: Very email cultured, people appear to have lost the ability to speak to one another, not great money for the work expected.

headline: Not too bad
pros: Great people, great work environment. Work hours aren't too bad, and you get plenty of support from colleagues. Pay is relatively decent.
cons: Very political, job promotions rely a lot on who your manager is and who you know, rather than how capable you are.

headline: Good place to grow and learn

headline: operation analyst
pros: offer a lots of welfare  and very stable
cons: there is no cons about barclays

headline: Good
pros: Great learning, reward and recognition, employee friendly, good salary structure, good opportunity , approachable managers, great peers, cohesive teams,
cons: I had a good experience with barclays and hence do not have any cons to enumerate

headline: Excellent group of people but lack of clarity from management in terms of strategic direction.
pros:
Excellent group of people across the company globally.
Dynamic/flexible working benefits are a great benefit.
Challenging and interesting roles make it enjoyable to go to work.
cons:
Aggressive unstructured cost reduction programs lead to significant risk taking.
Lack of career advancement opportunities.
Internal politics can be tiresome.

headline: OK but small money for back office
pros:
maternity welfare.... almost 6 months. 
if your boss is good, you can have flexible working hours
cons:
if your work is doing well, it does not mean anything. but if you could do a lot of charity events dancing event talk a lot etc, you will be promoted. it is not an investment banking. 
zero salary increase in few years even for the graduate program people.

headline: Cool IT development center
pros:
Development Center atmosphere,  full of smart people. The bank is using new technologies, a lot of development is going on.
Nice compensation. 
Meal vouchers paid fully by the employer. 
Trainings. 
Summer and winter parties.
cons: It's almost impossible to get promotion, you can work as AVP for the whole life.

headline: Data Entry Clerk
pros: Great collaborative environment, friendly staff, good pay.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy and hard to make an impact as a contractor.

headline: Global company
pros: Great benefits and attractive compensation.
cons: Work is business and thus do not expect lunch-outs or annual gatherings

headline: Compliance
pros: the people are amazing. very regulated. opportunity to further your learning. amazing opportunity to work within the financial services for a mulit national bank
cons: they don't like to employ their temporary staff on to a permanent contract even though there is a business need for them

headline: Vice President Banker
pros: Good culture in the company
cons: there might be a lot of Red tapes

headline: Surveyor
pros: A wonderful time filling cash machines making tea and admiring the scenery,punctuated by frequent and lavish all expenses paid trips to Cannes
cons: No luncheon vouchers,nor a good enough company car and surrounded by a surfeit of middle managers,high on their own narcissism and egocentricity

headline: Higher Apprenticeship
pros: The Higher Apprenticeship is a fantastic way to get your foot in the door and get given the opportunity to gain exposure across departments. My personal and technical development has increased massively since taking the role over a year ago.
cons: The bureaucracy dictates the level of your career development. Despite being offered roles to come off the apprenticeship and into Analyst roles, i am unable to do so due to blockers being put in place by people running the programme.

headline: Higher Apprenticeship

headline: Good people and company, suffers from same problems as other IBs
pros: Coworkers are enjoyable to work with, culture is not as cutthroat as some IBs. In certain trading sectors, overall ranking is top 3 and thus there is opportunity to work with some of the best sell-side traders.
cons: Relatively conservative management that will not take huge risks. Less opportunity to progress versus what it was like 5 or 10 years ago. Not as aggressive as other IBs in their desire to be the top player. Suffers from lack of innovation - which is something going on across the street due to increased regulations, etc.

headline: Good company
pros: Great flexible working options and mobility. Enables employees to work around their external commitments.  Overall a good place to work.
cons: Standard bureaucracy problems of working for a big company. Legacy technology causes holdups and frustrations at times. Constant changes in structure also cause problems with stability.

headline: IT Support Analyst
pros: Salary and benefits are competitive and you get to work with brilliant minds.

headline: Great company

cons: lack of staff in branches

headline: Analyst review
pros: Excellent graduate programme, good induction to the bank. Excellent technology. Very smart appraisal processes and goal setting process.
cons: Culture differences created barriers with work.

headline: Vp
pros: Interesting business model, great strategy

headline: Barclays
pros: Above average pay. Good infrastructure.
cons: The IT division (where I worked) didn't have well-implemented processes.

headline: Really good company with good work culture

headline: Great place to work

Good training opportunities
Lots of CSR activities if you like them
cons:
Can be stressful given the frequent job cuts if you are affected by this kind of environment.
Now not a very good company if you are in IT in Singapore
They are moving operations to India ( and for some teams to UK/US !!)

headline: Rapidly going down

headline: Barclays
pros: highly diverse, very demanding, good bonus for critical staff
cons: constantly changing structures, new direction all the time

headline: Analyst
pros: Dynamic Working, Job Perks, great development opportunities, good internal recruitment, management are very supportive and always address key concerns for colleauges
cons: desk space is very limited in head office, if you don't have a permanent desk it can be difficult to get a desk

headline: Vice President
pros: Salary, Benefits and total compensation.  Firm has very motivated teams and they are proud of the Barclay name and protect the brand.
cons: The organization's culture is very political and bureaucratic.

headline: Technology Analyst
pros: Encouraging work culture with relaxed atmoshphere

headline: analyst
pros: Good working place, modern offices in a lively area, meal vouchers, sick days, flexible working hours, work from home, work & life balance
cons: Lack of business trips, too much of administration in certain things, for some positions not that many possibilities for professional growth, sometimes lack of interesting project (or project at all) to work on.

headline: Great place to be a summer analyst
pros: Competitive work environment, lots of information to learn at a fast pace
cons: They should hire a higher percentage of their summer analyst class

headline: Summer Analyst (PCB)
pros: Famous British bank with great graduate opportunities
cons: HR slow to respond to requests

headline: It's a job
pros:
Work life balance is good
You will be working with some bright, talented people
Middle management have some clue
cons:
Can be a little sleepy
Can be a little bureaucratic
Promotions and good bonuses are not easy to come by

headline: Senior Manager
pros: High focus on a Values based culture
cons: Slow to change - like changing course in an oil tanker

headline: Great place to expand Your knowledge at first... bu
pros: Good place to start your IT career. It starts you off with all the necesities for a healthy IT career. It even helps You with training budgets and all the other things to help You achieve the best "You", with monthly and even yearly reviews(depends on your manager)
cons: Tried to implement agile methodologies - failed miserably. Pretty sad hierarchy in which most of the decisions are done really high up the chain, and if you have a low position, You don't even see yourself mentioned anywhere.

headline: Great internship
pros: Internship programme was well prepared by HR with great workshop sessions throughout introducing different banking areas.
cons: Some analysts that were assigned as 'buddies' did not put as much effort as others. It took away from the support system set up for interns.

headline: Poor management
pros: Immediate colleagues good to work with, nice office atmosphere. Pay good.
cons: Very poor management. Workers led by managers in ivory towers who have never done the day job themselves.

headline: Business Analyst 4

cons: Typical analyst compensation seems to fall below similar roles at similar major banks

headline: Barclays Graduate
pros: Good hours and good network
cons: not much flexibility and too much structure

headline: Technology Analyst
pros: Stress free work culture. Slow paced and relaxed environment. The company's services for employees are excellent. Being an intern, I got all my living expenses covered during the internship.
cons: The work culture is lacking a bit of dynamism and pace. The projects are slow paced and wouldn't suit someone who is used to a fast culture.

headline: Not worth your time
pros: Market salary but bonuses for only a very very select few
cons: Don't try to be proactive or bring new ideas, leave your MD alone and do your job and you'll be fine.

headline: Business Analyst

headline: Business Analyst

headline: assistant vp

headline: Good company to work for.

headline: Acceptable employer but not always treated fairly
pros: Salary acceptable for role compared with other companies. Part time working agreed. Carers days and childcare vouchers available.
cons: Management very clicky and no real option to progress within the role. Not given options for flexible working that other colleagues had the luxury of within same role. Outdated systems and frustrating processes.

headline: Good benefits
pros: Shift time is good to maintain work life balance. Good pay and bonus as compared too market. Recommended.
cons: For growth you need contacts with seniors.

headline: Personal banker

smart people in some places
technology focus, better at tech than other places

bureaucratic like some of the other large banks
lot of focus on non productive processes 
red tapism

headline: Analyst

headline: Retail Banking
pros:
Some great individuals working there still
Benefits outside of salary
cons:
Bullying tactics still rife in senior managers
No support
Breaches in staff privacy and data protection
Customer abuse
Expect to work over 45hrs per week and 6 day weeks
Mostly poor management with very limited leadership skills
Expect to be hit on by your boss with the promise of promotions if your willing

headline: RISES - ermmmm no
pros:
Experimental set up in Singapore
AMAZING PEOPLE. 
Very diverse.
Great technology investments
Dynamic environment
Some managers supportive and understanding of work life balance (working in Singapore but dealing with UK and US).
Singapore management tried really hard to build staff morale.
cons:
Too political. 
Bad salaries, bonuses and payrises for the actual "workers" aka AVP and below.
Blatant discrimination occurred. Everyone was looking for a fall guy or to cover their own hides.
People got overlooked by management due to personal opinions and prejudices
It became evident if you were friends with managers you would get promoted quickly and also get a better pay rise/bonus then peers.

headline: Manager

 Global brand, strong business, big company Worst things
cons: bureaucracy of any large company

headline: Work

Good Place to work
Co workers are cooperative
Good Salary
cons:
Groupism
Frequent Organizational changes
People are behind only making their managers happy

headline: Decent internship.
pros: Nice atmosphere, make you feel welcome.
cons: Poor tasks given to Interns.

headline: Pot luck
pros: Flexi working, colleagues make it a great place, NVQs are free & great career opportunities. Bonus scheme and buy or sell holiday.
cons: Penilised for sickness impacts Personal development plan even if you have a condition. Unable to follow own policies which goes against Barclays values. Job losses to offshore colleagues to save money which impacts customers. Large increase in complaints!

headline: nan
pros: Great team and atmosphere even with long hours

Very diverse
Plans well

Still facing reputational issues
Too slow as a firm to effectively implement change

headline: Finance

cons: Loads of internal politics and internal burocracy

headline: Review
pros: Good place to work with so much of flexibility
cons: Nothing to say really on negative side

headline: Build your career if you are prepared to slog it out
pros:
Great opportunities to move into new roles and take on new responsibilities (not necessarily with compensation to recognise this)

Global (although that's changing)
cons:

IT systems are extremely frustrating 
Major cost pressure means there are not enough people to deliver what is needed (and certainly not enough to be proud of the end result each time)

headline: Good Exposure
pros: Good environment to work on
cons:
No specific. Every company has cons
....

headline: Front Office Spring Intern
pros: Everybody was very welcoming and the week was well structured. Provided a good opportunity to learn more about the industry,
cons: There wasn't too much opportunity for networking. Furthermore I didn't have the opportunity to speak to employees from my particular divisions of interest.

headline: Good to work with Barclays
pros:
Nice environment 
Intelligennt ppl 
Handsome salary
Good bonus
Extra facilities like transport and pantry are at best in industry for free
Good work life balance
cons:
Unstable mgmt.
Be ready for layoff anytime
You can be out even if you have secured best rating because company wants a change

headline: Financial analyst
pros: cool environment to cop up with
cons: less growth,less innovation,less technology,hectic

headline: Barclays Change Management
pros: A huge variety of excellent opportunities and a great environment for talent to grow. Barclays are always driving to be innovative and are looking for quality individuals
cons: As with any large organisation it is very easy to become anonymous

headline: VP
pros: A company with long history, strong brand in the UK and good direction to focus on its core capabilities and dispose of non core assets.
cons: Too many mgmt and org changes. Employees are not motivated. Too much negative exposure in the media with regards to regulatory breaches.

headline: Analayst
pros: Good exposure to latest technology and values culture have made a great difference in the organisation.
cons: Promotions can only happen every 12 months and it is a long process that could take many more months. Company should be able to match-up to Degree/Masters/Phd qualificatons and other certification market rates.

headline: Barclays analyst
pros: Good work life balance and nice team. Good pay for level of responsibility.
cons: Cost cutting measures and hiring freezes resulted in a less progressive atmosphere within the bank. Duplication of effort and sometimes questionable as to how much value one employee really adds.

headline: Solid company but tough environment due to current economic situation
pros: Solid company, good prospects for progression, great value system, citizenship agenda to be proud  of
cons: long hours, work life balance not great,  lack of staff due to constant restructuring, high turnover of management

headline: Client Service Executive
pros: Some of the teams have extremely hardworking people who are vastly underpaid. Great for training and beginning your career, but would not stay for the long term. Most individuals took voluntary redundancy from my team.
cons: Vastly underpaid against larger US banks and often hours are pretty intense. Often under resourced to take on large amount of work and often customers are very demanding where autonomy is not given to employees.

headline: The worst place to work at.
pros: No pros what so ever.
cons:
They harass you in work if you do not do get the things implemented whichever ways possible mostly including wrong ones.
Secondly if you stand up against the breaching of any right ways..
They torture you mentally..
And when you ask them time and again to stay away from you.. they still continue the harassment..
And in the end when you just dont understand what to do you threat for suicide they go ahead and put you in simulation having cameras everywhere including washrooms and watch you.
Plus they mentally emotionally and sexually harass you to the worst possible limits.
Die but dont ever consider being anywhere in 1000miles near anyone of this company.

headline: A solid company...I would work there again!
pros:
+ Good benefits, especially for a working mom
+ Good paternity leave
+ competitive pay
+ smart colleagues
cons: Left due to my partner relocating to a different city. otherwise, I would have stayed with the organization.

headline: Loan Closer

cons: Horrible technology. Horrible IT support. Managers were very reluctant to escalate negative issues effecting employees to senior staff.

pleasant work area
diverse employees
opportunity for growth

upper management not in same location
work was sent offshore 
not supported
