headline: NA
pros: Flexible timings No minimum hours
cons: Depends on the project.  Very less onsite

headline: Barclays struggling to define itself
pros: the people are clearly its best resource
cons: need more decision making power at lower levels and not "at the center" (London)

headline: Black mark in professional world
pros: Nothing good, before joining the company the hr showed me what are the values and culture of barclays
cons: HR is pathetic can even play with the career dont resign till you get the written confirmation from barclays hr, they can go so down to save their jobs and play with your career. Wish can give in negative for culture and values

headline: Barclays gave me an opportunity to grow my self and be the best in the various roles.
author_position: Head of Governance, Compliance and Controls
pros: It has a great training environment. If you are committed and focus you can learn a lot, explore and bring your ideas to the table. In my 23 years in Barclays i got good performance ratings which propelled me to do even better.
cons: The first 15 years were great however with every change of CEO thereaafter, strategy kept changing hence affecting the direction of the bank which overtime took a toll on the staff and business.

headline: Make the most of it
pros:

headline: Sinking ship
pros: Provide great learning, atleast till 2015, before the leadership changes. Good trainings, cool working environment, free meals, free cab pick and drop facility.
cons:
After recent changes in leadership during 2016, they gave fired tenured good leaders as well as work force and hiring absolute crap. So one can very well think of where they will be standing soon!
Squeezing bonuses and annual increaments no matter how good one has performed, they are religiously giving 15℅ efficiency by cutting  The work force since 2015 as managers have it as their KPI. No growth for a non political employee. Highly political environment and cut throat competition.

headline: This is a great place to start your software development career with. Fantastic workplace !
pros:
Pros from a fresher software developer's point of view at BTCI (Pune technology center India):
1. You'll get to learn a lot.
2. Opportunities to work for very critical and real-time projects that one cannot expect in other IT companies.
3. You can interact with some of the great minds in industry as it's a FLAT organisation.
4. One can get huge domain knowledge of BFSI sector if interested.
5. Satisfactory work life balance.
6. The `Barclays` brand obviously.
7. And they pay you well :)
cons:
Many times simpler processes turn into sluggish requests and approvals game which may slow down your actual work. But it's understandable as BTCI is a part of a huge organisation.

P.S. I won't be able to comment on software testing or support profiles.

headline: Technical Lead
pros: Amazing place to work. Barclays is one of the very few banks to invest in technologies heavily. Highly adaptive environment, employees are given free hand to try new things that helps to push them in professional career. Senior management is very much approachable. Appraisal process is simple and great bonus at the end to say bye to the year on high note. Competitive salary and good tax reduction structure help employees to save more. With the Barclays brand name, one can feel the difference, business class travels, five star stays makes it more special.Also invests heavily on employee engagement to make work place better and full of energy.
cons: Despite all the pros, one major con is favoritism, senior management try to bring in their friends and closed ones. This is very much visible and seems like its kind of culture that prevails. Another big big con is with constant re orgs happening all the time, senior management keeps on changing. Its looks like power game at the top where one department tries to screw other department happiness. Bonus payouts are highly department centric. Also processes need to be streamlined.

headline: It pays to be with one of the biggest
pros:
An established Institution of the Banking World.
A great example of a 20th/21st century company who provide their employees with a range of benefits. These come in the form of security, bonuses, pensions etc and opportunity to keep up-to-date with the relevant industry knowledge. Giving that little bit more,, where you may take less.
Offered in-house communication avenues for staff, at all levels, in every sectors to give their own input into the overall running of a particular product or the company in general.
cons:
I worked at a time where around the World the industry or 'Financial Sector', was generally seen in a very negative light.
In order to avoid stagnation, I felt there was a need to further enhance the development programmes for those 'wanting' to climb up the career ladder.

headline: Global Technology is a sinking ship - get out while you can!
pros: Salary isn't too bad if you're a good negotiator. You don't have to work particularly hard - in fact, most people don't. If you have a family it's great, because you can work from home all the time and never do any work - just leave it to other colleagues.
cons: Global Technology in Barclays, or JPBarclays as it is now, is a complete mess. I can't overstate how much of a disaster it is. There's barely any talent left - the current employees are either on visas so cannot leave, or are too stupid or lazy to find another position externally. Promotions are absolutely impossible to come by, hiring is frozen across high cost centers, and requests to replace staff who quit have to be vetted by the CEO's team. There's so much bureaucracy it's impossible to get any real work done - rebooting a development server takes around 4 hours and 3 phone calls. Nothing actually works properly, from the helpdesk to the infrastructure services, so when a process or task completes successfully it's a surprise and quite possibly accidental.

headline: Team Leader
pros: Quarterly incentive measured on both personal contribution and team performance - can be very substantial if you put the work in and lead your team effectively. Well supported by direct line management (but I can only speak for my specific business area). Good approach to flexible and dynamic working - enables you to manage work/life balance more effectively. Values culture.
cons: Usual middle management issues - take crap from below and above. Can often feel dehumanised. Procedures can often be implemented by senior level without considering the logistics and impact on you and your team, with you left to pick up the pieces. A lot of focus on Roles outside of London are extremely limited and unless you want to progress further down the management route you can be left feeling very stuck.

headline: Experience depends on team

headline: VP

headline: Great job role, but......
pros: Great centrally located large offices in Poole, Free parking which would normally cost around £10 day maximum elsewhere around town. Onsite restaurant offering a wide variety of food and drink. Friendly colleagues and overall was a good place to work. Friendly senior management and banter plus team huddles and career options available.
cons: The downside is the high turnover of staff 40 in the last 6 months in the PBA complaint handler role. The job is on the face of it a really good role investigating PBA complaints using inhouse systems. What makes it an impossible atmosphere to work in is the quality control team that check  case handlers work, nothing is black or white only grey area's with everyone in the QC team having a different interpretation of the same thing meaning when marking a handlers case you are normally always wrong with something. The stress caused by it is the problem, if handlers just worked cases had them checked and then completed without the traffic light system of having to get certain green feedbacks or you enter the supervised environment then if you fail to make the grade you are out and this way of carrying on is ongoing the whole time, making for a very stressful job which caused me some discomfort. If the  QC department process was totally reinvented then decent hard working people would stay or not get sacked, too many people passing through and I think it is unique to this department as the rest of Barclays is brilliant.

headline: Assistant VP
pros: good salary, good benefits and very good social life - a lot of team outings - you can find very good friends there
cons:
Working at Barclays as an IT is extremly boring. The expectations at the interviews are high and only few pass it, so they recruit high skilled professionals and then let them do a work that a high school student would be able to cope with.

The Indian support (RTB) teams (both in India or UK) are awful, they hire incompetent juniors - for example for the unix support they hire people who never used the OS.

The meritocracy they advertise all the time doesn't really exist. The politics is the only key and if you want good bonuses, you need to be friend with your boss. The chances for being promoted or moved overseas are close to zero.

headline: Resolution Manager

cons: Depending on hire date you don't earn PTO for your hire month. Probationary period in which you are banned from scheduling PTO for future.PTO can not be rolled over. Use it or lose it but PTO is hard to get approved during holidays. Occurrences issued for calling out of work. Management micromanaged the employees. Team leaders like to dwell on the negatives and do not acknowledge positives.

headline: Depends on project
pros:
It really depends on the team and project you are on. I started on a fantastic project with a lot of great people which over time turned into a disaster which made about 10 people leave. We haven"t had a single hire or a promotion in over two years. It happens regularly that we have simply no work to be done and we bring our personal laptops to work and work on our own pet projects to keep ourselves busy. 

There is also virtually zero communication from upper management. Even though we are constantly told Prague is a key location for Barclays, it certainly doesn't feel that way. What is even more sad is that with no promotions over the last year we now have 3 open positions for more senior roles which could easily be filled from within, some of my colleagues have been with the company for 4 years. 

Also the raise & compensation this year was ridiculous. The (public) year results say "we made more money, but the compensation pool for employees is smaller" on the same page that also says "aligning compensations with results".  This just leaves me speechless.
cons: In general it just feels like no one cares from the upper management, which translates to everybody to just not caring. Maybe they just want us all to quit, in that case job well done.

Very good work life balance
Company's culture is good
Free transport service
Multiple offices in same city - pune
You can be innovative and learn whatever you want to learn in extra time

You won't get quality work
Quality work mostly outsourced to other company, in house developers do patching work only

headline: Great place to work, until management changed
pros: Pay is good as long as you make bonus every month. Incentive payout is higher than any I've seen in any other call center I've worked with.
cons: Pay is not based on experience like they say, because some people who only had one year experience in a call center, made $2-$3 more than those who had more than 5 years experience. As soon as the new management came in, the whole atmosphere went downhill, and they promise people who don't know what they're doing, and give agents wrong information when assistance is needed. They show lots of favoritism and don't value their employees, and they only care about numbers for the cosmonauts.

headline: Redundant
pros: I worked for bespoke offers and was sadly made redundant in October due to the whole business closing. Loved the whole department, lovely managers, a lot less 'banky' than the rest of the building. Encourage to develop but you have to put the work in and network to get yourself known.
cons:
The problem with a large company is you have to go through so many people to get something done and I spent half my time on hold to IT. bespoke offers was sadly all wrong from the start and it was only in the last 6 months - a year real progression was starting to show because amongst lots of other things they took the time to listen to us in the department to get a real feel of our suggestions on how to improve and to really sit down and look at the stats. All of us had such great ideas but the 'big boys' didn't sit down to listen and take note.  If we all joined forces and more people were listened too things may have slowly changed.  New CEO came in, looked what was loosing money and quickly said bye bye to bespoke.
Half year and end of year document took so much time, unfortunately due to being made redundant my boss didn't even read mine as not one single comment left which was very upsetting.  Cheaper food in canteen.

headline: Good company but requires stability

headline: Good for the CV but avoid if you can
pros: Great people, smart and capable. Barclays had top notch systems including market data repositories, risk engines etc obviously designed by excellent professionals. Capable trading desks too.
cons: Since 2012 the firm went downhill rapidly fast. No training. Very long hours with brutal deadlines. Poor pay, ranked top in reviews yet zero bonus. Bad vibes in the firm, culture was terrible. Miserable offices, 10 South Colonnade dirty carpets, 3 toilets for 500 people in the floor only cleaned once a day. 5 North Colonnade pretty much the same. Mediocre benefits. Sparse internal mobility opportunities, only for the very well connected.

headline: great place to work at
pros: good environment overall. I get to met a lot of passionate individuals and build good connections with them. Its never restricted to where you work or the department you work at -you meet people from the other departments too. They are quite good at career development, so you won't stay in the same position for long if you're seriously looking to commit.
cons: The type of managers (i.e. in terms of the character/ management style) you have will heavily influence your experience at work (in other words whether you'll enjoy working in that team or not) -this is bad if you can't seem to build a good personal connection with your manager (e.g. due to personality difference or lack of topic of discussion) -so you'll basically be stuck being the generic team member who will remain last on the manager's list of priorities.This means you won't be able to progress much with any career development plans you have. So take extra care to observe your future manager at the interview! Make sure that you feel comfortable enough with them and kickstart that by building up a strong work relationship (or even friendship) so that you could have a good start with your job.

-perception created of employess as  resources, they simply want the right no of people logged in and dont care about anything else..
-People who genuinely want to improve the work environment.
find ways to do things better ,basically care about the barclays values(Stewardship,integrity ,etc) will be disappointed after sometime and find the place a farce
-nothing is really in place, transport is rubbish, food at cafeteria is rubbish, even the rosters are not decided one week ahead, work schedules are changed on the same day and you cannot even be sure of your break timings, which are changed as per login requirement anytime.
IT systems are rubbish , with monitors not working, keyboards missing many keys, software routinely hanging crashing.
-Place is heading for doomsday as far as senior management goes , which is why I left after 3 years

headline: Great benefits, not much else
pros: Barclays offers great benefits: healthcare, adoption assistance programs, work-from-home opportunities, volunteering opportunities, and networking social groups (for women, minorities, and LGBTQ employees)
cons: Other than the benefits, the culture is toxic. From 2011 to 2016, Barclays has had 3 CEO's: Bob Diamond, Antony Jenkins, and Jes Staley. And during those 5 years, even more organizational restructuring and management moves occurred. All of these left many valuable departments and employees in limbo for many months without work or direction while the C-suite and the board tried to figure out what to do with the bank. Concurrently in those 5 years, demotivation, toxicity, and general wariness about the fate of the bank were pervasive world-wide. No matter what initiatives local manager would try to initiate to bring morale up among the sites, any efforts were made futile by upper management as production remained low and departments were left neglected.

headline: Conflicted company
pros: Direct management understand day to day issues. Flexible work schedule. Most colleagues are nice and down to earth. Free coffee. Generous vacation.
cons: Doing more with less or the same is the new motto. BCUS is a "growth" business but  the parent company wants to reduce headcount and invest as little money as possible. Company doesn't really care about the individual colleague. Lives by the corporate values only apply when it suits them. No accountability.

headline: Not all that glitters is Gold.
pros:
Barclays Brand is good. 
Good training materials available on the intranet for all staff. 
The Uniform is good but not enough for  every 2 years.
The internal IT SYSTEMS are good but can be better.
cons:
Promotion from Retail to Corporate Banking or Compliance is impossible.
Internal interview is unnecessarily tough!
Internal Promotion is almost impossible!
Salary not great especially for staff at the Branches.

headline: Cashier
pros: The company has great employee benefits, great team to work with. Good systems and internal help is fast and easy to get hold of.
cons:
Applies to bigger branches mainly:
Increasing lack of progression available. Internal politics. Increasing job in
Staff can be micro-managed and sometimes treated like children. 
Sales pressure, at times. The values that are set out are not imposed internally.
Constant staffing issues, Barclays keep getting the number wrong which puts staff in a pressurized, negative working environment. Appalling holiday booking system.  
Visions and plans for the retail bank don't seem to be  practical when put in place. 
Different rules and culture in different branches.

headline: Associate Director
pros: A company with a great reputation for training and developing staff, with plenty of opportunities to gain experience in a wide range of banking areas.
cons: The bank has become more process driven whilst support services have been reduced in recent years.  More recently, development opportunities have been reduced.

headline: AVP

cons: Less opportunities to go on upper level

headline: Overall a Great Company to work for

cons: Barclays remains a great company to work for but in recent years continuous company changes and job instability has become an overarching concern

headline: Administrator
pros: good place to work . benefits are good
cons: performance reviews are not fair

headline: Vice President
pros: BREXIT aside, Barclays seems to have been ahead of other UK and European banks in adapting to the new normal of lack luster markets and regulatory overkill.    This should situate the company well while some its rivals have waited until now to go through the painful process of shedding non-core businesses and letting good people go
cons: The amount of turnover among senior managers over the past four years has made it confusing for staff.     Not only is there uncertainty about the direction of the firm, but often, it was hard to figure out who your business line reported up to.    Also, too many silly and wasteful directives from senior management which have almost nothing to do with the actual business at hand, but seem to justify the company's fees paid to consulting companies

headline: Middle Office
pros: Good benefits, work life balance, strong team culture
cons: Poor compensation scheme , poor bonus, poor salary increment

headline: Abusive, Unstable, and Archaic
pros: Great HR team, competitive pay, and compensation packages.
cons: Archaic management structure, unstable environment where most employees have been laid off at least once in their career, managers are either completely hands off or utilize bullying and threatening to keep you in line, and the company fosters a culture of siloing working and not utilizing collaboration between different teams to get work completed. This company is also extremely process and ticket based to a fault. Many times you need to submit a ticket to submit a ticket only to have it rejected for no reason at all. It took me over a year to get an email address set up (yes an email address) and by the time I did it was on the wrong domain. I was then instructed to just deal with it because it was less work to deal with it than to get it fixed. This company lays people off frequently. I have been laid off 3 times already, my manager is on his 4th position in the company, and the fear of being laid off causes people to silo information out of fear of losing their jobs. The company is based off of reactionary decisions because employees aren't around long enough to see their projects through and many of these projects are aimed at innovating the company. I have worked at other financial companies and some are direct competitors to Barclays and I am shocked that Barclays is even still in business. Their practices and management structure have put them seriously behind the competition. At this point Barclays is surviving on its name brand alone and even in that case the Barclays name is being tarnished by bad management and executive decisions.

headline: Great culture

Crowded seating with no privacy or space at all.  Base pay compensation was comparable, but bonuses were low.

Good Benefits - Share save scheme, Annual Leave Entitlement and Staff discount etc
Good group of people to work with.
Canteen on site.
Advocates of charity and support fundraising.
Supportive of staff's external commitments.
cons:
Office politics - hard work doesn't always get noticed and often promotions based on who you are friends with. 
Managers have favourites who are selected for the best opportunities.
Stressful with a heavy unmanageable workload.
Absent managers that are awful team leaders and do nothing to address concerns. Dont really listen to you, There is a staff opinion survey but concerns raised are brushed under carpet - shut up and put up.

headline: Director
pros:
+ Some good colleagues are left, even though their number is shrinking every day as the best are leaving
+ As it used to have a great franchise, there are some rests of it, though not many left.
cons:
- No strategy, the company acts as a headless chicken.
- Weak leadership that is only driven by politics instead of company best interest.
- No accountability in the management bench. Those destroying the most value seem to be the ones getting the promotions 
- No career management. Employees destiny is solely dependent on direct management. So if you are not happy with your manager, your only option is to leave the company. HR is either non-existent, powerless or incompetent. 
- Tribal mentality. Senior management said on several occasions that who you know is more important on career promotion than performance. This translates into networks based on the nationality.
- Sub-standard financial package, lack of transparency, honesty and meritocracy

headline: Bullying is in the DNA
pros:
HQ offices are fantastic, great canteen and amazing views.
Exciting environment while things are fine.
cons:
Bullying and harassment are daily fare. 
Salaries are at the low end of the market. long hours are expected and extra efforts are quickly forgotten.
Raising the point that the workload is unreasonable and leads to long hours meets a 'work smarter not harder'.
I experienced first hand bullying and harassment and know of two other former colleagues having been  treated the same way without HR or upper management moving a finger.
I raised a case with HR before resigning and it was only met by denial.
Not a collaborative environment, a lot of back stabbing and politics. 
Brown nosing gets you farther than talent.

headline: VP Software
pros: Laid back environment, smart people, relatively progressive for a bank when it comes to technology.
cons:
All of the pros varies greatly from group to group, and from position to position.
It's a giant bank, and as such you have a lot of bureaucracy, and an environment where patches of mediocrity thrive. Also the pay is rather sad relatively speaking. No bonuses at all. Which tends to correlate with apathy and mediocrity.
IT is housed in the saddest excuse for an office building at 1301 Ave of the americas. It's a sad building. With a sad staff. It's really very very sad. The building that is. The employees are not sad. But the building is.

headline: Great Place for Technology (Technology Center in McKinney, TX)
pros: Competitive salaries (sort of - you can always find better salaries in technology elsewhere). Great benefits, including medical, dental, matching 401K. Very talented technology workers. These are some of the smartest techies you will ever work with. Very laid back open office, collaborative culture.
cons: Barclays, as one of the big banks who have been fined continuously by regulators, have had to make some cuts. Tech workers are being re-located to Delaware, the UK and India. Sad, but when the company loses its technology visionaries to other companies, and things get financially challenging for the board, cuts easily find its tech areas. Wrong focus, in my opinion. Also, so much politics with an old UK financial institution.

headline: Declining business

headline: Bring back the good old days

cons:
Like most large financial organisations, there is lack of clear direction from top-down across business units, which dilutes the efforts of teams to deliver standards across the group.
The working environment is also much weaker as people and positions are moved to other UK or offshore sites, leaving the London employees harder to find and cohere with

headline: Toxic workplace
pros: you get staff loans at a discounted rates
cons:
1. Subjective appraisal system: you can be downgraded in your performance because you are introverted. 
2. Nitpicky and irrational bosses who call you in for a performance review within first two weeks on the job because of "not contributing in meetings". 
3. Low salaries contributing to high incidences of staff defrauding customers or engaging in unethical work practices. 
4. Unprincipled work colleagues who gang up and conspire against someone to get rid of them. 
5. Overlapping salaries: some staff in lower grades earn more than staff in higher grades thus demotivating people from getting a promotion.
6. Appalling work conditions at branches: torn carpets, worn out seats, broken down ventilators' claustrophobic back offices.
7. Egotistical management team that looks down on subordinates and suppresses them
8. Exploitation of lead generators (LGs): deprived of travel and call allowance and hence sometimes have to borrow money from the branch manager in order to visit customers

headline: Personal Banker

headline: A real grind meant for short term employment
pros:
1) Open 24 hours so you can choose to work overnight, normal hours, or swing shift
2) You have the opportunity to earn significantly more through bonuses and overtime
3) Your duties are straightforward so no real surprises each day
4) Decent benefits/retirement
5) Decent pay for the work you do
6) They try to cultivate a cool vibe by doing stuff like doing community service and playing games during shifts.
cons:
1) A lot of emphasis on productivity.  Your job is to look at applications and determine if a person is credit worthy and how much they should be lent.  You also take phone calls from customers needing a credit limit increase or a reconsideration on their denied application.  You have to process a certain number of apps/calls each hour and it can be a real grind keeping up with the standards.

2) The hours suck.  You'll most likely have to work 4 days a week for 10 hours.  The extra day off is cool but the 10 hour shifts suck.

3) There's little room for growth.  If you stick around for a while you may get job as a quality review person whose job is to make sure analysts make good lending decisions.  You may also get a manager title but there are few of those jobs available.

4) Short lunches/breaks.  You get two 15 minute breaks and a 30 minute lunch.  I'd rather have an hour lunch and no breaks but maybe that's just me.

5) It's a real grind.  The number of apps/calls you have to work is no joke.  It's a little better if you work night shift as there's less calls which usually take longer to work than apps.  You most likely won't hit productivity standards your first few months there.  Luckily you have a 3 month grace period to get things together.

headline: It Pays to Suck Up

cons: Unfortunately, incomplete employees were easily elevated to VP and even SVP status just because they sucked up to the right people.  I literally was spoon feeding my VP information on how to do her job and it was absolutely frustrating.  Whenever I thought I would be next in line for more responsibility or a better title, I was passed on by the cheekier and talkative alternative that had no idea what they were doing.

headline: Never Ever going back
pros: Nothing i could think of......
cons:
Worst place to work for. Importance will be given to the consultants. If you are full time or contractor  than you are your own. You have to work for the consultants, work for them while they are gone for long lunches or left for the day or working from on Fridays / Mondays. They will take all the credits and you will look like a full. You might think to talk to your manager or his/her manager but it won’t help as I did many times. There were 6 employees in my team and then 5 left in 4 months due to this consulting firm and then I end up leaving too. I have seen 12+ people left in 6 months (including contractors) and Barclays absolutely did nothing to improve the work environment but hiring more consultants from this firm :)

And yes don’t forget long hours, weekend work and lot of politics. 

Have you ever noticed that Barclays recruiters will call you/ email you for new jobs and you wondered why? Well no one wants to work there and more number of people leave Barclays. Don’t believe me then, you can ask anyone who already worked there and left :)

NEVER EVER JOIN THEM

headline: Too much leadership churn
pros: Good company to work for, can work my contracted hours and not be expected to work in excess. Freedom to work from home whenever I like.
cons: No training budget, hiring ban so cannot move internally, leadership churns too often, bank has no clear vision, bonuses in Barclaycard take into account faults of investment bankers (reducing the amount available).

headline: Good Bank

headline: Technically challenging for all the wrong reasons
pros: Good benefits, free parking , remote working, Nice decor gives a Google-esque feel
cons:
Technical leadership seems to be waiting for a redundancy payout, so therefore have no interest in newer technologies. Poor man management skills seem to be ingrained at all levels.

Management seems very old school with rank trumping technical ability, and technical ability not being considered important in most cases. 

I would find it difficult to recommend Barclays as an employer to anyone who is technically minded, as other companies in the area are far more innovative and supportive, therefore technical roles are filled by those who are drawn to big business rather than techincal innovation.

I can honestly say I cannot see a set of events that would make be consider a role at Barclays.

headline: Barclays
pros: Barclays has a great culture with fairly flat hierachy as well as intelligent, helpful and friendly people. While not perfect, systems work reasonably well. At the junior level, analysts are also given opportunities to further their skills and have access to senior management.
cons: Compensation is poor and management is constantly cutting headcount, resulting in overworked staff with low morale.

headline: Assistant manager
pros: lot of opportunities, mobility, good starting point for freshers
cons: There needs to be more work life balance, otherwise a good company to work

headline: Managers play favorites
pros: Benefits, 6% match on 401K, good insurance options, wellness programs, and comfortable office space
cons: Limited opportunity for growth, promotions are not based on merit but managerial preference, cliquish work environment, and somewhat of a hostile work place. Management doesn't have a clue what they are doing and often times get in their own way for progress. Very little accountability or desire to assist on another. Technology is dated, salaries are below standard for industry, and progress occurs at a snails pace, if at all.

headline: Empty Promises
pros: Some Quality people.  New CEO desperately trying to right the ship

headline: Mixed
pros:
Salary and benefits
Flexible working
People - very bright, work well under pressure, consistently positive can-do attitudes, teamwork 
Leadership - some are inspiring and the team has a strong desire to remove obstacles for people and embed values, there are actions in progress to improve things and visible actions being taken to make it happen.
cons:
Very inefficient I.T. that doesn't keep up with the pace and volume of work
Hugely hierarchical approach leading to things being harder to get done than they should be (leadership are working on this though)
Lack of opportunity for progression (again being worked on), can feel like promotion is based on how successfully you massage egos over ability.
Lots of middle management and too many people doing the same thing.
The amount of Senior stakeholders involved in decisions teams beneath them slows things up and can cause inefficiency.

pros:

cons:

cons: Like many big institutions, how you play the game with appraisals and such seems to be more important than how you do your day job. Low chance of promotion if not interested in leveraging the appraisal process. Senior management making poor decisions.

headline: Senior Java developer

headline: Constant Change
pros: Work/Life balance is good. At certain levels (depending on relationship with managers), you are allowed to manage your own work very freely. Non front office positions allow great possibility for flexible working arrangements. There are some great people in all divisions, but you're lucky if you work with them. Because of the constant upheavals, there are chances to quickly progress if you are in the right place/time or know the right people.
cons: Constant change. If you have been with the firm long term at all, you've likely seen several different heads of your group/department (and the CEO too). Management that stays long term usually are due to their own short comings. Certain areas, atmosphere is ridiculously political and almost soap opera like. Expect many more changes to come, once it's over, I think the firm will be a great place, but who knows when.

headline: Moderately fulfilling
pros: Good people and some good bankers
cons: Too small a cog in the global wheel

headline: Internship
pros: Work on real projects, good internship scheme, meet lots of executives
cons: If you get a bad manager, it could affect your offer

headline: Not many growth opportunities @ BSS!
pros: Company policies are employee friendly
cons:
Favoritism among Senior Management for promotions

headline: Lots of good reasons to work for Barclays - still some way to go
pros: There is a lot of great work going on at Barclays around diversity, building people's careers internally and flexible working - these are all really positive things.  Barclays also has some really big pockets of innovation i.e. the Digital Eagles that we see advertised on the TV where there are some really engaged employees who are given autonomy and licence to do great things for their local communities - so there are a lot of exciting things that make me proud to be employed at Barclays.
cons: The leadership have traditionally got to where they have by being technical experts, not people leaders.  They won't develop these skills overnight and many really struggle with the human elements of leadership.  We have some great leaders and line managers but they are still not yet in the majority and some of them are hidden underneath leaders who have more alpha and technical traits than they do people leadership traits.

headline: Vice President equities
pros: The only pro about working for Barclays is that my colleagues are a great group of people. When I say colleagues, I specifically mean my peers.
cons: Lack of room for growth. Consistently poor raises and increasingly bad bonus numbers. Red tape all over the place. Incredibly bureaucratic. Compliance driven. Big titles at the top still paying themselves handsomely while they explain poor compensation to employees by complaining about how bad the year was. YEAR AFTER YEAR. There is a traffic jam at the exit doors, people running for the hills left and right. They preach values but it's all a facade.

headline: customer service

headline: Bureacratic
pros: Although there were some great former Lehman employees left, it was becoming fewer and fewer
cons:
The firm has become so bureaucratic, everything has to go to a never ending series of committees.  Nothing gets decided in the committee and finally when things gets to a crisis point something ends up having to go to the IB CEO in order for a decision to be made.  MDs have no decision making ability.

There was very much a Lehman vs Barclays culture which was resolved by either Lehman people being made redundant or taking voluntary redundancy.

Toxic, toxic work environment.

headline: PBA Case Handler
pros: I liked the hours which were 7am to 2.30pm weekends off with a weekly pay but this job was through an agency hence the excellent wage of £18,000 per anum with the offer to do overtime.
cons:
A very pressurising job with targets to be achieved daily. Could get quite stressful at times.
Not always supported when in need of help and advice regarding the job.
It is quite a difficult job to do as you are the decision maker and have to investigate all upgrades in order to come to the right conclusion. You undergo 6 weeks training then have to pass accreditation and as I said not always the help and support when you need it.

Poor morale with most staff unsure whether they will be employed still by the end of the year.

headline: Still trying to find way
pros: nice HQ, still some solid products
cons: Lot of dead weight still in equity division, turnover in number of divisions has left thin bench, management doesn't seemed committed to make investments needed to compete for US share

headline: Could be good but highly dependent on what group you are placed in
pros: You get to work in financial capital of the world and there were are lot of activities outside of work to get involved with. You do learn things, that could be of use.
cons: You are at the mercy of the group you are placed in which will either make or break your experience here. As much as HR will try, you will not always be placed in teams that will be of benefit to you or allow you to learn. This was really apparent as half of the interns on my intake were practically doing nothing and were stuck in limbo whilst the other half were actually given the opportunity to get on with things. This is primarily down to the way the bank is set up and operates.

headline: Good company
pros: Nice people, nice tools, nice environment
cons: It's a huge companies, everything is not always possible

headline: Barclays
pros: Despite what the media say, the place is genuinely a great place to work
cons: Thanks to few people who have a lack of conduct awareness, the Bank's reputation has been tainted. It will take some time to regain the trust of consumers.

headline: Great
pros: Great working full time with Barclays
cons: Branch opening times are long they could be made shorter.

headline: Summer experience
pros: Sophistiacted organisation with a friendly working environment. People are very willing to teach, mentor and assist you in doing your tasks.
cons: limited career development opportunities and not a very dynamic environment. Feels somewhat bureaucratic. Pay is not very substantial at the early stages of the career.

headline: Long way to go before entering the 21st Century
pros: Private Medical Insurance, flexibilty in some parts of the business, CSR and Diversity. Barclays sponsors Pride in London, and they are very committed to forwarding the LGBT agenda, as well as the Disability Agenda, particularly around Mental Health.
cons: Hierarchical, too large, ancient technology and systems, too much process, not enough autonomy or flexibility. A lot of outdated thinking and working practices, and too much uncertainty and change.

headline: Managing Director
pros: Good people.  Smart.  Desire to succeed
cons: Revolving door of management becomes a distraction.  constantly changing strategy is damaging to the brand

headline: Generally a good place to work
pros:
Plenty of internal opportunities and training available  
A supportive and generally friendly environment
Excellent pay and benefits
Not 'micro managed'
cons:
Lots of departments offshore 
Increased bureaucracy - as with any large organisation 
Some systems can be extremely slow 
Occasionally the culture can be quite 'cliquey'

headline: Intership
pros: Great experience! I interned two summers in a row and gained awesome experince from marketing related projects.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Strategy changes
pros: Global investimentos banking company, good people
cons: Strategy changes quite often and internak communication could be better

headline: Financial analyst
pros: Good Culture, Good opportunity, etc
cons: Disappointment in management level service

headline: IB Associate
pros: Good culture internally. Quality People with a non-cutthroat environment (though one does work hard - 80-90 hours/week - as expected).
cons: Inability to retain top-talent due to uncertainty around investment banking business trajectory. Emphasis on cost-cutting and downsizing has killed morale in even traditionally strong business verticals.

headline: Technology Analyst intern
pros: Great work environment. People very friendly
cons: The overall structure of the internship was bad

headline: Good place to work overall
pros:
Decent market share so plenty of opportunities
Some very clever people we work with, driving some big (positive) change in the bank
Good opportunities to progress if you build a good network and reputation
cons:
Run very stretched in terms of resource - very cost focused
Pay lags peers
Have lost some good people over last few years to competition

headline: Should get better from here
pros: Some great smart motivated people work here.
cons: Bureaucracy has gotten worse over the years. Technology used is outdated and definitely negatively impacts productivity.

headline: Learning and Development Manager
pros: Many diverse opportunities across the company
cons: Lots of change within the company

headline: Private Banking Executive
pros: Great exposure. Lots of work - very good to learn.
cons:
Company doesn't value analysts. 
Your compensation is not related with the management of the book that you actually help managing

headline: Good but not great
pros: work life balance is good
cons: renumeration is bad. Bonuses varies a lot between divisions. For IB, it's not great

headline: working environment
pros: They were good to work for
cons: There were no downside for me

headline: Old fashioned and out of date
pros: Great place to work if your good at office politics, are highly pedantic and love processes and it systems from the last century
cons: 325 year old processes, takes forever with 100's of levels of sign off to get even basic tasks done. No vision, strategy or leadership. Organisation is like something from the last century

headline: Confused
pros: Some great people in individual roles
cons: Very clique, small minded, over duplication of roles

headline: Culture needs a lot of work
pros: Barclays offers competitive base pay and benefits but their bonuses are slim.   You are surrounded by intelligent colleagues who like to hear themselves talk so you will learn a lot.  There is opportunity for travel but budgets for travel and training tend to be tight.
cons: Barclays has a competitive culture, risk averse management and as a subsidiary of UK parent, training and other resources are lacking.  Be prepared to work long hours and have little show for it at the  end of the year.  They are very slow to promote within and the buttoned-down culture offers little by way of diversity of opinion.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Quick advancements. Opportunities to learn and grow within the organization. Lateral movements around teams improves skill sets and reduces monotony.
cons: Work can be monotony and highly demanding extra hours. Overtime is not paid for.

headline: Satisfied
pros: Nice work culture, good pay
cons: Management is average and not people oriented

headline: Well paying call centre
pros: good starting pay for role,  good share plan options, good support
cons: minimal overtime hours, limited wages and bonus,

headline: Analyst
pros: Its a good company to work with.
cons: Cons still to figure out.

headline: Sales Manager
pros: Inclusive, progressive people focused organisation.
cons: May be in need of some fresh blood and ideas.

headline: Graduate Analyst
pros: - Learn from big architecture
cons: - Lagging behind cutting edge technologies

headline: Solid, growth organization
pros: Growth company with entrepreneurial spirit.  Strong management team and flat organization.  Great people to work with. The team is mostly centered in Wilmington, DE so there is a strong face-to-face meeting culture.  It is nice to have the backing of a large bank, but have the feel of a small organization.
cons: As a growth company, there are more goals than people to achieve them.  Barclaycard has been slow to hire to ramp up for growth.  It is currently outside the top 5 issuers within the US, so budgets are smaller than those of the larger organization.

headline: Good bank
pros:
Atmosphere is good
People are great
cons: Burocreaucy is too much. It systems not completely aligned.

headline: PCB
pros: Well known name that opens doors and gives you access to extensive client network. Good workforce, your peers will stand by you.
cons: Very hierarchical and difficult to progress beyond Director.  Even up to that level difficult as people don't move on and there are forever hiring freezes.

headline: Graduate Analyst
pros: Good initial training period which lasts roughly four weeks, consisting of tutorials, presentations and interactive games.
cons:
Poor management of the scheme
Roles are mundane and not properly evaluated in terms of their suitability for graduates
No guidance and career progression advice
High turnover of graduates - Only about 50% remained at Barclays after two years.

headline: Great.
pros: Good people, good work environment and work life balance.  Great culture committed to helping communities and volunteering.  Management is supportive.
cons: Need to do a better job at compensating talent and promoting good people.  Too much focus on cost cutting and not enough focus on developing talent within the organization.

headline: Great.
pros: Good people, good work environment and work life balance.  Great culture committed to helping communities and volunteering.  Management is supportive.
cons: Need to do a better job at compensating talent and promoting good people.  Too much focus on cost cutting and not enough focus on developing talent within the organization.

pros: good opportunities if you work hard
cons: sometimes not all good work is rewarded

headline: Busy
pros: Co-workers are great. I love the work, for full time employees there is a possibility for advancement.
cons: Management can be clueless. It can be hard to get direction.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good work-life balance , great benefits and flexible work hours
cons: Poor bonus and role based promotion process

headline: Good job

cons: They need to be able to make the difference to the treatment of the employees and the workforce and be more effective and patient

headline: Compliance Analyst
pros:
- Friendly, collaborative and supportive working environment
- Fantastic work life balance - genuine 9 - 5pm
- Genuine commitment to long term merits of good business decisions 
- Respected household institution - good brand on CV
- Invests in personal development through MBA leadership style training academies
- Diverse international environment - plenty of opportunities to find your own interest group
cons:
- Can be bureaucratic - lots of form filling and democratic processes for small initiatives 
- Bad IT help desk - takes ages to get help/solutions
- Too many cooks in back office resulting in lack of ownership - lots of 'its not my job' to do this

headline: Good Place to work
pros: Good technology stack, career growth nurtured, open door management policy
cons: Less compensation, less ability to move in different teams and roles

headline: Good company to work with

Leader in Banking Industry

cons:
Red tape does exists to get the work done.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good for career progressin. Internal mobility options. Work life balance depending on the team. Pays better than other compitititors
cons: Political, hard to navigate around it. Frequent re-structuring causes a lot of stress to people, also it seems like it lacks vision.

headline: Dump yard of mediocrity
pros: This is a place where careers go to die. If you want a place to park your career and come into work and do nothing this is the perfect place for doing that
cons:
In my ten years career, I have never worked with such a bunch of talentLESS, stupid people. Most of the people in Barclays have no expertise in their respective fields. Most people are unaware of the latest technologies, the latest best practices and are still stuck in the year 2000. 

Meeting after meetings about the most trivial thing, meetings to decide meetings, meetings to prepare power points, meeting to decide everything. In one of the meetings I was in, it took 26 members of the leadership team 1 hour to decide to add an additional column in an excel spreadsheet. (I am not joking) 

Most of my colleagues and managers are unfit for jobs outside of Barclays. Their skill sets are out dated and most of them are just plain stupid. No wonder some employees review Barclays as a "great place to work" and "fast paced".

headline: Analyst
pros: Flexible working hours, range of business units to develop in

headline: First Company

headline: Stuck in a rut

Not many at the moment

Permanent head count freeze

cons: Very tight budget restrictions make simple processes very hard. You will enjoy the role if you have a good boss who is open to change. If not it will be tough. Whilst internal mobility is possible, promotions are rare.

headline: Investment in systems would make a huge difference
pros: Good opportunities to move internally across a wide range of financial services businesses, from credit cards to asset management, all part of an internationally recognised brand
cons: Barclays is over 300 years old and many of the systems and processes have been cobbled together over time as different businesses have been brought together. It can sometimes be an uphill battle to retrieve relatively straight forward cuts of data.

headline: Neutral
pros: Atmosphere was positive for a while and fun coworkers

headline: Decent
pros: Easy to move up if you are a "Chosen One," otherwise you will go relatively unnoticed. Senior management tends to "get it" and says the right thing with a proper vision.
cons: Too hierarchical at times, can take longer than needed in order see projects through to delivery. Middle management doesn't carry out the messages from the top. Though internal moves are "highly encouraged" it is difficult to pursue.

headline: Decent
pros: Easy to move up if you are a "Chosen One," otherwise you will go relatively unnoticed. Senior management tends to "get it" and says the right thing with a proper vision.
cons: Too hierarchical at times, can take longer than needed in order see projects through to delivery. Middle management doesn't carry out the messages from the top. Though internal moves are "highly encouraged" it is difficult to pursue.

headline: Ok
pros: Great people to work with, lots of investment being put into the business

headline: Downhill.
pros: Big company so opportunities to move around.  Very well regarded for strong technical procedures.
cons: Annual bonus has virtually disappeared and not worth the hoops you have to jump through to get it.  Also the next scandal that 99.9% of staff had nothing to do with affects us all.

headline: Restructuring for the sake of it
pros: Areas such as Barclaycard are genuinely innovating and really interesting areas to be involved in and there is a genuine focus on diversity.
cons: I should have seen the writing on the wall when my manager "left" before I'd joined. 3 months later my new manager took redundancy, then Antony Jenkins departed as CEO and my area was no longer required. That is a personal experience in one team but on the whole I have greater issues with the way Barclays is run. They had a vision built on values and then a new chairman came in an it was all change. Everything that had been done for the last 3 years to change the bank into a socially responsible bank had to be undone. It just feels like change for the sake of change. Share price isn't going up so lets make a bunch of people redundant and see if that works. As for the values... they are printed on every wall but you only have to stand outside the lift bank at 1CP one morning at 8.45 to see that staff don't live the values. They're a statement of what Barclays wants the world to think they stand for.... not what really happens.

headline: Analyst
pros: Challenging environment with los of smart people.

headline: Nice. More like a college campus for Freshers

The management team is not diverse t like they tell you .everything they tell you in orientation is a lie. The issue with checks being wrong and the will not fix it..IT IS A BANK!!! No  promotional opportunities unless you in the click

headline: Challenging place to feel comfortable

cons: Some working environments (office spaces) are not very comfortable. This isn't a place to work if you are looking for job security. Strategy changes frequently which can lead to anyone being surplus to requirements. Redundancy benefits are not what they used to be and notice is not paid in lieu so you won't get paid if you move straight into another role.

headline: Great Technology Centre
pros:
- Great level of technical skill
- Friendly people
- Interesting investment banking projects (algo trading, ...)
- You can get promoted to Vice President even as an individual contributor (programmer) without, e.g., leading a team
cons: - It is easier to get a promotion by applying to another team within the company compared to waiting in you current team.

headline: VP
pros: People are great. Strong brand loyalty despite cut backs and an optimism for the future and what the new CEO can do for the company.
cons: There is a great opportunity for Barclays to invest and enhance their technology infrastructure, which would make it a better and less frustrating place to work. The IT support is also lacking.

headline: Just another big bank

cons: Politics, horrid systems and intranet, forced distribution of employee reviews which leads to low morale and unfair and poor compensation

headline: Great company to work for

cons: My group has just as many managers as staff members...that's way too much.

headline: Uncertain future
pros:
Good work life balance. Actually more balance and less work :)
If one is looking for a zero growth govt. job then Barclays is the one (except for job security).
cons:
No transparency in rating system.
No transparency in proving future roadmap.
Very unstable: (1) Optimistically hires too many people only to realise that budget is not there and this leads to a lot of firing
                           (2) Constant talks of selling of captive to some Indian service company (TCS, Infy, etc). Already, RTB has been sold to TCS.

headline: BTCI, Barclays IT captive in India
author_position: Assistant Vice President In Technology Services
pros: Pay package is good, year end bonus matches market standards
cons:
No job stability at all. Huge job cuts which happens atleast twice a year as part of cost cutting. Frequent managment changes/strategy changes leading to lack of clarity and indecision on what to achieve and how to achieve as a team/business unit/company. And as a result no tangible results and all the work/effort goes into the drain.
No work life balance at all.. For example 5 people would be the head count in a team where the actual need is 15.
Work ambience is not upto standards, outdates machines, crowded office space etc

headline: Barclaycard US internship program
pros: Relaxed Environment. Great support and advice from upper level staff. Great culture. Really amazing internship program, fun events and lectures.

I asked for more and was given some, but not enough to fill my time. Felt a bit like they were underestimating my skills, or they didn't trust me.

headline: Barclays
pros: Barclays has a well established brand name.  Their image has been hit with several bruises from various legal, and ethical scandals (Libor setting, FX..).  Fortunately, during the past few years they have made a concerted effort to drive a "values" program into its workforce.  They seem to finally be back on track and having outstanding lawsuits put to rest.
cons: As Wall Street firms go through the business cycle you can expect periods of hiring and downsizing.  At Barclays the turnover is significantly higher than their competitors.  They lack long term vision, and go after the "low hanging fruit" opportunities.  These business are usually short lived and they downsize the group right after the market contracts.  Its a company that is involved in many business, but few that are stable and growing.

headline: Horrible, Horrible, Horrors
pros: NoNe, none, none....none, none at all! It's a pretty nerve-racking work environment.
cons: They do not pay anyone on time - folks in the Henderson, NV have waited weeks and weeks to get paid - No practical training to use for your job position. The lie they make folks belief is that you are an Analyst, NO you are a Call Center Worker! The company tricks the local government that they are helping bring jobs to their city when in fact Barclaycard uses people and takes advantage of folks trying to make an honest living. This in turn makes a person's situation trying to earn a decent and honest living left to fend for themselves to get paid.

headline: Marketing Department - Hierarchical, Political, Old Fashioned, Command And Control Culture
pros: Lots of protection from HR if your a poor performer. Difficult to get sacked even if you physically threaten or harass people or go to the gym or shopping instead of actually working in the office. So great for useless people as long as you can con enough people to get hired in the first place.
cons:
Very top down structure with micromanagement from very top level. Patronage from the top more important than skill. Therefore it is very political. Job is more about sucking up to right people than doing right thing for customers. So talented people end up leaving and incompetent people are put in charge of areas they have no experience in. Department is laughing stock and subject of jokes from business areas.

Pay is below average and working hours are stupid. Calls and meetings often scheduled after normal working hours and can go on until 21:00 or 22:00. So-called commitment to work-life balance is a joke. No one believes anything senior management say about caring about work-life.

No connection between company values and the actual culture of Marketing Department.

headline: Vice President
pros: Too many people & little work - so work life balance is good.
cons:
Too much fat in the organization. Despite rhetoric from the management, they haven't made the hard choices that need to be made to realign the business to the new operating reality in the post-crisis era. 
People at the mid-to-senior levels more interested in "clipping coupons" and making sure the up & coming high performers are pushed out - to protect their own cushy jobs. An MD routinely makes about 5% of total revenue of the desk (not 5% of profits, but 5% of revenues). There are usually 2-3 MDs on a desk. 
Very much a revolving door for senior level management positions in the investment bank. 
Bad morale. At least half of my group will leave if they get a job elsewhere, even with a paycut. 
To move up the hierarchy, one needs to play the politics well. That's all that matters.

headline: A huge improvement needed to be an employer of choice
pros: Decent benefit package and in theory a wide array of options to move around the company.
cons:
Horrific processes which make no sense and do not seem to be documented - everything moves from one committee to another committee for weeks before the client sees any feedback.

Despite the company saying that performance reviews are not done on a bell curve, they are. It is essentially favouritism of management as to where you get placed independent of your actual achievements.

Clients are on very old systems and platforms and there is a huge amount of inertia to change in case things go wrong. I really feel like the company is being left behind by competitors old and new right now, as it seems more concerned with internal meetings then helping clients.

headline: Technology Dept. - No sense of direction
pros:
Note: These observations are from the perspective of a developer working in Singapore's Technology department.
- Competitive pay
- [Depends heavily on your team] low workload - more time for personal development projects
- You get to work with people with experiences from many other banks as people move a lot between different financial institutions.
cons:
Note: These observations are from the perspective of a developer working in Singapore's Technology department
- No long term policy in tech department: if business head changes -> tech policy changes, if new architect joins in ->  tech policy changes, Barclays gets fined and CEO changes - tech policy changes, your team moves under a new director as per bank's streamlining initiative -> tech policy changes, men's room on level 9 runs out of toilet paper -> tech policy changes. You may think that I am exaggerating, but there was a point when we started betting how long will it take for the new "revolutionary" idea to be scrapped.
- Talent retention is not a priority in a place which has no long term policy

headline: Trapping Employees that want to leave!!!!!
pros: Don't have to work hard, place is pretty laid back, and most people have given up
cons: Comp is low compared to other banks.  New hires get 30% more than current employees, but will stay flat after they join.  Bonuses pushed back to end of Feb, paid in March.  Have to give 90 days notice to quit as a VP, so you are basically trapped.  If you quit after bonus is paid, you leave in June, and the new place pays you 50% of a bonus.  Leave in June, you get almost no bonus at next place.  The entire company is filled with people that want to leave and cant, so they just sit around and do nothing

headline: Low moral

Ability to work from home
Casual dress as Radbroke
cons:
Promotions are hard to come by. A role has to open before you can be promoted/get a raise

headline: Good bank to work for!!
pros:
+ Great people, who do care about making a difference and very customer focused.
+ Great place to make a career especially in one of the main head offices.
+ Good employee benefits, pension, life assurance, share-purchase, share-save, etc.
+ Good management and willing to support your development.
cons:
- Lots of changes can mean the branch retail sector is not currently the best area to be in, can be very one step career focus unless you are willing to go to a head office location.
- Salary could be improved, especially within some roles other companies pay better.

headline: Indian counterpart of management is highly political
pros:
Salary. PERIOD 
Customer service is somewhat good they try and listen u can approach anyone at senior management but olb sucks to its very core..i have worked.for both departments.... I am a current employee serving notice period...
cons:
Here we go:-
*too many changes in internal management 
*worst transport drivers never reach pickup location on time and prefer rash driving 
*all they care about is meeting their cost matrix, they would try and meet it on the cost of customer experience (for example someone would disconnect a call right away if they cannot think of a rationale or argument), 
*feedback is not appreciated, i tell u how this works they would ask to present ur opinion im a candid manner and then they would use it against u 
*one just cannot disagree,  you have to b a "yes" servant in order to grow 
*if.they do not like u be ready for a destructive feedback 
*incompetent mangers in olb in terms of process and most of it all in terms of respecting  someone.. 
*this one is a bit personal, when i joined barclays i thought of it as a big company but it's been 2 years now,  u would get better exposure and work environment in a reputef domestic call centre, if u know what i mean 
*one can check the facebook page and read customer reviews and they'll find out how hollow this street giant is.......

headline: Great place to work, albeit too many changes
pros: Current I am still employed with the firm. Its a great place to work and where the bosses are flexible, responsible and listen to you concerns. There is a distinct lack of political issues at the trenches which is great as we don't have to fight politics all the time. Every team is serious and works together well with other teams on any issues without too much finger pointing or blaming culture. All in all, its a great place to work provided you are in the right team. Salary is good as per most Banks.
cons: Too many structural changes every 1 to 2 years and many which people could not really understand other than a short focus of saving costs, but it appears to be a trend in every Bank in the world. From what I've heard, some teams works ridiculously long hours and have micro managing bosses, which even though highlighted, really nothing was done to help them. In Asia, sometimes Asian-cultured employees are overlooked and Western-cultured employees are promoted or get more opportunities.

headline: Recruitment
pros: Friendly work environment. Very professional. High work ethics with some people... Whatever the number of good people still left behind.
cons:
Technology is stuck in time. Still stuck to desktops from 1998. It's a iPad world. Need to upgrade to laptops.

You would find people with some odd hierarchy politics and power hungry egos lingering around in each department.

headline: Great Starter Company
pros:
Great company to start your career at if you are in the graduate or internship programs. You are grouped together with a number of people around your age, which made the transition into the corporate world a lot easier. The employee networking events were great too, with a wide variety of attendees typically ranging from analysts to VPs.

The company hires people with similar personalities, which is great because you can make friends easily.
cons:
Limited career growth and lack of internal mobility. I found that HR really did nothing if any issues come across. 

They also need to screen managers better. It's pretty much like Russian roulette when you move to a new group, you either get an understanding and supportive manager, or  you get one of the screamers. 

HR should really listen to their employees and work with them rather against them for internal moves.

pros: If you don't want to work, you can keep your head down and get by for a while; many people were cruising like that.

There's great fear of bugs and no one wants to take responsibility for any new features or development for fear that raising their head above the water line is liable to get it chopped.  As such, the business gets few enhancements and is tremendously frustrated.

headline: The worst experience of my career
pros: Good name on your CV
cons: Too many unnecessary processes and procedures. Extremely political and bulling culture. Very high turnover, pay and promotion structure is not clear.. information systems are not working at all... Spent more time in internal politics rather than serving clients.. The salary package is not competitive at all...

headline: Overall not a bad place to work
pros:
Never a dull moment - some of the antics I have witnessed during my time here have been second to none.  Both by management and colleagues. 

Good name to have on the CV  - have found this has opened up many doors to move to other banking institutions and start ups.

Some areas of the bank are really at the forefront of innovation.  If you are lucky enough to work in one of these areas, you can have a very fulfilling career.
cons:
Too much change - the bank as a whole never appears to be in a steady state.  Strategy, goal, direction and people constantly seem to be changing.  This creates a constant state of fear amongst some colleagues.

Compensation could be better and the policy could be more transparent.  Difficult to determine the link between workplace performance and compensation.

headline: Financial Analyst
