headline: Too many cooks....
pros: People on the front line really want to make a difference for customers and do the right thing. Freedom to move departments (fairly) freely so there's quite a lot of cross dept knowledge.
cons: Top tier management only cares about costs and profit margins. No confidence that they are listening to staff (no matter how often they say they are) who are very knowledgeable. Can be very frustrating.

headline: impending restructuring
pros: Good benefits and training plans
cons: no work-life balance, no strategic investment banking, you always worry about job security

headline: Great for a medium term stint
pros: Great community feel about the place, with all the perks of a big corporate employer (good HR, proper management and development, corporate discounts...). Facilities in new base at Piccadilly Place are second to none. Plenty of room to move if you're ambitious, with different teams hiring all the time.
cons: Pay and benefits aren't great considering the work. This is a broad grade - you may end up with far more complex work than someone on the same wage depending on team

headline: Mortgage advisor
pros: they create a wonderful environment to work,provide great support for one and another.great training and I met lovely people.i love their intergrity, respect for their customers
cons: Working under pressure all the time to meet deadline,

headline: Big corporate
pros: The Bank provides a structured environment with a Nice office environment and a wide circle of colleagues. Lots of training on offer
cons: The bank's appraisal and bonus scheme seemed to be focused on ticking the right boxes rather than delivering any actual value to the organisation. Highly political

headline: Good Paymaster
pros: Professional, good environment, good management, learning oppurtunity
cons: sometime lengthy process, technology, adapt new trends fast

headline: Investment Banking
pros: I-banking at Barclays wasn't as cutthroat as it would be at GS, MS, JPM, or DB.
cons: The pay was worse and the hours still sucked. You also didn't get on the truly interesting or noteworthy transactions.

headline: Barclays
pros: good working environment, good people,
cons: no raise in last 4 years, bad senior management

headline: Manager
pros: Good place to work for and friendly environment. Lots of different roles and benefits. Great building and cheap gym. All in all is ok.
cons: Canteen is a little expensive. There is little or no progression. And a lot politics. Also a lot of roles that are talking but not doing.

headline: Summer Analyst - Hong Kong
pros: Awesome experience, great people and I learned tremendously
cons: Long hours, work life balance is tough

headline: Company
pros: Good company to work, Great work life balance, Training opps.
cons: Wont get any international travel

headline: VP
pros: Broader exposure with freedom to do whatever you want to do.
cons: poor leadership, lack of vision. people are paid way above the industry average so literally no attrition in certain areas. worst technology teams you can think of.

headline: Good opportunities for BAs
pros: Good exposure, opportunities in the company. Can prove fortune for really ambitious employees
cons: Poor decision making at Senior management and not transparent enough.

headline: Slightly inefficient
pros:
In some departments (such as Technology) there isn't very much pressure.
People working there were friendly and many of them were very competent.
cons: Some processes very were inefficient and seemed artificially made more complicated. The company probably has many more employees than it actually needs.

headline: Video department
pros: I worked in the webcast department. Management was good and coworkers were great. The training provided was helpful.
cons: We rotated shifts which was kind of rough. The equipment being used by the department and A/V team wasn't up to date and was buggy which made the job a little more difficult.

headline: barclays
pros: good location being in canary wharf
cons: awful moral and team spirit

headline: Great culture, good progression
pros: Relaxed place to work where you can approach pretty much anyone. Good people and decent remuneration.
cons: Salaries and bonuses have been slightly below market rate in recent years but is improving.

headline: The Barclays Way
pros:
Work with great people
Ability to move within the company
Flexible working hours
cons: No clear goal and change is constant.  Would like to see more commitment to younger employees and more incentive to stay with the firm.

headline: Too british focused, not enough American Independence
pros: Great reputation, diverse businesses, good on site amenities, sought after place to work at; international mobility options
cons: Very focussed on London supervision, not enough independence for New York office to make their own decisions; too many fines; too much senior management turnover; not an e-verified firm

headline: Move to the USA
pros:
flexability
Work life Balance
Department is Respected
cons:
Political
No clear promotion strategy
Methodology Driven

headline: horrible managers
pros: Barclays offers competitive compensation, but you must negotiate that in base from the very beginning and should not expect that to come through during bonus time.
cons: Horrible line managers, many of which have been there so long that they have "checked out" and are there to collect the check.  Little room for personal or professional development and no support from newcomers.

headline: It's been a roller coaster
pros: People are nice.. Good culture , good work life balance
cons: A lot of restructuring , and politics and poor bonus structure

headline: Former Employee
pros: Nice people to work with, high base salary
cons: It can get very busy

headline: Barclays
pros: Very good work life balance. Very liberal HR policies
cons: Careerr growth and control at India center is lacking

headline: Negative attitude towards ex staff.
pros: Company with strong tradition and procedures. A lot of prestige associated with working in Barclays. But prestige does not go beyond the name and the past glory of the bank.
cons: HR team is unfriendly and horrible, creating a lot of damage to the business. They always find reasons why a job cannot be done rather than finding reasons why the job could be done. Collections and recoveries team is another horrible team. No ideas or thought process to work.

headline: Good
pros: Its good place ..new technology and good collegues
cons:
Lomg working hours
Some times can be hectic

headline: Awesome Company
pros:
Provides a lot of opportunity especially internal mobility - locally and regionally.
I was able to get my Green Card through Barclays. They really support their staff if you work well for them.
cons: Its hard to get a VP or Director promotion especially for minority women. There are a lot of leadership layers.

headline: Work
pros: People, Culture, Open, Transparent, leadership. And that's pretty much all I have to say about that
cons: Pay, Regulatory Scrutiny; Lack of automation; Poor teamwork, more interested in competition and politics. And that's pretty much all I have to say sbiut that

headline: Great Group; Good culture
pros: Great culture- intense when it needed to be, goofy at other times
cons: Long hours and bad work life balance

headline: Technology Analyst
pros: Nice Friendly Environment to work in
cons: Not many challenging projects to work on

headline: Financial Control
pros: Nice, genuine and sincere team mates.  Head of Finance is very understanding and tries very hard to promote work-life balances.
cons: Unfortunately, the current market condition does not allow the bank to sustain it's hiring and so a lot of leavers are being replaced by contractors and the future of finance is bleak.

headline: Company going nowhere, continued poor quality of MDs and senior leadership
pros: VP and Director-level staff are good. Salaries are relatively good.  Good work-life balance. Some good work being done, especially in the behavioural economics arena
cons: Poor control environment, blame culture, second-guessing, passive-aggressive organization, quality of MDs is very poor, senior management is not cohesive. Haven't met a single MD who is an inspirational leader in my 8+ years of working there. Indeed the quality of MDs is so poor that other parts of Barclays joke that "he must have come from Wealth" whenever they come across a poor leader . And more often than not, they are right. Past senior leaders have done untold damage to the franchise. Thankfully they have left, but the present management is incapable of repairing the franchise. Needs to grow fast, or shut down. It is  drag on rest of the Group.

headline: Good to work company at the risk of your own
pros: Barclays pays handsome salary. The organisation value for employees. In fact the organisation has good compensation policy for who have been asked to leave the job.
cons: Barclays maintained good values for employees and customers on paper only. Everytime employees feels uncertainty and fear of laying out from the job.

headline: FT employee
pros: Your working hours is the shortest for most of the bank. It is stated in your employment contract that it is 9-5pm
cons: Claims for OT and PH are minimal.If it is your first job, they tend to lower their offer which I think in unethical.

headline: Hierarchical, political, outdated
pros:
- You can work at 10% capacity and no one will notice. 
- Bank makes a lot of money with very little effort. Is not subjected to intense competition like ecommerce etc.  Therefore, if you want an easy job this place is great.
cons:
- Top down. Every decision is made by a decision committee and then handed down to the employees. Very hierarchical. Employees are not encouraged to make decisions or have a sense of ownership. 

- Managers surround themselves with "yes-mens".  Everyone is busy having an ego-trip. As long as you feed the egos, you are good.

- Very poor decision making by the decision committees. Decisions are not based on commercial gains but a host of ego centric factors. Decision committees are staffed by people who can "talk" but are not subject matter experts. These poor decisions are then handed down to the employees for execution who get blamed in the end when the project inevitably ends in failure

- Lot of talk about values but not practised. Be prepared to sacrifice your integrity everyday at this job. Honest and integrity are not encouraged. 

- A normal day consists of making tons and tons of power points, attending meetings and generally talking rubbish. Outdated processes, outdated technology.

headline: VP of technology
pros: Best place to be if you are looking to retire and not do any work.
cons: Excessive bureaucracy and politics. Very few people does any work. Horrible culture. Don't expect to be paid.

headline: VP of technology
pros: Best place to be if you are looking to retire and not do any work.
cons: Excessive bureaucracy and politics. Very few people does any work. Horrible culture. Don't expect to be paid.

headline: Good place to work
pros: smart people with a solid work ethic
cons: sometimes a little stuck in the past when it comes to technology and etiquette around who arrives first and shouldn't leave until your boss leaves, but even this is improving a little

headline: AVP Test Manager
pros:
Very Good starting salary.All fixed . Bonus additional.
Free company transport
Lots of opportunities to learn
Global teams
Better job security as compared to other Investment bank captives, especially if you are a part of BTS - Barclays Testing Services
cons:
Annual hike and bonus is less as compared to other captives
Lots of showcasing and data collection activities which sometimes hampers deliveries 
Beauriocracy is more
Unstable Senior management
Frequent changes in senior management / strategies.
Promotion is difficult , especially in BTS

headline: Barclays review
pros: Good working environment,Growth opportunity,lunch and dinner is free,drop facility at night and even the ambience and overall infrastructure is good.
cons: Salary is not at par with rest of the investment banks,bonus and increment is a bit on lower side.Process is redundant

headline: Quality People
pros: great people to work with
cons: lack of recognition and difficult career progression

headline: Former Employee
pros: Fun work environment.  Casual dress.  Great location.
cons: Poor diversity in leadership.  Very, very bureaucratic.  Agenda set and dominated by UK.

headline: Barclays singapore
pros: Good work life balance and compensation
cons: No job security, less oppotunity in Singapore location

headline: Horrible HR department
pros: your paycheck is usually on time
cons:
finaly paycheck not delivered or direct deposited within 3 business days which is against Nevada laaw
you cant reach anyone in HR
NO Communication with management

headline: Internal controls manager
pros:
Barclays is one of the best employers when it comes to training. I gained immeasurable skills in all areas of my work. 
The training sets me apart when compared to peers from other companies.
cons: Sometimes work life balance was unachievable. This affected me personally and my family

headline: good place to work
pros:
friendly staff
good bonus 
flexible rotas
good sick pay
cons: progression is not as easy as said

headline: Excellent so far
pros: Good salary and benefits, strong focus on personal development and inclusion.
cons: Things move very quickly! And you get thrown into the deep end occasionally so if you are not prepared then you may feel a little overwhelmed.

headline: Good employer with excellent perks
pros:
Better growth opportunities
Flexible work culture
Good market rates
cons: Hard to get big picture

headline: Review of Barlays
pros:
Employee friendly policies
Work life balance
Truly global exposure
Great people around
cons:
More involvement at strategic level for all technology teams 
Can do more 
Alignment and futuristic Planning need to be clear

headline: Culture needs improvement
pros: Intellectual challenging fast paced global
cons: Negative people that are looking after themselves a lot. Should be more team focused.

headline: Technology Analyst intern
pros: Good learning experience for start of career
cons: Exposure and type of work assigned depends on project and people on it. Varies a lot

headline: AVP
pros: Working Culture is too good
cons: it is in the developing phase

headline: Great place to work in, unfortunately long-term career progression doesn't seem too good
pros:
- Nice colleagues with a highly positive working environment
- Jovial environment whereby colleagues are highly comfortable walking around the office and chatting with one another
- High salary for interns, especially amongst the foreign investment banks
- Internship is well-structured, with many opportunities to interact with Senior Management
cons:
- Low salary increment for full-time despite high starting salary
- Non-guaranteed employment after 3 years analyst role
- A lot of outsourcing going on in back-office, hence there might be job security risks

headline: Dynamic environment but salaries below market
pros: Don't expect to earn a bundle but a great blue chip to have on your CV and a very Corporate and grown up environment
cons: Salaries significantly below market but a relatively safe environment. don't expect big bonuses but overall package is in line with banking sector

headline: Morale low
pros: It's a global bank and the departure of Jenkins should reassure some investors and employees in investment bank
cons:
Morale is low
the company lacks vision
Stock is going nowhere
Pay in markets is below peers 
Career progression is also slower than at other banks

headline: Good Place to work for few years
pros:
1. It is a well established bank.
2. Bank has spent lot of money and focus on infrastructure, automation and internal processes which work well like a well-oiled engine. Other banks haven't invested so much in infrastructure and automation processes for employees within company (this is from my personal experience of working in three banks here in Singapore).
3. Good opportunity to learn and grow if you have right people with you.
4. You get the flexible hours of working. I could work from home without any issues and my managers supported it. 
5. Company culture was good for learning and helped me a lot in learning new stuff.
6. Despite of not having a local manager in Singapore for 4 years, I never felt neglected and was well rewarded and taken care of my hard work by my managers in UK. (Previously, my local managers were horrible).
7. Company gives amazing redundancy package and is very generous in giving compensation. They are one of the best and will take care of you financially if your position is being made redundant. 
8. If your position would be made redundant, you could apply for positions in other departments (if available) or other low cost locations if you are willing to locate. 
9. If you are happy to relocate to low cost locations, you could apply to a higher position and get a promotion (provided you are in company for a while).
10. Per Singapore standards, they had ample leave plans (annual leaves, hospitalization, maternity and sabbatical).
11. Healthcare insurance plan was one of the best (includes dental and family).
12. Despite of your experience, if
- you are working hard and your manager recognizes it and fights for you.
Or 
- you have charmed right people enough (despite of not working much), you have better chances of promotion.
You will get promoted. People don't judge you from your experience, they evaluate based on your calibre and strength.
cons:
1. Due to flat hierarchy in designations, it was frustrating to move to next position. When their IT base in Singapore was huge, it was too much competition and less promotions. However, it became better post 2011/2012 once their IT strength was reduced. 
2. When they had Offshore development centre (ODC) concept in Singapore, they had horrible procedures, bureaucracy and horrible leadership. Situation became 100% better once our department directly started reporting to managers in UK. Prior to 2011, some of my local managers were horrible  and manipulative, they had no clue about management and leadership. Managers in UK were much better, at least they were honest and upfront about career and opportunities guidelines. Basically no bullsh*t.
3. They were pay masters 6-7 years back, now their salary does not match with current market scale.
4. IT in Barclays Singapore has reduced almost 90% in past 3-4 years, if you have been offered a position after 2014 either your team is really required here or your position might be retained only for short time. They have major plans to cut down in Singapore. If you are already working there and it has been only 2-3 years, search for a better job with good compensation. Severance package is good, however, only worth waiting for people who have been there for a while.
5. Promotion process is extremely horrible. You would be interviewed for the position by Senior Managers, someone who has never heard of you might have a say in your promotion depending upon how well you were in interview, it doesn't matter how well you performed in last few years. Even your line manager can't help you sometimes. However, if you have managed to influence people well, you would get promoted easily - you don't have to work hard then. Recently they announced that you could only get promotion only if they have positions otherwise you can't move ahead which is even worse. (However, if there is a position in another department vacant, you could apply for it and get promotion which is better. The catch is most of these positions were in low-cost locations and if you are in high-cost location, you don't have many options then).
6. Due to cost cutting and move to low cost locations, their quality of service has declined a bit.

headline: BARCLAYS
pros: Good working env.  Leave policy is good .
cons: Work life balance will be difficult.

headline: Investment Product Manager
pros: Great role with international coverage.
cons: Company going through difficult time, not great place to work

headline: VP Barclays - Investment Banking
pros: A lot of scope for improvement and to shine in the role and organisation. Opportunities to move internally if taken sensibly when the warning signs are obvious.
cons: Too many changes in overall organisational structure and management teams. No consistent processes . Disorganised HR. Lack of defined long term strategy.

headline: Mix of great opportunities and challenges
pros: Working for Global information security is a fantastic experience. A lot of digital innovation is happening in the organisation which offers sufficient challenge while also allowing for great work life balance.
cons: Frequent change in senior management makes the working environment volatile.

headline: Too many Sr. Management changes
pros: Good work life balance. Good base pay. Great colleagues
cons: Ridiculous budget process. Unnecessary management layers.

headline: Decision Science
pros: Compensation used to be above the market but lately it has been adjusted downward. Good culture and values.
cons: Cost cuts and massive attrition. Best people have left the company. Lack of vision and funds to keep the company in line with competition.

headline: Barclays Personal Banker
pros:
has good benefits for employees
Participate in sharepurchase and sharesave
cons: professional mobility is very limited especially in retail sector

headline: Good place to work
pros: Pay, work culture, social activities
cons: Strict procedures, hard to make changes

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Work life balance, Talented people. Learning is quite good. You have access to trainings( technical, soft skills).
cons: Compensation is not that good, bonus is low, As compare to Morgan and Goldman. No activities to motivate employees.

headline: constant senior management turmoil
pros: decent compensation, often above market
cons: high staff turnover, senior management instability

headline: AM Business Transformation
pros: None I can think of
cons: Many, list is long. Management are politicians and have no respect for talent, or people. They treat employees as laborers. There is so much of office politics that life feels suffocated here.

headline: Director
pros: Great brand.  Pockets of excellence. Access to global resources.  Some wonderful people and clients.  Organisation cares about work/life balance.
cons: Lots of change.  Strategy implementation inconsistent, regularly rocked by management change. Still clinging to grand ambition without the resources to be all things to all clients.

headline: Propositions Manager
pros: Good people, good benefits both monetary and lifestyle
cons: Inflexible, slow moving, cost cutting

headline: Screwed work lif balance
pros: Good salary. Excellent learning apportunities
cons: No work life balance. No parties.

headline: Standard Large Investment Bank
pros:
- Good working hours (9-6 typically)
- Salary is good compared to friends with similar / more experience
- Colleagues are friendly, sociable and knowledgeable 
- Regular social events
- Work is challenging but not overbearing
cons:
- Limited Management Presence in U.S.
- Heavy focus on Regulatory Deliverables - no long term improvement strategy
-Uncertainly around future of US operations
- Outdated technology for both systems and desktop pcs

headline: It an ok place to work.
pros: Pension. Benefits. Maternity pay is good. When the branch is busy its good but when its not its just boring.
cons:
The branch itself is a very boring place to work. I found a lot of employees that have been there for quite some time found that progression is slow and the only reason they stay is because of the benefits. The branches are quite a "talk behind your back" place to work and there is definitely not a "team" feel.
If you get the right manager then great but like me I didn't which resulted in me handing in my notice and taking a pay cut in another job where I am treated like a person.

headline: director of security
pros: flexible working, benefits, role, work colleagues
cons: bureaucracy, constant change, decision making processes

headline: Nice Work Culture
pros: Good benefits, flexible team envionment
cons: Higher management unaware of issues at lower ranks

headline: c# developer in Prague
pros: Top salary and benefits. Nice office on a great location. Very good work/life balance and flexible working hours. Relaxed environment open for suggestions and improvements.
cons:
Teams are very different, your mileage may vary. You can end up maintaining decades old legacy systems.

Tons of internal bureaucracy. Cryptic and unpredictable appraisal and promotion process

headline: VP
pros: There are none. It is a disjointed group with horrible management that don't care at all about their employees. Only pro is leaving every day.
cons: Horrible management with no regard regard or respect given to employees unless you are in "the directors club". This is by far the worst job I have ever had. I count the minutes until I can quit!

headline: wonderful

cons: No con's at all

pros: sent me on secondment abroad.

headline: Enjoyed it
pros: Small, fast paced; really easy to get things done. Can go and chat with Traders, Risk Management, Middle Office, other asset classes - everybody knows everyone. Whatever project comes up you'll have a mate in the other department with whom you're working and be able to get  introductions to take things forwards.
cons: In my opinion the low cost centres sometimes aren't utilised to their fullest extents; there's a tendency to manage from London with little training, in my experience, being handed to the other centres. This sometimes makes learning curves steep for LCC resources.

headline: Fine
pros: Good benefits, nice culture, interesting work
cons: Lots of very average people

headline: 5 Year Employee
pros: Good Training, changing environment, challenging, friendly working culture.
cons: Unorganised, lack of clear stable strategy. Tolerate low standards from staff. Operations teams are not efficient or helpful.

headline: Average
pros:
- Good brand
- Good salaries
- Nice place to work (if you are in the right team)
cons:
- Bad place to work (if you are in the wrong team)
- Improper knowledge transfer
- No knowledge database

headline: Excellent Place to Work At
pros: Friendly, Great Work Culture, Great People
cons: Location, that's pretty much it

headline: Ship with too many captains

headline: Excellent Place to Work At
pros: Friendly, Great Work Culture, Great People
cons: Location, that's pretty much it

headline: Ship with too many captains
pros: Decent hours, work was not taxing
cons: From the moment I joined, the strategy changed 10 different times.  Revolving door of management made it difficult to execute any strategic initiatives

headline: Compliance
pros: Diverse and global business. A good place for beginning a career in banking. Majority of colleagues are genuine and want to help clients and each other.
cons: At senior levels work life balance was terrible. Also too much focus on "your individual brand" / having the right profile instead of actual merit for being strong team leaders or for actual achievements.

headline: Barclays
pros: Flexible working hours, the company goes out of its way to help local communities.
cons:
Every employee who joins the company has to wait a minimum of 2-3 weeks before they get their systems access (sometimes more) so be prepared to sit around for a while when you start.

Worst HR function of any company - nearly every colleague will experience missed or incorrect pay at least once in their time here.

The true culture of this company is all about gains in the short term at the expense of long term losses be that by making staff redundant unnecessarily or paying for cheap systems that don't do the job they're supposed to do. This is why Barclays is struggling and will only struggle further in the future, expect this company to go under in about 5 years time.

Be prepared to learn at least 3 to 5 different acronyms relating to the company's hollow values which change every year and can never be realised due to the aforementioned issues.

The company has gone from one extreme of being a cut-throat organisation that was all about numbers to the other extreme of a company that now pretends to be a humanitarian aid charity (its still all about the numbers) - no basis in reality and why it will continue to fail. Absolutely no commitment to any kind of coherent business strategy, in some areas of the business the name of the department you work for and your job title will change at least once a year if not more. The internal organisation of the company is an inefficient constantly fluctuating mess.

For any job you do at Barclays be prepared to earn at least £5000-£10,000 more in Lloyds, Nationwide or even in a smaller company for the same role, Barclays prefers to hire cheap. Intelligent staff don't last long and move into more reputable companies that pay their employees better, idiots stay behind and learn to hone the key skill of BS which is the only real way of getting far here.

The company expects to own you for a really low wage compared to others, if you get paid more than £32,000 be prepared to lose evenings, weekends, sleep and your partner. If you get paid anything below this you will should have a good work life balance.

Being actually good at your job will only ensure that your managers keep you in your position for as long as possible which is why Barclays prefer to hire external management candidates over experienced and competent frontline staff.

Only about 15-20% of the employees in this company are fit for their roles, the rest are incompetent; there are many Project Managers with no qualifications or previous experience, Analysts with no skills in Excel and don't understand the nature of their roles and Managers who don't understand the departments they're managing and delegate every aspect of their work to frontline staff. The company is rife with parasitism.

Generally the company is less racist compared to others, any racism is only ever localised as there are a lot of individuals from ethnic minorities evenly spread throughout the business however they tend to only hire Muslim women who dress, how shall we say, 'liberally' - there aren't many headscarves about. Sexism is rampant, there are a lot of older women in senior positions but male managers will routinely act inappropriately towards younger female members of staff.

The management staff generally fall into two general categories; the first are poorly qualified individuals who have been there since before the 2008 financial crisis, have slowly risen the ranks by default and hence owe everything they have to the business, aren't likely to leave unless they get pushed out and are generally brainwashed drones of the cult of Barclays, there is a strange cultish mentality around corporate grades and how people are treated based on them. The second kind are also poorly qualified individuals who have come in from the cold and hired directly into management positions, they have no real experience except for a couple year long management positions in other companies, are good liars and have to parasitically leech off competent staff beneath them - the latter tend not to last very long and usually jump into a management position in another company after a year or so (repeating the same lies).

Due to the abysmal hiring processes in the bank the wrong people are hired time and time again. Hiring is a continuous process with staff constantly leaving for better jobs or being made redundant and then the business having to be re-hire their positions again after realising their roles were vital.

Internal mobility does happen but it is very slow due to the fact that the company does not put any real investment training its current staff. The company would rather hire a stranger from outside who has the role qualification they need over investing in someone trusted who possesses everything needed in a good employee sans the required qualification for a higher job. Be prepared to hear a lot of BS regarding personal development.

Only consider this company if there is absolutely nothing else available in your area.

headline: AVP
pros: Pay was decent for the difficulty of work, and didn't need to work too many hours.
cons:
Where do I start? Definitely the worst role I've ever had and inspired me to go back to school. As a bit of context, was working in Financial Decision Support, providing support for execs

- Totally mind numbing work, mostly consisted of running reports for execs. Could've trained monkeys to do this. You will learn very little in this role, at least you don't need to -- to be effective. Do not come here if you want to push yourself to be better. 

- Your opinion does not matter to said execs, you are there to run reports and find answers from other people.

- Colleagues were mostly uncooperative and only cared about their core responsibilities. Constantly needed to get their bosses involved to get things done

- Promotion based on tenure, not on ability. Highly political environment. Staff 

- Mobility around the bank is poor. Finance / Decision support roles are a death sentence. You are virtually stuck there for life. You may interact widely in the bank but these people will never view you as a peer, regardless of knowledge / ability. Where you start out of college is essential.

cons: Very uncertain future w/ top management; kind of a malaise has set in amongst the workers as management strategy keeps veering from one form to another; people are heading for the exit due to the foregoing; working in NY office means always being ruled by London

headline: Bureaucratic monster
pros:
* Good work/life balance -- family friendly culture in most teams.
* Still some really good people. Former "no dicks" policy still seems to be working.
* A serious player.
cons:
* Highly bureaucratic, diffusion of responsibility, culture which promotes talking over doing.
* Still reeling from multiple scandals.
* Quality of people at same corporate grade highly variable across teams/departments. Incompetent managers can prosper for years without being discovered.
* Lots of time spent on reporting project plans, but plans never stuck to, constantly being "rebased".
* History of making arbitrary rate cuts to contractors.
* The "Values" have received positive press coverage, but employees on the ground hate the implementation and find be told they need to show "Respect" and "Integrity" insulting. Evangelical delivery doesn't help. Little actual buy-in from management e.g interpreting in the context of their businesses, rather just repeat vague marketing material down to employee level.
* IT is laughable. Some great techs, but culture of progression to business analyst / project manager rewards arranging more meetings over execution. IT alignment to business is terrible.
* Perceived lack of opportunities in shrinking organisation leading to exodus of talent.

They will hire you and put u in a team managed by developers and their manager. in this way you will be controlled by not only your manager, but also by developers manager and even by developer.
and developer give no respect to testers.
And the notice period oh my GOD it is 3 months and they will never leave u early even if no work (i have seen those dark days).
And the manager in testing department knows nothing just to pull the data from its resource about testing , they can't even talk straight with development management.
People will help just in the start (for boys) and for girls they will always help (Pathetic)
Development mgt have their parties and all that and testing mgt have their own and no one invite each other, in this way resource like us hangs in between and can't do anything.

headline: Do not work here
pros: Unless you can negotiate a ton of money for yourself, do not work here.
cons: Across all groups in the bank, front office, banking, compliance, legal, ops, tech, it doesn't matter, there is constant turn over, mostly because lower and mid level employees are treated like crap and they know they can do better else where. The problem is they have a lot of managers that have been there for 10 or more years and they are too expensive to remove so they employ a revolving door of employees beneath them. They don't care about you as long as they can keep their head count allowances. It's a running joke as to how long each new hire will last. The promotion structure makes no sense and if you get stuck working for a bad line manager who hates you, you might as well start looking for a new job because they will find a way to get rid of you. If you want to move internally bc you don't like your current role, be warned, you must put at least one year in and be in good standing, and it can take months for that transfer to happen. You are better off just going to work somewhere else. Oh and that whole work life balance is nonsense, you will intentionally be given assignments that make it impossible to get out the door at a reasonable hour. If you complain you will not be seen a  "team player" which will affect your crappy bonus and can cause you to get a negative review. They have a work from home policy but your manager can say "no" at anytime and not let you work from home, don't think that you are entitled to any of those "wonderful" perks that they offer. Unless you get it in writing, they can deny you all those work life balance options.

headline: A mess of a company
pros:
- You get a bi-weekly paycheck.  
- A few of the employees are good to work with.
cons:
- One of the most political environments that I've worked in. Hard work is punished/taken advantage of by other employees trying to get credit for doing nothing. 

- So much red tape to get anything accomplished. Most times filling out forms or getting approvals takes 2-3 times the amount of time it takes to do the actual work. 

- Wall Street bonuses are non-existent here. Over my tenure I never received a bonus or raise, ever. I got a lot of excuses why it was a down year for the company though.

- Promotions are also non-existent here, even for lower level titles. The process was constantly changing/unclear and nobody seemed to understand how it worked. 

- Unclear company direction due to the multiple fines/lawsuits. 

- Multiple rounds of layoffs.

headline: Sr. VP. Just resigned. DIFC, Dubai, UAE.
pros:
Great salary and benefits. Strictly 9am to 5:30pm. Extended (3 day) weekends; as Dubai has Fri & Sat weekly off’s and the world is closed on Sunday’s (not much work on Sun.),..we hence literally have 3 weekly off’s. In addition to a month’s annual leave there are atleast 15 compulsory public holidays; and sick leave in the UAE is upwards of 45 days. Minus the sick leave with pay, we only have to work about 215 days a year. Absolutely no disturbance on weekends and weekday lunches are a good 1 hour affair with enough other breaks through the day.

After selling the retail business, all staff is retained in DIFC and we have enough people so that no one person is fully loaded, which is helpful because there are 10 hands for even a single task, however, unhelpful because there is an awful lot of (dirty) politics, incompetent and ill-attitude people (especially in the indirect functions), lots of internal spying and suspicion and generally worthless communication and relations management. It’s a bad environment, but fab salaries and no work stresses, hence, people are fighting tooth, nail and dagger to keep their jobs and have fun.
cons: I agree to most of what is has been already said in the posts below. Indirect (questionable) roles with fancy designations are paid about +85,000/- GBP in annual salary. The excess of staff, unprofessionalism, lack of focus, general chaos, etc.- are all causing severe strain on the business in an already increasingly difficult market environ. The market potential is steadily declining and lean and focused local banks and institutions are quickly taking away whatever is left of the dwindling business in the markets. People who butter their bosses and manage to hide and slink away by sucking up to their bosses; and offer (illicit) gratitude not just survive, but thrive and get away with anything.

headline: Values it's Employees

The salary increases with every years service and there is a fantastic bonus structure for all employees. The career prospects are fantastic and various benefits are offered such as a very competitive pension scheme, private healthcare, gym discounts, 25 days holiday plus bank holidays and many more which I can't remember.
cons: For me the only con was that I absolutely hated the job itself. I worked as a Premier Banker in the Call Centre and it was my first job within a call centre and can easily say it wasn't for me. Do not go into this kind of work if you don't take well to extremely rude, arrogant and nasty customers.

headline: Management doesn't value its human assets
pros: Barclays will likely offer you an opportunity if you are already working in finance and hoping to grow your client base or build connections to move elsewhere.
cons: Barclays has an unhealthy, destructive culture with high turnover and poor management. Coworkers are constantly stressed and unhappy and feel significantly undervalued. Although Barclays is trying to move past recent negative headlines, its stated values are not effectively implemented, and miscommunication with and misvaluation of human capital continue to be extremely problematic at all levels.

headline: Test Analyst
pros:
1. More autonomy as compared to service industry.
2. Good bonus
3. Barclays care about it's community services and include it in employees appraisal objectives also.
4. Appraisal system is fair
5. Opportunities to contribute are emmense
6. Provides opportunities to switch team / profile internally by Internal Job Portal
7. Barclays advocates a lot for 'Values'
8. It's a brand
cons:
1. Work culture is changing rapidly and moving towards service industry work culture
2. Roles and responsibilities are not clear. 'You touch it, you own it' is the funda here
3. Less recognition
4. Takes a long time for promotion internally (exceptions are always there)
5. Rare onsite opportunities
6. Vendors (service industry partners like Infosys, CG etc.) are given more onsite opportunites
7. Co-ordination challenges between Barclays permanent employees and vendors
8. Dead slow systems and red tapism
9. Extra-ordinary expectations without providing tools and training
10. High work load. Many people work more than half of there weekends in the year

headline: Cost control is the predominant concern
pros:
People are friendly
People are helpful where possible
cons:
Reducing costs is the dominant driver of decisions. As a result ageing systems and equipment are not improved, redundancy rounds leave fewer people doing more work, high staff turnover means few people are able to explain or justify what was done in the past, obtaining approval for any expenditure is difficult, and compensation is significantly reduced.

Barclays is reducing in size so the environment is one of managing decline.

The effect of this is to increase the time and effort required on process work at the expense of seeking improvements.

headline: Overall, Unprofessional people, especially in support functions
pros: The DIFC location is good enough and there is little (productive) work and that is about all there is to it.
cons: As far as wealth, investments and overall business is concerned, this place is nearly finished. There is absolutely no focus and the work environment is as unprofessional as it can get. The support functions like admin, communications, events, etc. are full of incompetent people who do not know a word of Arabic and draw hefty salaries and generally waste their own and everyone else’s time playing dirty politics and justifying their crazy salaries. Bulk of the top management like John, Richard, and all the great guys have already moved on. UK management has no time to look into what’s going on here and the communication coming across to us is miserable and a total sham. Most people are just waiting to get the next best offer and jump ship and no one really belongs or has any clear idea of what’s going on. We are headed for a big disaster here.

headline: Working as Data-warehouse Test Lead in Barclay's with 4+ years of Experience.
pros: Good Team, Challenging work, Lots to learn

Salary not as per the workload
Very High workload

headline: It's all a bit...'meh'
pros:
Okay...first things first - this will now be the 4th bank I have worked for over the years and I've been at Barclays for almost a year. I'll save you some trouble - apart from Goldman Sachs they are all more or less the same. 

Barclays will look good on your CV

Most folks are nice enough to work with (despite being busy all the time) - they're just human. Most won't shout at you or whatever; it's just everyone is so rushed and busy all the time.

Can be hit or miss as it's so large - get an average or above manager and you'll be alright

Pay seems on par with other banks but nothing incredible like the media portray (we can't all be millionaires; most are well paid grunts). haha

Pretty clear senior management considering they have a day job as well (sending out announcements, updating blogs and intranet sites and so on) - although you're obviously not going to know everything. Be realistic.

Good chance to learn on the job (you don't need to have 3 degrees in finance or anything stupid). Just sit, watch, learn and help - you'll soon get it.

Offices on the whole are decent. North Colonnade could do with some updating but it's alright - South Colonnade is very nice with airy open plan offices and lots of light. You get all the tech and equipment most people would need (multiple monitors, etc).
cons:
okay - let's get this out the way first - bonuses. Unless you're one of a lucky few, don't start thinking of mansions, fast cars and so on - it's media hype. Those days are gone for most. Numeration day is a total joke (almost insulting) so unless you're pulling in hundreds of millions for your boss (unlikely) don't think you're on the ticket to success when you get here. Learn lots, work hard and see what happens - but it's not Leonardo DiCaprio wolf of wall street ticket to success stuff. You missed the boat big time on that one.

Crazy working hours. Yes, you get paid well however when you work it out per hour it becomes very average. If you're contract says 9-5 don't honestly expect to work those. I work 8:30am til 6:30pm (middle office) - a lot of my team work longer and we aren't compensated like successful traders / sales people (most old school are long gone).

It's the same everywhere I've been, especially in banks - politics. It's a huge company and people are looking after themselves - it doesn't mean you're going to have a terrible time but managers are so busy looking up pandering to the needs of those above and playing politics with others that what chance to those at the bottom get? Real leadership inspires, nurtures, listens, etc - but most in leadership roles (big and small) are not natural leaders.

With the greatest respect to those in India; stop offshoring Barclays. Seriously, I know you can get 3 Indians or more for the price of 1 in the UK or US but it's about value and not price for what you get. Let's not confuse value and price. Half the company is based out in India by workers utterly confused and inexperienced, not able to think beyond their checklists printed for them. Empty promises, not delivering work, when it is delivered it's all wrong or fudged - ah, I can go on. Seriously, it's easier to get up and work with one person on the other side of the floor.

Some teams can be a bit 'old boys network' but they are rare. It could be much worse - most are normal.

The biggest issue at Barclays investment right now (early 2015) is that it is run by a chap that knows retail banking (CEO Anthony Jenkins). The investment bank is a mere child compared to what it was a few years ago and staff morale is low. It's low because people are heavily overworked due to ruthless job slashing yet the business keeps demanding more and more - there is no more juice to squeeze. I get the feeling the top guys want to turn the overall Barclays group into a retail bank and sell of the investment part eventually - so long as it's providing a good enough return then they'll keep hold. But seriously, the workforce are drained, exhausted and good people leave within just a year.

The bank has tens of thousands of staff. Even those extremely good at the bottom deserving promotion have odds heavily stacked against them because of the numbers game. It's very hard to get noticed when you have so many also wanting to be noticed and seen as 'special'. Don't expect quick promotions, like with most banks (a lot of good timing and luck involved) rather than natural talent and skill.

headline: Management plan is disjointed with limited staff over worked.
pros: Work location and the knowledge to build your understanding of subject matter.
cons:
Managers manage up and not down. The volume of work with limited staff support and expectation of execution of that work is unrealistic.  Changing priorities everyday without focus, then to have the work that was said to be priority put aside after spending time and shifting current work load to execute. 

Found that most mid-level management are YES people without questioning the rationale for the reason why, for fear of not being part of the niche crowd. Line managers adhoc requests are vague and unclear but you are expected to figure it out with no support. 

Work-Life balance is stated but not practiced.

headline: A successful commercial bank struggling to stay in the investment banking business.
pros: The bank has a long and rich history.  Its retail and commercial banking operations are doing okay.
cons:
If you are contemplating a career at the investment banking division of Barclays, then you need to 
be aware of the following facts (The source of the facts can be googled easily):
	
	As of May, 2014, Barclays announced that it will cut 19,000 jobs by year 2016. (Source BBC News, Guardian)
	Of the 19,000 job cuts, 7,500 will be in its investment banking division. (Source Bloomberg, Yahoo Finance)
	Barclays was fined $450 million for its manipulation of the global benchmark interest rate 
	(the LIBOR scandal). (Source USA Today, CNBC)
	Barcalys is currently under investigation for its manipulation of the global foreign exchange
	market. (Source Bloomberg, Guardian)

The crucial issue, however, is that the return on equity at its investment banking division is a 
meagre 2.7% (Source Bloomberg, Barclays Annual Report), far below the bank's target of 12% and its 
other divisions. 

When the return of equity of its peer bank Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) reached such a low level, RBS decided to phase out its investment banking business over the next four years.

headline:
A confused, non-ethical firm of sorts
Micromanagement
No IB background considered
pros: big brand...that's it. No other benefits as I see !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
cons:
A very confused and incompetent management - they have setup three offices in pune and probably even the CEO doesn't know where to operate from. The result has to be bore by the poor employees, who are daily plying ~27kms-30kms one way to reach office. The management doesn't care and gives very short notice to start working from one of them.

Incompetent management - they don't get people to join them to easily. Their market reputation is itself very shaky (well they are themselves to be blamed for it). So the easiest way out for them is to start giving higher roles to people not worth their years of experience to handle such roles. Result is projects having no sight of roadmap ahead. Neither where the project is stuck. They even don't consider IB background for taking people, result is people coming from service based firms and hence the slogging culture which is fast catching up in the firm. They try portraying themselves as IB in pune.....my foot !!!

HR - I've never seen such a dormant HR as in here. They hardly are good for anything. No words for them...simply awful

headline: Never-ending bad news, layoffs = bad morale
pros: Compared to other investment banks, decent work/life balance.
cons:
Since the bank announced last May that the investment bank will be shedding 7000 jobs, the mood has been bad.  Morale is poor.  Annual rankings force each manager to classify 10-20% of their direct reports as "needs improvement".  Anybody that gets this ranking is let go.  In other words, every manager has to let go of people every year.
The number of scandals and regulatory issues Barclays is currently involves with is embarrassing and depressing.
Bonuses were laughable or nonexistent.

cons: Some terrible behaviours. Barclays group level vision relayed but not lived- micro cultures allowed to exist. Slow to deliver and make changes, despite common beliefs.

headline: The best house in a bad neighborhood.
pros:
I worked in front office research, based in London.

Nice people. Not as bureaucratic or political as horror stories you hear at some investment banks.

Mixing socially was encouraged, and engendered loyalty / trust.

CEO Antony Jenkins is trying to create a more responsible culture across the firm.
cons:
Internally-developed technology not very good. Simple things like CRM and research publishing was either very manual, or had buggy internally-developed software.

Like most investment banks, a culture of obsession over bonuses, and suspicion (rightfully so) that management was trying to pay you as little as possible so they could afford to pay the next guy more. That being said, all investment bankers are really well paid in an absolute sense.

Work life balance is still a myth in front-office investment banking, apart from maybe Sales and Trading. The whole industry is still figuring out how to retain juniors when the allure of high pay is no longer realistic, yet the demands on your time have not adjusted commensurately. Barclays is no exception.

headline: Stratified and Compartmentalized Roles

cons: Everything is compartmentalized. For security, data, operations or job, information and the dissemination is very tightly controlled. Inefficiency is the result.

headline: Good place to work if things work out well
pros: Great coworkers and management. Very competitive pay. Good job for mid-career or senior-level positions in general.
cons: Experience depends entirely on team. For entry level positions, certain teams have huge possibilities of growth and development while some teams are very stagnant. The team can either make your career or add zero value to it.

headline: Good place to work if things work out well
pros: Great coworkers and management. Very competitive pay. Good job for mid-career or senior-level positions in general.
cons: Experience depends entirely on team. For entry level positions, certain teams have huge possibilities of growth and development while some teams are very stagnant. The team can either make your career or add zero value to it.

headline: One of the most dysfunctional companies I have seen.
pros: Decent perks, holidays, environment. Barclays does hire some excellent people although retention is an issue. They invest quite heavily in innovation. Pay is competitive.
cons: Infighting between silos. Poor transparency into opportunities - definitely a "who you know" place, not what. People are not treated with respect and the customer is an afterthought. Misogynistic behaviours by senior male leaders make this a poor place for senior women. The way to survive at Barclays is to keep your head down and try not to call attention to yourself.

headline: A sinking ship whose managers have lost decency
pros: The company offers free coffee and tea.  Colleagues are cooperative in general.  Manager is hardworking as the staff.  The CEO seems to want right ship and create a moral atmosphere after some scandals.
cons: The company is struggling to keep talent because of multiple rounds of layoffs.  Managers have a tough time choosing who to get rid of.  They sometimes make the unsavory choices based on favoritism.  The manager treated his employees with decency only when pressuring them to deliver projects and did not give credit where credit was due after the projects were delivered successfully.  The bank's pay is below average compared to other banks in the i-bank business, to put it generously.

My team and colleagues were friendly but I rarely went out to lunch or after work with them. Typical drones. I was laid off after a year and a half. headline: Global Company reinserts expatriots into management  jobs with no regard for their knowledge of native employment laws!
pros: While there could be pros garnered in the areas of innovation and sharing of best practices learned somewhere other thatn the native locale, the observed premature reinsertion of mangement without reorientation and training only sets up the returning employees and the company for failure and unfair employment practices.
cons: This company has a definate disconncet concerning reinsertion of leadership into the organization upon their return to the native locale and thier need to respect and comply with the existing employment laws that apply in their home country.  The use of contractual  human resource management professionals who do not participate in the personnel actions implemented by these low level and mid level managers returning to a work in a legalistic environment that they have been working outside of for a number of years as expatriots lends itself to highly problematic applications of employee/management relations initiatives without proper oversight or standardized (i.e., equitable) policy implementation.  Therefore, there is a culture of favoritism and unfair treatment and discrimination that shows a lack of leadesip, or at least a lack of leadership values in areas that should not have this type of a void.  A global corporation should have a global strategy for ensuring compliance with local employment laws and avoids sending signals to employees that are not appropriate in their native countries.

headline: Process automation engineer specializing in gaining efficiencies while maintaining regulatory compliance
pros: I work with amazing people in a relaxed and collaborative environment. Work/life balance is paramount to me, and at Barclays, they understand that colleagues work best when we're not stressed-out. There is lots of flexibility to work from home, for desk sharing, and for alternative scheduling.
cons: As anyone who works in a technology-based field, it's a dog-eat-dog world. Specifically, if you're looking for advancement, or even recognition, you must be prepared to chase it. The workplace environment is challenging as we work in Agile-like groups located in loud, hollow rooms which challenge everyone's ability to concentrate. Bose is the best friend of anyone who needs to maintain a train of thought longer than a few minutes.

headline: Can be good, if you end up in the right team
pros: A lot of the people have been helpful and approachable plus the benefits schemes are pretty good.
cons:
A lot of processes, which are already mature in other companies are barely there and it can take a very long time to get things done.
There are quite a few employees in senior positions, who can't deal with day to day tasks and lack basic knowledge in their area of expertise.

headline: Good company culture, employees well cared for
pros:
-Management very understanding of employee needs
-Quality options for Health / Life Insurance
-Steady hours, plenty of available overtime
-Room for advancement
cons:
-Long hours, dull work in most entry level positions
-Very rigid attendance requirements, you will not be judged / held back for calling out, but there are strict limitations

headline: Keep low expectations and you'll be fine
pros: Pretty good work/life balance, all things considered (no crazy hours like investment banking). When I worked there, there was overtime for analysts so that was a great form of compensation. I made a lot of good friends at Barclays.
cons: This is not a prestigious job. You are working in the back office of an investment bank. You're not working with Ivy League graduates with MBAs. If you're okay with this, then you'll be fine. It's very hard to be in this group and then switch to a front office role...but in rare cases, it happens.

headline: Most ill mannered and group of idiots and liers
pros: Good company but top management all scoundrels
cons: Managers at barclaycard are simply pathetic people don't listen and understand your problems manager blocks his team member from his fone and say that collegie fif not turn up

headline: Not bad but not great. Double standards prevail
pros: Good people who work hard and deliver for colleagues and customers alike. Plus they're a social bunch who know how to enjoy themselves.
cons: Feels like the values are talked about a lot but not often demonstrated by snr mgmt. When they want something values and work life balance go out the window and the work is expected to be done regardless.

headline: AVP
pros: good compensation, good reputation, smart ppl
cons: really bad culture. too corporate and insecure approach from employees. not an ideal environment to learn

headline: Had its ups and downs but overall the firm is a good company to begin your career on the street
pros: The opportunity to learn and network with experienced industry leaders. Also, the name of the firm gives you the opportunity to go other places as well.
cons: The political aspect of the firm, which is present in many other firms and industry's and can help you continue further into your career

headline: One of my biggest disappointments  in entire career
pros: Hard to find. But there are very smart people somewhere there. They are constantly trying to hide from HR and senior management.
cons:
HR service is really bad.
Compensation is lowest in the market.
They are firing people at will.
Bureaucracy is overwhelming.
This is simply the worst place I have ever worked.

headline: Good Company
pros: Plenty of learning opportunities
cons: Company now undergoing cost reduction and restructuring

headline: Complete dysfunction at the senior management level
pros: Those professionals left standing are, for the most part, hard working, intelligent and consciencious. They do attempt to provide quality service to their clients across the full spectrum of financial products. They have a massive footprint in almost every market globally and their aren't many things they cannot transact as a bank.
cons: Senior management is terrified of public perception. It almost felt as if they'd rather have happy headlines than happy employees and stock holders. Morale is awful. Barclays did not grow organically in the United States post the Lehman acquisition. The result of that has been 6 years of purges and downsizes and business realignments. Barclays wants to be the biggest and has lost sight of the fact that its more important to be the best at a few things than very mediocre in everything. Compensation, by all acounts, is 20-30% lower than counterparts at other similar shops.

headline: Don't recomment

headline: Great people but morale is down, and strategic direction unclear.
pros:
Friendly, intelligent people (depending on your team)
Decent internship and graduate training programme
Work/life balance reasonable/better than other places (at least in sales)
Brand name still good to have on the CV
cons:
- Low morale on trading floors due to constant cuts and voluntary departures. 
- Lack of communication from upper mgmt and no clear strategic direction
- Grads have no chance to try placements on different desks and are dropped onto a team that needs headcount with very little regard to his or her professional interests.  It is not easy to move teams. If you are a markets intern at Barclays, be very careful which desks you are courting and find out how things are really going for them. 
- Compliance and internal approval processes for anything and everything have become far more stringent and time consuming than they are at other banks (from what I've heard). Not a bad thing per se, but it makes the work very tedious.

headline: Work Life Balance
pros:
Good HR policies
Good work life balance
Decent Pay
cons:
Opaque Appraisal System
Non-uniform Internal Postings
Slow HR and IT issue resolutions

headline: Loved the environment to work.
pros: People are helpful and there is a good knowledge base to explore more about the work.
cons: Still does a bit of manual work which can be solved by employing more people who could do automation

headline: Nice colleagues, dreadful management
pros: Barclays definitely hire a 'type' for the branches- bubbly, friendly etc so you always find someone you can get along with
cons:
The self service machines have made a cashier's life hell. One till for ALL business customers and transactions over 750.00 is a joke. I worked in a self service bench for 5 days before handing in my notice. Customers (rightly) hate the new style and therefore set about making a cashiers life hell because they're miserable. 
Also- giving cashiers a 4% max pay rise for this is laughable. I'm going to a job which will increase my salary by 20%, better hours and paid overtime.
Overtime-a paid working day in Barclays is 9-5 with 1 hour lunch.Fine on paper but you are required to be at branch by 8.30am latest and are never paid overtime despite rarely leaving before 5.30PM.

headline: company trying to figure out its NA and APAC brand....
pros: large global company with opportunity for mobility if you get the right support/sponsorship.
cons: alot of turnover with senior management. growing and trying to figure out people operations. emea is strong. americas and apac are disconnected from the corporate centre.

headline: Not a good company to work
pros: So far no pros as they are limiting their facilities day by day.
cons: Managers are very biased and no growth options in the company

headline: Have enjoyed it and really feel I have progressed my carrer
pros: less pressurized working environment
cons: non competitive bonus salary

headline: An environment that is stuck to convention - junior Director level utterly resistant to change and improvement.
pros: Compensation is ok and some of the senior management are extremely good.
cons: What senior executives want to achieve and change, is halted by a bureaucratic layer of institutional lethargy and denial.  The junior Director level is overpopulated with individuals who are simply hanging on for a pension.  The Bank is constantly trying to change and evolve, but is continually dragged back by dinosaurs who don't like to be held to account - the culture remains: 'bowler hats and typewriters'.

headline: Rubbish
pros: No Pros at all as everything is Cons

headline: Well Balanced Employer, with strong emphasis on execution, results and rewards
pros:

- Accountability is clearly visible and thus it makes any mistakes quite obvious
- No blame culture, everyone works towards resolving the issue rather than pointing out fingers

cons:
- Being part of a traditional bank with a history, some of the things from past need transformation for the "new" age
- Employees could promote more sense of togetherness, bonding and social networking among themselves

headline: The firm is in the midst of a culture overhaul.  The Lehman IB culture is gone.
pros: If you are a junior developer recently out of a university, you will probably do well working in New York.  If you are a senior IT manager in London you will also do well.
cons: The decision making/leadership positions have migrated to London in the IB.  The commercial bank was always this way.  The firm has embraced the British culture recently.  A number of new executives have been hired in London who have all brought their own reports and have taken over IT strategies.

headline: BARC prior to 2012
pros:
This was before 2012 so things might have changed:

Good networking opportunity,
A lot of social events for junior employees,
Used to be a fast growing business,
Used to be a less bureaucratic place.
cons:

headline: Low Morale, Very below average meritocracy

cons: Unintelligent people,  many without university degrees. No interest in financial markets, no ambition to grow. Lots of politics.

headline: Barclays Woolwich Branch Work/Life ratio and working environment.
pros: Only reason I chose to work for with them was as it was easy to get job with them and the transport commuting is easy as it is near a station and bus. Also parkiing permit given.
cons:
Managements spying on staff to the extent that they will come into the TOILET to tell you to hurry up as the customer queue is getting big!!! Even when ones just gone in, is this not bullying in the work place?. Management has a habit of picking on selected certain staff also. When it comes to emergency childcare management tells staff "get your finances in order so that you can afford a proper child career or get a bigger mortgage from Barclays to help you. Others get away with more than simple wrong doings and attitudes. When a complaint is made about this the management hide their favourites by making statements similar to "each person is dealt with on individual circumstances", "confidentiality" or "they will be spoken to". They still continue to do the wrongs. Management get transfers as "They find it too busy a branch from my old one....I can't take this." Other staff can't get transfers as "there's too much going on" as being the answer. Well if they find things "too much going on" then they are not worthy of being managers. Managers stick up for each other even when they are wrong. When challenged to many things the reply is "It's down to managers discretion", this even applies to getting time off for child sickness and doctors appointments etc.. Even cash differance are taken likely when made by certain staff and management come down hard on others who don't even make often or great value errors- favouritism. This is then paraded between themselves as an example setter...just to get marks and say "I have done my jobs" but they have done more wrong by NOT doing their job where it counts, both to company and colleagues. Customers are persuaded to take insurance and package account even when it is obviously not suitable for them. Management encourage this for the income for the branch.
No work life understanding by management, they just want to look at company. There attitude an behaviour is having a negative effect on staff and moral and also work productivity.

headline: It had been a fantastic experience working with Barclays
pros:
1) Work life balance
2) Fantastic onshore team
3) Good pay
4) High motivational level
5) Great place to work
cons: Local HR team is a pain. HR team has a very laid back attitude when approached with problems or issues.

headline: Average Technical Growth (Barclaycard US team)
pros:
Good Salary, Work flexibility, FBP component good,
Good number of annual leaves.
cons:
Promotions are bit difficult. Management is forcing employees to concentrate on citizenship activity rather than actual work most of the times.
Managers rarely talk with their US counterpart which is blocking good work flow to India team.
Some managers don't give Respect to the senior team members.
Managers cannot distinguish between a good resource (who is working hard) and a resource who only shows off.

headline: analyst

headline: Great team, enjoyable work and a lot of bureaucracy

International teams allowing to mix ideas + other benefits coming from this
Enjoyable work that requires both good knowledge of business as well as good communication skills
People around are friendly and willing to share know how. Even though this holds at least for most of Prague offices, there are exceptions to this
Reasonable work-life balance
Good salary and no useless employee benefits
cons:
High level of bureaucracy in hiring and in day-to-day life
A bunch of legacy stuff that could be easily and cheaply replaced
Some people are extremely arrogant and selfish. If you cannot avoid them, they can make your life hell

headline: A respectful organization

cons: Barclays is a very competitive environment, you be good, you get rewarded, you slow down, you miss the train. Some of their 3rd world countries branches might be suffering a bit from the lack of proper and fair management.

headline: AVP - Middleware Specialist
pros: A competitive pay and very good benefits. I often get positive feedback from colleagues and customers, they acknowledge your skills and experience. Internal jobs available in case you get bored in your current role. I want to highlight the benefits, these are really good, lots of great benefits, support and employee discount.
cons: There is a PD-game every year; just recently noticed management does not really care about what you achieve if they already decided your grade. This is not a great motivation. Same applies for carrier development. If you are looking for a relaxing job, you can get into a very stressing one where always there is a pressure on you to deliver service without any mistake. Making processes even more complicated and our (technical staff) life more difficult in the BAU work.

headline: I have been worked 5 years in several roles but mostly on the phone and on shift. Nice colleagues but poor management
pros: There is opportunity to support (unpaid) other dept and than move in case there is an open position. Basic salary is 22K plus bonus.
cons: Environment is not bad but in Dublin since they outsources to HP they cut all expensive; canteen is very poor, equipment old, pc not efficiently working ect

headline: Good place to start out
pros:
Young optimistic environment - this is the only Barclays Capital location that is growing
Fun
Friendly
Relaxed
Ping Pong Table, Fussball Table - after you've been working for 5-6 hours a game or two really helps get you going again. It makes you more alert, and promotes a friendly workplace environment.
Full of long time IB veterans that are completely open to mentor the young
Lots of growth opportunity
cons:
Hours are a bit long but that is to be expected working for an Ibank
When your parent is in the UK it creates all sorts of issues surrounding communication etc..
Parking is a complete mess. Though there is a parking garage and Ibanking employees always get a spot (since they are in so early).
Cafeteria food isnt the best and there are almost no food options within walking distance, awesome food trucks every other day, though

headline: The bank lacks direction in the UAE

headline: Average experience

headline: Too many radical changes

cons:
- No progression opportunities. You will end up being stuck there due to the inverted pyramid strategy of management. 
- Radical changes mean that there is no set way of business and this can be harmful to retaining clients and progression.
