pros: Pay was sufficient but as a quant felt invisible in the company.
cons: Lack of possible advancement. Continual malfeasance

headline: Great career opportunities
author_position: Vice President Structured Trade & Commodity Finance
pros: Bank that is changing it´s core values to adapt to the current regulation and improve it´s market perception.
cons: The bank is cutting jobs in some areas related to Investment Bak ad Personal Banking.

headline: More interested in sales than customers
pros:
Training is freely available to anyone that wants it
There was a focus for a while on upskilling the staff
Working from home in some positions
Some benefits
cons:
Obsession with sales over customer services
Bonus is terrible - always full of promises but it's rarely worth having.
Management is incompetent in most offices. There doesn't seems to be any need for management skill before you're promoted.
Office politics is rife. Prepare for back stabbing and constant complaining
Internal promotion process is overly complicated

headline: finance
pros: accelerated learning.  good learning curve and mobility
cons: big organization and challenges, hours are challenging

headline: chaotic & Disorganised Outfit in Dubai
pros: Used to be a very good bank. Good history, had good ethics, had good people, used to be safe and strong
cons: UK took their hands off the UAE operation, No organisation, disharmony between sections and departments, no communication between staff, legal department in chaos and makes lots of errors, compliance department dont do their work properly and when things go wrong they blame their clients. Legal department incompetent and irresponsible. Bank trying to cover up their shortcoming by blaming clients. Ruined businesses in dubai.

headline: Trader
pros:
Worked with a very talented group of individuals.  All possessed a great work ethic and promotions were based on performance.
Excellent leadership at every level and long term approach to business.
cons: Challenging work/life balance at all times of year.

headline: Good company
pros: Flexibility good pay diversity bonus
cons: Culture, hierarchy, lack of progression opportunities

headline: Worst culture ever
pros: Pay and benefits and general rewards/compensation package are what you'd expect from a bank
cons: JFDI organisation controlled by the very top. Zero empowerment and high blame culture throughout the senior levels across the organisation.

headline: Low morale
pros: Barclays Capital is still being considered a good name in the street, so it is good to have it on your CV when going to interview somewhere else. And base salaries are still good.
cons: Since Barclays' CEO announced major redundancy plans, including 30% in investment banking until 2016, people stopped working. It is difficult to find a person keen to develop business. The majority spends more time discussing who else is hiring, who is a good headhunter, who will be fired next etc. You feel very low morale.

headline: Low pay but great people to work with
pros: Great team to work with, everyone was friendly and a relaxed atmosphere. There was scope to progress
cons: We had to do overtime everyday so work/life balance was no so good. Low pay, no good benefits. Team leader has no leadership skills.

headline: Very political even at junior levels
pros: There's still some collegial culture left over from Lehman Brothers
cons: The "Wild West" culture has nearly taken over. Also, the bank itself is shrinking because of all the legal issues due to aforementioned culture.

headline: Low pay but great people to work with
pros: Great team to work with, everyone was friendly and a relaxed atmosphere. There was scope to progress
cons: We had to do overtime everyday so work/life balance was no so good. Low pay, no good benefits. Team leader has no leadership skills.

headline: Very political even at junior levels
pros: There's still some collegial culture left over from Lehman Brothers
cons: The "Wild West" culture has nearly taken over. Also, the bank itself is shrinking because of all the legal issues due to aforementioned culture.

headline: worst management
pros: nothing to talk about this company. The management in Jersey City (IT division, now moved to Whippany) is clue less. Some one should speak to Perry Metviner to get rid of age old managers who are hanging out there like parasites without working hard.
cons: worst place, stupid boss. He does not know what he is doing

headline: Good employer with a global footprint
pros: Good people, great work culture and possiblity to progress professionally
cons: Unclear focus and business strategies

headline: Below average place to work
pros: Amazing benefits from pensions to private health, etc.
cons: Crazy amount of politics, really can't get worse!

headline: Not the best
pros: competitive pay, great location of offices
cons: lots of senior management changes

headline: Great reputation, awful culture
pros: Good benefits, upper management recognition of need to change the culture and reduce complexity by shrinking the IB.
cons: The poor IT infrastructure cannot meet regulatory requirements. Deep mistrust between departments. Lots of meetings that accomplish nothing. Stunning lack of communication.

headline: Great place to work and progress your career.
pros:
The culture within the organization is excellent and I could honestly say that my current team is one of the best teams I have worked so far. I can always trust my colleagues and I case I have question they are always there to guide me to the answer I need.
 
Senior management are transparent and approachable when needed. Lots of communication about what is going on within the group and etc is distributed internally. 

Moreover, we really live with the Barclays values and as organization we do lots of charity. 

There is opportunity for career progress vertically (within the structure) and horizontally (within other structures) and middle and senior management are supporting it. Training is also provided, although that the process is quite slow and takes few months to arrange everything.
cons: The salary and non cash benefits are below the average for the industry, however I believe that when you consider all the Pros this could be discarded.

headline: Life - changing
pros:
team work skill development
great work culture
good compensation
cons: difficult work life balance and timings

headline: Graduate Program
pros: The people were really friendly; my managers really helped me in navigating the early stages of my career
cons: The nature of the graduate scheme has significantly changed, no longer includes international rotation and natural transition into a private banking role. Probably going to be doing a back office role on this program

headline: Good company to work for. Nice working culture based on its values
pros: The work-life balance was fair enough and the training provided was adequate to start offering to the company quickly.
cons: Not many opportunities for promotion or career development.

headline: Undergoing major changes in IT
pros:
From an IT perspective Retail and Investment Bank have very different cultures.
The Investment Bank was global, entrepreneurial and fully very high caliber engineers and management.
The Retail bank is UK focused, much larger, and more bureaucratic.
The consolidation of IT operations across Retail and IB means it is more retail, than IB.
cons:
Downsizing is never fun and morale is low.
Entrepreneurial, driven IB culture has been replaced with sleepy, 9-5, retail mentality.

headline: I've been with Barclays for a year. Overall great experience. Lots of changes for the past year in the firm. It's hard to say whether it's good or not.
pros: Good benefit and friendly working environment
cons: Long hours morale is not very good; Low pay and slow promotion

headline: Review for Barclays Technology Centre India Pune
pros:
Good pay structure. 
Good for those who like staying always in comfort zone. 
Flexible working hours can be feasible. 
Good facilities for remote working. 
Good facilities when company sends employees to onshore.
cons:
Not very good canteen facilities. 
Not very good transport facilities.
The company has very high end political environment where company values can loose to personal interests. 
Got an impression that perhaps, the company needs more strong D&I environment to allow everyone progress independently and have enough opportunities and support to bring out more positive change to the way business is done. 
Too much macro management and dominating behaviours observed.
Biased senior management.

headline: Summer internship at Barclays
pros: Laid back atmosphere.  Nice managers
cons: No open source code. Do no use latest technology,

headline: good visionary company
pros:
great place to work for same level employees
good training
achievable targets
cons:
favouritism during promotions
too much emphasis on results, less on process

headline: Barclays
pros: Very big firm with lots of opportunity to interact with people of different areas, regiona
cons: Long decision making process makes it little difficult

headline: A place where I progressed and learnt all I need to know about Investment Banking
pros: Career mobility within the firm is highly encouraged to retain talents.
cons: Bad press hitting the firm due to legacy issues.

headline: If you like politics you will enjoy here
pros: Good salary and good number of PLs and SLs
cons: There are managers and more managers who been around for long and no one else can afford them. Do no work and trouble the ones who do... And then show they are the one doing everything...

headline: It is a Mixed Bag.
pros:
Met some great people on my team and some team leaders are lovely. You get some sort of community spirit in the contact centre. 

Benefits and salary are good for the job.

Premier Telephony tends to be quiet for a phone job usually. It is not constant calls like Retail.

Some career opportunities if you try.

Company is trying to change and respect customer service over profit.
cons:
Targets to promote digital options to 90 year old ladies. 

No communication between departments so letters end up getting sent out to customers about something and we do not know about it and sound thick when customers call to query it.

Debit Card Fraud based in India - fraud should always be UK based.

Some important telephony departments closing at 5pm which is unhelpful at 10pm.

Branch telling customers to call when they can deal with an issue.

Too much emphasis on statistics like call times and hold times. 

Senior management make decisions that the little people like us on the front line have to deal with.

pros: Good salary and good number of PLs and SLs
cons: There are managers and more managers who been around for long and no one else can afford them. Do no work and trouble the ones who do... And then show they are the one doing everything...

headline: Culture Shift from Lehman PIM Divison and Lots of Attrition, but Overall Decent Experience Given Financial Environment
pros: Market hours (comparatively to other finance roles), nice office, clear career development paths and training, one of the best HR departments I have experienced
cons: Definitely felt like we were the ugly step-sister to Barclays Capital when it came to investing in the future of the investment platform and business

headline: Quant Developer
pros: Challanging technologies bot IT and quant. Wide ranges of exotic financial products and risk technicks like CVA, Expected Shortfall, VaR, Greeks, P&L attribution.
cons: Not convinced it is easy to step further up on the business leaderhip ladder. At my last position I was an Associat Director, I am not sure if I can get the same rank at Barcap.

headline: Promised everything, delivered nothing.
pros: Some reasonable intelligent people work there.
cons: These people are demotivated by the atmosphere and culture.

headline: Place to learn and grow
pros: Friendly team, good to learn things on investment, if you start from different background like IT. Plenty of space to grow within the department.
cons: As the culture of big firms, you are boxed in, ie. switch from IT analytics role to quant or trading is next to never.

headline: Worked at Associate level in 3 divisions across firm
pros: Seamless internal mobility process. Offers a broad range of products. Nice office space.
cons:
Subject to excessive regulation, target of multiple domestic and foreign investigations resulting in major fines
Cannot compete with peers on comp; hemorrhaging talent over the last few years.

headline: They lost there way during the credit crunch, but once they got rid of the leader from Capital they are improving.
pros: Fair managers, no bullying, good drive.
cons: Bring back managers from the 90's.

headline: Investment Banking Analyst
pros:
Personal development and growth opportunities
Highly competitive program
Excellent learning experience
Hours better than average
cons:
Long hours, but not long for banking
Recent bad press
Management changeover

headline: No Clear Strategy
pros: Compensation was competitive. The people who came from NYC to train us in Houston were great.
cons: Poor work life balance. Manager had an NYC state of mind so she was not concerned with working timely and efficiently. Managers tend to micro manage and there is no consistency across teams. The benefits were just ok as far as prescription coverage I felt I paid more with Barclays. The company is behind tech wise and they are just now going through changes other banks went through years ago. They are having another relocation strategy after less than a year in Houston.

headline: Serious Leadership Issues
pros: They pay more than some of the other banks.
cons: The leadership changes its mind about the direction of the company almost weekly. There is no guarantee that your work will ensure that you continue to be employed there. It seems like each month there is a new "townhall" meeting with one of the very senior mgmt people telling us what the new "corporate slogan" is. Overall it leads to a strong feeling that no one has any idea where things are going. Quite depressing.

headline: Business analyst
pros: Good to stay for long term
cons: No major cons as such.

headline: Good Company to learn
pros: Learning is good.. but you are all on your own
cons: HR stuff needs to be followed up n number of times... The work is your responsibility since the time it is assigned.. Follow up and get done..

headline: Job
pros: Good salary, flexi timing and nice work
cons: Decision making 100% with leaders even for you. You will never know what has happened so you are getting certain feedback.

headline: Brutal lifestyle but learn a lot
pros:
Steep learning curve
Great branding
Hours will always feel easy after this
cons:
Long hours
Not respected within office
Your time isn't your own
Menial, tedious work

headline: Growth in career is always possible for proactive folks
pros: Overall, working on this company provided significant positive impact to develop ones skills.  People are always open-minded and great to work with.
cons: Just like other large companies, relationships and networking is a must learned asset so one must always watch out for this.

headline: Work culture
pros: Focussed, and sharp, meant for performers only.
cons: Training can be strengthened, HR need to be more responsive

cons: nonearCap is usually requiring prooven experience in certain technologies, like SQL/T-SQL, multithreading, etc. and they are seriously asking about it on interviews and are canceling appli

headline: just another BPO
pros:
Only if u are  under the wings of a humane manager else  you are gone for a toss

Good training period again if u get good trainers
cons:
1. There is no RISES for employees in customer service
2. High attrition leads to high work load
3. Pathetic HR that only approach employees while begging for refferals.
4. A mini east india company
5. Be ready to face racist customers over a span of 8 hours.
6. Only bootlickers reach the peak.
7. Full of biharis and bengalis who spoil the ambience at work.
8. People will try to armwrestle specially hr and managers , just break their fake ego.
9. OT money coming in arrears but if you take leaves incentives deducted immediately in the subsequent salary slip.
10. Transport dept is poor n clumsy.
11. Typical slave like mindset.
12. Ready to concede every demand of customer. 
13. Pathetic food in cafeteria and in pantry,

headline: Nice place to grow and learn, vertical as  well as Horizontal growth is encouraged
pros: Pay is good as compared to counter parts also job security is also a factor to be considered.
cons: Structural changes after every three months which leads to unpredictable job scenarios and work culture

headline: Good opportunities to learn, but politics dominates career progression
pros:
- Very good training programs
- Clearly focused on changing the public perception and the image, filtering down from senior management to juniors
- Diverse range of people
cons:
- Very political
- A lot of new initiatives started by new managing directors - often felt like these detracted from the work that needed to be done and were more a way for the organizer to get their name out there
- Not much flexibility to relocate

headline: Project Manager
pros: Good opportunities for professional growth
cons: Bureaucratic as times which can be frustrating

headline: Really a great experience working with a bunch of enthusiastic techies.
pros:
Please note that my review is totally depended on the project/manager that I have worked on/with.

I worked on a challenging development project from scratch. We were a bunch of enthusiastic techies, everybody was an individual contributor. There was no internal politics.
It all depends on your manager; the culture he/she set and the exposure that he/she give to his/her team.

Pros: -
1. Individual contributor role. 
2. No micromanagement.
3. The managers are highly technical.
4. Good exposure.
5. Transparency in management. Higher management (ED and MD) are also very approachable and always ready to answer your queries in as straight forward manner as they can.
cons:
1. Parental Mediclaim policy is the worst in the industry. I sincerely believe it needs to be revisited. It was the only reason I left BTCI.
2. Work life balance could be improved.

I would say it again that it all depends on your project/manager. My experience was fabulous just because the team/manager were the best guys I have worked till now.

headline: Cut-Throat Investment Bank
pros: I guess the best thing working for Barclays is the fact that you can throw the name around and people will be impressed.  Only your colleagues and those close to you will realize that Barclays is just a turn-over machine.  If you have no choice and are desperate, I would recommend Barclays but simply as a springboard.
cons: Barclays is a typical turn-over machine.  It does not matter how much time you have put in the firm or how valuable you are for day to day operations.  YOU WILL GET THE BOOT! They work you non-stop with no recognition whatsoever and when its time to cut jobs you will be on the list.  Only those that are working there because they know someone are the ones receiving the kudos (even those individuals are not safe from the Barclays sword).  I personally dealt with upper management and lots of other sections of the firm and most of them had no idea what they were doing.

headline: Lots of experience gained
pros: Excellent reputation, secure job, good salary, opportunity to develop and further career.
cons: Process improvement, staff cuts mean May branches are under staffed putting more pressure on existing staff. Can be relocated for no apparent reason.

headline: So much potential to be great...
pros: So much talent, it's amazing to work with such wonderful people.  The company was a true melting pot of individuals  and  backgrounds but everyone came together to focus on achieving the goals that were set.  Pay was fair and the flexibility around time off was more than generous.
cons: Long days, especially outside of the UK.  Management in certain areas tends to not appreciate their people and fail to give credit where credit is due.  There has been a wholesale shift in the corporate belief system in an attempt to appease the UK press.  Sadly, the result of this has been a changing of the guard with senior leadership.  Many of the original Barclays Capital leaders have been exited from the organization and are being replaced with Retail Bank personnel.  Morale is at an all time low given the number and frequency of redundancies.  It's a challenging work environment when you're constantly looking over your shoulder and wondering if this is the round where you are exited.  Due to the challenging financial culture, management in technology seems to be focused more on hitting budget numbers than setting a strategy and leading their people.  In recent times, it felt as though more effort was being spent on audit remediation than building the strongest product.

headline: A MNC Captive with good overall culture
pros: MNC Culture, Work life balance, compensation
cons: Leadership and global vision changes are too frequent - leading to employee low morale.

headline: Aggressive, entrepreneurial shop that became too political. Lehman was the nail in the coffin.
pros: As long as one is politically connected, one can coast for a long, long time here.
cons: The ex-Lehman mentality has destroyed a once admirable shop.

headline: Analyst
pros: Always new things to learn as it a very huge setup of IT across the globe
cons: globally team across different time zones

headline: Overall, it was challenging and fast-paced environment, full of ambitious and hard-working people.
pros: I worked on the trading floor in a sales support capacity and finally in a sales seat.  I was never bored or wanting for a challenge.  The people around me were energetic and entrepreneurial in nature.  I was always surrounded by a stimulating buzz of activity.
cons: You have to enjoy working with aggressive, hard-charging people.  Work-life balance can be out of whack unless you are extremely talented at your role and managing yourself and those around you.

headline: Cashier
pros: Lots of customer interaction, good way to join the ladder, ideal for school leavers
cons: Very sales focused, not paid for hours above and beyond the branch working hours

headline: Company is doing OK
pros: NYC. HEart of times square. Work life balance
cons: Bureaucratic. Groupism. Pay does not depend on performance

headline: Great Experience for Intern
pros: Extremely flexible work environment, open door policy, sportive managers, work life balance is maintained, consistently 'fun' activities are planned for all employees including tournaments, townhalls, potlucks etc. Great opportunity to learn, rewards and recognition are common.
cons: Growth opportunities are not immense, stretching is a regular practice in the finance department.

headline: Memorable, fun, and good culture
pros: Good training place. Quite a comfortable team environment for me.
cons: Difficult to get promoted. But it's simile to other banks, have to have somebody to leave to get his position

headline: Very good start, terrible towards the end.
pros: Good salary, good annual bonus, exposure to niche technologies and  processes.
cons: Terrible management style,  too much empowerment to people close to top leaders,  lot of prejudice and favortism,  poor HR support in case of any harrassment.

headline: Friendly  & Flexible working Enviroment
pros: Very friendly environment, Colleagues are respectful. Salary is competitive

headline: A P at BARCAP
pros: Nothing that I can think of. Started talking about exit from day 1.

cons: Excellent company, fabulous work environment

headline: Chaos
pros: Interesting work, not bad remuneration, had lots of opportunities. Strong push internally to embed new values, not just for show
cons:
Bureaucracy, lack of definition of responsibilities - too many people trying to compete to do the same thing. Move to a 'one Barclays' model making slow progress and moral was very low. 
The flat hierarchy and promotion process meant that you could end up taking on much more responsiblity than you are rewarded for and people would work alongside each other with the same role and level of responsibility but different grades

headline: Ever Changing Projects and Managements
pros:
Competitive Salary
Exposure to latest tech trends
Appealing Leaves
cons:
No Job Security
Ever Changing management & thus it's Decision
High Pressure Work Environment

headline: Good People to work with
pros:
It abides by its values of diversity
Growth opportunities
flexible work hours
cons:
Rationalization is not apt
strict timelines with assigned work
poor coordination inter team

headline: Mixed
pros: growth opportunities, good local management, centralized IT systems, focus on training within some departments, focus on mobility within departments, unofficial writing on the wall to hire internally displaced staff when outsourcing
cons: Centralized decision making sitting in London delaying approvals, massive offshoring plans, while they have an unofficial 'no-jerks' policy there are quite a few people that could be only classified as that and still prospering, inter-regional conflicts of interest always settled in London interest irrespective of what is good for the bank, focus on being seen as demonstrating the right values versus ingraining them into your daily work-life, implicit suggestion that career progression can only occur if you relocate to off-shoring location

headline: I love it! Especially, casual dress code!
pros: Great people, and opportunities to move up in future.
cons: It can be a long day, but I mostly enjoy everything.

headline: Hard working marketing team
pros: Good collaborative working environment, lots of opportunities for driven people.
cons: As with any commercial environment, projects can move very fast and workloads can change in the blink of an eye.

headline: If I see just one more email entitled "Changes to Leadership team..."
pros:
The name is still good on the CV, apparently. For reasons that escape me. There is a healthy work-life balance, shown in spades by the fact that even the MDs have started leaving at 3pm on a Friday afternoon now. If they don't care, the rest of us certainly shouldn't.

A BIG pro is that there is no downside to doing a bad job! No, really. None whatsoever. People are never fired from Barclays Wealth if they're not pulling their weight. They're tolerated for years on end until they get paid off with a fat redundancy cheque whilst those of us STUPID enough to hang around and do some work get paid a bonus which is less that these lazy people got paid on a tax-free basis for being laid off.
cons:
The best reasons would be to witness - first hand - what a chicken does after the head has been cut off. Of course, not all chickens are born into this world equal. Barclays Management chickens, however, are given bottomless pits of money to buy in expensive management consultants who will go out and interview the staff and then repackage their own employee's advice as their own. And then set a new "Strategy". Yay! New strategy! 

Expect that - and this is the brilliant bit - none of the Senior Leaders want to taste their own cooking. We have lost three very senior people in the space of a month. The Financial Times noted this, as did everyone else. Every couple of weeks, we get another banal email from the "Leadership" team about the latest changes to team structure, reporting lines, brand of tea.....

My simply advice would be - STOP WITH THE COMMS AND START DELIVERING SOME ACTUAL STRATEGY.

This is a uniquely "Wealth" Problem. No other part of Barclays is this sick, unmotivated or leaderless. Staff are leaving in droves. People are bored stupid. There's no career progression within Wealth, and why would you want to stay anyway? They haven't a clue what they want the business to be, look or smell like in a year. It's dull. Really, really dull.

headline: The most unpleasant place I have ever worked
pros:
The command-and-control style of management has had some wins: the market data infrastructure is better than many peers.

Some very good quality teams in IT/quant
cons: More bullying than I have seen in all my jobs put together. Simply vile. Worst offenders were trading in IRD and Equities. But bad behaviour almost everywhere. Shouting, hounding, nervous breakdowns, you name it. I was an appalled spectator rather than a target but just witnessing things was enough to thoroughly depress me.

headline: Good staff but very poor senior leadership
pros: Most people have a positive attitude and want to do the right thing.
cons: The management all pull in separate directions with the senior leadership team usually resigning within 9 months of starting the job. The bonuses for people vary hugely who are doing the same job performing as well as each other. No career opportunities for a long time due to re-org.

headline: No Comments No Comments
pros: Will Let you know once i have it, as require a lot of thinking.
cons: Let me Think again, Very less thinking required but not wanna spend now

headline: Work hard with good benefits
pros: A company in a constant state of change at the moment where you can do well if you keep up and are in with the right crowd. Friendly bunch from varied backgrounds. They seem to value diversity, so not everyone from financial services anymore. Really like the new values and personally feel valued. Good benefits.
cons: Very long hours required if in London office, plus high pressure. Deadlines always excessively tight.

headline: Wasted talent....
pros: There are a lot of very able, hard working people at the Firm who really know what they are doing.  It is such a shame that there is so much wasted talent.  Department management realizes that morale is at an all time low and does what they can to offer perks that they are permitted to offer.  Work life balance is decent.
cons: The employees who actually do know what they are doing at the firm are not promoted, paid or recognized for their hard work.  In fact there is no recognition for hard work or going above and beyond for any of the employees in infrastructure.  Compensation is poor.  Morale is the lowest it has ever been.  There is very little faith in the current company management and CEO.  Current employees often feel as if they are paying for mistakes others made in the past.  Management appears to be satisfied with status quo and affecting any change is very difficult.

headline: On the way down
pros: Good people to work with, salary is good for most part
cons: No direction, Constant Layoffs with no rationalization around the cuts.  Americas GTIS head seems to survive all the layoffs

headline: Aggressive bank but lack of vision
pros:
Above Industry standard Pay and Bonuses
Work on new technologies
Flexible work environment
Good learning curve
cons:
Poor management
lack of vision and proper protocol
Laying off rumours

headline: Time to leave barcap
pros: Used to be a good place to work with smart people, although it went nose down after the libor news
cons: The entire place git Really messed up

headline: Good professional opportunities but the firm is falling behind the leading investment banks.
pros: Global investment bank so it provides opportunities to work across the globe. Good and balanced blend of legacy Barclays and legacy Lehman employees plus new hires since 2008. Good work-life/vacation time.
cons: The lives of the majority of the employees were encumbered by an expensive and time-consuming rebranding and reengineering of the firm's culture that had suffered because of the missteps of a small number of key employees. That lead to lack of focus on producing. Morale is at new lows.

headline: Some smart people with great intentions but there's a mountain to climb...
pros: The talent (in the areas where you can find it) can rival that of the best banks in the City.  Those who are engaged are sincere and hard-working, and there is plenty to sink your teeth into if you like a challenge and can see your value-add.  Staff are friendly and want to help.  CEO has also made a good start with re-emphasising core professional values at every level.
cons: Staff who want to help don't know how, leaving a few people carrying a lot of the load.  Better investment in resources (salary, training and career development) is needed.  Although there are a lot of great ideas, there is seldom enough time given to implement; changing direction is fairly commonplace, leading to constant upheaval and a sense that management is reacting instead of planning.  IT systems need better cohesion.

headline: Uneven shift timings, undefined schedule and no utilization of working hours
pros: If you are looking for free cab services, beverages  and waste of your time.
cons: Unethical work schedule, perks are provided only if you wanna ruin your social life. The break timings are not defined properly, leading to haywire schedule at work.

headline: Aight
pros: Work environment is average, it's comparable to other large banks. They have great holiday parties. THere are opportunities for advancement but you may be required to relocate.
cons: The may make promises in the hiring decision and not follow through with them. Be careful if you are promised the moon.

headline: Very demanding with a sharp learning curve
pros: You will learn a lot in a short period of time.
cons: Long hours and unpredictable schedule.

headline: Work here if you enjoy being constantly disrespected.
pros: Opportunity for decent pay with little education or experience required.
cons:
There is zero flexibility and management is not at all understanding and can be very disrespectful. While I was there, just about every person I knew who worked as a Fraud Analyst repeatedly had their vacation requests or leave requests denied. Even if you have vacation time and request to use it months in advance, it was almost always denied for at least part of it. One time, I requested off for my aunt's funeral and tried to use a vacation day for it. My request was denied, so I spoke to a manager about it. He became extremely rude and asked if it was really necessary for me to go, and suggested that I take only a half day. I told him the funeral was an hour away from the office in my hometown and he said something like "Well it must end at noon, right? You can drive straight here and be here around 1". Not once did he offer even a fake expression of sympathy or condolences. He made it very clear that he found it stupid that I wanted to stay at the luncheon afterward that  my parent's were hosting. Apparently only an idiot would want to help their mother out after she just lost her sister. 

This was a terrible place to work and I got out as soon as I could. I started there with a new hire class of 10 employees. When I quit 8 months later, only 3 of the original 10 were left. Some people became so upset with how they were treated that they literally would unplug their phones and walk out of the office to quit right away with zero notice. I was able to stick it out until I got a new job, but barely. 

They try to make this job sound better than it is, but the reality is you will be answering phone calls nonstop from the second you walk in each day until you leave.

headline: Good  REPUTATION for LIFE LONG WORK.....
pros: Excellent chance to gain EXPERIENCE in Foreign Exchange TRADE
cons: Do not  ARGUE  with FOREX TRADER on the DEALING Floor.

headline: Great Loved working there
pros: Independent , allowed autonomy, Good compensation
cons: When UK Barclays came in they squelched creatuvity

headline: Good place to work at
pros: Good chance for leadership and Personal growth. Very Global in its perspective and diverse work culture.
cons: Management could use improvement, Transport facilities need to be better

headline: Company Culture
pros: Big company, can be good if you are good in relationship building and networking
cons: Sometimes things will be very difficult to move

headline: It got slowly worse
pros: I loved it at first.  I worked hard and was rewarded for the hard work.  It was wonderful to get profit sharing each year and also a Christmas bonus.
cons: As time went on, everything changed.  The rewards were harder and harder to get.  When my Mum died I had to take unpaid leave.  The perks, few and far between

headline: My time at barclays
pros: Working at Barclays has so many opportunities. You never really need to leave. It also has fantastic pension, annual leave, healthcare and the pay is pretty good. The bonuses are great. It is a very comfortable place to work. It is quite easy to network and move your way around. Its very 'PC' and friendly. Social scene can be varied. People are generally out of the office by 5.30pm and your work life balance is mostly respected.
cons: You have to play the game, rather than just be good at your job. There are so many people that you really have to work smart to stand out/avoid being a number. But everyone is kind and fair and so long as you work out how to play the game, the sky is the limit really. It can become quite stale with very little breadth to roles (i was there 6 years) but i enjoyed my time there and it has set my career up for the future - people really respect the name on your CV.

headline: Company and top management is growing but team members at executive levels are frustrated.Promotions are totally biased.
pros: Work life balance in pockets
cons: Very poor yearly increase in salary. Promotions highly biased

headline: Great fun, hard work,  very political
pros: Good compensation fixed comp and bonus
cons: No work life balance, very political

headline: Grooming Organisation with sufficient Growth Opportunities
pros:
Good Salary Package
Good Professional Management
Opportunities to move abroad
cons:
No Work Life Balance
Less Cross Departmental Opportunities

headline: Good company to work with
pros:
Good pay
People friendly atmosphere
Perks and benefits
Oppurtunities
cons:
Systems and work procedures
Lack of management action
Work life balance

headline: Too much change!
pros: Cannot think of any good reason!
cons: Revolving door, exodus of senior managers

headline: big company bureaucracy, lots of process but good in many other aspects including training, diversity perspective
pros: salary for this location, top performers get good bonuses, good for cv, good training, peers good folk to work with, most management ok.
cons: process heavy and hierarchical, no real decision making power at middle let alone junior management level.  Recommendations go a long way up line.  To make significant progress takes much more than standard 35 hours as need buy in from so many people. probably + 10 hours on standard week which can affect work life balance.

headline: Demotivating and uninspiring
pros: Company has a lot of good people working internally.  Great skillsets and good personalities, talented as well.  Great place to hang out at if you don't like doing much work or accomplishing much of anything.  Pay is decent, but below market rate for location.
cons: Lack of ability to get anything done.  Everything is rule by committee and unless you're Director level or above, no one listens to nor cares for your opinion, no matter your level of expertise.  Dual-headed teams engenders competition and lack of clear direction inhibits progress.  Promotion is done via good ole boys network and grading for reviews is done on a curve; one person must receive a poor grade even when undeserved.  If you're not in the UK, your opinion does not matter.

headline: Lots of opportunities to progress!!
pros: Great organisation with good benefits
cons: Unreasonable targets at times to difficult to achieve

headline: Technology Analyst
pros:
reasonable working hours
nice colleagues to work with
cons: lost too many talented people during last two years

headline: Good company to work at
pros: Listen, able to give feedback and chance to move in  your career
cons: Culture within different parts of the organisation not working together

headline: Technology Analyst
pros:
reasonable working hours
nice colleagues to work with
cons: lost too many talented people during last two years

headline: Good company to work at
pros: Listen, able to give feedback and chance to move in  your career
cons: Culture within different parts of the organisation not working together

headline: Good workplace, inconsistent HR / IT policies
pros: Values internal talent over external, highly aligned to global functions, grades etc. Flexibility options and compensation is good.
cons: Technology often creates hurdles especially for data intensive work. HR policies are wildly inconsistent at times

headline: fine place to work
pros: Employees generally get along and treat other co workers well.  There is a good work life balance.  Good place to start off career and finish out but not as good in between.
cons: The company lacks direction and a lot of turnover of leadership in past few years.  The talent attrition continues to be a problem and one they have to fix if they want to remain competitive.

headline: Alright for contract work
pros: Everyone is friendly, working hours are good
cons: Got hired through an agency so I dont get the same pay and benefits that my colleges do.

headline: Trainer for Barclays bank
pros: Great development, had no experience in training delivery but was given every chance to grow and improve my skills and abilities. My managers in this area were the best I've ever had and it is a meritocracy so hard work pays off. Development plans are clear and achievable. Very nice and well equipped training venues as well. The most tech focused bank and are way ahead of the competition in most of these areas.
cons: Overly complicated management structure where sometimes common sense cannot prevail as too many people need to be involved in a task. Although it is changing, the company is still very "Silo'd" - communication between departments is something that needs to be improved. Training department goes through many phases of displacements and restructures. Annual compensation not very good

headline: Not great long term
pros: Good on the CV, learning about corporate structure and general banking experience such as key training.
cons: Not a lot of room for progression.

headline: Great place to work for
pros: Great office culture. Good choice for personal growth due to the large number of teams available. Flexible working hours as well.
cons: Too many teams. Work can get hazy due to a large number of teams collaborating. Case of too many cooks spoiling the broth.

headline: tax avp
pros: work life is the greatest
cons: turnover/scandals make it not fun

headline: Confused
pros: Barclays has talented people across the organization, there are definitely smart players here who understand the market and the business they are in. The place was fairly flexible about time off, and some work life balance.
cons: The place is quietly very political, with different fiefdoms among teams and individuals who are supported and not supported. The lack of success in the investment banking space means the place is shedding people and not paying competitively. Often the true status of things are not expressed until people are shorted on bonuses or let go. The future of the i bank as a major player in the US is really up for grabs

headline: Bank in a state of flux
pros: Excellent talent to work with and a vast array of products to sell.   Working with management side by side truly helps get you involved in the banks plans as a whole and what direction they are going.
cons: The talent is all leaving, either voluntarily or being forced out and what is led i'm not sure will be a sustainable institution for very long.

headline: Overall great people in the main, naff system and well intentioned senior managemet team
pros: Most staff are hardworking and friendly. Great values and strategy is clear.
cons: Poor pay, work life balance, some areas are concerned about perception than what you deliver.

headline: Barclays is a great organisation to work with.
pros: great work culture, challenging job, great counterparts. i learnt a lot in the process of working. it has been a great journey
cons: ther r no cons in working with barclays. it provides ca lot of opportunities to talanted people

headline: Strong company great opportunities for development and progress
pros: Strong culture, excellent training and great colleagues
cons: Given the size of the organisation it can be a little slow to react - think oil tanker like

headline: High and Lows
pros: Really talented and all-around great people (for now).
cons: Very political - progress is slow and changes are usually too little too late. Lots of turnover - losing good talent due to frustration with the organization. HR promotion process makes no sense - is not based on meritocracy and contributions - and compensation is weak.

headline: It's Okay
pros: Everyone works together. People are pleasant.
cons: Layoffs have become the "norm"

headline: Great career move, poor life choice
pros: Resources to do great equity research, decent pay and if you're in the right group, it's a meritocracy. The pay at one point was good but with all of the scandals bonuses get cut with regularity.
cons: The HR system is abysmal, management does not care about its employees and morale could not be worse. Everyone at the company got their bonuses cut during recent scandals despite being in completely different operating groups. Furthermore, nothing ever happened to those involved, they had already left the firm. Also, the pay discrepancy between your superior and yourself is massive. For example, my former boss made over 20x my salary.

headline: Its ok
pros: Decent benefits and work-life balance, hours are average.
cons: Outdated technology, management is clueless, no room for growth, a lot of turnover.. a lot of layoffs and in result great talent has left. Salary average at best.

headline: Good company for a spring week
pros: Broad overview of all businesses and plenty of opportunity to branch out
cons: The 5 values things is a massive gimmick that everyone but HR has realised is not serious

headline: Hope it gets better
pros: Used to be a great firm
cons: Unsure about lot of things

headline: Good Company to work, gain lots of experience
pros:
Good range of projects, to gain lots of experience
Good people, very friendly and helpful
cons:
Very long hours
Training needs to be improve

headline: Overall it is a good place to work
pros: Good salary, training opportunities along with travel. A lot of positive people who a willing to help.
cons: Some teams have unclear goals for the present/future. Company strategy changes too often recently.

headline: a
pros: a good company with lots of diverse people. good support management. share scheme is very good. lots of support form hr during iniation. senior guys know thier stuff and have worked thier way up the business
cons: can be very competitve to get noticed. also hard to understand who does what becuase the company is so large. but if you are used to large corprate environments it should be fine. also good company benefits such as share scheme

headline: Shambles
pros:
- Very good work-life balance. This is essential because it's too disheartening to go into the office every day.
- Some buildings have nice, modern areas. Not mine, but some.
- Some good internal resources i.e. catering, creative services. Great for when we finally have budgets again.
- Salaries are ok, but bonuses are non-existent.
cons:
- No clearly articulated strategy. No one seems to know what they're doing or why.
- Huge morale problem.
- Poor internal communication. 
- Feels like everyone has checked out.

headline: Relaxed environment in ops dept
pros: Relax, no pressure, relatively good pay and benifits
cons: Career path unclear. Aggressive outsourcing

headline: Positive In a tough market
pros: CEO Jenkins strategy to refocus the bank along stronger values has been a positive for moral and a real game changer in making barclays the "go-to" bank.
cons: Head count reductions is making internal promotions opportunities more difficult in the near term

headline: some ups and downs
pros: meritocratic and give emphasis on delivery, good pay, good bonus, freedom to grow, steep learning curve as the company is in growth phase
cons: too aggressive, overly competitive, no work life balance, no training, no easy movement options and needs more internal opportunities

headline: Political
pros: long maternity leave i didn't benefit from,
cons: highly bureaucratic, political, ppl only work on the own personal agenda, long hours,

headline: Most Pathetic IB I ever worked for
pros: Nothing on Pros side... Not even Salary... Only thing is Training is very good.
cons: Many... No work life balance, No Company Value

headline: Good for CV
pros:
Good name to work for
Friendly people to work with which makes it better
cons:
Company don't have a clue what direction they are going
Too many focus and changes

headline: Culturally lacking
pros: Good locations for offices and staff benefits are pretty standard for the banking industry; most staff are competent and pleasant to work with.
cons: Management are lacking in moral fibre - caring more about their own bonus than about their staff and the people around them. Minimal flexible working and offices and working practices are dated.

headline: Solid place to work
pros: Headroom to grow and scope to learn
cons: Too many restructure on a regular basis

headline: Client Service Manager
pros:
Knowledge of various Barclays Products
Relationship Management
Stakeholder Management
cons: Set rules, hard to deviate from processes

headline: good
pros: flexible management, firendly environment to work in nice people to work with in retail environment
cons: sales. can be under staffed in retail. long hourrs when things go wrong, sometimes not allowed to claim expenses if not pre approved

headline: A good learning experience and full of bright people especially in technology
pros: Lots of in-house learning opportunities and regular seminars hosted by the business. A strong culture of working across different teams. People were very motivated and passionate about the firm. This was the Bob Diamond era.
cons: Timescales for project delivery in IT were very tight with the expectations that you will did whatever it took to get the work done. Forced ranking was in place during my time, which meant some people had to be in the bottom quarter. This quarter were always in danger of losing their jobs when redundancies were announced.

headline: Performance Oriented Culture
pros: Barclays gives a very good base salary and comprehensive benefits. There is free medical coverage and some dental coverage. A transportation allowance is also given.
cons: There is a lack of cohesiveness in the corporate culture.  Business groups are rather siloed and there is a lack of cooperation between them.

headline: A good place to work if your face fits or if you don't want to develop your career.
pros: A steady work environment with some really good people. Benefits are reasonable with an excellent pension. A great name to have on your CV as people recognise that if you can work at Barclays you can work anywhere.
cons: Career advancement depends more on who you drink with than your ability. The importance of company values is emphasised by senior management but their behaviour does not display them. Prospects for career development are very poor.

headline: Used to be great, now disappearing fast
pros: Was great until the decision was made to shrink the investment bank. Now, everyone is running for the hills.
cons: Layoffs and more layoffs. Morale is at the all time low.

headline: Great summer analyst program
pros: A lot social events for intern to reach out senior employees in the company. Freedom to choose your team with plenty choices
cons: I really cannot think out any cons here. But a few weeks ago, Barclays in AMER laid off many people and now it is in the law suit issue about its dark pool.

headline: Head of Latin American Interest Rate and FX Valuations
pros: You're pretty much left alone to direct your own career
cons: Extremely limited opportunities within the firm.  Can't keep its name out of the news

headline: Respect the person and not the job role
pros:
Working with a global workforce
Potential for training
Potential for progression
Lots to learn
cons:
Too much politics
Issues (widespread) take too long to get resolved due to the amount of teams normally needed to be involved.
Unable to accommodate flexible working
Inconsistent following of policies
Get fobbed off when you actually have an issue
Inability to commit to long term plans. 
Very over managed within the role
Push back on following processes correctly.
Too much to learn about - makes it difficult to easily share knowledge in team and external to team

headline: Good package if you are a strong performer, but you have to give up your personal life to get it
pros: Dynamic, fast paced, challenging, lots of scope to move around
cons: Constant threat of redundancy, extremely long hours, leadership levels have excessive amounts of politics and in fighting which gets in the way of them achieving the new vision.

headline: Awful, do not come here
pros: Money is good, Canary Wharf is pleasant, there are some good individuals
cons: The worst kind of investment bankers, especially in IT... Team work is unheard of

headline: Truly inspirational and groundbreaking.
pros: The team is a major motivation, the benefits package which barclays provide is also outstanding
cons: Some of the targets are out of reach as they set by colleagues who do not work in that particular sector, thus not understanding the challenges we face on a daily basis

headline: Absolutely terrible
pros: It's nice to say you work for a top bank
cons: They almost seem to target Managers for sacking people. Terrible environment. Charge people for a cup of tea. No flexibility regarding sickness - 3 strikes and you're out. Use of poor recruitment agencies, so people coming onboard were useless.... where should I end this list - I could keep going for hours?

headline: Good organization to work for long time
pros: Remuneration, Less work pressure, Work life balance
cons: No self development, exposure to various other functions is limited

headline: Great work experience for an entry level hire.
pros: Really talented, smart, ambitious employees contribute to a high functioning organization. Relatively flat hierarchy so plenty of access to senior leadership. Entrepreneurial environment makes for a place you can get experience contributing to a variety of projects.
cons: You can invest 25 hours a day and bring your A+ game and it doesn't feel like enough to get the job done. Work never feels finished and leadership forgets to appreciate your work in any real form/fashion, monetarily or not.

headline: Good training & a well oiled machine
pros:
Adequate remuneration, excellent hygiene factors (offices), good training and good trainers and they did actually spend a lot of time on the "culture change"/"values" change.
I was also very impressed with the clarity of the organisational structure and responsibilities. I was always clear what to do and who to deliver results to and was confident when handing over to other team.
cons: Little or no opportunities outside of London (1CP), average bonus payments (as % of base).

headline: Top bank undergoing restructure.
pros: Great history and great staff. Could be great again if restructure is done correctly.
cons: Lost a lot of good people during the current restructure.

headline: It's a parking zone.
pros: Depend of the department and you can find more or less flexibility to your needs. In a very short term can useful to grasp some experience, but it is not worth more than 1 year.
cons: Poor investment on developing employees. Very little chance to grows professionally. Very low compensation, shifts can be exhausting, but if do not work on shifts, the work life balance is definitely one of the best, 35 hrs p/w.

headline: Working at Barclays motivates me to improve my skills
pros:
Nice environment
Skilled people
Modern technologies
Continuous integration
Scrum
Ongoing learning process
You can learn from other people
cons:
More managers than developers -> current situation in the project
The older employee, the more skilled in making excuses why job has not been done yet
Waiting for issues to be resolved instead of resolving it by myself, e.g. issues with the applications
Proxy

headline: Started off all right...
pros: Got to try out a few roles when I started, got some good experience and training, and (while not relevant to me) they supposedly allowed for a good work-life balance for working mums.
cons: Change after change after change. Everyone was constantly ready for battle, knowing you'd be at risk every 6 months meant everyone was fighting against their colleagues, doing anything they can to make themselves look better. Projects regularly started and thrown aside, wasting time and money and killing motivation. Hoops to jump through at every stage.

headline: Good work environment, good career growth opportunities, brand name, values based, good exposure based on your profile
pros: Employee concerned, good career growth for hard workers & good paying organization
cons: Can't recollect any - none

headline: Very lucky experience with my team
pros: The structure of the Finance Graduate Program was ideal for a first job out of school, providing a well-rounded training curriculum and an opportunity to learn about all the different areas within in Finance.  I can say that there was a recognition of the higher-performing graduate analysts, and that they were rewarded with the placements they sought out.
cons: There is a lack of true cohesion among all teams not only inter-departmentally, but also within Finance itself.   Many teams seek to "protect" themselves rather than all constructively work together toward a greater purpose.  Collective morale also took a big blow with all the high, senior-level misdeeds and the associated bad press.

headline: It was rich and rewarding experience with Barclays. Was there for two years and found that it offered a good platform.
pros: Wonderful Brand name. Excellent Working culture.
cons: Their businesses exited a few countries while still doing well. This I felt was unusual strategy

headline: Few progression opportunities, people are horrible, hours are long and little to none social events
pros: Nice building, decent canteen, and on the whole they will provide training if you need it.
cons: Little opportunity to move, long hours that are sometimes not necessary. The culture is very poor, most people can be quite nasty in front office and everyone is extremely selfish. A place were you don't want to wake up to go to work, that's for sure.

headline: 'Interesting place to learn'
pros: Sincere staff, good promotions. Open to new ideas.
cons: too much reporting work in the name of analytics. Honestly, rarely any analytics. Back office work mostly.

headline: trader
pros: salary is paid on time
cons: the atmosphere needs are ignored

headline: Dynamic
pros: Highly dynamic environment, a lot of intelligent and enthusiastic people to work with, interesting technology challenges to solve. Environment is very open and the management culture flat. Very good global setup. In my job I felt supported and cared for.
cons: Dynamic and demanding environment may not work for everyone - it requires people who are bright and quick on their feet.

headline: Working at Barclays is completely educational
pros: Barclays is very structural with a full set of policies and procedures. It is very helpful to find everything set and clear.
cons: Environment is very competitive with a prejudice for grades among employees. Fluctuations of salary among same level. Barclays expansion was not well studied with defects in infrastructure.

headline: The worst  experience I have ever had in my life
pros: The paid me on time and sometimes early if it was a weekend but the staff incentives for having accounts had been lowered over the years.
cons: Bullying managers at branch level.I almost had a breakdown due to the pressure put on me.Targets and profits is all they are interested in.Even when it was raised as high as I could go nothing changed.I met some great people who had suffered at the hand of this this "go to bank."variation management" is another word for measuring your sales targets. The new moral high ground which was supposed to change the whole bank has not changed a thing.My friends who still work there are the people I feel really bad for.

headline: Very good personal experience in small team but overall organization needs a great deal of work.
pros: DIrect managers are extremely caring and a joy to work for. Flexibility, boss is extremely understanding of all outside factors. Work/Life Balance provides opportunity to focus on family life. Down to earth colleagues make for a collegial environment. Independence  to build, own and manage processes lets you make what you want of your role.
cons:
Very bureaucratic, it takes forever to get an answer or an approval due to countless layers and endless mixed messaging. Extremely slow pace for anything.
Compensation was flat out bad and promotion process is inconsistent. No focus improving, just a focus on cutting costs. Very volatile organization with no stability due to lots of layoffs and a revolving door of employees. Communication is lacking as folks make decisions in isolation. Directors sit with their doors closed and many colleagues ignore emails and do not return voicemails.

headline: Good pay and benifits, Worst culture
pros:
Pay and benefits
Work life balance
cons: Highly political, no value for new ideas, no growth

headline: Good learning experience
pros: IB toolset at bulge bracket
cons: IB lifestyle at bulge bracket

headline: Sad demise of Barclays
pros: Local to where I live,good part time hours,wonderful customers.
cons: Company values have disappeared over the many years I worked for Barclays.I gave my all and they gave nothing back not even respect for my 38 years service.Not even a 'Happy retirement ' or 'Goodbye ' card.

headline: Its just a cool place to work
pros:
Work Life Balance is simply superb.
I had a very good mentor and personally we should try making more friends
cons: I haven't come across any cons. Just be good and be work properly.

headline: Great! however was cut short due to company budget/job cuts!
pros: REAL worklife balance and committed to employee's welfare!
cons: Nothing really minus the budget/job cuts!

headline: Android Developer
pros: they will make you sit without work for ages. if you are fresher best place to start
cons: no pressure in the work. needs to deal with lot of teams. no one will communicate to you

headline: Good place to learn from onshore but mentality of BSS bosses not big enough
pros: Anyone who has the appetite to learn with patience can strive and succeed
cons: Lack of transparency and openness in dealing with people.

headline: Corporate VP Front Office
pros: Good benefits and career prospects.  Below market average pay.  Good culture and peer support.  Continuous professional development supported and encouraged.
cons: Hierarchical.  Can be political and internally focussed.  Very heavy governance and compliance requirements. Numerous reputation and legacy issues remain unresolved.

headline: Good place to work!
pros:
1) Life work balance is good
2) No overtime required.
3) Employees benefits are really good
4) Management gives ample opportunity to learn.
5) Good number of holidays and paid leaves
cons:
1) Too much process to be be followed to complete simple activities.
2) Organisation is moving towards agile but still stuck with the old SDLC process.
3) Feels like people are getting fired every month. Keeps you on your toes.

headline: Very busy times with a lot of technical change delivery
pros: Plenty to get involved in with good technical innovation and a friendly working environment. Performance management driven with staff reward based on performance. Good set of ethical values for a financial institution.
cons: Poor project management and team silos. Too much red tape and brick walls are put in your way to hinder getting the job done rather than working as an extended team.

headline: Great place to start a career in finance
pros: Investment banking at Barclays provides a great learning experience for college graduates.
cons: Compensation is never above the street.

headline: A truly awful culture; political, blame, "jobs for the boys/girls" - avoid at all costs
pros:
Money - they have to pay high end to get anyone to work there
Benefits - the pension, insurance and stock options are pretty good
mmmm that's it
cons:
Senior Management know they are fighting a losing cause so surround themselves with "yes" people and pull up the drawbridge.
Presentee-ism culture - and backward looking - they block the use of Social media in this day and age!!!
Execution driven and cant stick to a plan, strategy...analysis and forward thinking are non existent
Huge distrust between Management and middle ranks
There own self defined definition of "Talent" is "The top 200" or "SLG" - nothing else matters and forget the notion of talent rising through the ranks - they just buy in at the top. Even supported by what is well known to be the worst HR Management in FTSE.
CEO is slowly smothering the cash cow Investment Bank rather that re-structure the company properly.
The "culture change" programme has been a flop - C suite think by "sheep dipping" 100,000 employees through a 2 hour culture session it will change the company's culture!!!
Have a look at the Salz Review and see how Barclays has missed nearly every target set for sustainable change

headline: Contracting and culture not changing
pros: Scale and opportunity to do different things
cons: Actions do not match words when talk of values and changing culture.  Workforce treated as resources in a short termist way rather than long term partners in achieving the corporate goals.

headline: WonderFull!

headline: excellent company

headline: Do not join GCOO Strategy team. There are two Senior managers who are bullies

Not a friendly environment, quite hostile
Not much development available

headline: Ehhhh.
pros: Most of the people I have met are very helpful. Great health benefits, 401k match.
cons: Promotion process is unclear and completely different depending on the area of the bank you work in. There are seemingly people with titles who shouldn't have them as they don't do anything, or know what you would expect them to know for having that title. Executive management does not appear to have a pulse on all the negative sentiment that exists internally. Not a fun place to work. Direct mgmt seemingly doesn't care about it's staff. It's not a growing company, it's a shrinking one.  No raises for years. Seemingly impossible to get an interview internally without knowing someone. HR is the worst. They are slow to respond: to queries, job submissions, etc. completely unhelpful.

headline: Ok when Bob D used to run things.  It has fallen apart after his departure.
pros:
Good internal mobility
Good international mobility
cons:
Terrible pay
People paying too much attention to how long you've been away from your desk

headline: Decent package, messed up management with constant reshuffling.
pros:
- Decent package including pension and other benefits
- Good on your CV if you're a graduate
- Relaxed environment with a lot of very smart people!
cons:
- but then there are as many not so smart people...
- IT roles technically not challenging - if like me you come from a engineering / hard-core tech background you will be bored with the role within a year.
- politics, politics and politics
- reminded constantly to be on your best behaviour
- rubbish appraisals process

headline: very much depends on who you work for, the feudal system is alive and well
pros: smart people and an interest in doing things well , decent pay when you perform well, You can get things done with support and when you fight to get organisational resources allocated to the right things.
cons: senior management too focused on the short term bottom line, not the business growth. The internal feuds between different business silos is depressing, though probably not worse than anywhere else.  Currently seems to have zero long term vision

headline: Do NOT join this firm!
pros: A few... such as a good health plan and decent training opportunities.
cons:
The list is endless... but I'll give you some of the highlights:

1. Lots of politics, ZERO meritocracy... Earlier these problems only percolated into performance ratings and bonuses, but now with the redundancies, it decides who gets laid off and who doesn't. Lots of fantastic people are being laid off and lots of useless folks are being kept on board purely because of political reasons. Everyday, this company's total employee calibre (if there were such a thing) drops to new lows :)

2. No management foresight: The decisions taken by management are very short sighted. This includes HR policies, decisions to enter/exit businesses and geographies, and even corporate real estate policies. There are numerous examples: i) spending millions of dollars to build a new system and then as soon as it is ready, realizing that it is useless and reverting to the old system. ii) Firing somebody and giving them a redundancy payment and then calling the person the very next week to offer them a job back! iii) Moving to a new office due to lack of space and then within months, firing half the people in the office iv) Setting up back office operations in a particular country over 2 years and then closing down that centre within a year... the list is endless... the management seriously have no clue what they are doing. Completely useless!

3. Questionable hiring practices... You just need to look at the mix of people in some teams to realize that there is something wrong. Forget about managers hiring employees from the same country. In Barclays Singapore, you see a focus on hiring people from the same state or province! A manager from Maharashtra (a state in India) would have a team filled with employees from Maharashtra, for example. It's weird that the HR does not notice or do something about this.

4. Policies that punish employee loyalty: It is much easier for a manager to hire a new VP from outside than to promote a current Barclays employee in his own team even if the Barclays employee has far more experience and is far more capable for the role. I know a case where a manager advised his own team member to quit the job and reapply to Barclays to get a better position!

5. No organizational stability: I know it is important for an organization to be nimble, but the way the org structure changes in Barclays is crazy... it's like an amoeba! One of my friends was technically moved across 4 different teams during the course of one year, all while doing the exact same job throughout (even his desk did not change!)

6. Increments and bonuses are pathetic. They will lure you with a decent starting base salary, but that's almost all you're ever gonna get :) 

I could go on... but you get the picture.

headline: Various roles: Great company to work for. Real chance of progression.
pros:

If it hadn't been for me starting at the bank 4 years ago I wouldn't be where I am today (Mortgage consultant)

Challenging but very worthwhile, depending on your role some more training would be useful...
Target driven environment has been disposed of which is a bit of a shame, now the targets are on the backburner....

headline: Review

headline: What a mess!
pros: I wish I had something positive to say about this bank.  Unfortunately, I do not.  It has been riddled with scandal after scandal and remains only a shell of its former self.  As banks cycle through these sorts of problems on a fairly regular basis, I am sure Barclays will rise again but not for a good long while.
cons: The recruitment was amazing!  Barclays recruited me over the course of 11 months.  It took that long to organization a package that I and my family could live with.  Within 21 days of my coming onboard, the entire management that had recruited me so carefully had all been replaced.  All promises made with no long in effect and I found myself scrambling.  Horrible experience!

headline: Challenging

headline: Okay place to be in.

headline: loved it

cons: just making sure we did our jobs to the best of our ability

headline: Rogue bank with law breaking, whistleblower breaking culture
pros: Decent offices, good third party managers, weak control and non existent compliance
cons: Constant law, rule and reg. breaking, finra and sec violations daily is usa.  Retaliation from management if you complain about it.  Policies that screw clients of best returns and deliver false performance reports to clients

headline: Barclay's The Grave Yard of Ambition
pros: Overall a solid company which is built on long term stability
cons: Barclay's idea of training is sticking something on a computer screen, they do not sign up to any form of extra qualifications for you to take. They do not give you any time or structured training other then your job title. Finally progression is based on "sound bites" its not how good you are.. its if you say the right things. The Pay structure needs to go up by 5k per grade.

headline: technology analyst
pros: The people in Barclays are generally nice and welcoming. They are willing to help new learners, especially grads who just came out of school. The graduate training program is good as it helps students without finance background to know more about the industry.
cons: Culture here is pretty laid-back, most people in the bank do not actively seek cutting-edge technology solutions, partly because the systems wouldn't work with new technology. Most platforms are at least five years behind the modern technology available. If you want an interesting technical job, go to silicon valley.

headline: Assistant Vice President

headline: Great Work experience, Lots of changes
pros: Good salary and benefits. Working conditions are also very good.  All of my managers were extremely supportive and allowed for plenty of networking opportunities.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy making promotion very difficult.  HR cares more about perception than employees safety.

headline: Very political, moral is in the dumps
pros:
Large investment bank
Looks good on the resume
Good place to start
Work/life balance
cons:
Very political
Moral is rough
Hard to see your value (HUGE company)

headline: The highs were great but the lows were dreadful.
pros:
The people I worked with were great, we had fantastic laughs, and supported each other through the tough times both personal and business related. 
If you wanted to move your career forward there  were many opportunities, however you 'face had to fit' a lot of the time.
cons:
The demands that were put on you were often unrealistic. The focus on sales rather than service was the biggest problem. You often felt like middle and high level management had no idea what it was like to actually work in a branch and speak to real customers. 
While they went through the motions when there were people with health issues they were in fact very unaccommodating when it came down to actually helping people with disabilities (in my personal experience).

headline: Dissapointed
pros: I worked with a fantastic team, in a nice office. As we were far enough away from 1CP (global HQ) we had the freedom to enjoy a good work/life balance, and were monitored on the quality of our work rather than the amount of face time we put in (which is what colleagues at bigger offices tell me is the main thing they're judged on)
cons:
Lack of opportunities for progression.
Inept management and leadership by MOST on all levels of the organisation.
Uncompetitive compensation cf. elsewhere in the industry - no rewards for loyalty (several of my colleagues left the bank, then returned in the same job for much higher wages as an external candidate).
Complete global ban on travel hinders business.

headline: Good Employer
pros: Good experienced staff, reasonable focus on L&D and excellent share incentive scheme for the employees.
cons: A bit old school, people in same roles for a number of years - lacks innovations.

cons: The bank still maintains a target driven culture that inadvertently encourages bad behaviours across the board. "Bonuses" at the branch / call centre level are unreliable and frankly subjective.

headline: Software Engineer

headline: Horrendous working hours
