cons: Extremely fast paced working environment. Expectation on you to work 60-70hrs a week excluding meal breaks. Average salary with no increments or bonuses. Hire and Fire policy.

headline: Although I had a rocky start, overall a good company to work for with good values and ethics
pros: The possibility of career progression, good training systems and good benefits. Majority of people I worked with were friendly, helpful and supportive.
cons: Frequent branch moves, no progression for me although I passed a personal banker assessment. Uncertainty of job security due to job cuts moving into self service branches etc.

headline: Like banging your head against a brick wall of bureaucracy on a daily basis
pros: Good renumeration, benefits, great holiday & pension. Supportive management. Nice offices.
cons: Very difficult to turn ideas into actions, was always a struggle to get things to happen.

headline: Great people to work with
pros: Great people to work with. Collaborative atmosphere. Work-life balance is good.
cons: Compensation. Poor base salary, poor bonus. No opportunities for growth.

headline: Stultifying and frustrating processes to get basic stuff done.
pros: The compensation was very good, and working hours really weren't bad for this type of a company.  I did have the opportunity to work on a pretty good project so there was some satisfaction there.
cons:
The level of talent there was very uneven. When staffing a project, I was under considerable pressure to hire "warm bodies" rather than find the right people for the job. Schedules were unrealistic (though to be fair it did not translate into a demand that employees work longer hours). Though I enjoyed the work and the challenge, it was in other respects just very stifling. 

The worst part was the unimaginably complex and unworkable system of requesting anything, or putting any change into the system. This made attempting to do your job efficiently very frustrating. They practically have to hire dedicated people just to operate a byzantine change management system designed by demons.

The company has a binge/purge mentality with respect to its employees.

headline: Good
pros: Company has a good policy and values in place. But, they need right people implement (Now the values are only hanging in Walls and Desktop)
cons: Management should listen to their reportees and not to the stakeholders.

headline: It was wasn't that great which prompted me to want to leave the company.
pros: They were pretty good with balancing personal life  and work.
cons: No one in IBD got a raise, OT or bonus in the past 4 years.

headline: Excellent package, aggressive culture not for everyone, revolving door at the top
pros: The salary and benefits were excellent. There was a sense of teamwork within my own team, although this didn't extend to the senior management.
cons: Work-life balance was very poor, with often unfeasible deadlines and very long hours. The amount of travelling required could be extreme at times. Senior management were dictatorial. The performance appraisal process was very much a "management tell" rather than a two-way discussion, with decisions on performance ratings having already been made before the meeting took place. Feedback could make or break your career in an instant.

headline: My Experience
pros: Benefits (such as My Barclays Rewards) are great. Incentives ('Colleague Reward') is terrible, especially if you are part-time.
cons: Management of individual teams are not yet fully on board with the new Values - many (especially Telephony Team Leaders) are too focused on 'Sales'.

headline: Barclays provided excellent opportunity to learn and devlopmy skills in IB.
pros: Learning opportunity, Global exposure, Relative good work life balance
cons: No career progression, front office will never hire anyone from ops, no competitive salary / compensation, job security issues as they are keep moving jobs.

headline: Well paid but they own you 24/7
pros: Money is good. Nice Office. They had a very good canteen at Canary Wharf in London.  Plenty of food & drink establishments close by.
cons: I can sum this up using the advice given to all staff 'Going home to your wife & family at the end of the day is a wasted business opportunity'  In my time there I saw people being dragged back from holidays half way round the world for ad-hoc meetings that were a waste of everyones time.  I saw a clerical junior being couriered a mobile phone so they could keep asking him stupid questions about unjamming the printer etc. while he was in his hospital bed (then made him redundant a month after he returned so they could save money)  I had to work almost all bank holidays even though there was rarely any work to do.  I soon learned to take my holidays in places with no phones or mobile signal and tell people all my weekends were being spent at the other end of the country.   When I finally left it took me three months to stop jumping every time the phone rang.   But I am probably describing every big merchant bank in London.  Just make sure you save or invest as much excess salary as you can so you can retire early.

headline: ruining a good place
pros: Making moves that should help it in the future..although it will take some time and pain to get there
cons: Talent is jumping ship as people aren't getting paid and they announced 25% reduction in headcount.

headline: Working culture was good
pros: Work Life Balance, good salary package
cons: cafeteria is not good and un hygenic

headline: Used to be place to work at
pros:
Still sizable but with all the talent going else where.
Can't think of anything else...
cons:
Horrible communication by management.
CEO that has been put in by regulators in UK to do Lehman acquisition
Impossible to get promoted these days
Other banks will eat BCS lunch

headline: awesome
pros: amazing place to work, fun environment
cons: none that i could possibly thing of

headline: Values and behaviours
pros:
- good office location
- diversity networks, volunteer events, lunchtime talks, clubs, etc make for good networking
- internal mobility
- talented colleagues
- Learning opportunitites in many shapes and forms
- flexible about leaves and good leave allowance
- stated values are great (albeit not necessarily real)
- Innovative products that Barclays brings to the market
cons:
- Sourcing operating model makes no sense - the wrong thing done for the wrong reasons
- interaction with key stakeholders only over the phone, even large projects are expected to be done on a "call center" mode, no travel
- management has failed to make investments and provide support to make remote operating model work. Videoconferencing services are terrible
- odd working hours (late nights) and uneven rules around flexible working (depends on mgr). Contrasts with diversity goals, e.g. very difficult if you have family
- lack of return - all take no give. E.g. no travel allowed, poor bonuses, etc.
- HR is terrible and makes leavers even angrier. Also Failure to create a professional interviewing/ hiring process and hence very poor employer branding with applicants
- lack of empathy and failure to address dissatisfaction on the floor and attrition with measures that make a real impact
- missed opportunity to leverage innovation and change potential from large influx of new joiners from other industries. Processes inflexible and culture not geared towards best Sourcing practise. Compliance and process skew versus best practise Sourcing, good deald and innovatiin

headline: A great experience and enjoyed the team and technical work environment.
pros: Got well together, amazing infrastructure and amazing team support. Flexibility in timings. Wonderful learning experience. Great platform to exhibit self ingrained skills.
cons: some challenges i have encountered here is I took a little of time for me to first catch hold of the financial sector and its intricacies.

headline: Barclays whats going on
pros: Free wi fi excellent team feel satisfied you have earned your pay.
cons: promotion within the team SUCKS. The management team are unfeeling robots. pay not that great environment to P C. very stressful

headline: Barclays whats going on

headline: Management out of touch with reality

cons: There is no accountability for poor performance.  Management lives in it's own little boys club patting themselves on the back preaching this "Go to bank" nonsense as vrevenues fall and clients run out the door.  The amount of self righteous notifications to their employees on how the Transform plan is working out is sickening as they continue to miss revenue estimates.

headline: Corporate Relationship Manager
pros:
Great support and work environment
Great corporate mentality and ethics
cons:
Limited progression opportunities
can be overlooked in favour of graduate newcomers

headline: Values
pros: Great Values. Can relate to all.
cons: Senior Management not diverse Enough.

headline: Senior Change Manager
pros: Salaries are good as are benefits, which tend to be "golden handcuffs" when considering leaving
cons:
It has to be the most toxic culture I have ever worked in ever, senior management are too many levels away from the workface to understand that the functional processes are unusably complicated and ineffective.
Being politically correct is more important than being good at your work. It is a sad force fed culture that drives values that the company itself will disregard with impunity. A recent redundancy project at Barclaycard has been the most dire, shambolic and poorly executed process ever conceived and oh so poorly executed.
It is trying to transform itself but will have to shed layers of institutional stupidity to achieve the turn around envisioned

headline: Average
pros: Mobility is encouraged, you can typically move across functions/locations within 18 months. Work-life balance is a plus. However, job stability is now in question.
cons: Compensation, bonus and promotions are limited

headline: avoid
pros: beats being unemployed in the current job market
cons: Very stratified.  Very British.  If you are not in London, expect to be the last to know about any changes.  Bank doesn't know what it wants to be when it grows up.  You are only as good as what you did yesterday.

headline: Frustrating
pros: Great colleagues to work with
cons: Lack of career path, delay in decision making, low morale

headline: Good place to work. All depends upon group.
pros: Good perks and benefits. General Wall Street perks.
cons: Work-Life balance but this is banking.

headline: No longer a premiere financial firm to work in
pros: Working from home is allowed.
cons: Too much bureaucracy and office politics get in the way of people actually getting work done.  Morale is very low especially with the 'Bad Bank' announcement as people feel unsettled not knowing when they'll be next to be cut.  Too much restructuring going on and the feeling is nothing at Barclays is ever stable.  Lots of budget cuts and as a result hiring is also limited.  Bonus and raise have been horrendous the last few of years.  Only higher ups are getting bonuses which is not fair as it's the doers that get the job done, not management.

headline: Totally dependent on whether you're in with the right people

cons: Sincerity in high level vision does not translate down to lower levels of management where quick wins and box ticking are the order of the day. Ridiculous amount of story spinning goes on and Managers choose the people/areas that enable them to tell a good story in the short term. Other areas or people are left out.

headline: Myopic, out of control. Hates its clients.
pros: Lovely people to start with. They really do employ top talent at the lower level.
cons:
Systems nightmare
Bullying
Accountability is absent
Strategy is absent
Focus on values is hysterical....senior and mid management take decisions that directly oppose the values.
Hr is management protection
Political behemoth. Staggerring that it is still in business.
Anti client experience at all levels.

headline: Good place to work, great colleagues, no work life balance
pros: Co-workers are friendly and helpful. FO systems are good but BO systems are not so great. Internal mobility is promoted well.
cons: No proper training is provided. Due to cost cutting a lot of redundancies, people are not motivated enough. No rewards & recognitions.

headline: Good organisation to start career.
pros: Good for starters. The BFSS department is worthwhile. RT is great for starters. The class of people working is good. Academy coaches are cool bunch. BAU managers are typical managers. Salary is paid on the dot by 8PM on 28th of the month. The set of beliefs are foundation for any good personality. Overall a good experience until you are happy.
cons: RT is monotonous. Over time nothing is left to learn. Tedious trainings for the process but no certified training. Transport department is inefficient and seldom annoying. Negligible global exposure. Just a part of Barclays, not completely Barclays UK standard. Food at Noida 2 is pathetic(you'll agree from day one).   Never employee centric. Just a cost center. Don't expect huge exposure or package.

headline: Credit Risk Application Analyst
pros: Good place to learn new technologies. Management encourages hard work, attend training etc.
cons: Very Stressful and no work life balance.Hire and fire culture.

headline: Moving target. Every year new management and new plan.
pros: work life balance and training is good
cons: no carrer development, no success culture

headline: Experience is very good as far as the banking sector is concerned.
pros: Staff loans, efficient HR, training
cons: Rigid promotion structure, career specialization is limited

headline: A difficult place to work right now
pros:
Good added benefits on top of your salary , reduced child care , gym membership , insurances etc that can be taken out of pre tax pay .
Fantastic team of people to work with.
Real innovation in moving the business forward so it is sustainable in the future.
cons:
The customers that come into the branch do not want the changes that are being implemented and are rude and abusive to the staff on a daily basis. 
Long working hours .
Staff leaving and not being replaced, the rest of the team having to pick up their work load .

headline: Vicious cycle
pros:
- work life balance: flexible working hours
- work load is not bad
cons:
- bad management, no continuity on policy and strategy, always changing, wast of money and resources
- bad morale, always lay off people every year
- bad retention strategy - management don't care about talent people

headline: A good company but heading in the wrong direction
pros: Strong middle management with a lot of intellectual capital and great opportunities for informal learning
cons: Senior management is weak, with a lack of focus on business topics, and far too much focus on internal politics. A strong tendency to pass this to their teams to encourage territorialism

headline: Senior Analyst, FICC GLOBAL OPERATIONS
pros: Over-Time plus Time and a Half
cons:
1. Long hours - It is a prison for work and you will not be recognized for your hard work and successes.  Working in global operations, a regular day could begin at 7/7:30 AM and ended around 7 PM/8 PM - 11 PM or 12 PM some nights. Only stepped outside for 15 mins to grab lunch and ate at my desk. This was a typical day. 

2. Poorly managed organization - Management is narrow-minded, hypocritical, and narcissistic - apres Lehman days. Your mistakes will be magnified under a telescope and you will be constantly pushed to do more. 

3. Professionalism and social respect is obsolete. - Barclays is not an institution upholding integrity and respect. It does not encourage sharing knowledge and learning from each other. Management sets the standard and have the only prerogative to come in, get the job done, and leave. Senior leads and management buddy up and turn their heads in bias. Do not bother questioning if what you do is right or wrong, management will not listen. People actually had the audacity to yell at each other on the floor. This was appualing.

4. Technology is Legacy - Difficult to use and puts the bank at major potential risk. All at operational cost. Bank is stuck on old ways (technology) and so it seems to be that management is stuck on old perspectives as well. 

5. HR does nothing to your concern.

I WAS RELIEVED TO LEAVE. Working for Barclays was THE WORST YEAR OF MY LIFE. I have worked 3 years at an equally top-teir investment bank prior to this position, and now at a another, and my experiences are a great contrast to Barclays.

headline: Your talent or skills doesn't matter. You'd be fired anytime.
pros:
Follow process for projects
Some managers are good to work with.
Flexible working options (I used to hit the gym taking an hour out).
Hiring process is stringent; so naturally the people working inside are smart and talented.
cons:
Lousy hiring process. It takes unusually long (~3 months in my case) from interview to offer. When they dont retain employees for even an year, I wonder why they take so long to make a hire.
They always talk about "long term strategy", which they change every month.
One month you feel safe, the next month you realize you're already fired.
While attending interviews, the director/Manager will assure you of long term prospects and can give you 100 reasons why this role is important, but while firing they have 1000 reasons to give why this role is redundant. So never go by their assurances. Just join and keep your fingers crossed.
Firing happens once in a quarter these days; its always like sitting on knife's edge. A good place to lose your peace of mind.
I'd certainly advise any one seeking a career with Barclays to stay away from it.

headline: Bad time to be in Barclays
pros:
compensation is decent, work-life balance is good
lots of flexibility can be arranged with your immediate superior
cons: promotion chances are low. benefits are reducing in the lights of bad performance by the company. very frequent redundancy cuts, especially in the recent times. morale is very low.

headline: Consider any opportunity carefully
pros: There are many talented and good people working here who provide a good atmosphere when the politics are removed from the equation.
cons: The political and bureaucratic environment here stifles creativity and eliminates the possibility of internal advancement. Senior management is focused on saving their own careers and will not choose the right thing over the action that carries political weight. Layoffs are common and frequent and the well being of mid and low level staff is not of great concern to the company.

headline: High initial salary but no increase
pros:
Fast pace. 
Very talented people to work with.
Advance in technology
cons:
Bad bonus.
Low transparency of management's view

headline: barclays
pros: good company, good pay, and good learning opportunities
cons: no work life balance, no transparent perfomance rating system

headline: Team Manager

cons: Limited relevant growth oppurtunities,does not know how to retain good talent

headline: Company review
pros: Great work-life balance, perks are ok, not the best dental, just increased maternity leave in the US to 4 weeks. Company takes a lot of effort in providing various courses and training for human capital development.
cons: Low compensation leads to best people leaving the company, especially in the investment bank.  US division must comply to both US and UK regulatory rules.

headline: working environment is non=collaborative
pros: The reputation has been good up until the last few years.
cons: The company is going through a major restructuring so it is very unstable.

headline: Meritocracy nothing but a buzzword
pros:
You work together with very talented people.

At least during my time a good name to have on your resume.
cons:
The company is extremely political. The one thing you need to know is you will only get promoted if you have a good relationship to your management. Performance of course is part of that, but unfortunately by far not the most important one. Far from the meritocracy they promote when hiring you.

Pay. Gets smaller by the year. And an increasing workload as they keep cutting people.

Culture and morale. The culture is far from cooperative. You have to be lucky to get into a good team. My management didn't care one bit about what I was doing. Morale is extremely low since from the very beginning that I've been there they like to have job cutting rounds twice a year. You just wait to see if you're part of the next one.

headline: IT
pros: Cant think of anything that stands out
cons:
No difference between Permanent staff and contract staff
Hire and fire policy
Treat employs as furniture 
no transparent decision making
top management really bad at communicating things

headline: declining
pros: one of the biggest banks in the uk.
cons: too many changes recently. management seem to be confused about stakeholder management. employees are at the losing end of the bargain

headline: Good Experience
pros: They provide an inclusive environment.
cons: No real culture, no specific promotion process

headline: Barclays Bank - A Premier Employer in the Financial Services
pros: Good environment, Highly Motivated People
cons: Staying too long at work because you enjoy it.

headline: Politics and reorgs
pros: Bring your own device to use on the wifi
cons: The most political place I've ever worked! Very old fashioned development methods and poor technologists.

headline: Pathetic company to work with. Hell lot of politics and pressure (not work but political pressure).
pros: Compensation is good but not the best as compared to other captive untis (like other British and American banks - like BoA, Morgan Stanley, RBS, JPMC). Compensation is peanuts as compared to the amount of work that one is made to do. There is work from home options but seldom. Hike is above industry average, but many are sacrificed for others to get a decent hike. Trainings are good.
cons: Heavy politics. Need to use all the talent not to do productive technical work but to save skin and avoid from getting trapped. Very ugly competition at top level that percolates down. Need to fight with peers in other teams only because the bosses are competitive and fighting out. Worked in several banks prior to this, and never experienced a culture as bad. Work pressure is no less, as they make a person do 2-3 persons' work.    Growth is slow as it is in any captive unit. No one is helpful. No one likes questions being asked. Manager does not like if you ask him/her questions. Manager does not like even if you do not ask him something and ask someone else. Huge resource problems. You are expected to do work, but never provided with resources. Some managers are very psycho. They make life of their employees difficult only so that they can help them with resources later and get a sense of achievement. Work hours are extremely stress-full, but after that you are not disturbed till next day (but its difficult to get rid of the thoughts of activities that happened throughout the day).

headline: Great place to work challenging
pros: Flexible work env  too much politics
cons: Bonus  too much politics

headline: Fantastic learning opportunities
pros: Great flexible working environment, manage your own hours and just as happy to allow staff to work from home. Lots of access to some great training courses and great opportunity to network across the organisation
cons:
Bureaucracy, matrix management and not enough senior management living the 'values and behaviours'.
Serious hierarchy issues where grade is everything regardless of what is said.

headline: Review
pros: Good with staff. Professional environment
cons: Difficult supply chain. Excessive governance

headline: So So
pros: Barclaycard US is specialized - only credit cards and deposits. If you know these products, you do well.
cons: Barclays, the global bank in the UK, is almost always struggling. So, even though the US card business does pretty well, they have to deal with global problems such as financial issues with the investment bank and a slow-growth consumer franchise in England. This results in budget cuts and layoffs every 2 years.

headline: Poor work culture
pros: This place is good if you want to gain some banking experience. The projects are led by a competent technical team in the UK.
cons:
The work environment here is not too good. Basically the entire management here is from Verizon. It is a pretty well known fact that Verizon has pretty bad reputation in the Dallas region as far as work culture goes. Its pretty much the same here. 

This place has way too many redundant managers who seem to have gotten here just because they were all friends with each other at Verizon. The main management for the projects is in the UK which does a good job of maintaining a process. The Plano center mainly develops the requirements passed down from the UK, it does not have projects of its own. The managers here have zero control over the timelines, deliverables, new features, etc.This also means that this place is at the mercy of a projects from the UK. This has resulted in many layoffs recently as a result of there being less work and budget cuts. They are now also outsourcing most of the work to TCS in India. This is not the best place to be for job security.

headline: Co-operative and motivating to progress

headline: Disorganised, Political and Cheapo
pros: Still a good brand name
cons:
1. They can initially offer decent base salary to attract you but thats it. Bonus, raise and benefit are worst I have seen. Cost cutting can be extreme. So better negotiate your base hard enough before joining to make up for the rest.
2. Highly political organisation with no meritocracy.
3. On technology side, quality of people is generally not good, esp. for an investment bank
4. On technology side, work is very messy and disorganised. Most production systems have been done in most quick and dirty fashion I have ever seen. All that legacy is very difficult to live with but also very difficult to change now. But yes there are few teams which are exception. So its best to get a clear picture work-wise like before joining the organisation.

headline: Struggling with culture

Learn patience and and hard work, therefore appreciate your next job when you get sick of doing meaningless tasks 80+ hours a week.
cons:
Your regular i-banking culture: no work-life balance, don't question senior folks, lots of grunt work 
Combined with Your regular large corporate culture: bureaucratic, political, HR will always find a way to screw you etc.
Do not rely on getting a decent bonus, IF any. Yes, you might not get one.
Attrition is darn huge, people fleeing to industry jobs that pay the same base or higher and work a third of the hours, OR boutique advisers or investment firms, where the is less BS.

headline: Always overtime, chaos, cheap outsourcers is the way to go!
pros: I hardly can say something here. Look for pros at some other reviews.
cons:
1.	They hire people with terrible English. Some managers worship naive and cheap students at outsourcing locations. You can easily find at those places incompetent and quarrelsome people who don't have any basics of work ethics, responsibility, and essentially don’t understand what they are doing.
2.	If you are a professional software developer you better avoid this place, you have to be crazy to go work there. At some places people shoot emails late night and across weekends and try to meet fascist deadlines.
3.	It doesn't matter how good you are or whether you are right. Once you shown a mirror to your manager you will be always shown in a bad light. Objective difficulties to meet a deadline are not considered. It is always only your low performance is the root of all evils.
4.	If you work at outsourcing location you will be cut off from many things they do in London. You have to guess what they know or decided or already done. You better guess well otherwise you will be labeled incompetent and stupid. As soon as one knows something it is a weapon to present itself as a smart and competent. Don’t expect too much help from anyone.
5.	Have a good salary? Watch your back then! They will fire you first as soon as you finished all they wanted you to do, unless you are a one’s favorite.

headline: Great experience

headline: Not good
pros: It is better to work for Barclays overseas, rather than in India. In US/UK, the company has a decent brand name, and benefits from a strong local leadership team in the major geographies that it operates in. Conservative in its market posturing, it is doing reasonably well from a financial and strategy points of view.
cons: In India, the main issue for Barclays is terrible leadership. Lack of transparency, ethics, professionalism. Performance appraisal is simply an eye-wash. Ratings and bonus are not determined by (a) the quality of work you do (b) the value you have generated for the company, but by other factors (read nepotism, cronyism, bias). HR best practices and leadership best practices are routinely flouted, because you can get away with the same. There is a tremendous culture of change resistance, innovation simply cannot happen because it will either be stalled because of vested interests, or, because leadership support will not be there. Strategy and management changes too frequently. Inadequate technical training for high end, high skill jobs.

headline: Work hard, play reasonably hard
pros: Work life balance _is_ taken seriously.  There are opportunities for travel, secondments etc, both within the UK and internationally.  Very broad mix of cultures in the office.  Professional and dedicated colleagues for the most part.
cons: Career trajectory still defined to a large extent by what your boss says about you at PD and moderation sessions - which he may not tell you about. Culture of secrecy still pervades the whole remuneration/bonus area.  My dept can be totally focussed on MI and internal metrics, and not see the bigger picture.

headline: WORST SALARIES and BENEFITS ever!
pros: Good name to put on a resume (maybe).
cons:
Every year people are supposed to have reviews with their managers and they are supposed to receive their salary increases and bonuses. NO SALARY INCREASES whatsoever, regardless of the long nights, constant pressure and stress, and increasing chaos. To add salt to the wound, BONUSES WERE INSULTING. It does not matter how efficient you are and how much you improve the processes and how well you work with others. Nothing matters because in the end YOU WILL NOT GET REWARDED FOR ANY HARD WORK. 

All management cares about is staying late, falsely assuming that more hours will result in more work being done. People are tired of this, which is why they are flying out of this firm. Morale is low. Compensation is worse than any other bank. Talent is moving on to better firms, that's for sure. 

If you want to love your job, don't come here. You will not only hate your job here, you will also hate your life.

They need to recognize employees at all levels and compensate them for their hard-work, rather than only rewarding those at the top. The company will not change anytime soon...it will take at least 10 years to rebuild the company culture and make it a 'go-to-bank'.

headline: Initially it was excellent but you soon realise you are just a number and their 'values' count for nothing. T

cons: Senior Management have no concern for the actual people and they think they can do whatever they like. They consistently want staff to work longer and longer under extreme circumstances. Retail Banking is a dying industry and Branches will be closing even though they have denied it to the media.

headline: Worst company Ever if you are in Data management
pros: *Good pay master but you have to negotiate.
cons:
* Senior management is always lost, keeps experimenting for bad to worse, one day their strategy is something else and every other day they 
* Too many managers for you - One/two in UK, one in India, one may be in US
  and there is absolutely no coordination between them.
Every manager will assign you tasks with toughest deadline possible and if timeline missed even by a day it will be escalated to higher managements.
* Senseless managers sitting in between only to disrupt you, had they not been there I guess everyone would become more productive.
* No one cares about no one here, very unfriendly people.
* Too much power given to manager and no one would ask you for their feedback.
* Transport department could not be worse, make you wait and wait for drops , cabs provided like tata winger etc, changes the drop location without even informing you
* Food is free but it tastes like feet.

headline: Think twice
pros:
Generous in trainings and paid leaves.
Values being promoted by the senior management are good
cons:
The ideas and values being promoted by the senior management (read: CEO, MD's) are great and even bordering on ideal, but what happens on the ground is far from it.  It's as if the head is disconnected from the neck!  For starters, there was this mess-up when dress-down Fridays was introduced.  People got mixed messages from the middle managers on which offices can wear jeans and which cannot dress down at all. Came to a point wherein the regional COO had to be called in to clear up the confusion. Talk about cra-zy!

Then there's that flexible, work-from-home benefit being promoted as well, but guess what?  People who wanted to do that in the SG office had to file for paperwork and get Director-level approval, and this process took practically a month. And this approved period is good only for 3 months, and can be revoked.  Most applicants don't even stand a chance, they get shot down immediately by their direct line managers.  Reason being given is that there is a different impression when people work from home, that the productivity is not that high and your appraisal gets hit if you do so. Yet interestingly, they do not account for are those late-night calls with London and New York offices and still expect people to be in at 10am despite being in meetings until midnight the previous night.

It does not end there...

There's this weird practice of firing people on redundancy in January, and then the bank gives the crappiest bonuses to those IT staff who are left behind.  The director delivering the bad news starts with this glum "the-bank-didn't-do-so-well" speech, then hands over the insulting numbers.  Think 2-3 DAYS worth for an annual bonus despite getting a "Fully meets expectations" rating in your appraisal.  And then give it a few days and the big bosses announce the company profits. Kind of insulting, especially since we have to pick up where those who got retrenched left off with no handovers whatsoever and still expect to deliver their work PLUS our work.  So yes, redundancy is the new promotion for those of us left in the trenches. 

So there, it may be better in other office locations, but the SG office, err, think twice.

headline: A horrendous place to work, both professionally and personally
pros: [Depending on your role] you can be reasonably well-paid (caveat: if your management chain wants you to be - see cons)
cons:
1. Total absence of senior-level leadership, none. 
2. Seemingly no collaboration between senior managers - often blatant hostility. As a result more junior team members have to force cooperation and results from other teams without senior management buy-in and often will be openly blocked.   
3. The culture at Barclays is driven by job retention, earnings, and fear of exposure among the senior executives, meaning that cronyism, patronage, and bias is rampant. 
4. Ability, impact, and quality of work is irrelevant. All that matters is how your management decides your face fits during the notorious consistency meetings.
5. If your face doesn't fit you can expect to be managed out (by lack of patronage, zero career development support, slashed bonus).
6. Bullying is pandemic and brutal - and can be shockingly open. Instances of whistleblowing being openly discouraged and warned against by senior managers. HR not trusted. 
7. Staff dissatisfaction and turnover is massive - everyone in my team, and many others who I worked closely with, were looking for jobs elsewhere all the time.  We celebrated those who succeeded.
8. Air of total depression among middle management (B5-B7).
9. Everyone acknowledges the total stagnation which has come about through the impenetrable defensiveness and politics within the business - so many good ideas and beneficial strategic decisions are blocked due to senior politics and personalities, along with constant 'playing with the numbers' to twist reports to meet the desired conclusion, even if factually untrue.

headline: A lot of politics, a lot IT incompetent managers in london, you will not grow here
pros:
Investment in IT is substantial, relatively open to new technology/solutions however don't expect support/help from anyone. Internal move policy, after 1year you can move to other team however your manager can oppose, crucial to do it politically. Prorbably highest salary in Praugue, don't hesitate to ask big pay if they want you. Be sure to negotiate it, coz bonus, promotions,salary increase are very very very difficult (BIG MONEY is eatedn in LONDON nothing is left for other location). Very good location, new, clean, some free drinks. Very good engineers however you will work and report with teams in London/NYK which consider you like outsourced workforce. If you have good relationship with lodnon team you don't need to work much, you can have very good work life balance.
Barclays is a very good brand on your CV after a few years you can move abroad looking for much better opportunity
cons:
You will have a line Manager in prague and will work with team in lodnon, High probability that your line manager will not support you and will not know what you are doing.
Knowledge sharing very poor, not part of the culture
No trainings regarldess of what other are saying, at best  you will have 1 tech training per year with limited choice and sometime questionable quality, there are soft skills of half a day but not clear to me what to do with it as there are not growth opportunities besides becoming a line manager. There are some finance training of half day, totaly useless as finance is very complex and requires much more time.
Big management hierarchy, from you to ceo there are 8 levels. IT manager above your line manager are very incompetent, impressive. You need very good political skills and extreme good communication skills to make you stand out, do not think that you tech skills you bring you anything good (sooner something bad)

headline: Pretty Decent Place
pros: I found it to be a meritocracy, fairly good management, not as aggressive/ competitive as some other large shops. Very smart people and team was always willing to provide support. They have a push towards training. You get out what you put in. If you truly have a desire to rise to the top and are willing to make personnel sacrifices then you will be able to. Fairly good benefits. the new CEO seems very values driven and is ethical.
cons: It is unstructured so many become disgruntled if they are used to a very precise and directive place. This is partly the culture. There is very high turnover, at least in NYC. I think this is due to the competition for top talent. You are only as good as your last months performance so you have to have an A game at all times. Like any place, it depends on who you are working for. I had a couple great managers who I reported to. A few others I would have been miserable. Competition on the street is fierce, layoffs always hang overhead but this is the same everywhere. Don't work at an investment bank if you expect to ride it out for 20 years on easy street.

headline: Good place to work but a big company so some bureaucracy
pros: Good work life balance, decent compensation, really a meritocracy so if you know you stuff and you know how to relay it, you will do well.
cons: Like all big companies, there is some bureaucracy you need to deal with.  This is being reduced so hopefully that hurdle will be eliminated soon.

headline: Good Investment Bank

headline: The big blue boring bank
pros: There was a lot going on and I got to cut my teeth on a lot of remediation work in compliance. I got a lot of experience in a very short space of time. My team was very proactive and we got on well and got on with it. In our own bit of the business we were doing well. I had an engaged line manager and a very good, albeit tyrannical Head of Section. That may be a con too! The facilities in the office were good and the office culture was largely good, though somewhat regimented. It's not a bad place to cut your teeth if your face fits.
cons:
Senior managers are not as engaged as they might be, there was little appreciation for a job well done. Salary was awful for the industry and the level of responsibility. I observed racism in the office more than once, nothing of any note was done about it. Opportunities to move in the business and progress were poor. I was a bit ashamed to work for them at the time because they were involved in countless scandals. 

The business want to make money first and do the right things second, but that is to be expected. At Barclays sense won out more often than it lost but it was a battle.

headline: Political; you have to shout about everything that you do. Most people perform to an excellent standard.

cons: Low salary. Political. You have to shout about everything you do. Lots of backstabbing. Rubbish PD system as the pot of money gets divided by team according to target hit; then again within the team. Even if everybody performs well at the same level; it still has to be split to reflect grades across the board. So really it comes down to how much your manager and your managers' manager knows and likes you!

cons:
One the worst payers in the street ( especially if you stick with them for > 4 yrs or so in non front office functions). 
Reward for performance in areas such as product control, operations , risk and IT is not great. So eventually people either leave or do nothing and become part of the system.
Most projects tend to be delayed and systems are antiquated compared to other top banks.
Preach internal mobility but make is impossible to happen in reality even you get an internal offer
Most Directors in infrastructure are non technical and just people managers with fancy ties.
Traders keep all the money ( almost 75-80% of the pie is for them)

headline: Benefits are a lie
pros: This review deals specifically with the benefits package in Singapore.  I will address the company itself in a separate review.
cons:
The health insurance makes up nonsensical reasons not to pay out once it decides it doesn't want to pay out.  For example, refusing to pay for a medicine because they don't have the actual prescription as well as the receipt (not actually a requirement under the contract, and never required for any other prescription) or not paying for doctors visits if you ever change doctors because they can label the new doctor a "second opinion" which they refuse to pay for.  They don't pay for preventive care.  They don't pay for specialists.  They don't pay for prescriptions.  They don't pay for doctor visits even when you're sick with a serious illness (they don't even want to pay for the doctor who diagnosed and treated my wife's autoimmune disease.  They claim that's not really a disease!) 

The clinics that do take the insurance directly (instead of requiring cash payment upfront, and making you deal with the insurance company directly) are generally terrible quality and not worth visiting.  They have long lines, don't accept appointments, and you get very little time with the doctor for your trouble.  My family has received awful misdiagnoses, and had symptoms completely dismissed by these clinic doctors.  

If you take this job, consider it as not coming with health insurance.  Absolutely do not count on this insurance if any member of your family has any sort of chronic illness.  It will not pay out, and there is no way to change their minds.

headline: Less growth prospects and Mental Trauma.
pros: Meals and Cabs (unless you have no foresight, you will be attracted with this aspect only)
cons:
1. Management is not Employee friendly, especially old employees (they treat them and think of them in management discussions as 'baggage' and thus focus on new-hires).
2. Always give in to any kind of customer demand , whether justified or not. 
3. Promotes stretching and over-the-weekend work culture.
4. Things told in interviews are much better and prospective than actually given on the floor.
If they told you 10 things, you would be actually doing 2-3 things out of that only and sometimes not even those, but totally different . And justify by saying this has become more critical now , so you need to do this.
5. Separate team-divisions are not comfortable with each other and inter-team movements tough if team heads do not like each other. 
6. Deadend of career to people who are stuck up in low standard work and 'mirage' of IJP is shown.
7. IJP policies are non-transparent and some teams are always looked as sub standard, so people stuck in that team are not able to move.
8. Sick mindset of management, inhumane behaviour and treat you like their servants.
I have actually seen some girls crying in cafeteria as they got scolded for small things.
9. Some people are overworked, some are underworked. 
10. Lie blatantly in while hiring and ask things at very higher level to show the that company is great. But reality explodes when you come on the floor.

headline: Good experience
pros: Benefits are pretty good and they tend to pay a little more than above market rates.  The work is certainly challenging and interesting.  The Geneva office tends to act as the hub for most of their locations given that their platform is run from there.

headline: They invested in me and helped me grow
pros: My direct manager when I started there was a great mentor in addition to being a really good person to work for. As I moved around in the company, I found that the line management was really good across the board. I met some great people, was able to work in a highly professional environment, and had decent benefits. I had good opportunities for mobility and advancement and I was able to work in the UK and AsiaPac for short stints to broaden my experience.
cons: Its a very big company, and all the challenges that come with working in a large organization were present. That said, I really enjoyed my time there

headline: Excellent for contacts, poor people development

cons: Barclays doesn't seem to understand what it wants to do. In the time I was there (5 years) the head of the AFrica business changed 4 times. The organization's reporting structure also changed quite a bit. And of course they lost their Group CEO. All in all, they seem to be riding/coasting on their 300+ year reputation. They will attract good hires because they are Barclays. But they will lose even more good people than they bring in - because they are Barclays.

headline: Working in Barclays

headline: Secure job, but not very interesting
pros: Most people I worked with were talented and easy to get along with (those straight out of public accounting firms once qualified). Once you are employed there, it's quite secure (at least at head office location). Compared to public accounting, the hours are tolerable and there was NO weekend working at all within our planning department, so good for work / life balance.
cons: To progress within the bank, it is VERY political and there is generally a lot of bureaucracy. I did not receive encouragement from my line manager regarding future opportunities within the team - basically, unless he leaves, there is nowhere for me to progress, which is a drawback of having a small team and a limited budget for promotions / headcount.

headline: Brandname

headline: Great people, but unappreciated
pros: People and culture are exceptional, very knowledgeable and approachable.  There's lots to be learned here.  There is a lot of loyalty to the people on the floor (including mine).
cons:
Change is being badly managed, directed and communicated by Senior Management.  4 bosses in 2 years. 
IT is under resourced and does not deliver as a result.  Systems are outdated and creaking under the strain.  
Resource of the right level and knowledge is constrained and there has been an unwillingness to pay to get the right resource in permanently especially given the longer term location strategy, leading to a dependence on contractors who tend to leave within a couple of months.  This leads to a continual round of training with no benefit and leads to an additional strain on permanent staff.
There is a feeling that we are being made to pay for working in the investment bank, especially pay and bonus wise, which given that the culture is quite different in the rest of the bank (hours and benefit wise) seems unfair.
Location strategy makes people afraid for their jobs and often leads to inefficiencies and loss of learned knowledge and increased risk as processes are transferred.  Especially when there is a huge amount of change going on in the organisation.

headline: Hemorrhaging cash, BWA cuts bonuses and makes VPs do the work of 3 people
pros: Great research - name recognition...that's about it.  It's very difficult to think of any other pros, honestly.  People seem to be defecting left & right.
cons: cut-throat culture; local Managing Director has a poor reputation in the industry and creates a challenging & hostile work environment; rather than fostering a team environment, mentorship and advocacy among subordinates and across business lines.  It's a real morale killer.  Sr. Mngmt pushes reps to sell proprietary structured products & ETNs, even if not suitable.

headline: Great people but too much middle management and a lack of internal promotions.

- Training although that's obviously budget dependent.

cons:
- Management have little foresight/tunnel vision. 
- Very little promotion opportunities. Most change roles to gain what they believe to be the right level of grade/pay. Also the move to another internal role isn't easy either. There needs to be a internal program to give people more transferable skill to move around! 
- Pay structure isn't great (useless your oncall) and the ranges needs to change.

Senior management changes.  ie. 6 management changes in 4 years. 
Layoffs managed very poorly and people treated very poorly during the exiting process.
 
Quality staff leave once they get settled seeing the lack of advancement, constant reduction in compensation, long hours and highly political environment.

headline: "Boiler Room"
pros: None at all- a true boiler room.
cons: This is the WORST company I have ever worked for. There is no upside- you will be expected to work in slave-like conditions and not be rewarded for it. The blame culture in the nyc office (200 Park) is prevalent- every meeting starts with "who did this, give me a name" so all the good people who really cared about getting it right are gone or pushed out. Even after the recent scandals in the Wealth division, and the new fake "values" being rolled out, NOTHING has changed. The same managers that were hired by all those fired are still there and running the business- unbelievable. Cronyism is rewarded, not merit. Rules and regulations are non-existent, and fraud is rampant.

headline: Great Corporate Culture
pros: Friendly environment, smart people and innovative. They work hard to ensure that there is a strong sense of culture.
cons: Can be long hours but at the same time, you feel motivated to work.  Everyone is onboard with the company objectives.

headline: Very poor compensation no outlook
pros:
Training
Good health benefits compared to American banks
Towards flexible working
cons:
No bonus and raises
Very poor compensation
Flexible working is only on paper
High attrition

headline: Fine
pros: Smart driven people, hard workers
cons: poor corporate culture and communication

headline: Blocked from progress because of race
pros:
Good on your CV
Work life balance is fine in my area
cons:
Currently short-staffed. For the past month 2 of us doing what 5 people normally did. There have been instances where I have been the only person on the desk.
There is still a glass ceiling for blacks. People get blocked multiple times from promotions..not even allowed to interview, or have to watch less talented relatives of long-serving staff members move up above them.
Pay is very low in my area of corporate banking compared to the market...cases where people on graduate programme getting almost double what people with 20 yrs experience who train them get.
Bullying culture is allowed to thrive by a network of lifers determined to slow the progress of those around them in line with their whims and fancies. They have contacts everywhere (HR are not confidential) so you either have to make your mind up to go to tribunal or straight to the top, threatening publicity. I have seen at least a dozen people bullied out of the business in my time here.

headline: Analytics leadership was all about "the popular kids" who already knew eachother
pros: Barclaycard was a company looking to improve and change all the time by introducing technology such as Contactless payments and customer benefit programs such as Freedom. It meant there was regularly something new to work on.
cons: The leadership in analytics was very much about a group of people who had worked together in another company before and who continued to just favor eachother and not really introduce much new people to the leadership. Promised promotions and salary increased were rarely fulfilled and performance reviews were very un-transparent and vague.

headline: Unprofessional
pros: Some really good collegues. Excellent place to get a pay bump.
cons: Highly unstructured and unprofessional work environment. It seems like there is a general lack of cohesiveness and directionality with projects from the management. Almost everything is trapped in the world of ad-hoc requests and one can never see any of their work come to fruition. Though the money can be very attractive, I did not see this place as a good next step in my career. .

headline: Do not work with them and especially for them.
pros: There is of course some advantages. Interesting and challenging tasks to solve in the investment and optimization practices. Working from home is possible. But still in the theory. In practice they will hate it and you will have problems. Interesting training is available, especially in the investment banking field and advanced finance. Work with some well known and smart peer. Stability of the industry is also some kind of advantage, nevertheless, all of the above highly depend on team you are in and the lead.
cons:
Being one of the largest bank in the world they will save money not only on you as a resource but also on software and hardware. It makes it really nasty to come each day to work with fact like this in mind.

They trying to be international company etc, however in reality this is not true. To get promoted in this environment - something unbelievable and unachievable. Depends on your boss, you will be even scared with the fact that he can even make an entrapment for you (which probably also happened in the past). The most surprising is some management members with incredibly poor communication skills. You will feel yourself like a slave.

The most wandering fact is that you will be hired for one job by one people, but in fact you will be working on something totally different and with totally different (sometimes really stupid) peoples. Wandering is also the HR people - they like working for some another company. Ignorance of you as human is quite common. Performance reviews is some game where you always loose. It is known in advance what evaluation you will have :). The company has very effective mechanism on controlling and not promoting people / giving bonuses. They can fail you on anything and make a reason for not to be promoted or recognized.

Very nasty environment to be on. Management will keep saying you lie like we will be the best in entire industry. Annoying is also the fact that there is no such thing as collaboration. It is pity to see some really nice people inside this company. Especially the international members who are getting pissed off usually.

If you coming from some tech industry - think three times before joining this company. Better - simply avoid. Specifics of the business makes it tough as it is very regulated business, in addition, stupidity of some people, miss-communication and even elements of racism makes this kind of job worthless, despite the brand (they trying to promote) and advantages.

The innovation happens rare due to very huge bureaucratic machine. To utilize something new, you have to wait for almost a year to get it working, still with restrictions. Usually people simply give-up of doing something new. Team spirit - is something unknown in the company.

Insulting is the fact they making interview process nice and pretending to be really good by paying good money to recruiters and attracting talent who are "naive" and not aware about inside life and a lot of legal restriction. By the way, interviews are really good - they will assess you from many different angles (probably out-sourced) - use them to get trained :). What these guys are afraid of is LIBOR scandal as they loosing/lost their reputation not only as a bank but also as employer. I would say quite unfair player of the market. This is typical game when legally everything is correct but the people are unhappy.
