headline: Change Leader
pros: Ive found it to be Diverse, dynamic, empowering,
cons: I have to say not many!

headline: Technical Lead
pros: Work-life balance is good and do no unforeseen lay-offs.
cons: No technology initiatives. No visionary technocrats left in the organization.

headline: Barclays Capital
pros: Strong people, tend to be knowledgeable regarding their area of expertise.  Compensation tends to be favorable.
cons: Can be very bureaucratic as this is a large company with many decisions being made overseas.

headline: good place to work and start off career as there are lots of areas to learn from.
pros: lots of changes and development work going on, so plenty of chance to work on different areas of the business.
cons: quite hierarchical, so could be frustrating at times. working hours could be long or after 6pm since supporting business in europe/uk

headline: Service desk Barclays
pros: You can improve English and network, a great dealof chances to move through departments.
cons: Every initiative must comply with company's policy

headline: Ok
pros:
-Good Pay
-Good Bonus
-I've had pretty good managers during my time here
-They give good benefits as weell
cons:
-There are very long hours which may possibly lead to a poor- work life balance I suppose.
-Not the best working enviroment always

headline: Good learning experience
pros: Good leadership with focus on retaining talent
cons: speed on decisions needs improvement

headline: Terrible.
pros: None what so ever. Awful place to work.
cons: Management, pressure for sales, complete disregard for anything personal.

headline: professional Bank
pros:
potential for growth
professional
good salary increase
cons:
business politics
difficult to get leaves

headline: Head Of Consumer Products
pros: Work Life Balance, Open culture, Friendly people
cons: Poor Talent Management and lack of contingency plans

headline: Senior Mobile Developer (iOS)
pros: Good interview structure, four rounds
cons: Salary is not that good, but in TX it is okay

headline: Great place to work
pros: Compensation and Benefits, Work life balance
cons: Career growth and career mobility

headline: Good for starting up a career
pros: Good starting pay. They also provide free training in almost anything you can think of. Not bad work-life balance.
cons: Bad career growth, too much politics, promotions and bonuses are NOT based on merit and technical skills. No job security

headline: A stressful environment. You can learn
pros:
Some learning opportunities
Recognized brand to have on CV
Compensation is Ok
cons:
No career opportunities
Long hours working
Not well organized and not balanced workload

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Good pay, work culture, opportunities. Barclays encourages mobility within the bank and geographically too
cons: Long hours sometimes and not much in terms of bonus

headline: Barclays Capital has more room for growth
pros: Good renumeration and health benefits. Office facilities is generally well-maintained. Colleagues are professional in daily dealings.
cons: Lacking of diversity. Overly process-centric. Cost-cutting in recent years has caused good talent to flow out.

headline: Micro-management
pros: Some smart people. Initiation of a mentoring program has been good, but growth can be difficult.
cons: You will be micro-managed and misled about your compensation. The company, especially in Finance is way too top heavy. Directors dont have a clue about the mis-management that is going on a level or 2 below them

headline: Pleasant and Challenging Environment
pros: Most managers are very willing to help their employees achieve whatever goals they set (including internal movement, education, international opportunity, etc)
cons: Recent management changes have left the company with continually changing objectives and strategies. Likely to get better.

headline: Barclays provide the better work exposure and it is very useful for female employees.
pros: Barclays provide the cab facilities and food. Also they will provide the night shift allowances.
cons: There is a chances to come to office at the weekend also. But they will provide the pay for that.

headline: Ok place to work, if you don't mind a stagnating career with limited promotional opportunities
pros: good work life/balance, good pay/OT
cons: terrible promotional opportunities, low morale among employees due to outsourcing initiatives

headline: Good place to learn and develop but not hugely rewarding for the amount of work
pros: Dynamic with opportunities to learn quickly
cons: Long hours with no bonus prospect, a lot of staff turnover and business changes

headline: Good for resume, bad for social life
pros: Reasonable brand name for resume, decent training programme
cons: Beware of extremely long hours

headline: horrible, after lehman's collapse, this is now a compete circus with no direction from the management
pros: good 401K, good benefits, fridays WFH
cons: no leadership and lack of vision

headline: Decent package, zero work life balance, treated as a number.
pros: Good hard working support staff
cons: Firm is too big, too many IT systems which don't interact.

headline: Good if you're starting off
pros: Fast growth, smart colleagues, opportunity to move internally
cons: aggressive market approach, shrinking foreign banking sector  in the country

headline: Barclays review
pros: good social scene and opportunity to work for a good company
cons: poor pay rewards and lack of promotion

headline: Armpit of Investment Banking
pros: In Menlo Park which is nice and quiet if you prefer a more family oriented environment.  Easy drive to work.  In the heart of Silicon Valley
cons: Barclays tried to regain an identity after Lehman's collapse, but utterly failed.  Companies do not like the bankers, and the only attraction is the bank's large balance sheet.  If you are an analyst looking for M&A or a heavy modeling experience, completely avoid this office.  Most the work you do is pitching and it's rare to work on a live deal.

headline: Benefits
pros: Extremely good benefits being a global bank
cons: If you are under contract, you do not get to enjoy most benefits

headline: High professionism.
pros: Good atmosphere, nice building, good people. Cycle to work scheme. Pay
cons: Not all people are up to standard and you have to deal with some so called experts.

headline: It was a wonderful and rewarding experiebce
pros: It really depends on team to team and manager to manager but in my case it provided me to think independently and take decisions indepently.
cons: At times it looks too bureaucratic. They should provide more internal opportunities for employees being laid off.

headline: INCONSIDERATE EMPLOYER
pros: average incentives scheme. average incentive scheme.
cons: at will firing of employees.

headline: Good for experience and networking. Wouldn't stay for a career.
pros: Intelligent people, open minded attitude. Accessible management at MD level. Flexible and honest HR people. Good networking opportunities.
cons:
Technology support is sub standard leading to a lot of menial admin work.

Cut throat culture. A lot of the management are poached from other firms purely on the basis of compensation without looking at cultural fit or forming a team. High turnover.

headline: The company was fine. The problem was its strategy.
pros: The environment was fine. It enhanced creativeness.
cons: They suddenly changed their strategy due to the LIBOR scandal.

headline: On the job learning is great
pros: Great Opportunity to learn all the time
cons: Nothing bad to report at all

headline: Good whilest it lasted
pros: Depending on the team you work on you will get far in terms of career progression
cons: Mobility or chance to cross train in other products is very limited

headline: AVP
pros: It was growing quickly and changing rapidly
cons: Managers too caught up in politics watching out for their backs.

headline: Its good but you need to practice in doing things for yourself
pros: Its a growing organization in Indian Market
cons: Quality of work decreasing cont.

headline: Great office environment/benefits, above average salary, sinking ship in singapore for IT folks
pros: five months of maternity leave for women, comprehensive health insurance and 21 days of annual leave. Great infrastructure and office environment. Most people you will be working with have great attitude and smart.
cons: iT in singapore are slowly being outsourced to India, Ukraine and some other countries cheaper than singapore. Old time employees have low morale and are all just waiting to be fired so they get their package. Priorities and direction keep changing. Some employees who were asked to leave were offered contractual roles.

headline: I worked with Barclays Bank PLC India for 3 months
pros:
The best part of working with Barclays Bank PLC was
1. Work Culture
2. Support from Senior Management
cons: I served very little time in Barclays Bank PLC

headline: I worked with Barclays Bank PLC India for 3 months
pros:
The best part of working with Barclays Bank PLC was
1. Work Culture
2. Support from Senior Management
cons: I served very little time in Barclays Bank PLC

headline: Analyst in SP Tech Team in FICC
pros:
Will give good salary
Good Brand name in your CV
cons:
Bad and confused Management
 Too Much Politics
Support and configuration stuff for India while Core Stuff is in NYK and Singapore team

headline: Worth my time in this firm
pros:
Diverse group of colleagues
Open-minded
Performance driven (most of the time)
Strong global presence
Depending on the team you work in, some of them are very hardworking, strong bond within the team
cons:
Bad compensation for years, causing strong players to leave the firm.
Inexperienced management in some groups within the firm.
Lack opportunities in Asia
Bad at project management

headline: Worked in Barclays for more than 5 years
pros:
Good salary hikes,
Good compensation
Work -life balance
Good place to work for ladies!
cons:
No career opportunities (at least I didnt find any)
no transparency in the PD process.

headline: Bank that is trying to grow needs to cut the bureaucratic internal structure
pros: Smart people, platform to get things done
cons: Lots of bureaucratic nonsense. Compensation wasn't on par to the street

headline: Good company
pros: good company to work for as a graduate
cons: senior management tend to lack experience in the department they manage

headline: New Business Co-Brand Credit Cards
pros: Bright, friendly, competent people. Teamwork a plus.
cons: credit cards business is very challenging

headline: Good pay, no much deal flow, too political and no diversity
pros:
Interesting assignments
Smart people
Nice offices
cons:
Bad place for women with families
Too much politics
No client focus but rather internal promotion
Values face time at the office
Lack of balance sheet to support clients

headline: Good Base pay....
pros: They base salaries are very good, but bonus component is minimal...Good work life balance since most of the work is done by contractors and done by offshore firms..
cons: Very low variable pay and bonus...hard to move up the organizational chain...Managers need to be better trained to work with subordinates...

headline: Ideal firm to advance career
pros:
Advancment within department
Training
Commute to work
cons:
work environment
mobility at senior level
unclear objectives

headline: Excellent but Aggressive decision
pros: Good career advancement.  Lots of exposure and opportunities.
cons: Job insecurity.  UK centric.  Aggressive business decision which may result in lose-lose outcome

headline: Great place to work
pros: Smart people all around you
cons: Long hours and hard to get noticed

headline: Director - Infrastructure Support
pros:
Better work environment than other banks I've worked at. 
Hard working, intelligent but collegial co-workers
Working hard to grow the firm and compete at global level
A bit more entrepreneurial than other banks
Good effort to retain quality people
cons:
Tends to lay people off before the bonuses, which was not my experience at other banks
IT infrastructure needs continual improvement, but Mgt knows it's a priority
It's banking; hours, quality of life are what you'd expect.

headline: if you like hard work your in the right place
pros: Great people, never bored at work as busy workplace.
cons:
Too much red tape and cost constraints to get changes made.
Lots of computer program's to learn

headline: Bureaucracy Stifling Innovation
pros:
Work closely with business stakeholders.
High level of autonomy in solving problems.
Lots of resources available.
cons:
An incredible amount of red tape to access any of the aforementioned resources.
Paperwork straight up the wazoo.
Promotion's seem to be more politically based than merit based.

headline: Experienced AVP in the project space
pros: Good employer all round, would recommend to anyone at any level. Demands high-performance and integrity but will reward this.
cons: Usual institutional problems that face all very large companies. Snr management are commitment to changing this as much as possible and are making good progress.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Stress free work culture, good package, good hikes and decent allowances.
cons: Lack of upgraded technology and lenthy process to follow

headline: It was good except some of the policies which were not at par with the industry
pros: Gud work enviornment ....work place
cons: The policies regarding employee and medical benefits are a bit off.You cannot add your parents oif you are a girl and things like tht

headline: Had a good chance to do something game changing - but failed
pros: Great brand, fresh start-up, the world at the feet
cons: Poor management, no direction, went in to a very service-based mentality

headline: Excellent place to work, far better than Barclays Capital
pros: Relaxed working culture, well travelled and well rounded colleagues
cons: Compensation is on the lower side

headline: Great company And fantastic people
pros: I have been with Barclays since a graduate and there has never been a dull moment. The company values it's employees and the people I work with are really smart and committed
cons: There is always a slight bureaucracy in every team even though they promote a flat, meritocracy culture. Just make sure you know who to impress at all times.

headline: Terrible Management and Terrible Team Environment
pros: Decent salary, and decent benefits.  Other than that, I can't really say that there were any other benefits.  Oh, and free coffee in the pantry.
cons: Upper management has no interest (or does not care) about anyone except themselves.  I worked as a P&L analyst and was appalled at the "just get it done and stop bothering me with your questions" attitude of the VPs and Directors on my team.  They turn a blind eye to us slaving away until 9PM, but are the first to leave at 5:30PM and the first to complain about things not getting done in a timely manner the next day.

headline: Interesting work, very political, constant change
pros: Massive budgets, huge desire to do things better and to show that they're ahead of the competition. Bonuses for top performers are great.
cons: Everyone needs to sign-off the smallest detail so slow to adapt. Salary increases for internal moves tiny if at all. No recognition of external market rates. Bonus ratings fit forced distribution so more about who likes you than what you actually achieve.

headline: Great company to work for with old culture
pros: Very positive culture and good teamwork Demonstrated by most. Good leadership development course and good overall
cons: Its a shame the frm was sold to blackrock, but I understand the reasons why, given the challenging environment at the time

headline: It was a good experience
pros: A place with wonderful people
cons: Not long enough to see any

headline: Very fulfilling, the Graduate program is very nurturing and you go into your full time position, completely ready to im!
pros: Great product/soft skill training classes.
cons: Two one-year rotations is a bit lengthy to wait until you are placed permanently (Operations specific)

headline: I loved working at BGI
pros: I worked at BGI over 10 years. It was a wonderful place to work. Now has been bought by BlackRock and a much diminished company. It was a fairly flat organization and very innovative, progressive in policy, great benefits and the smartest coworkers one could hope to have. You worked hard, sometimes to the detriment of your personal life, but it was often worth it and there was a real feeling of accomplishment, support of the firm, and camaraderie.
cons: There were glass ceilings and limited opportunities at BGI at times. In some departments, getting ahead was dependent more on who you knew and how you appeared than your actual talent.

headline: Automatons Unite!
pros:
A few of the one and two starred reviews gave a refreshingly candid depiction. I can only add:

* leading edge valuation technology
* reliably repetitive work, if that floats your boat
* bright, knowledgeable people
* looks good on CV for some reason

The above features can be used wisely, but a clean exit is recommended if the cons below conflict with your personality.
cons:
Lack of humanity due to 
* severe fixation on political advancement/strategizing
* ridiculous cost-cutting (e.g., tea is not free)
* location in Scary Wharf
* lack of team collaboration
* lack of acknowledgement of effort
* employees lacking a basic sense of cognizance and humanity

Bad internal prospects/day-to-day work due to
* below market rates; cards will be shown upon your exit
* lack of proper project work
* lack of connections to other FO/risk functions
* steady flow of repetitive work

headline: Its Awesome in DE but very dissapointed with the PTL of INDIA Pune
pros:
Get to work on different project.
Good work environmen in DE
cons:
PTL is a USELESS.
Fully biased.
no quality of manager
and list can go on and on

headline: Good place to work however off late the focus has been setting up low cost centers and regulatory work.
pros:
* Global workforce - great in terms of being able to experience working in different geographic locations worldwide
* One of the strong global investment banking players
* Bank wide focus on doing the right thing
cons:
* Focus on establishing low cost centers, there by fragmenting teams.
* Many projects off late are related to regulatory reform - assuming this is the case with most of the banks.

headline: terrible work environment
pros: great people to work with
cons: horrible business and technology structure

headline: Great place for learning.
pros: You get to learn a lot in Barclays including your professional and personal develop through various training. Safe place for Female employee.
cons: Transportation service is not up to the standards.

headline: Never ok having to deal with liars and cheaters.
pros: For a part time agent, very good work/life balance, although 12 hours shift were maddening. Many oppportunities to switch full time and move to other departments.
cons: Worst ethics ever seen, colleagues and mentors lying in reports to be able to steal bonus % from other more honest agents.

headline: This is what good looks like.
pros: Culture of performance, ahead of the curve.
cons: Doesn't reward RTB efforts, only CTB efforts rewarded.

headline: A varied experience on the finance graduate programme
pros: A large bank with a wealth of opportunities across multiple divisions. However like all large organisations there is bueracracy when trying to get things done.
cons: The culture in this organisation needs to change (as many have heard in the press). Also there is a lot of face time and working the system that goes on where managers try to look good at the expense of actually doing value add work.

headline: Unstable in Technology
pros:
Lots of smart people you can learn from both in hard skills and soft skills.
Always the chance to transfer in such a big institution.
cons:
Politics are insane. Every senior IT manager is out for themselves and doesn't care about the big picture only their own domain.
Ridiculous resignation notice policy where they 'demand' an option of 3 months for VP's and up (yes VP's)
Poor work-life balance...(Probably why they want 3 months notice as they are just so understaffed)

headline: BW London
pros: Fast Growing company, good career opportunity if you manage to get into the graduate programme
cons: interesting corporate culture, career pass internally could be challenging, high turnover, be ready to work with 25 internal IT systems

headline: Product Control at Barclays
pros: Job security, decent work life balance, ok pay.
cons: Highly political environment. Pay seems below market.

headline: Barclays rating as an employer
pros:
Pay rates are pretty good.
Training provision is excellent
Job satisfaction is considered important.
Good holiday entitlement.
Better reputation now without Diamond Bob.
cons:
Flawed annual review EOY forced ranking.
Work / life balance not always rght.
Some of the upper management had utterly lost the plot - Bob included.

headline: Awesome company, incredible people
pros: The company has great values that are shared by all employees.  The people are the smartest I've ever worked with and there's a minimum of politicking given the strong culture of being all-in together.  Good employees stay for a very long time and it feels like family.
cons: As the company has grown it has accrued more bureaucracy and the global offices, while operating under common rules, feel more and more isolated in nature.

headline: Not that great but I've heard it has gotten better
pros: Innovative company for credit card marketing
cons: Weak senior management that lacked direction

headline: Barclays is taking steps in the right direction, but the view from inside is a little less rosey.
pros: Many educational resources and opportunities.  Making a concerted effort to turnaround its image and values, and is ousting employees who aren't on board.
cons: terribly bureaucratic and political still.

headline: As shakespare would say " Work or not work for Barclays, that is the question!"
pros: There are still decent and nice people around to work with in that place.

headline: Getting worse
pros: There are no pros other than reasonable compensation
cons:
Complete lack of respect for employees. This is an environment  of bullying, horrendous overwork, unreasonable demands and chronic understaffing in operational areas. The culture they talked about in the Americas is the culture that Kalaris created throughout the firm.

All management are interested in is offshoring UK staff and quieting dissent. Morale is the lowest I have ever encountered. A truly horrible environment I wouldn't wish on my worst enemy.

Work life balance? A joke.

headline: “Spring Week”
pros:
Overall view of bank
Ability to organise meetings outside of schedule
Employees very willing to help
Trading floor experience
Ability to organise meetings outside of schedule
Employees very willing to help
Trading floor experience
cons:
If you know what you want, maybe a division specific program would be better
If you know what you want, maybe a division specific program would be better

headline: Getting worse
pros: Solid pay, decent pretense of a meritocracy and generous if they fire you. Good international connections.
cons: You're not going to get paid as much as the American banks, but the public hates you more.

headline: Good but not great experience
pros: Considered a good brand to work for in the banking and finance sector
cons: Movement to various projects and roles within Barclays is not encouraged a lot.

headline: Challenging, fast paced environement to work in
pros: Fantastic people to work in, plenty of opportunities to learn about new products and internal mobility
cons: Not much involvement in CSR

headline: This place will eat you if you don't make noise
pros: some people are nice and polite. people respect each other.
cons: you should keep on making noise about your compensation/promotions etc. otherwise nothing happens.

headline: Retail Banking Technology Centre
pros:
Flexible work environment - no restriction on time to spend in office as long as the work is done
Above average pay
cons:
Not a career company - Absolutely no job security even for permanent employees
High work load, working model of hiring minimum staff, overloading them and then disposing them as needed
No growth oppurtunities

headline: Changing for the worse

headline: Great for an internship, terrible as a grad / full time
pros:
- Mostly great co-workers. BarCap employees themselves are great although the culture has soured since the Lehmen acquisition.
- Clear promotion opportunities if you're not a graduate.
- Great internship scheme - lots of training and networking events.
- Good technology working groups, some managing directors are very switched on, especially in Equities.
- Reasonable meritocracy for full time hires - although not within cookie cutter graduate positions.
cons:
- Typical of banking, most people are motivated by money and not love of their job.
- Most graduates are on the same salary as new interns - even after having 1-2 years of experience.
- Many graduates get sub optimal placement when joining teams which don't reflect their interests adequately. They are allocated according to 'business need' - but if the wrong part of the business needs a graduate, it can negatively affect your career.
- Graduate scheme training is a waste of time and money for those not in front office. As a technology grad, give us actual technical training. A two day 'beginners Excel' course is not sufficient, particularly for the vast majority of technology grads hired from non-CS courses.
- Internal mobility is a joke. Anecdotally - most people quit and are rehired at a higher salary.
- Since the acquisition of Lehmen's - considerably increased management. When an intern I had 3 managers in between me and the CIO. As a graduate i had 7. What do these guys all do?
- Technology is old, outdated and generally under invested in. They often refuse to spend a few hundred pounds on a workstation dated less than 4 years old (despite salaries being above market for most employees). Bizarre.

headline: Friendly people, heterogeneous culture, progression and pay driven by internal politics rather than performance
pros:
- Good chairs, great given the time you spend in them
- SeamlessWeb deliveries, for those late nights
- Friendly people, many colleagues genuinely sitting in the same sinking boat
- Good learning experience, depending on your team
cons:
- No reward for loyalty. Management would much rather pay large guaranteed bonuses (deferred from other banks) to "A-Team" recruits from other big banks, who often turn out to add limited value.
- Limited senior management knowledge. As a trader, I have to seek approvals from managers who are clueless about the product, market and risk being discussed. As it is easier to say "no", this leads to significant missed opportunities.
- No link between proposed culture and compensation. The "RISES" philosophy (Respect-Integrity-Service-Excellence-Stewardship) is a bit of a sideshow when it comes to rewarding performance, which is driven more by politics than by performance.
- Inefficient business set-up. Head-count often unduly high because risk is split across more desks/businesses than required, compared to other banks. Leads to (a) risk not being pooled together to be optimally managed, (b) more headcount with less responsibility and less potential for progression, as well as the wrong people being made redundant.
- Internal IT systems off-the-shelf and around 15 years outdated.

headline: Chaotic and poorly managed
pros:
The salary/bonus was pretty good, although not exactly stand-out from companies outside the financial sector. 

My immediate colleagues in the team were a pleasure to work with.
cons:
Senior management are pretty much wholly disengaged from the staff who actually do the work, which leads to very poor choices when it comes to systems, processes and restructures. Few such developments had a positive impact on an individual or team basis, as they were imposed from above with little to know dialogue or engagement beforehand.

Communication was generally really bad. It tended to improve for a short while after this was highlighted, but then returned to what it was like before.

Key things such as external training in new skills, which were vaunted in the interview, failed to materialise (budget constraints were often cited, despite the bank making billions in profit each quarter). Instead, what was offered was the absolute bare minimum – largely focussed around 'internal training'. This boiled down to overworked staff being leaned on to share their skills with others. Hardly ideal.

Resourcing and hiring were very problematic – the demands being placed upon the team were increasing significantly, and group-wide headcount freezes meant that no new additional permanent staff could be hired. Instead, they ended up spending significantly more on short-term contractors to bridge the gap.

Even for a bank, the amount of bureaucracy and time involved to progress things was staggering. 

There was a general obsession with regard to which 'grade' you are – the extent of this is something I've only ever encountered at Barclays. These are, rather obliquely, B5, B6, B7 and SX (senior exec). You quickly get to know your place. 

Restructures within the wider business happened with surprising regularity – almost as if the senior execs need to justify their existence. Often, they had little very impact. We just shifted from being under one overarching division to another.

headline: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Until recently Barclays had mostly escaped the pitfalls of the sub-prime mortgage crisis and had kept a clean image making it a great place to work in terms of morale.  Pay was above average.
cons: Lots of discombobulation after the Lehman takeover.  Management structure was all over the place (as to be expected after a takeover) and operating on a global platform never seemed to be within reach due to regional politics -- both before and well beyond the Lehman integration.

headline: Difficult to be an adviser at Barclays Wealth Americas
pros:
World class research.
Access to high quality investment professionals across Wall Street.
Strong relationships with other service providers. 
A well known brand.
Strong analytic work from internal teams.
Competitive levels of pay for top performers.
cons:
The management of Barclays Wealth Americas is run primarily through a culture of fear.  Employees are discouraged from presenting issues or opportunities to improve the firm.  There is no formal process with which to do so.  Employees who informally attempt to raise issues are penalized or disciplined, and hurt their chances of future career growth.

Benefits are skewed towards the top producers, which reduces the amount of collaboration between employees.

Investment recommendations are most often made on the basis of what will earn the firm the highest amount of revenue.   Products are pushed on advisers weekly.  The advisers that sell the most commission-based products are rewarded and recognized more so than others.   Management has a broker-dealer focus that adds conflicts of interest to the Wealth Management platform from succeeding.

Finally, the technology in place is older and slower than that of its competitors, putting everyone at a disadvantage.  Time is often wasted having to correct or re-enter data into various systems, making it harder to stay on top of your day-to-day tasks and goals.

headline: Very interesting but very uncertain
pros: Great variety of work, lots of good projects and initiatives to get involved with, some very smart people.  You can create your own job where you find something valuable that needs doing. Technology is getting more investment than it used to and Barclays IT wants to function more like a Technology company, this is starting to come to fruition. Lots of opportunity to progress.
cons: Everyone is very uncertain about the future, management seem to have no long term plan (that they have shared at least) so often good talent leaves for something more secure. No top-down leadership in IT, very tribal and bottom-up organization, often leading to overlap on work, lots of duplication and no clear picture of where you fit. Broken processes that have been lost in multiple, incomplete restructures make getting most things done a real challenge.  If you work outside of the UK, be prepared to adjust to their time zone, and any other region you need to speak with as part of your role.

headline: Great company with potential for growth
pros: Great smart caring personable people

Resources

headline: Experience has been frustrating at times due to constant outsourcing and uncertainty about future.

headline: BTCI Pune
pros:
1) good salary. around 20% more than market salary(if you have negotiated during HR discussion)
2)Work from home option sometimes when you need 
3) flexible work hour
4) year end bonus of 10% if you have got average and good rating
cons:
1) Work pressure. similar type of work on daily basis -so no growth
2) Work from home does not mean you will be working less. This is the catch to provide you laptop and blackberry and burden you on work
3) No transparent process in Appraisal. so lobby/oiling works. so tjose who are well politically stay here for long term
4) No promotion . the role on which you have joined you will have to work on same role and no defined process to move to next level
5) Whatever a 2yr guy does in support even a 10 yr B4 will do same work and when rating is provided manager has lot of point to tell what you have done when a 2 yr guy is doing what u also are doing
6) no onsite. if u get a one/2 week onsite then it is a loss for you. as there is no per diem amount. whatever u spent at onsite they will provide the same amount once u provide the bill and same money u will get in 2 months.
7) any monetary claim amount is paid after a month or more(45 days around SLA time)
8) some manager who have joined 2-3 yr back does not want to switch job as they are getting paid very good salary and for them no work. just co-ordinate and bother the technical people

9) You can not escalate anything to HR as it looks like HR process is there just to recruit the people and have 2 days of induction
10) No internal position change as your current manager does not release you
11) firing at singapore center - so no job security
12) Some managers tries to bully you

headline: Backstabbing
pros: Nice offices, looks good on your CV.
cons:
It is possible to have a really great career at Barclays if you are prepared to climb over others to get to where you want to be. 
However having worked in various departments, you cannot trust your colleagues, as the culture is very dog-eat-dog.  I have seen many people bullied out of the business. 
This is not typical of large corporates in my experience.

headline: Some good - some bad, its what you make it!
pros: Good work colleagues, everyone is behind you to support and work as a team. Diversity in role (depending on your job/team). Good opportunities to work on non-BAU work.
cons: Managers and Management. Perceptions count for more than the work you actually do. The perception of one, appears to count for more than the perception of many. If one person (i.e a manager) thinks something, and reports it, its taken as gospel, whereas your whole team have another, its blatantly disregarded. If you have a personality, I would advise you to stay away from certain BU's in Barclays. Also, too much competition between managers to be best. My manager would frequently talk smack about the other team manager yet be all nice to their face, and also tell them things that you have spoken to them about in confidence. At times it was laughable and was noted between the entire team as being wrong (even those people who were 'pets'). Salary is OK, but bonus time they literally move the goal posts to match whatever they want. They need to stick to their objectives and if you deliver, you deserve a reward. Also - certain managers instill a god like persona. Not right to be scared of someone you work for.

headline: IT is becoming a commodity
pros: Salaries, at least for legacy people, are competitive
cons:
Barclays has chosen not to be "exceptional" but to strive to lowest common denominator
Many groups have STRONG Lehman bias if senior management is from Lehman
Discontinuation of Pension plan remove any reason to be "loyal" considering Barcap is not doing anything to differentiate it from it's peers as a "special" place to work
IT is becoming "commoditized".  Push to "outsource" IT work, even that with specialized finance knowledge and front office roles, to India under euphemism "Location Strategy". 
Crazy requirement of 1 month notice for AVP and below and THREE MONTHS for VPs and above. Company is VERY aggressive in enforcing this. 
Also, theoretically, this notice should go both ways, severance pay for those laid off incorporate this 3 month pay so in reality, company has its cake and can eat it too regarding holding you by the short hairs. 
Internal mobility highly touted, but is a joke. Unless you know somebody, you will not get a reassignment via "official" channels. In fact, hiring managers most often don't even respond to internal mobility requests. 
Most people have not had salary increase in 4 years and decreasing bonuses. 
Forces grading curve is not fair for smaller groups and favoritism in these group make it impossible for "good" performers to advance unless they are a "golden" boy/girl.

cons: Can be a little hectic profile..since it belongs to the Support function segment.

headline: boys' den
pros: strong in fixed income, up and coming for equity business, generally well received on Wall Street
cons: too English, despite all the outward emphasis and noise on diversity, very little is actually done internally to promote female and/or minority talents, it has a great maternity program, but in terms of career advancement for females and minority, they are way behind most banks

headline: Stagnant environment but good benefits
pros: The salary and benefits offered are very generous and are very easily accessible to all levels. Internal promotion is relatively simple at lower skill levels and this quickly corresponds to increased wages.
cons: Very slow at change and innovation, the company is very behind in terms of IT systems, banking systems and more importantly at attitude towards the customer. There is a very imminent presence of Senior level slogans that do not materialise in employee eyes. Operations are too widely dispersed, approaching diseconomies of scale.

headline: Working at barclays technology center india

lots of decision making in your hands unlike service industry

work from home is available at times, so definitely a plus
salary is good but need to negotiate a lot while joining
bonus depends on your manager :) so be in their good books
cons:
slow growth in career
little bit of bureaucracy
lack of transparency in appraisal process

headline: should be more employee friendly rather than management friendly

headline: Non Visionary approach of bank & no Role of HR in company

cons: concentration of alot of power to some individuals which sometimes made the working environment abit frustrating because that powerled to the whims of some individuals being met, some of which were ridiculous.

headline: Big organisation but  unchanging with a big reputation

headline: Best ECC facilities..
pros: Good for freshers, get to learn lot of things from different people.
cons:
Not a good company for long run, unless you like your comfort zone.
Now no onsite, no salary hike, less promotions, ineffective certification system... list is long.

headline: Current IT AVP
pros: I am still working here.
cons: The company got really worse after Lehman guys took over. Full disregard of people, imposing of Lehman (bankrupt) culture. A last straw for a loyal Barclays employees is discontinuing of the pension plan. All Barclays (not Lehman) employees had a real pension plan and it was recently announced that it's getting frozen as of September 30th 2012. How dare are you, given that just over 2000 people are still eligible for this plan? Rule of thumb: when management starts a penny pitching - company is going downhill.

headline: Barclays is totally dysfunctional and needs new leadership.
pros: Barclays is located in a nice building in mid-town New York, so it is convenient to the rest of the city.  There are some nice, good people working there; unfortunately, those people don't have the ability to affect any change in the organization.
cons: Too many to name ... Bad comp, bad incentives, low ethics, bad morale. Claims to be a meritocracy but in my view there is a lot of cronyism and good old boy networking going on.  Not a great place for women to work.

headline: Competitive
pros: Good team enviroment and good Customer relations management
cons: Abu Dhabi Barclays Depemartment got closed.

headline: Would recommend although be prepared to work hard!
pros:
Good employer

Working conditions very good

I have enjoyed it
cons:
Unless you go to a part of the business that is performing well or has a good portfolio, there may be the chance in future of lay offs or redundancies

Want your pound of flesh and no room for people who do not perform and progress

Very competitive and hard targets

headline: good company to work with

headline: Good Work Life balance but too much Politics
pros:
1. Good Work Life Balance
2. People get paid good, but you need to bargain while joining
3. You will be able to learn domain if you get good supportive UK counter part (some luck is required).
cons:
1. Politics at middle management level 
2. No Career progression. Technically you will not be able to grow.
3. No Promotions, so choose your role correctly. 1-3 years B2, 3-6 years B3, 6-9 years B4, 9-13 years B5, 13+ B6. 
4. No direction around how they want to invest in India.

headline: Senior Engineer
pros: Academic, well paid, great bonus, fantastic benefits. Culture of thinking. Resource rich.

headline: Boring
pros: Colleagues and bosses were all very nice, they also allowed me to reduce my hours to accomodate my husbands shift hours.
cons: Position was not suitable due to a shift pattern which I was not required to do unless I remained as a permanent member of staff.  The job I had to do was very boring and tedious, however it was a means to an end and allowed me to look for other positions more suitable.  I found the department to be very unflexible with permanent staff members with regards to working hours which caused them to look elsewhere for jobs.

headline: Barclays...

headline: Business Analyst in Barclays
pros: Opportunities to work with people around the world
cons: Career development may be slower than in other places

headline: Not the best environment to write software
pros: The people are generally very nice.
cons: Global staff turnover has been very high in the IT dept I work (which has several hundred people at any one time). The level of IT near shore outsourcing has escalated to a great extent and working with teams who don't speak English as a first language is a huge challenge.  The business doesnt value the importance of quality when it comes to building reliable, well engineered software and neither does the IT management chain which is incentivized to always cut corners to get the next delivery on the desk as soon as possible. This comes at the cost of never repaying technical debt so the software is forever descending towards an unmaintainable mess which delays delivery which in turn angers the business which in turn causes smart developers to seek employment elsewhere as dismal bonuses are paid.

headline: The rules are clear: put in your time and impress those in positions of influence
pros: The work is not complex and it is relatively easy to impress your boss by doing normal, BAU work.
cons: The work is not complex and you may feel that you are bored or forgetting what you studied in Uni. Depending on your team, it's also difficult to plan your life as something last-minute may come up, forcing you to cancel or delay plans after work.

headline: Average Experience for Junior Investment Banker
pros: There are many opportunities to work in US and abroad, so if you are interested in a multi-national experience, this company may be a great fit.  I know several investment banking analysts and associates offered temporary or full-time opportunities in London who worked in the US office.
cons: They wear business formal on a daily basis.  All banking floors are designed to feel like a trading floor.  Therefore, until you reach VP level, you work in an environment with little to no privacy, which can be challenging if you are building a complex model and need quiet.  Company generally pays mid to lower end of street.

headline: Great global brand but lacks empowerment and decision making locally
pros: Great global brand, good salary and benefits, great global network, good people.
cons: Too centralised, lack of career progression

headline: Good career growth at first, stagnant after a few years
pros: Smart company, good people, willing to make investment
cons: Poor people management, CMA leads to inaction

-  Inefficient processes

headline: Good company to work for

headline: Work is not creative

Base salaries are higher but bonus is really sad

headline: Dont feel like a professional but a hired skilled labor who is put into a deadend job with less of growth prospects.
pros: Good compensation, Good housekeeping of the building, eatable food in the cafeteria(initially one usually happy with it)
cons:
1) Company culture is not good. Its not employee friendly, all focus is on the clients and they are like Gods to management here, and employee is only a hired skilled labor
2) Lots of people feel overworked without logical and smart reasons and have to bear whims and fancies of client (on shore people) with no consideration of improving motivation level and unable to find justified reasons for accepting work smartly.
3) Way to move up corporate ladder - a dead end. Very tough to go up.
4) Some people are overqualified for their roles with whom they are getting sub-quality work done with no consideration of their future and career ,and some are under-qualified whom they are giving trainings which are already known by people sitting in poorer profiles.
5) Infrastructure is a problem, though acceptable, as its a growing company and they are trying to improve and manage.
6) People do not feel motivated and there is so much pressure sometimes that one works on weekends for a particular period . Overall work life balance is pretty less or skewed.
7) 'Get the work done' focus only and no focus on employee learning and growing up in their career

headline: Behind the times
pros:
Good medical/dental/vision benefits.
Good company match on 401k contributions.
cons:
A meritocracy is preached, but not followed.
Compensation model is poor, even for a bad economy / industry environment.
Promotions and lateral position movements are too restrictive, creating a "trapped" environment.
Systems are too numerous and outdated.
IT Development budgets are weak, preventing a streamlined processing strategy.

All international repute clients give you good exposure to various cultures and improves your communication skills as well
cons: Lots and lots of politics. I found this as the most irritating aspect in the organization and mind you it is not limited to one or two teams neither is it restricted to the lower level of organization but the termite of politics has eaten the organization from within since it took over Lehmann. Sorry to say this but the upper management almost always turns a dead ear to employees and always supports and stays by the manager / management which is a huge put off. I know more than a few people who left only due to this

You just need to get used to bureaucracy here or you're not getting anyway

headline: Barclays Capital Technology
pros: Good structured processes, and teams. Strategic systems, and well defined teams, which makes working here enjoyable. I have seen my friends at other investment banks where there are no separate teams for production support, for release, for testing. These people always end up in a fire fighting more and life is more stressful. Processes are almost none at other places, which also makes life tough in the long run.
cons: Bonuses have been very bad in last two years.

headline: A very mixed bag

cons:

headline: Unprofessional
pros: Easy work. As long as you do not try to shine too much and finish your work, you can stay safe for a very long time.
cons: Completely unprofessional when dealing with employee relations. I gave my resignation only to find out they will force me to stay for three months. When I begged and reasoned for over a month, they finally decided to reduce that sentence to 2.5 months. But after 2 months and with two weeks left, the management decided they don't need me any more and let me go while claiming I have been "disruptive" to the team environment because I only worked a few hours a day in the office all the while making sure there is absolutely no work for me to do. Even though the work itself was too simplistic and politically charged, I was treated fairly well until I gave that resignation letter. I believe a company's professionalism can be measured simply by watching how it treats its leavers. I have moved from companies to companies but never was I treated as poorly as Barcap did.

headline: Cold
pros: Is a sophisticated practice and no space for lingering, meaning dynamic.
cons: No straightforwardness and loyalty.. Plenty of delegation, no ownership. Left hand does not know what is happening with right one. No communication at all.

headline: Dysfunctional organization, misrepresentations
pros: "Aura" or Barclays brand, but that is all...
cons: The organization does not function.  Mired in bureaucracy, irrational decision making.  Gross underinvestment in critical systems and infrastructure coupled with an intransigent administrative approach.  Struggling to attract advisors to grow so they make promises that they cannot and do not intend to keep.  Every advisor that I spoke to that had been hired in the last yeat was extremely unhappy... miserable in fact.

headline: Stable business  in current economy

cons: Promotion process Is not clear

headline: Horrific - stay away if you do not want to be treated as a commodity
pros:
Flexible working hours
30 days holiday
cons:
Utterly incompetent leadership
Absolutely no moral courage what so ever
Promotions and reward have nothing to do with hard work, but everything to do with cliques
Barclays will either break you, or institutionalise you.  Be warned, be prepared - do not join!

headline: All that glitters is not gold
pros:
Better package compared to other organizations
Lots of leaves - 30 casual and 12 sick
Fairly good transport facility
Free breakfast
cons:
No work life balance
Managers treat resources like labors
Barclays has lot of vendor staff, so there is constant permanent vs vendor politics ongoing, your managers will never support you whereas they will treat vendor staff better than client
Hardly any vertical growth opportunities.
This being a captive organization, managers know that opportunities within the organization are less as compared to other service based companies, hence they make full use of it for their advantage and leave no stone unturned in terms of exploiting the resources

headline: Enjoyable 16 years working with professional staff
pros: Offer a very competative salary within sector, good working environment, adequate pension scheme, very friendly approachable professional staff. Work life balance.
cons: In my experience recieved no real appropriate training to keep up to date with the changes being made in my areas of technology thus feeling over the years as de-skilled.

headline: Menlo Park Tech Banking Group
pros: Barclays' Menlo Park office is made up of a bunch of ex-Lehman technology bankers. The office is very busy office with good deal flow and, for investment banking, is very friendly and laid back.
cons: The main downsides are the long hours (but that's typical for banking) and the location. While Menlo Park is beautiful and you're right next to Stanford and downtown Palo Alto, it's not that convenient if you want to live in the city.

headline: not a safe place to work
pros:
Good salary.
Have a good available leave days (21 days minimum for permanent)
Depending on the team, you might get quite flexible working hours
cons:
Not a safe place to work and build career.
Practice regular employee layoff (they are not concern on retaining employee).
Depending on the team / department you might get a lot of overtime work.

headline: Disappointed with the promotion process.
pros: Great place for Work Life Balance.
cons: Management keep changing, hence very little oppertunity for career advancement.

headline: Not like Lehman Brothers
pros: Good talent, a lot of remaining talent from Lehman Brothers.  The fact that the firm is international gives one a full perspective of a global institution.
cons: Very British, low risk appetite, a lot of bickering between departments, low bonuses compared to other firms, clients prefer us competitors.

headline: Overpromised and underdelivered
pros:
Has a desire to be successful
A lot of fantastic people at or below VP level
Good (but getting worse) reputation in the marketplace when looking to move on. Still resume-friendly
A lot going on at the moment
cons:
Not everywhere, but definitely a lot of managing upwards and not so much leading at the upper-mid levels (VP/Director). 
A lot of buck passing and not so much team building and development. Step one seems to be first find someone to blame.
Personality-based decisions/favoritism
Unclear and shifting priorities. Difficult to get a decision to stick

headline: nothing much to say
pros: not much overtime normal hours
cons: too many politics please do your work

headline: Some great managers, many of average (at best) competence.
pros: Good, flexible benefits, interesting work and many very engaged colleagues
cons: Low visibility of senior management

headline: Great place to work
pros: we have great kit, great people and a good understanding of strategy and governance however i feel struggle with the implementation
cons: the off shoring is really slowing everything down, more often than not the on shore teams in the UK and US are picking up the work not completed by the off shore teams even though the on shore team sizes have been dramatically down sized

headline: Depends on who you know
pros: Pretty relaxed for a financial firm.  Work is easy.  Good opportunity for advancement in the UK.
cons: The focus on meritocracy is really a sham.  Promotions have more to do with who you know and how long you've been around.  Equities are decent, but across the majority of the internal engineering organization - most of the talent has already walked out the door.  XP desktops are still the norm.

headline: large co, lost in translation!
pros: talented people and good assets
cons: Poor processes and lack of agility

headline: large co, lost in translation!
pros: talented people and good assets
cons: Poor processes and lack of agility

headline: Very limited career progression and opportunties but ok work/life balance. Very UK centric culture.
pros:
1. Work life balance is more possible to manage than in IB.
2. Industry salaries but on a higher than industry level.
3. Not a competitive environement between colleagues and relatively good job safety.
cons:
1. Very process driven and buraucratic organisation.
2. Career progression is not structured. 
3. Very stong UK culture - if you are a foreigner that might considerably slow down your possibility to grow and be promoted.
4. Limited career opportunties

headline: Barclaycard US has great people and interesting work.
pros: Barclaycard US pays well compared to its competitors and gives out 22 days of vacation to new employees. It has a friendly environment and has a lot of fun and interesting events to keep people engaged. Recently we had a ping pong tournament and have a baseball game planned soon.
cons: Right now most employees don't have laptops so we need to print out presentations before we go to meetings instead of just emailing it.

headline: No objective assessment of employee performance
pros:
Pay is competitive, however bonuses are extremely low. Possibility to work with multiple groups.
Located in the center of manhattan
cons:
No fair assessment of employees, very subjective and decided solely by your immediate manager.
Very incompetent managers at the vp level.
Directors seem to be very far removed from their groups.
Employees at the more junior level are treated like little kids
Very poor communication within finance

headline: Poor employment practices if you are a parent
pros:
Salary and benefits were good 
People and teams were well qualified 
Location is great 
Challenging work and a commercial focus
cons: No real drive to flexible working or supporting part time work

headline: So much potential, so little leadership
pros: Decent salary and decent benefits, that's about it.
cons: Horrible management, specifically in the global technology and infrastructure organization.  Basically all NY employees and management are puppets for the leadership in London and have no say on what goes on.  There is no communication between teams to know what's going on.  Management is very narrow minded and set on a path they have come up with in some back room and will not accept any detours to that path.  Very little opportunity for growth unless you move to London.  Management is on a cost cutting rampage and at our clients expense think it's a good idea to outsource our jobs to India, Lithuania, and Kiev.  Big mistake!  Yes, you can get 10 employees for the price of 1 but in the long run it hurts the business and gives an overall poor impression of technology at the firm

headline: Good expereience
pros:
good company 
pays well
good infrastructure
cons:
frequent changes in management 
long working hours

headline: Clowns
pros: Managers maintain very professional demeanor. Mandatory training includes course that train managers not to yell at their subordinates. After Goldman you would feel like relaxing on (wild) resort.
cons: First year managemment promises good bonuses, promotions, in exchange to long hours of product development and sleepless nights of product support, but then delivers nothing at the end of the year. Next year you are extremely frustrated and don't deliver that fast. Some people jump, some wait hoping to get a package at the end of the quarter when layoffs happens. If you happen to stick for another year you will loose even more in your total comp. But there always be a story that it's not you, it's market situation that drives your comp down. Quality of people in IT distributed as AAA grade ~1%, B+ ~3% and D~96%. The phenomena are easily explained by a simple inability to pay.

headline: Long hours, but worked with smart people
pros:
-  work hard, play hard mentality
-  worked with talented, smart people
-  solid training program
-  ability for career advancement
cons:
-  little clarity or visibility from top senior management
-  long hours and much weekend work
-  cut-back on perks and benefits

headline: Good experience and environment for learning
pros: Good experience, good training, good culture, management and everyone in generally are very approachable
cons: Need to perform better in EMEA league tables

headline: Positive, even if I believe that the company sometimes lacked long-term view
pros:
- Challenging environment
- Multiple opportunities
cons: - Occasional lack of long-term view

headline: Average
pros: Benefits - Pension plan after 5 years
cons: Depend on your group. If you are lucky you can be on a growth oriented group.

headline: An OK place to work
pros:
Good benefits
Good Compensation compared to others in same industry
cons:
Very limited work life balance
Review process is not too fair

headline: I use "Barclay" as my "bench-marking" when i look for jobs.
pros:
Learning aspects
Internal and external environment
Subordinates and colleagues
cons:
Its drastic measures only considering their profits,
Employee retention policy is weak

headline: Good
pros: Well balanced strategy and consistent push for execution
cons: Rewards not upto the market benchmarks - very conservative payscale

headline: It is a good place to learn and advance my career.
pros: There are good training and development opportunities (online and classroom training).  In addition there is excellent internal research and a high knowledge base among peers.
cons: It is a large firm and at any large firm there are politics that make it difficult to work and learn as efficiently as possible. Sometimes it is difficult to excel compared to your peers.

headline: Very good
pros: Management team being very supportive
cons: may be difficult for promotion

headline: Overly Bureaucratic and Political
pros: Benefits, Brand Name, Global Company
cons: Awful local management is compounded by even worse over arching management in the UK. Nothing is accomplished without 5+ sign offs by Directors and MDs. Advancement is based more on sucking up then achievement. Overall people are extremely unhappy, with the best employees leaving as soon as they can.

headline: IT Environment
pros: Competitive compensation and benefits package,
cons: No commitment to long term development models. Current emphasis on short-term cost cutting.

headline: pretty good
pros:
good reputation, intelligent people, reasonable pay, many new business opportunities.
management shares a polite culture. very nice office environment. good promotion ledder
cons:
uncertain but exciting future, often draws a sense of insecure. 
often bear non position related tasks. insufficient support of employee psychological needs

headline: average
pros: friendly culture, nice people, opens doors to other bulge bracket
cons: not hungry enough, poor pay

headline: Frustration vs monthly cheque fight
pros:
Very good pay
Highly talented individuals
Nice office
cons:
No meritocracy
No chance for promotion unless you're part of the clique
Industry not to be proud of

headline: excellent
pros: work culture, management, employees, technologies
cons: Uk centeric company, moving jobs out of NY

headline: Challenging work environment
pros: Competitive compensation package and benefits; frequent company training; tuition reimbursement
cons: Difficult to advance one's career; politics and favoritism; Barclays vs Lehman employee sentiment; too many mind numbing processes.

headline: Good place to work
pros: relatively less stressful when compared with other banks and less politics involved
cons: not competitve on salaries and packages

headline: Gives a good introduction to the world of finance
pros: Barclays offers a good spread of opportunities and allows you to develop
cons: The company had lost its way slightly but has come out of the downturn looking one of the best banks globally.

headline: Just okay for me!
pros: Good open discussions and access to immediate and next level management. Good benefits and perks
cons: Promotion process is horrible, needs improvement!

headline: Good experience
pros: good exposure and good pay
cons: slow to promote if you're not part of the clique

headline: Not a place to grow a career for the long term / feels as though it is a constant battle up a steep hill with no support
pros: Large Investment Bank, good knowledge to be obtained.
cons:
Middle Management has no influence and does not support people
Cost Cutting, no interest in growing peoples careers
Terrible Pay
Short Term Focus versus Long Term Strategic Vision
Much of management do not have MBA's / heavy influence from UK - e.g. feels like a two class society at work

headline: Stagnant
pros: Above Market rate compensation package
cons:
The company has very little career growth. 
No work life balance

headline: Prestigious but unfulfilling
pros:
Big bank means lots of flow
Management is thinking along the right lines and driving the company the right way
cons:
Highly political
Sub market compensation
Managers realize Barclays is Bulge Bracket now so think they have to do less to retain staff

headline: Different culture post Lehman Acquisitions.
pros: Was a decent learning environment.
cons: Not the right culture for everyone.

headline: Good
pros: Long maternity leave and health care benefits. Good dental benefits. Work life balance. Management has respect for staff and focus on developing people
cons: Doesn't have much team bonding activities and funds to allow staff to get together outside of work. No xmas party nor year end dinner and dance at al

headline: Positive
pros: Good boutique, godd reputation and working conditions
cons: Structure is too complex which makes big deals hard to get approved

headline: Highly mentally stimulating
pros: Very Challenging work environment(Positive); Highly motivated and bright peers; top brass clients who continuously demand for better and improved solutions
cons: Some of the management has very old views in management style; hidden politics and hierarchy; HR influenced by the management

headline: Do not value human capital
pros:
Relatively low pressure
Some interesting projects
Variety of technologies
Nice people
cons:
Management has very little vision
British companies place very little value in people except at highest levels in organization
Don't expect any assistance in advancing your career. Don't belive in claims that there is tuition assistance - non-existent.

headline: Wad a good experience for developing my career, could not see this as a long term role though
pros: Global presence presents many oportunities and confidence in the brand.
cons: Can be a typical ruthless plc.  Local leadership issues caused for an unpleasant envirnoment to work in from time to time

headline: Interesting, Challenging, busy.
pros: There are always a lot of thing to do and to learn.
cons: To big to be found or to see others

headline: It's OK
pros: Good salary, interesting projects and a lot of good people.
cons: Too bureaucratic even simplest tasks takes ages, constant redundancies. Very difficult to get promotion. Bonuses next to nothing.

headline: Well managed but needs incremental improvements
pros: A lot of talent in the development teams.
cons:
Too much Windows technology used. 
Software logistics and application management should be improved.
Very international so need to work a bit all the time to connect with the teams at various places in the world.

headline: Good place to work, opportunities for those with the right mindset
pros: Lots of talent, very driven people keen to progress professionally.  Good bunch of people on a personal level,
cons: Work v life balance is difficult

headline: Good Company to work with, but of non-IB culture.
pros:
Good work
Great work life balance
Salaries at par
cons:
Very low bonuses
Poor management vision

headline: Overall, not a great place to work
pros:
- Friendly people
- Challenges make work interesting
cons:
- Lack of a coherent implementation of a firmwide plan for improvement
- Constantly changing (but not improving) internal environment due to changes in strategy, short-termism, high turnover etc.
- Poor firmwide performance and strategic bonus allocation towards front office results in poor compensation for everyone else
- Too many MDs and Ds, making it extremely political and increasing the amount of conflicting messages. Too many people giving instructions, not enough actually doing work.

headline: Much Needed Improvement in Glasgow
pros:
1) Reputable employer to have on your CV
2) Opportunity to work with people from other countries
cons:
1) VERY political
2) Glasgow site recruited very quickly due to a strategic decision to bring a significant portion of Operations there (to lower costs). As a result, many of their management team were recruited from a constrained resource pool (a significant portion of management are former RBS employees who were made redundant after the bank nearly failed and it was nationalised). Some of the management team brought RBS cultural management styles into the business that don't necessarily fit the Barcap environment or its aspirations.
3) A need to improve resource management - realising what talent has to offer and utilising their skills according to their abilities and backgrounds

headline: Politics, red tape, office gossip. It depends where you land (NH, London, HH)
pros:
- Good compensation for either FTE or contract staff. Bonus is "ok" for financial services company, if you consider the economic climate and how boring the products actually are.
- You can select the office location, either Northampton or Canary Wharf for management, more locations for non-management staff.
- The colleagues are well educated, very social, friendly/polite and from good backgrounds. Capable.
- There is a lot you can learn within the payments/credit card industry.
cons:
POLITICS:
The amount of politics is mind-blowing. Barely anything gets done unless it goes up and down the entire hierarchy. Decisions-making, product-development and strategy processes will take ages. I have spent 1 year in this company and we as a team have not delivered anything so far.

PRODUCTS
Credits cards cater for a specific market and customer segment. Future of payments technology and processes is a question mark. Strong competition from all sides, i.e. which are more innovative and interesting/appealing to customers.

Work attitude
People are hired to get warm bodies onto seats and to keep them busy (at least trying to keep them busy). Nothing significant gets done in BC Global or BCE.

headline: Great work environment and culter
pros: Work culture is great compared to other banks and the environment is also great for software developers. I have worked with three different teams and all have been satisfactory.
cons: I have not found much downside of the firm, yet. However, there are some issues with the internal mobility. One might find it hard to move internally once you get in.

headline: Prestige and Polish on the outside; not so much on the inside
pros: The company's reputation holds a great deal of value in the investment market.  However, their infrastructure does not promote cross functional training, movement, nor the ability to mentor/mentee others outside of the business groups
cons: The company is very political and hard to maneuver if you are not willing to sacrifice your integrity for the organization.  They make internal organizational changes without regard how it affects others outside the group

headline: A top heavy,  chaotic and self serving environment
pros:
Pay is good for the breadth of responsibility
Some great colleagues, especially new starts who come with energy and bright ideas
Home working technology is very good
cons:
-Massively top heavy as an organisation - little clarity of accountability
-No real plan for the business very chaotic although front office was better than mid/back office
-Very reactive
-lots of untapped talent felling disaffected
- Self serving and political

headline: Superb, no regrets of having moved from one of the top 3
pros: Great place to work. Talent everywhere. Innovation, ideas, people, the best of talent from the rest of the street mixed under one roof. Friendly and positive environment. Entered the inner circle and now among the titans
cons: Still a way to go in terms on consolidating the technology infrastructure, and in bonding the groups. Still have some work to do in defining its own corporate identity, values and profile

headline: Frustrating
pros: The people I work with are good folks.
cons: Long hours are expected while compensation is poor. Very gossipy.

headline: Frustrating
pros: The people I work with are good folks.
cons: Long hours are expected while compensation is poor. Very gossipy.

headline: Great, learned a lot
pros: People are pretty nice and friendly. Even some of the managing directors are very approachable.
cons: Compensation might be lacking behind

headline: freat
pros: great money, even greater bonuses
cons: no breaks, no gym, so you don't have much time for your health

headline: Fits and Starts
pros:
* World-class company with solid business development strategies for the US market
* Interesting and challenging work
* advanced procedures, good risk management
cons:
* multiple changes in management in a relatively short period of time
* application of strict corporate standards to small initiatives, resulting in high deferred opportunity costs
* mix of really great managers and the opposite

headline: good flexible environment
pros: secure, family friendly, good remuneration, good work
cons: review process is farcial, as there is a fixed quota for promotions

headline: Good.
pros: Travel, Experience, Products, Fairly Decent People.
cons: Bonus structure. Work life Balance, Can be cut throat Environment.

headline: A good place to work overall
pros: Multicultural, global bank, major player in financial industry.  Focused on growth, as well as on client experience. Competent people.  Opportunities for internal mobility
cons: More red tape than one would wish for.

headline: good work life balance, mediocre professional environment - a good place to retire
pros: work life balance is good - many people work from home.
cons:
- talk of big ambitions but lacking the will to break with a "clubby" past and reward/penalize based - on merit
- very political, low levels of trust between senior and middle management
- has talked of becoming international for some time but highly UK centric - would prefer if "they" could be more like "us"
- technology and HR (talent management) are shockingly poor, even for a large organization

headline: Satisfactory
pros: Competitive bank and not much more
cons: Location and building in wrong location

headline: If it doesn't kill you....it will make you stronger
pros: Good work-life balance. Possibility to work from home every now and then. That's pretty much it.
cons:
Culture of unbearable oppression, bullying thrives and is actually encouraged. "Nice people" are penalised for not becoming sharks. A lot of backstabbing from bitchy colleagues. Career progression is achieved through "licking" the right person and "blindly complying"and is completely unrelated to the quality of the work done. They make people redundant very easily, especially now with the very unpopular new CEO. No fun, no company events, they save money on everything, we even have to bring our own stationery!  Non-English are discriminated and in general treated poorly, but you cannot mention this as it is one of the many tabus. Salaries below average. Huge turnover and yet they say that employees love working there. 
I don't think so!

headline: front office was tough
pros:
leader in several businesses
fast growing company, in asia and US
fast pace
rewarding
cons: Front office was quite cut-throat

headline: it is a demanding work place
pros: pay is ok compared to competitors. well known global bank. prestige. good to have on your resume. most people are friendly and appreciative of your work.
cons: depending on your manager, the place can be very stressful to work at. i felt the performance evaluation at times werent all that fair though.

headline: Strong brand and a desire to grow
pros: Better capitalised than many and still independent of Government. Flexible working practices and premises mainly of good quality. Credit function becoming more enlightened despite difficult economic conditions
cons: Role scope creep with no discussion of improved remuneration is typical. Change of approach many years ago means that development of internal talent seems a secondary priority to hiring so called "top talent" from other banks. Some of these "hires" clearly knwo how to play the "Top Grading" game.

headline: Okay place to work for 2 years
pros: Some good work and projects in hand
cons: Senior Managment needs to wake up and work hard

headline: It's a job.  It's not the best I've had, it's not the worst.
pros:
work/life balance
rather casual dress code
cons:
the organization is flat.  opportunities for advancement seem few and far between.
not enough hiring from within.

headline: Interesting & challenging
pros: Good name, challenging environment, opportunity to work with senior people.
cons: Location, work/life balance, pay and development

headline: Good quality employees, reasonable working hours and professional environment
pros: Good progression opportunities and driven employees
cons: Don't give much help for new joiners to get going

headline: Good place to work but some morale issues
pros:
- Reasonable compensation.
- Access to a number of very smart people.
- Good benefits compared to competing firms.
- A very good balance between family life and work life.
cons:
- Morale is poor in some areas of the firm.
- At times, there is an in-congruence between internal news about our success and what we see externally.

headline: good
pros: great atmosphere to work in
cons: intense starting training which you have to be fully focused

headline: Was good. It is now truly, truly awful
pros: Some good and talented people, who are usually marginalised, under-rewarded, and exploited
cons: Constant churn of senior management who are brought in from outside and who are frankly incompetant. Back stabbing is rife, there is no strategy, people take credit for things others work hard on, decisions are made that would make a mad man scratch his head. There is no future for IT staff based in the UK - its ALL being moved to India. Current management have sacked hundreds in support roles, the number of live incidents goes up, but apparently the two arent linked ! I am off...
